ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 4.--Orleans, N.Y., where Harrison, the young Irishman who gave himself up to the Chicago police on Friday, says he murdered his wife, is a place of 200 or 300 inhabitants, in Ontario County, about 40 miles from Rochester. No such tragedy has occurred there.

NEW-HAVEN, July 4.--Neither the Yale nine nor the Yale crew has yet succeeded in electing a Captain, although such elections generally take place immediately after the end of active work for the season.

There has been a sad scandal in a cathedral town in the West of England. A governess living with a family in the city had been corresponding for three years with an individual who had engaged to marry her.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., July 4.--There was a big religious mass meeting on the beach at the Galilee Fishery shortly before sunset this evening. The announcement that Dwight L. Moody, the evangelist, would deliver an address attracted people from miles around, some coming as great a distance as 15 miles.
PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 4.--Sunday was passed in unusual quiet in camp. The extreme heat kept every one within the shelter of the tents, or the shade of the trees which line the bluffs.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 4.--The Twentythird Regiment, of Brooklyn, arrived here this morning in the steamer Pilgrim. The steamer reached her pier at 4:30 o'clock. She was not expected until 6, but quite a crowd was on hand to greet the welcome visitors, including the officers of the Newport Artillery, who acted as escort.

The July meeting of the Rockaway Steeplechese Association begins its July meeting to-day at Cedarhurst, and the admirers of steeplechases and of polo and hurdle races will have ample opportunity of enjoying the sport. There are six races, for which the following are the entries:
LANCASTER, Penn., July 4.--The celebration of the one hundred and tenth anniversary of American independence began yesterday, and the town was in an uproar until after midnight.

GETTYSBURG, Penn., July 4.--To-day about 100 carloads of excursionists came over the different roads, and all day the street leading to Camp Hancock has been thronged. At the rostrum in the National Cemetery this morning Chaplain J.W. Sayres preached from the text, "The Lord is with us."

The news that no fewer than eight French torpedo boats have been lost during recent storms on the Atlantic may be a little discouraging to those who are just about to call up in Congress the measure providing similar boats for our own country.

LONDON, July 4.--Discount was inactive during the past week at 1 for three months and for short. The Stock Exchange loan rate to next account is 2 to 2 . Business on the Stock Exchange continued animated during the week.
Hobart Pasha was attended by Dr. Farnoni during his last illness, and passed away in the arms of his wife, a young lady of English nationality, who is now left a widow at the age of 27.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--The body of a young man about 26 years of age was found lying alongside the down track of the West Shore Railroad at the Washington-street (Newburg) crossing last night at 11 o'clock.
It is reported in this city on very good authority that the President has decided not to remove Postmaster Tobey.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--Secretary Manning, accompanied by his wife and daughter, his private secretary, Mr. Brennan, and Mr. Miller, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, arrived in this city on the late train last night from Hot Springs, Va.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--Patrick Cronin, an employe on the yard of the Rose Brick Company at Roseton, four miles above Newburg, was instantly killed by a train on the West Shore Railroad at Clark's Dock last night. Cronin is said to have been intoxicated at the time. The inquest was held at Marlborough this afternoon.
I had a talk a few evenings since with Clemencean, Dr. Ball, the Forbes-Winslow of Paris, and some other physiologists about your theory that a mad King is the best kind of monarch for his subjects.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 4.--John Dailey, a converted Roman Catholic, attempted to address a gathering on the river bank this afternoon, when he was roughly handled. He was thrown down the river bank into the river, and would have drowned had it not been for the timely arrival of a squad of policemen who rescued him.

CINCINNATI, July 4.--The first Sunday game of the season to-day drew 6,000 persons to the ball park to see the Athletics shutout by the Cincinnatis. Good fielding and superior batting on the part of the home team gave them the victory.

"The Golden Rule in Political Government" was the subject of a paper by David J. Dean, Assistant Corporation Counsel, before last evening's congregation of the St. James Methodist Episcopal Church, at Madison-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-sixth-street.

There was a very large supply of all kinds of fruit now in season in this market last week, causing every description of fruit to sell for exceedingly low prices. Fruit growers are very much depressed and scarcely know how to manage their crops.

The yacht Atlantic made a trial trip yesterday to determine the effect of the alterations recently made in her. That she has been improved was made manifest soon after she got under way, and her performance on every point of sailing fully demonstrated it.

MONTREAL, July 4.--Joe Laing, of Montreal, has made a deposit of $100 with a challenge to James A. Ten Eyck, C. Enright, James Griffin, or H. McKay for $500 to $1,000 a side to make a match for a three-mile race with a turn, the challenge to hold good for 14 days from date.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 2.--To no place in the world comes Summer with more gladness and beauty than to this nook in the Berkshires. The Winter is long and dark and cruel, and the frozen blight lies long upon the hills.

Sir Charles Warren, the Chief Commissioner of Police, has just issued some statistics with regard to mad dogs and deaths from hydrophobia which have come under the notice of the Metropolitan Police from January, 1885, to May, 1886.

Charles W. Scott, ticket agent in the employ of the Long Island Railroad Company, was arrested yesterday on a charge of stealing a trunk containing property valued at $640. Scott was stationed in the ticket office at the Thirtyfourth-Street Ferry.

WASHINGTON, July 4.--There are a good many Democrats in Congress who profess to be very much amused at what to them appear to be gross inconsistencies in the bill recently introduced by Mr. Randall to head off the Tariff bill of Mr. Morrison.
A gentlemen whose health had become impaired by the excessive use of tobacco was asked if he got very much sympathy in his misfortune.
CHICAGO, July 4.--The Fourth of July was, from a national point of view, observed here chiefly by patriotic services in the churches.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, July 4.--Teemer and Hamm rowed a three-mile race for second place in the regatta this evening. In the first mile both came down the course together. In turning the buoy Hamm steered wildly, from which point Teemer pulled rapidly away, winning in 19:21 . Gaudaur takes first money, $450; Teemer second, $300; Hamm third, $150. They leave for the South in the morning.

Gen. John A. Logan arrived in St. Louis yesterday from Bloomington, Ill., where he had been in attendance at the funeral of the late Judge David Davis. Among the cards carried to the Senator's room in the evening was one from a reporter of the Globe-Democrat.

Mr. PATRICK EGAN has shown laudable promptness and indignation in denying the Fortnightly Review's story about the Phoenix Park murders. Perhaps he will also deny an incident well known in this city which certainly tends to corroborate at least part of that story in no small degree.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 4.--This has been day of jubilee for the First Methodist Episco pal Church. Its new sixty-thousand-dollar house of worship was dedicated to-night after a debt of $20,000 had been raised by subscription through the efforts of the Rev. Dr. Flood, of Meadville. The Rev. Dr. Vincent, Chancellor of Chautauqua, preached in the morning, and Dr. W.G. Williams, of Allegheny College, this evening.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 4.--To-night, after having been out 23 hours, the jury in the trial of the Anarchist leaders, Frank Hirth, Carl Simon, and Anton Palm, found them guilty of conspiracy to burn the Court House and destroy the records, and of inciting mobs to riot.

PORTLAND, Me., July 4.--This city began to-day a three-days' celebration of the one hundredth anniversary of its incorporation. The ceremonies connected with the celebration will be most elaborate and imposing.

Isaac Klein, a journeyman butcher, 50 years old, employed in Strassburger's butcher's shop, No. 219 East Fifty-ninth-street, committed suicide yesterday by cutting his throat with a butcher's knife in the yard behind the shop.

The Socialistic and boycotting elements in the Central Labor Union created a great excitement at the meeting of that body yesterday afternoon, and a great part of the afternoon was devoted to discussion over the conviction of the boycotters last week.

The first annual report of Commissioner CARROLL D. WRIGHT, of the Federal Bureau of Labor, contains, on page 251, a table that should be carefully studied by all who are still open to conviction with regard to tariff reform.

MOBILE, Ala., July 4.--The condition of the cotton crop east of the Mississippi is exciting general alarm. The season began with excessive rains and floods in March, and most of the crop had to be replanted.

The law of the State includes among the powers of the Common Council of this city the power to pass ordinances "in relation to the use of guns, pistols, firearms, firecrackers, fireworks, and detonating works of all descriptions."
Several fires were caused yesterday in various parts of the city by firecrackers thrown around by careless and mischievous boys. Fortunately they were easily put out and caused only little damage.

Adolph Corbett, the supposed proprietor of Theiss's concert hall, at No. 61 West Fourteenth-street, was arrested on Saturday, charged with a violation of the law regulating places of amusement in giving orchestral concerts without having a theatrical license.

That Collector Hedden is a most "offensive partisan" of the Squire or "dummy" species there can be little doubt after a knowledge has been obtained of the peculiar way in which he has been graciously permitted to run the Custom House by Hubert O. Thompson, Surveyor Beattie and Special Deputy Collector Arthur Berry.

CHICAGO, July 4.--The impression that the Lake Shore strikers will soon be forced to return to the company and ask for employment is a mistaken one. They are in reality almost as well provided for as before the strike.
To us belaogs the merit of having a number of writers who, with a decided leaning toward natural history, are gifted with striking descriptive powers.

ALBANY, July 4.--Albany was always a quaint town and always contained queer people. This is a conclusion partly based on an inspection of the old archives, just now in great demand for the Loan Exhibition, and partly upon observations made during many months' residence.

MADISON, Wis., July 4.--Crops in this vicinity are much damaged because of lack of rain. A drought, which has continued two months, has so injured crops that the yield in every way will be much diminished. Winter wheat is well headed, and is turning yellow in some places. The hot weather has rather injured the berry in filling.

Mr. Manson puts down the cost of contested elections at 800 to each candidate. The average cost is, I believe, about 600. But this is far too much. What is done at Northampton might be done elsewhere.

CHICAGO, July 4.--Manager Palmer and Manager Tillotson are still able to comfortably fill McVicker's and Hooley's theatres, despite the the warm weather, and there is no sign of a lessening of interest in the performances of their companies.
POUGHKEEPSIE, July 4.--A crew of the Atlantic Boat Club, of Hoboken, left Hoboken at 5 P.M. yesterday with a 10-oared barge and reached Sing Sing at 10:30 P.M., and remained all night.

CHICAGO, July 4.--For the first time in many years the Orangemen of the city have decided to commemorate the anniversary of the battle of the Boyne. The question was referred to a committee consisting of 27 members appointed by the various lodges, and they were given the power to decide whether any demonstration should be made on July 12. The route of march is through the business centre of the city.

The inhabitants of Long Island had an opportunity yesterday morning for the first time in their lives of reading the Sunday papers before attending church.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--An enthusiastic and well attended meeting of Irish-Americans in the interest of home rule for Ireland was held at St. Patrick's parochial school building, Newburg, this afternoon. A stirring and patriotic address was delivered by the Rev. Joseph F. Mooney ...

THE NEW-YORK TIMES has set on foot the most remarkable specimen of newspaper enterprise that has as yet graced the wonderful journalism of the United States. It has sent an exploration party to Alaska under command of Lieut. Schwatka, the noted scientist and explorer.

For the first time in nearly five years the tramp of the armed sentry before the tomb in which rest the remains of President Garfield is silenced, and the guard of United States troops is withdrawn from Lake View Cemetery.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--A man whose name has not been ascertained was found this afternoon near Walsh's paper mill in the town of New-Windsor, near the Newburg line, with his head beaten fearfully. He is still alive but is said to be in a dangerous condition. It is not known who inflicted the injuries.
CHICAGO, July 4.--Yesterday was the opening day of the "World's Pastime Exposition" at Cheltenham Beach, and it terminated rather unpleasantly for those who returned to the city by boat.
The mass meeting to express sympathy for home rule in Ireland that will be held under the auspices of the Central Labor Union, in Union-square this afternoon, will doubtless be very largely attended.

Early yesterday morning Fred Witenbecker, residing on Flushing-avenue, Astoria, was shot in the mouth, during an altercation subsequent to the wedding of his daughter. James Smith, aged 25 years, living near by, was arrested, and was identified by Witenbecker and others as the man who fired the shot. Smith was locked up in the county jail and will be examined to-day. It is feared that Witenbecker's injury will prove fatal.
OTTAWA, Ontario, July 4.--One of the neatest and most successful pieces of detective work done for years was performed Friday by Detective Daniel O'Leary, Inspector of the Dominion police.

John W. Pethard, of No. 39 West Twentyfourth-street, the Englishman who shot at his wife about a week ago, attempted to commit suicide last evening by taking a quantity of opium and chloroform. He was taken to the New-York Hospital.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 4.--A dispatch stated briefly some days ago that there had been a shooting affair between two brothers in the back portion of the parish of St. Lareday, and that one of the parties had received a mortal wound. Not until to-day were all the particulars received of this remarkable affair.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 4.--Although the home nine played a rank fielding game to-day, they won from the visitors by their timely batting and good base running. Hecker, for the home nine, pitched a good game, the visitors scattering their hits ...

WILKESBARRE, Penn., July 4.--Dr. George S. Prince and Mrs. Gray, his sister, are at present making a tour of this country. While in Toronto, Canada, Mrs. Gray had a wardrobe made, upon which she advanced $190.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--Thomas White, an Englishman, and a school teacher by occupation, went from Mount Hope, Orange County, to Port Clinton in 1776, where he taught school during the greater part of the revolutionary war, dying at Mount Hope in 1807.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 4.--The hopes of the fishermen of Newfoundland are not very high at present, not that fish are scarce, but rather on account of an overabundance. Of late more codfish have been taken than are required to meet the wants of consumers, causing ...

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 4.--This morning Company D, Twelfth New-York Regiment, was escorted to the First Reformed Church, where the Pastor, the Rev. A.P. Van Gieson, preached a sermon upon liberty. During the sermon a private in the company ...

Coney Island was pinched for room yesterday. The railroad companies pined for more rolling stock, and the vessels of the Iron Steamboat Company were neither numerous nor large enough to satisfy the people whose sole desire was to spend the Fourth at Coney Island.
The programme for Monmouth Park, today, is attractive enough to draw an immense holiday crowd, the "card" of races having been made with special reference to the day.

A call has been issued by the Executive Committee of the Canal Improvement Union for a convention to be held at Syracuse, on the 28th of August, to consider the problem of securing an improvement of the canals of this State.

When Mr. and Mrs. Thomas P. Kelly, of No. 11 West One Hundred and Twenty-fifthstreet, returned home after a visit to a friend, late last Tuesday evening, they found their rooms in a state of wreck.

LONDON, July 4.--The Gladstonians are elated over the decisive character of their victories in Dundee, where Mr. Robertson and Mr. Lacaita, Gladstonians, received, respectively, 8,236 and 8,216 votes against 3,545 and 3,346 for Mr. Nixon and Mr. Daly, Liberal Unionists.

CHARLESTON, S.C., July 4.--About the 1st of June, in Barnwell County, John Steedley was publicly cowhided by W.T. Connelly and A.L. Ott for circulating slanderous reports about Connelly's sister Emma. At Hunter's Chapel Church this morning while the Sunday school was in session Steedley was shot and killed by Emma Connelly, who gave herself up to the authorities after the shooting.

CHICAGO, July 4.--James Brown, a patient in Ward No. 13 at the County hospital, was stretched out on his bed under the northeast window of the ward just before midnight last night. Suddenly there was a loud explosion outside.
A rather remarkable little episode occurred in a broker's office in St. Louis the other day, going to show that sometimes even very acute gentlemen do not know how well they are off.

Ex-Gov. Dillingham, of Waterbury, underwent an operation for cataract at the Mary Fletcher Hospital, in Burlington, last Tusday. The operation was performed by Prof. Moore and is likely to prove an entire success.

In the League contest, the Detroits still hold a lead over the New-York and Chicago clubs, but the latter are closely pushing the Michigan players for first position. The New-Yorks have been playing a remarkably fine game on the present Western trip, losing only one out of nine games played.

HOTEL KAATERSKILL, N.Y, July 4.-- Those who are floating in this aerial region, poised above the dim, broad valley that vanishes in the silver haze below, are wondering how people feel in New-York to-day. It is hot even here in these noble mountains.

Col. Bob Ingersoll has an ambition, so one of his friends tells me; and this ambition is to make such a record in New-York as will give him a high position here as a jurist. "The public is likely to hear a good many less lectures on holy writ from the Colonel," said this authority, "and see a good deal more of him in the court room."

Since the 1st of January Archbishop Corrigan has administered the sacrament of confirmation to 10,777 persons. The Archbishop is at present the guest of Mr. Chapin at his country seat, near New-London, Conn.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 4.--The dead body of Isaac White was found this afternoon at 3 o'clock by some boys in a lot on Pamanter-street, near Mill-street, Newburg. The head of the dead man was in a terribly battered and bruised condition, the injuries having been evidently inflicted by a bludgeon or large stone.

BARNES COMMON, June 14.--In England it is as difficult to escape from politics as from smoke or bad weather, but I may fairly congratulate myself upon having done so for once.

PARIS, July 4.--Le Paris confirms the announcement of the loss of eight French torpedo boats in a storm on the Atlantic. Fifty persons were drowned. Saturday's dispatch denying the loss of the torpedo boats was based upon a statement of the Minister of Marine referring to other torpedo boats.

WASHINGTON, July 5.--The PostmasterGeneral does not expect to see anybody assuming to represent the railway postal clerks in the capacity of objectors to his dismissals of men who had been found guilty of what he calls a conspiracy to cripple the service.

KANSAS CITY, July 5.--The Cowboys demonstrated to-day that they cau play ball, a matter which has been somewhat in dispute of late.

The twentieth annual games of the Brooklyn Caledonian Club were contested yesterday at Myrtle-Avenue Park, in the presence of a host of enthusiastic spectators. The games began at 11 o'clock and continued till sunset. A half-mile race for amateurs was the first event.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 5.--Six thousand people attended the morning game at Recreation Park between the Pittsburgs and Baltimores.

PATERSON, N.J., July 5.--Valentine Sim, of No. 248 Pacific-street, was firing off a cannon in front of his house, at about 7 o'clock to-night, when it burst, and one of the fragments went tearing through his taroat, coming out through his cheek. Ho was removed to St. Joseph's Hospital, where he died within an hour.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 5.--The yacht Puritan, which has been at Naushon recently, came here to-day.

CHICAGO, July 5.--The further prosecution of the war on Western freight rates will depend in a great measure upon the result of the meeting of the Managers of the tripartite roads, in Commissioner Vining's office, to-morrow.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 5.--Late this afternoon John and Frank Pasztor, two Hungarians and brothers, went into Joseph Gillet's saloon, near Shore's brick yard, in North Haven.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 5.--The inquest in the case of Isaae G. White, whose body was found yesterday in a vacant lot, with the skull crushed, was begun to-day by Coroner Corwin.
The disappearance of Count Bandino Panciatichi, of No. 253 Ocean-avenue, Jersey City, was reported yesterday.

The Pittsfield Advertiser recalls the fact that at the end of the war the town of Detroit, with a population of but 700 and a valuation of but $130,000, was $15,000 in debt, and the first tax thereafter asseased was 10 cents on the dollar.

PHILADELPHIA, July 5.--Patrick Coyle, a little man with whitened hair, nervously wiped huge beads of perspiration from his wrinkled brow to-day as he vainly sought rest and comfort in a stifling cell of the station house, at Thirty-ninth-street and Lancaster-avenue.

Five thousand people attended the annual picnic and games of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, in Jones's Wood Colosseum, yesterday afternoon and evening. This festival and the ball given in the Winter are the regiment's only sources of revenue, save the State payroll.

There was an exciting scene yesterday on the Grand-Street Base Ball Grounds in Jersey City. There is a strong rivalry between the Jersey City and Newark Clubs, which were playing, and the Jersey Citys claim that their losses to the Newarks have been due to unfair umpiring.

The second and last day of the national festival for the benefit of the German Hospital and Dispensary, held in Brommer's Union Park, Southern Boulevard and Willis-avenue, was even better attended and more enjoyable than the first.

A dispatch from Detroit, Mich., on June 25, stated that "Reddy" Kelaher, who two days before had killed a policeman while resisting arrest, had been lynched.

The first midsummer games of the Nassau Athletic Club, in Washington Park, yesterday drew a large crowd of spectators. C.T. Wiegand (B.A.A.) beat the record in the 220 yards' hurdle race by three-fifths of a second.

ST. LOUIS, July 5.--An unprovoked assault, that will probably result in a murder, occurred about 10 o'clock last evening at Nineteenth and Biddle streets.
LONDON, July 5.--Two express trains, one from Edinburgh and the other from Glasgow, same in collision to-day at Fullwood Junction. Thirty-five persons were injured.

BOSTON, July 5.--Twenty-five thousand persons witnessed the rowing regatta on the Charles River to-day, which was the principal feature of the Fourth of July celebration. The water was smooth at the start, but before the race was finished it was rough and choppy.

DETROIT, July 5.--The New-York and Detroit Clubs placed two games on the home grounds to-day. The weather was splendid, the heat of a July sun being tempered by a comfortable breeze. The morning game drew 7,000 people to Recreation Park.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 5.--Many incidents occurred to-day that marred the general festivities, although the celebration of Independence Day was generally observed with more enthusiasm than has ever before been witnessed in Elmira. Several small fires occurred, but were quickly subdued.
CINCINNATI, July 5.--The contest between the Athletics and Cincinnatis this morning was dull and prolonged, and was won by the home team through heavy batting.

Mrs. George F. Slosson, wife of the billiardist, died in Chicago of puerperal fever yesterday afternoon. She had given birth to a child on the preceding Wednesday. Mrs. Slosson was the eldest daughter of Mr. Thomas Foley, and was married to Mr. Slosson in October, 1885.

MEDINA, N.Y., July 6.--A young man named M. Gleason, living near Middleport, committed suicide last night by taking a quarter of a pound of Paris green. At a meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League, in Justice Kelly's court room last evening an attempt was made to elect officers for the ensuing year, but the struggle between the contending factions was so fierce and prolonged that at a late hour no result had been reached.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 6.--A desperado named King while drunk boarded a Cincinnati Southern freight train near Pine Knot, Ky., and butchered in a horrible manner Edward Pelton, the conductor. Pelton died immediately, and King escaped.

CINCINNATI, July 6.--The Burke-Nolan fight of yesterday was the talk of the town today. Contrary to expectations the two principals were arrested this morning on warrants charging them with fighting, contrary to law.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 6.--Albert G. Braun, a book agent, has been arrested here on charges of forging the names of prominent firms to orders for books published by the Elstner Publishing Company, of Louisville, Ky. MINERSVILLE, Penn., July 6.--Emma Oberlies, the only daughter of John Oberlies, one of the leading citizens of this place, is lying at the point of death from burns received last evening, when her clothing ignited from a firecracker.

At the Essex Market Police Court yesterday the Retail Shoe Salesmen's Protective Association prosecuted Morris Levy, of No. 204 Parkrow, for having sold a pair of shoes at 11 o'clock on Sunday morning, June 27.
HARROLD, Texas, July 6.--A cyclone visited this section this afternoon. A number of dwelling houses were blown down, and considerable damage was done to growing crops.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., July 6.--The red-letter day for this county is July 1, when the fish law comes off with a bang and the boys can rush up to Sayles's or ever to Echo Lake and skitter for the frolicsome pickerel, dredge for the mischievous perch, or troll or cast for the pot-bellied but bewildering bass.

TROY, N.Y., July 6.--Martin B. Waite, an eccentric character, died tow days ago at Centre Cambridge, Washington County. He was born near that hamlet, but went West when a young men. He married a Western woman, but procured a divorce when their first and only child was 5 years of age.
TITUSVILLE, Penn., July 6.--A man named Wilson, residing near Townville, was arrested today on a charge of having murdered the two Mrs. Everharts, at Lickingville, Clarion County, last Winter.

VICKSBURG, Miss., July 6.--There has not been so much excitement in years as there is now in Mississippi over the local option elections. The question comes to a vote in this county on the 17th inst.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 6.--Charles Isaac, a stage driver, aged 26, spent yesterday at Akron, returning to his home in Oakfield in the afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6.--The ship John Mann, with kerosene, from New-York, for London, went ashore on the northwest side of Block Island during a fog last night. She lies easy and is making no water.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 6.--The insurance frauds perpetrated by E.S. Phillips, of Matteawan, are attracting general attention. The first attention to the matter was called by the burning of the Carroll property in the village named.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 6.--Sight drafts on New-York, 10; telegraphic, 15.

There was a contrast, and a striking one, between the Monday and the Tuesday at Monmouth Park, for although there were 5,000 or 6,000 people present to witness the races yesterday, it formed a crowd insignificant in comparison to that of the preceding day.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., July 6.--News has just reached here of a terrible gale at Apalachicola on Wednesday, the 30th ult., uprooting trees, unroofing houses, and causing a loss of $40,000. The telegraph wires were blown down, and six persons--four white and two colored-- who were caught in the bay during the storm, lost their lives.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 6.--Eight persons were yesterday poisoned by eating bread baked by Mrs. James Williams, near here. The sufferings of six farm hands and of Mrs. and Mr. Williams were intense, but emetics saved them. A piece of bread fed to a dog killed it. It is supposed that enemies of the Williams family put poison in a sack of flour while they were from home last Sunday. The flour will be analyzed.

FREDERICK, Md., July 6.--This city is considerably excited over the shooting in the main street of H.R. Besant by Dr. Joseph A. Webb, which occurred last night.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 6.--Gen. Gordon, in the primaries to-day, received more than the necessary 176 votes which it takes to nominate, and will therefore be the candidate for the next Governor of Georgia.

CHICAGO, July 6.--In the United States court this morning Judge Blodgett decided the case of Rudolph Aronson against George Fleckenstein and others, of the Chicago Casino, which was a bill filed by Mr. Aronson to prevent the Casino people from producing "Erminie" in this city.

The boy and girl who were brought to the notice of the Sheriff at Kingston, N.Y., on Friday last as likely to be an eloping couple were Alfred W. Nichols, 17 years old, and Emily Duryea, age 13, of Brooklyn.
TOLEDO, Ohio, July 6.--Under the bridge in front of the Hotel Montreal this morning the body of Mrs. J.L. Lilley was found floating in the Maumee River.

Nearly every State in the Union was represented yesterday at the ninth biennial convention of the American Association of Instructors of the Blind, which was opened at the New-York Institute for the Blind, No. 412 Ninth-avenue, and will continue to-day and to-morrow.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 6.--The American flag was fired on yesterday by Anarchists as it was flying over a procession in the northwestern part of the city.

CHICAGO, July 6.--The Chicagos were unfortunate enough to go down before Radbourn's pitching, though they made something of an effort in the last inning to catch up the lost ground.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 6.--The weather continues fine for the encampment of the Twentythird Regiment of Brooklyn. The boys went out out to do the town to-day and brought many cheap cabs and omnibuses into use.

PHILADELPHIA, July 6.--The Times to-morrow will print the story of a startling accident in a dentist's office. Mrs. Josie E. CHICAGO, July 6.--It is understood that before many weeks official announcement will be made of the promotion of two of the priests of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago to the episcopate.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 6.--The Philadelphia won the third successive game from the Maroons to-day, winning with ease through the inability of the St. Louis men to hit Ferguson.

The St. Regis and Cornwall Island Indians played a match at lacrosse yesterday at the Brooklyn Athletic Association grounds. The play was very exciting, so much so that there were several small fights during the game.

The President continues to have much of his time taken up with the consideration of private pension bills, and he is not deterred by the criticisms of the Senate committee from doing his plain duty and vetoing those which he is convinced are without merit.

CHICAGO, July 6.--Lizzie Cole, an intelligent young quadroon, who lives in Taylor-street, told Inspector of Customs Crowley a story this afternoon which, if true, can hang a Captain of one of the lake tugs.

WASHINGTON, July 6.--Probably all the vetoed pension bills which originated in the Senate, with one exception, will be reported from the Committee on Pensions with recommendations that they do pass, the President's veto notwithstanding. The one exception will be covered by a new bill, the vetoed one being defective in consequence of a clerical error.

Prof. Joseph Echteler, the Bavarian sculptor, has completed a model of a proposed monument to Gen. Grant, and has submitted it to the Grant Monument Association. He proposes to construct it of polished granite, and it is to be 59 feet square at the base and 72 feet high.
ERIE, Penn., July 6.--The grand biennial Turn Fest of the Lake Erie Turn district now in session will close to-morrow, but the prizes were awarded to-night.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 7.--The address of President McCosh on "Elective Studies in Colleges" before the University Convocation this evening was the most notable lecture of to-day's programme. ATLANTA, Ga., July 7.--Fifteen years ago James F. Porter, a city official, was detected in a blackmailing scheme which he had been working successfully for quite a time, and was tried on charges preferred by two of his victims.

BELMONT, Mass., July 7.--The dwelling house and stable of Edward Barry, a day laborer on the Fitchburg Railroad, was burned to the ground early yesterday morning. When the fire broke forth Mr. Barry was walking upon the railroad track in the direction of home somewhat under the influence of liquor.
CHICAGO, July 7.--To-day was the anniversary of the disappearance of little Lillie Schaffer, the child who was kidnaped last year.

LONDON, July 7.--Daly's theatrical company produced "Nancy Co." this evening before an enthusiastic house. The performance was a great success. The principal members of the company were warmly applauded. The verdict of the critics is universally favorable.

VICTORIA, Texas, July 7.--The Democratic Congressional Convention of the Seventh District assembled here to-day and unanimously renominated the Hon. William H. Crain.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 7.--The Pioneer Press will print to-morrow reports on the condition of the crop from every wheat-growing county in Minnesota and Dakota, and also from 100 counties in Iowa, Wisconsin, and Nebraska.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 7.--This has been quite a lively day at Camp Wetmore, where the Twenty-third Regiment, of Brooklyn, is quartered.

DETROIT, Mich., July 7.--Detroit shut out Philadelphia in a quiet game to-day, in which light hitting was the feature. Bennett made his first appearance since his accident in the Chicago games, and played in his usual perfect manner.

ALBANY, Mo., July 7.--Considerable excitement prevails over the discovery of coal at Gentryville, a small town in the southern part of this county, a vein of 26 inches of superior quality having been discovered at a depth of 475 feet. A shaft will be sunk immediately and other towns in the county are already preparing to uncover hidden treasure.

The programme of the third annual regatta of the American Yacht Club has been issued. The regatta will take place on July 15, over the club course, from Larchmont to New-London, a distance of 80 knots, or about 90 miles.

CHICAGO, July 7.--At a stormy session of the City Council, which did not adjourn until nearly 1 o' clock this morning, an ordinance was passed granting the North Chicago Street Railway Company the use of the La Salle-street tunnel.
LAWRENCE, Mass., July 7.--Miss Bessie Sherwood and young Harry Southwick hurriedly walked through Garden-street, arm in arm, in the middle of the day.

CHICAGO, July 7.--The weather here has changed very much in the last few hours. At this time it is quite cold, with a strong wind, but the prospects of fair weather for to-morrow are good.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 7.--The college authorities have just received notice that Mrs. James Oswald, of Troy, has bequeathed to the college $5,000, to be known as the William L. Oswald scholarship fund. The conditions upon which the bequest is made have not been made public yet.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 7.--On the morning of June 26 Dr. W.S. McCollum, of Niagara Falls, was found dead in his unfinished house in that village. He had, it was first supposed, committed suicide.

When the Civil Service Commission wrote on to President Comstock, of the local Examining Board, to inquire whether or not the powers that be at the Custom House were faithfully carrying out the letter and spirit of the civil service law, President Comstock sent back word promptly that they were not so carrying it out.
The eighth annual convention of the Business Educators' Association of America began its session yesterday at Packard's Business College, No. 805 Broadway.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 7.--There was another hearing to-day in the city court in the Journal and Courier libel case against Benjamin F. Glidden, Walking Delegate of Typographical Union No. 47.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 7.--Henry Shepard, 55 years old, came from Albany to live with his son-in-law in this city three weeks ago.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 7.--The correspondend of the Freeman at Kerhonkson, a town of Rochester, Ulster County, writes: "A romantic marriage was solemnized here on Saturday.

The upper floor of George I. Cook's flat house, at No. 192 West Tenth-street, is rented by George Koch, and it sheltered Tuesday night himself and his family and three lodgers--Dr. R. T. Rutherford and a man known as Joseph or John Werner and his son Joseph, 14 years old.

CONCORD, N.H., July 7.--The name of Col. C.H. Sawyer, of Dover, has been for some time prominently mentioned in connection with the Republican nomination for Governor. Col. Sawyer is a native of New-York, but has lived in Dover since he was 10 years old.

BUFFALO, July 7.--The Buffalo Alumni of Ingham University, of Leroy, gave the founder of the well known school for women, Mrs. E.E. Ingham Staunton, a reception to-day at which Mrs. Jennie Scott Dyke, President of the Ingham Association of New-York and Brooklyn, was one of the guests. She spoke of the great interest in their Alma Mater shown by the New-York and Brooklyn Alumni and felt that the future of the school was assured.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 7.--James scott, the agent of Wilson Waddingham, the West Haven millionaire, and who was reputed to have captured $50,000 of his employer's money, today pleaded guilty of embezzlement, and was sent to jail for one year by Judge Stoddard, of the Superior Court.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 7.--The committee appointed by the New-Brunswick Fire Insurance Company to investigate the accounts of Lewis Applegate, the Treasurer, who was reported to be $18,000 short, have reported that the deficiency is but $3,000.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 7.--The Captain of a steamer from Charlottetown, which arrived at Pictou to-day, reports having passed this morning the new Boston steamer Merrimac ashore on Rifleman's Rock, east of Point Prim.
ALBANY, Texas, July 7.--Reports received from Shackelford County to-day reveal a sad state of affairs. There is not an acre of corn, wheat, or oats in the county.

MACON, Mo., July 7.--The City Council recently passed an ordinance prohibiting the sale of liquor within the city limits in less quantities than one gallon. The proprietors of the saloons yesterday presented to the County Court their applications for licenses, but they were all refused, and to-day there is not a saloon open in Macon. The same state of affairs exists in Linncus, Mo.
BATAVIA, N.Y., July 7.--William Enright, a stonecutter, and August Schaerf, a tailor, were, with a dozen friends, at Charles Blumerick's saloon last night.
LEWISTON, Penn., July 7.--Altoona, 11; Hamilton, 3. BINGHAMTON, N.Y., July 7.--Binghamton, 4; Utica, 0.

SPENCER, Wis., July 7.--The entire hamlet of Romeo was burned at 1 o' clock this afternoon, including the saw mill, planing mill, 5,000,000, feet of lumber, store, boarding house, and dwellings of William Van Hoosear. Loss, $150,000; insurance, $50,000. The woods are on fire and further particulars cannot be obtained.

LONDON, July 7.--Advices received here say that on the 2d inst. a body of Albanian Mussulmans attacked and pillaged several Montenegrin villages, killing some of the inhabitants and capturing a number of elders. ERIE, Penn., July 7.--The customs authorities along the chain of lakes, and particularly in New-York State, have been annoyed by a persistent and audacious scheme of smuggling carried on for years.

WATERVILLE, N.Y., July 7.--Failure is written upon every hop yard in this vicinity, the centre and richest portion of the hop district of New-York. Trustworthy reports from every county in which hops are cultivated are of the same despondent character.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 7.--Lieut. Darrang, of the Bridgeport police force, started this afternoon to take Thomas Hayes, a 16-year-old boy, to the Reform school in Meriden.
The forthcoming report of the Civil Service Commissioners on the conduct of ex-Postmaster VEAZEY, of Baltimore, will have much interest outside of that city.

Work was resumed at the Brooklyn Navy Yard yesterday, but strangely enough nearly all the men taken back were Democrats. Late Tuesday night Commodore Chandler received a telegram from Secretary Whitney stating that provision had been made for the extension of the naval appropriation for 15 days.
Mr. J. Dixon suffered a loss of $2,000 by a fire which broke out yesterday morning on the roof of his five-story brick building No. 289 Bleecker-street.

BOSTON, Mass., July 7.--At about 11 o' clock last night, as Frank Reardon was groping his way through a dark entry at his home, No. 6 Kenne-place, he was startled by hearing groans from his mother's chamber.

In Arizona irrigation is aiding the rapid development of the Territory and demonstrating its productiveness. Outside of a few small elevated valleys in the northern part of the Territory irrigation is everywhere essential to cultivation. Small grain requires to be flooded from two to four times during the season.
LONDON, July 7.--Mr. and Mrs. Flower gave a brilliant entertainment last evening at Stratford-upon-Avon in honor of Dr. Wendell Holmes.
COLUMBUS, Mo., July 7.--J.W. Sanborn, Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture, reports that the crops in this State during the month of June were somewhat affected by drought and the chinch bug.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 7.--In accordance with the representations made by Paul Wilcox, New-York counsel for the American Press Association, who visited Ottawa for that purpose during the last session of Parliament, the import duty on stereotype plates has been reduced to 5 cents per pound.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 7.--The Indians and Cincinnatis played a dreary game this afternoon, which was won by the home team by lucky batting. The visitors had the bases full in the last inning, but were unable to do any hitting. Pechiney succumbed to the heat in the fourth inning and Mullane pitched the rest of the game.
Morton Edwards, the sculptor, has cut a bust of Alexander D. Sharon from Inyo County marble, which is the first attempt ever made to use California marble in sculpture.

At yesterday's meeting of the Board of Education only 14 Commissioners were present. Commissioner Crawford surprised his colleagues by moving to elect a new clerk of the board in the pleas of Mr. Kiernan.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 7.--In spite of the intense heat to-day the tennis players who are taking part in the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club's tournament had some very pretty and well contested matches.

LONDON, July 7.--The latest totals of members elected are: Conservatives, 240; Unionists, 47; Gladstonians, 119; Parnellites, 55.

It is announced in Harper's Bazar that the next number of that paper will contain a portrait of Mrs. Grover Cleveland, appearing as a double-page supplement. I have learned that the photograph from which this picture is to be reproduced was taken immediately after the return from Deer Park.

Police Commissioner Carroll, of Brooklyn, availed himself yesterday of the law providing for two additional Inspectors and appointed Capts. Edward Reilly, of the Van Brunt-street station, and Patrick H. McLaughlin, of the Gates-avenue station, to those positions. Each will receive a salary of $2,500 a year. Both are Democrats.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 7.--The severest wind, hail, and rain storm known for years struck this city from the northwest at 6 o'clock this evening. It lasted about 15 minutes and was most terrific. It was similar to a Western tornado.

CHICAGO, July 7.--In the Anarchist trial to-day not another juror was secured. Forty-six men were examined, and 36 were excused for cause, 6 on peremptory challenges by the defense, and 4 on peremptories by the State.
ST. LOUIS, July 7.--The Republican State Central Committee met to-day. The resignation of Chauncey I. Filley was accepted, and Gen. D. P. Grier, of St. Louis, was elected to fill the vacancy.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 7.--The Prohibition State Convention met in this city to-day, with the largest number of delegates ever collected in convention here, and placed a full State ticket in the field. J.E. Childs, of Waseca, was nominated for Governor, and J. Pinkham, of Hennepin, for Lieutenant-Governor, both by acclamation.

BUFFALO, July 7.--The State Teachers' Association began its forty-first annual meeting at Niagara Falls this afternoon. An address of welcome was delivered by W. Caryl Ely and responded to by Superintendent A. McMullan, of Utica.

ERIE, Penn., July 7.--The Ohio River and Lake Erie Railway Company is dead, having been sold by the Sheriff and constables of every county between Erie and the Shenango Junction.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 7.--John Lind was nominated for Congress by the Republicans of the Second District to-day to succeed Wakefield, the present member.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 7.--Capt. Penrose, of Memphis, defeated Capt. Meaders, of Nashville, to-day, killing 95 pigeons out of a possible 100. Meaders killed 93. The stake was $250 a side.

PITTSBURG, July 7.--Timothy Mead and Fritz Maxheimer, aged respectively 10 and 14 years, were drowned in the Allegheny River near Kittanning, Penn., this morning. Mead was seized with cramps while bathing and Maxheimer jumped in to rescue him. In the struggle both buys were drowned. Their bodies were recovered at noon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 7.--John McNamara, of Cedar Hill, this county, was arrested to-day on the charge of assault with intent to kill Frank Osterhoudt, of the same place.

Yesterday made a great many generally good men forget their grandmothers and comb over their stock of language to get out expressions not usually given space to in a family paper. When the sun climbed over the oriental gates of pearl he had a bad eye and meant business.

NORFOLK, Va., July 7.--Mrs. Oberley, the wife of a German farmer of Norfolk County, attempted to kindle a fire with kerosene yesterday, when the oil can exploded and the burning fluid was scattered over herself and two children, and instantly the clothing of all three was in a blaze. The mother and one child died last night, and the other child, while horribly burned may live.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, July 7.--A freight train on the Grand Trunk Railroad came into collision with a cow near Omemee last night. The engine and eight cars left the track. A brakeman named W. Powell was instantly killed and Fireman Daniel Geard was fatally scalded.

MADRID, July 7.--A severe shock of earthquake was felt at Malaga to-day. The heat in this city was so overpowering today that the Cortes was compelled to adjourn before reaching a vote on the budget estimates.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 7.--On motion of Alderman Kelly, the Newburg Common Council last evening voted unanimously to authorize Mayor Odell to offer a reward of $500 for the detection and punishment of the person or persons who murdered Isaac G. White in this city on last Sunday afternoon.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., July 7.--The Prohibition Convention nominated a full State ticket and adopted a long platform. The Republican Executive Committee, acting upon the power given them by the State Convention, met here to-day and nominated a full ticket. Arthur Bingham Talladega, a prominent Republican politician and ex-State Treasurer, was nominated for Governor.

CHICAGO, July 7.--The Customs Inspectors to-day discovered that the outrage alleged to have been perpetrated on Lizzie Cole, a young colored woman, yesterday morning, was committed aboard of the tug L.B. Johnson, commanded by Capt. Patrick Gorman.

ALBANY, July 7.--The Railroad Commission this afternoon announced its decision in regard to the car-coupling tests made at East Albany last month. They award the first place to the Hoag coupler.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 7.--Two lumber drivers, coming down the Gatineau River, quarreled. One of them, Joseph Phillips, struck his companion, whose name is unknown, with a crowbar, felling him and breaking his collarbone. Phillips was about to repeat the blow when the prostrate man pulled a self-cocking revolver from his hip pocket and shot him through the heart.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 7.--The Louisvilles played in great form to-day and won easily from the Athletics. Atkisson had a split hand, and was hit for a total of 26 bases.

ATWOOD, Ill., July 7.--Twenty-five men under the lead of the Sheriff stood guard around the home of Henry Wildman last night. There had been so much talk during the day of lynching that the strong guard was deemed a wise move in the interest of law and order.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8.--Connecticut members of the Ancient Order of Foresters held their annual field day here to-day, and 1,500 men were in line in the parade.

MONTREAL, July 8.--The number of ocean steamships and sailing vessels which have arrived in the port of Montreal up to July 1, this season, has been 191, with a tonnage of 242,757 tons, against 173 vessels and 200,806 tons last year. There were only 1,488 inland vessels entered in port up to the 1st of July, 1885, against 1,755 this year, showing a substantial increase for this year.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8.--Charles Edward Hellier, of Bangor, Me., who graduated from Yale College a week ago, was married this afternoon to Miss Mary Lavinia Harmon, daughter of Gen. George M. Harmon, of this city.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The following races were contested to-day: FIRST RACE.--Three-quarters of a mile: Varina, 102 pounds, (West;) Grisette, 102 pounds, (Millar;) Margo, 102 pounds, (Fuller;) Nellie B., 102 pounds, (O'Hara,) and Wary, 107 pounds, (Stoval,) started, Betting--Wary, $100; Nellie B., $20; field, $20, Wary won by a short half length, Grisette second, Margo a qad third. Time--1:15 . Mutuals paid $6.80.
The bidders at the auction sale of condemned boats at the navy yard yesterday were mostly boat builders, and they got some good bargains, particularly in gigs and cutters.
BOSTON, July 8.--A report that a syndicate of prominent Boston capitalists has recently purchased the Kansas City Street Railway has excited much interest to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 8.--J.S. Delay, a prominent Knight of Labor, who acted as Secretary of the Joint Committee of District Assemblies Nos. 101 and 17 during the late strike on the Gould Southwest system, is in the city.
The Chicago and Atlantic Railroad yesterday abandoned the practice of cutting rates on east-bound business in which it has been indulging during the past six months.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The Western Trunk Line Association (the tripartite combination) was revived to-day, but the action does not give promise of a settlement of the existing Western freight complications.

The Executive Committee of the Committee of One Hundred, having in charge the citizens' movement, met yesterday at the office of the Board of Fire Underwriters, in the Boreel Building.
HENRIETTA, Texas, July 8.--Yesterday morning Louis, Elmer, and Jim Smith, three brothers, were shot in Clay County, near their home by Jack Douthett, Doc Thompson, and Sterling Dawson.

A humming bird has built its nest on a small limb of one of the large sycamore trees in the rear of the Court House. This species of birds generally seek bushes for their homes, and the disciples of Audubon are puzzled at the strange location of the nest. The birds seem to enjoy their out-of-the-way home nevertheless. The nest is not more than one inch in diameter.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 8.--The Louisville and Nashville and the Ohio and Mississippi Railroads have entered into a lively fight over the Knights of Pythias' excursion to the Supreme meeting at Toronto, Canada. Several points are involved that will come up before the Central Passenger Committee.
A few of the striking painters of Williamsburg returned to work yesterday at the old rate of $3 a day of 10 hours, and many more wanted to do so.

Just as an excursion boat bearing members of a secret organization reached St. George, Staten Island, on the afternoon of June 30 a row occurred among a number of men who strove to get first to the gangway.

NYACK, N.Y., July 8.--William Eickhoff, Tax Collector of the town of Clarkstown, met with a strange and severe accident yesterday. He was in his stables near New-City for the purpose of feeding his horses, and in coming up to the manger he fell, striking on a metallic crosspiece on his throat, inflicting a severe wound there and injuring his windpipe so that he has been unable to speak since.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 8.--Yesterday Coroner Standrough, of Cold Spring, held an inquest upon the remains of Capt. Black and the boy Golden, who were drowned in the collision between the steamer City of Kingston and the schooner Mary Atwater.

Guilty of manslaughter in the second degree, with a recommendation to the mercy of the court, was the verdict against Dr. Theus Taylor, of Merrick, Long Island, in the County Court at Long Island City yesterday afternoon.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 8.--William Cromie, than whom there are few merchants in Louisville more widely known; made a general assignment for the benefit of his creditors this morning. Judge H.L. Stone was made the Assignee and accepted the trust of record.

Every one by this time has been through the St. Gothard Tunnel, and most travelers no doubt imagine that the line was made in order to facilitate their tours to the Italian lakes and Milan. The fact, however, is that the line was made not for the tourists but for the traders.

CHICAGO, July 8.--Board of Trade circles were much excited to-day by rumors of a gigan tic fraud in the wheat market. Very few were willing to admit that they had suffered, but later disclosures revealed the fact that a good many had an entry ...
NEWPORT, R.I., July 8.--In view of the heat this morning it was wisely decided to omit all unnecessary work at Camp Wetmore by the officers of the Twenty-third Regiment, of Brooklyn.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 8.--Much to everybody's disappointment to-day Prof. A.L. Ripley was not well enough to go on with his unfinished match with H.W. Slocum in the New-England championship tournament of the New-Haven Lawn Tennis Club. Mr. Slocum therefore got the match by default and was then pitted against F.G. Beach for first place in the singles.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--Duncan C. Ross, the ex-wrestler, was arrested here to-day for brutally assaulting Sergt. Walsh, his competitor in a mounted sword contest exhibition. The contest was a very tame one.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., July 8.--The open regatta to be sailed at Ipswich Buoy July 17, under the auspices of the Sandy Bay Yacht Club, promises to be one of the greatest yachting events on the New-England coast this season.

It is unusual for the Monmouth Cup and the Oaks to be run for on the same day, and as both of them were on the programme yesterday, together with the July Stakes, for 2-year-olds, and four other races, the "card" was considered an interesting one.

BELLEVILLE, Ontario, July 8.--This evening an old pensioner named Penland having quarreled with a family named Mack, who occupied a part of the same house in which he lived, shot Mrs. Mack through the chest, fatally wounding her, fired three shots at Mr. Mack, none of which took effect, and then committed suicide by shooting himself through the heart.
THE NEW-YORK TIMES celebrated the Fourth of July by putting on a new dress. THE TIMES is now as handsome as it is able, and that is saying a good deal.

TRENTON, N.J., July 8.--The spectacle of a man bleeding from a terrible wound in the neck and springing from a train head foremost into the Assanpink Creek, near the Clinton-street station, was witnessed at 5:30 o'clock this morning as an express train from the west steamed into the city.

WINCHESTER, Va., July 8.--While digging a cistern yesterday on the site of Fort Loudon, built by Washington after the battle of Fort Necessity, in Pennsylvania, in 1756, to protect Winchester against the French and Indians, there were found a portion of a skeleton, with hair and teeth, buttons, iron cannon wheels, balls, grapeshot, and hand grenade. These relics of war prior to the Revolution attract much attention.
Early yesterday morning Julius Hofflacker, a tailor living at No. 415 South Fourthstreet, Williamsburg, left his bed and went into another room.

Jimmy, son of Mr. James B. Coleman, of Ridgeway, was in bathing several days since, and while in water three or four feet deep was bitten on the foot by a snake which he had stepped upon. It has been thought that a snake could not bite in water, but this instance disproves it.

For a hot July day the attendance at the Daisy Murdoch benefit performance yesterday afternoon was very large. The lower floor of the Bijou Opera House was almost crowded, and there were many persons upstairs.

VICTORIA, British Columbia, July 8.-- Elections for the local Parliament were held yesterday.

LONDON, July 8.--At the Newmarket July meeting to-day the race for the Chesterfield Stakes, five furlongs, for 2-year-olds, was won by A. Benholm's br. c. Freshwater, with R.H. Combe's br.c. Maxim second and the Duke of Westminster's ch.f. Freedom third.
Once of the conveniences of free Niagara will be a new system of transportation similar to that in Central Park, New-York.
Nicholas Kraus, who lived in a wretched shanty in Sixty-fourth-street, near Eleventhavenue, was found yesterday morning at the foot of his bed dead.

CHICAGO, July 8.--The Detroit Baseball Club may win two games out of its three with Chicago, but it can't win them all, for Chicago took one to-day. The Wolverine yell is somewhat subdued to-night, and the town isn't being painted nearly as red as some Michigan men had planned.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 8.--The Browns shut out the Baltimores again to-day. Kilroy was somewhat wild and was hit freely, while Traffley's catching was wretched. Fulmer caught one inning, when Traffley again resumed his position. The Browns won, hands down, and there was no enthusiasm ...

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., July 8.--Prof. J. F. Davis has owned a terrier for a long time which was a great favorite among the children. As the Professor was going out of town yesterday he gave the animal to Miss Annie Berndt, a young lady well known in society here, to take care of while he was away.

PORTLAND, Me., July 8.--One of the most peculiar results of the present strained relations between the United States and Canada on account of the fisheries matter is the imposition of heretofore unknown dues upon vessels putting into Dominion harbors.

Judge Lawrence refused yesterday to dismiss the complaint of Receiver Farnsworth, of the Bankers and Merchants' Telegraph Company, against the Western Union Telegraph Company. Joseph H. Choate, senior counsel for the Western Union, then summed up the case.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 8.--The little 3year-old son of Millard Norris, living at Riverview, about 16 miles south of the city, was bitten by a mad dog near his home at that place on Tuesday.
"Grimshaw" has sent $2 to THE TIMES for Mrs. Landgraf, which was delivered to her last night.

MONTREAL, July 8.--The New-York "boodle" Aldermen Dempsey, Keenan, and De Lacy have left the city. One of them will, it is said, sail by one of the Allan steamers to Europe and the other two will take a sojourn in the Lower St. Lawrence.
QUEBEC, July 8.--Capt. Schramme, of the German bark Demetra, at this port from Sharpness, reports that at 2:30 A.M., on Wednesday, June 23, off St. Pierre Banks, he picked up two men in a small dory.

PHILADELPHIA, July 8.--Eighty-six vessel owners, Captains, and ship brokers, representing the whole shipping interest of Philadelphia, met to-day in the rooms of the Vessel Owners' Association to take action against the ...

Mr. Home, the spirit medium, whom I often met in the different phases of his varied career, and whose death has just taken place, was buried to-day at St. Germain-en-Laye beside an infant daughter whom he lost 12 years ago.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 8.--The village of Waterford, in Racine County, is terribly stricken with typhoid fever. Fifty people are down with the disease, and four deaths have occurred thus far. One family of 11 persons, and another of 9, are all in their beds. Great excitement exists in the village, and the State Board of Health will be asked to investigate the cause of the disease.

WASHINGTON, July 8, 1886. All the executive departments were repre sented at the Cabinet meeting to-day. One of the questions considered was in regard to the status of nominations which may remain unacted upon at the close of the session. The Cabinet also had a brief discussion concerning the course of Congress in the matter of pension legislation.
ASTORIA, Oregon, July 8.--During a heavy gale which prevailed off the entrance of the Columbia River Monday night seven salmon fishermen were drowned.

WASHINGTON, July 8.--The general court martial at Jefferson Barracks has been dissolved, and the following court ordered in its stead to meet on July 12: Capts. R.H. Montgomery, Fifth Cavalry Adam Kramer, Sixth Cavalry: S.M. Swigert, Second, Cavalry; First Lieuts. George F. Chase, Second Cavalry; S.A. Mason, Fourth Cavalry; ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 8.--The third tragedy within two weeks occurred at the Parker House in Latrobe, Penn., last night. During a quarrel a well known person named Palmer was shot and instantly killed by a per son in the crowd. No arrests have been made.

We have had on exhibition here during the past few days a strange marine animal. It was captured in Trinity Bay by some fishermen, who pursued it in a whaleboat and at length got near enough to shoot it.
By sitting from early in the morning until dark Judge Barrett disposed yesterday of the Landgraf boycott case by sentencing six of the boycotters to mild punishment.

The action of the Massachusetts Legislature in putting bounds to the extortion of the Bell Telephone Company is one that should commend itself to other State authorities if the lesson is not heeded by the corporation.
WOONSOCKET, R.I., July 8.--John and Frank Kelly, aged 16 and 14 years respectively, sons of John Kelly, of Millville, were drowned in the Blackstone River last night. The bodies were recovered.

MONTREAL, July 8.--Yesterday Mrs. St. Pierre placed on the stove a can of oil paint with which she was about to do some household work. On lifting the can the bottom fell out, and the contents immediately caught fire.

Last night as a gymnast belonging to Frush's Circus was performing on the flesta grounds, at Phoenix, the trapeze broke, precipitating him to the floor below. The chandelier, holding about 20 coal oil lamps, came down with him and the lamps exploded. Great excitement prevailed, but the fire was soon smothered and no one was seriously injured.

A good-looking young woman was seen loitering aimlessly on the dock at the foot of Delancey-street at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. A few minutes later she jumped into the East River.

PITTSBURGH, July 9.--This afternoon the Brooklyn players outbatted and outfielded the local club, and won a game by figures of 4 to 0. Terry pitched strongly for the visiting club, while Morris, the lefthanded twirler, was hit rather lively by the Brooklyn boys.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., July 9.--On Monday the New-York Ideal Opera Company, Charles D. Nagle, manager, opened a season of comic opera here. At 2:30 o'clock this afternoon, the time announced for a matinee performance, it was discovered that Nagle had disappeared, leaving unpaid the salaries of the members of his company, some of whom are penniless.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 9.--At the session of the State Teachers' Association at Niagara Falls to-day George Griffith, of Lockport, was elected President.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 9.--Milton Evans, a farm laborer from Southern Missouri, died in great agony from hydrophobia at the police station this afternoon. A madstone was applied last night and apparently took effect, but its owner said the patient had come too late.
Vincent Majowski, a dog fancier, of No. 136 West Twenty-seventh-street, was tried in General Sessions on Tuesday on a charge of assault preferred by Officer McCullough, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct.

DENISON, Texas, July 9.--In a recent decision the United States Court in the District of Columbia held that the Indian Territory is a foreign nation over which the United States courts have no jurisdiction.

Coroner Eidman and a jury held an inquest yesterday in the case of Mrs. Kate Lehman, who died in the Ninety-ninth-Street Hospital last Monday morning from the effects of a shock received in falling down the air shaft at her home, No. 2,414 First-avenue, on the evening of July 4.

The Committee of Fifteen appointed some time ago by the New-York Board of Fire Underwriters to favor a plan by which the business of fire insurance in the metropolitan district could be lifted out of the unprofitable rut into which it had fallen presented its report yesterday.
Ex-Assemblyman James Irving was mentioned in yesterday's newspapers as a man whom ex-Alderman Charles B. Waite feared and from whom he fled to the House of Detention.
It is a matter for special satisfaction that the report of the Civil Service Commission in regard to the action of ex-Postmaster VEAZEY, of Baltimore, was prepared by Mr. OBERLY.

AUGUSTA, Ga., July 9.--The hands in the picker room of the Augusta factory struck today for an advance of 10 per cent. in wages, President Phinizy having replied to their demands that he could not grant the advance, that ...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 9.--John Norton, tramp, in passing through the woods near the North Asbury Park station this forenoon, discovered the body of an infant child buried in a thicket of brush. Pulling the child out, he discovered that it was yet living.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 9.--Curtis Reed, John McIntyre, and James Maloney, the sailors who were arrested on a charge of piracy for stealing the sloop yacht Mamle from Kenoska Harbor, were this morning dischared by Commissioner ...
Prosper Thourault, a Frenchman, 65 years of age, infirm and weak-minded, was brought to the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday as an insane person.

The early closing excitement continues unabated in Jersey City. Merchants and clerks are directing their efforts toward persuading or forcing Manager Metzler to close the Boston Clothing House at 8 P.M.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Tripartite matters continued to be the prominent subject in railway circles to-day.

ST. LOUIS, July 9.--There are several rumors in baseball circles regarding a deal between Henry V. Lucas, of the League club of this city, and Christian Von der Ahe, the President of the American Association club.

ST. PETERSBURG, July 9.--It is officially stated that the closing of the port of Batoum does not constitute a violation of the Berlin treaty. Batoum was made a free port under the influence of circumstances which have entirely changed.

In compliance with a request from private counsel employed by Commissioner McClave, of the Police Department, the Corporation Counsel has given an opinion in regard to the disposition of the money accumulated during a year, by deducting $2 from the pay of each member of the force for the relief fund. Mr. Lacombe says those from whose pay the amounts were deducted have a right to demand its return.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 9.--James Bolton, a brakeman on the "short freight" between New-York and South Norwalk, on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad, fell between two cars to-day and his right leg was terribly crushed by the wheels, making amputation necessary. Bolton lives in Saugatuck. He is 20 years old and unmarried.

JACKSON, Mich, July 9.--Military circles here are excited over the disappearance of Alexander Brown, Jr., Second Lieutenant of Company D. He was one of a committee appointed to pay the bills incurred by the celebration of July 4, and had about $1,000 in his possession. He was not been seen since Wednesday. He was the founder of the suspended Daily Telegram, in which he sank much money. His relatives fear foul play.
PITTSBURG, Penn., July 9.--The most important matter considered at the convention of window-glass workers to-day was the question of reducing the assessment for the defense fund.

MOBILE, Ala., July 9.--M.D. Wickersham, nominated for State Auditor, and Gen. G. M. Duskin, nominated for Associated Judge of the Supreme Court by the Republican State Executive Committee at Birmingham yesterday, state that they were not consulted and are not candidates for these or any other offices.

LONG BRANCH, July 9.--Phil Daily, the proprietor of the Pennsylvania Clubhouse, and Charles Whitcombe, of the Ocean Club, who were arrested at the raid made upon the two clubhouses last evening, appeared with counsel before Esquire Morris to-day for trial.

Ferdinand Keerns, Charles Ritter, John Van Duyne, and M. Haas were arrested at Newark, N.J., last evening on suspicion of having shot and killed Joseph Zimmerman last Monday. They were firing at a target in a direct line where Zimmerman was lying under a tree when shot. A Coroner's inquest will be held on Zimmerman's body to-day.

Two burglars were discovered early yesterday morning in the house of Mr. Eggerton, in Maple-avenue, Elizabeth, N.J. Officer Fadde, who made the discovery, fired two shots at them. One of the shots struck one of the burglars in the leg.

The indignation of the American people against the boycotters is virtually universal, and it is as intense as it is general. It is an old saying that the American people are the most conservative people on the face of the earth.
