The muffled sound of deep moans coming from a spot just back from the big bluff at Fort Lee attracted the attention of two wandering French musicians at about 7 o'clock on Thursday evening. Lying on her face, almost on the edge of the cliff, was a young woman with blood streaming from wounds in her forehead.

The debate in the House yesterday upon the President's vetoes of Pension bills exhibited in a clear light the desperation of the attempt to make political capital out of those vetoes against their author.
BAR HARBOR, Me., July 9.--At the session of the American Institute of Instruction this morning J.M. Hall, of Providence, was elected President and the other officers were re-elected.
VICKSBURG, Miss., July 9.--The four wards of this city held their meetings to-night, and selected solid delegations for the Hon. L.C. Catchings, for re-election to Congress from this district.

Current Republican criticisms of the Administration seem to us to be a trifle strained and awkward. They do not appear to flow easily and naturally from the tongues and pens of the critics, and most of them are so void of pith and point as to serve no good purpose.

CINCINNATI, July 9.--The Metropolitans lost a game to the Cincinnati team this afternoon. The batting on both sides was good, but the local players can attribute their victory to strong field work. Forster's second base play and the field work of McPhee and Fennelly were the features of the game. Score:

PLYMOUTH, Mass., July 9.--In the Foley against Nash-Ramsdell case, asking $10,000 damages for causing the death of Mrs. Foley by an error in putting up a prescription, the jury today brought in a verdict awarding $200 damages to the plaintiff.

Mr. Charles Scribner, the senior member of Messrs. Charles Scribner's Sons, the publishers, announced yesterday to a reporter of THE TIMES that the firm would begin the publication of a new monthly magazine as soon as the necessary arrangements could be perfected.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July. 9.--A special from Benson, Minn., to the Pioneer Press says: "Three heavy hailstorms struck this locality last week, breaking 400 panes of glass in various buildings in the town and pounding crops and gardens into the ground.

UTICA, N.Y., July 9.--Reports from Montgomery County to the Herald show that the hop crop in that county will be almost a total failure. Many growers say that it will not pay to pick the vines. They are confident that good hops will command 25 cents or more.

DIGBY, Nova, Scotia, July 9.--The demand made by Secretary Bayard on the British Government for the release of the Gloucester schooner David J. Adams has been complied with, and Mr. E.S. Newcombe, counsel for Capt. Lewis, has commenced proceedings against the Collector of Customs to recover $12,000 damages for the seizure.
DETROIT, Mich., July 9.--Lorenzo B. Austin, a private banker of this city, who died a few days ago, left by his will bequests to Baptist churches in Akron and Middlebury, Ohio, where ...

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 9.--It is reported here on good authority that the attorneys of Miss Harriet F. Tracy, of New-York, have decided to contest the will of her father, Frank W. Tracy, husband of Agnes Ethel. By the terms of the will Miss Tracy receives only a life interest in $100,000. The case will come up before the Surrogate on Monday next.
LONDON, July 9.--The new Parliament approaches so near us now that, like the British files at Bunker Hill, we can see the whites of their eyes. The Tories will not have a majority.

The Rev. Dr. Robert Laird Collier arrived from Liverpool yesterday on the Baltic. Cappa's Seventh Regiment Band will play this afternoon, at 4 o'clock, on the West Drive opposite the Seventh Regiment Statue, in Central Park.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 9.--New-Haven's lawn tennis tournament is practically over, though the second best man among the single entries has not yet been found.

CHICAGO, July 9.--The failure of E.I. Dwyer Co. proves to have been a magnificent bet upon the turn of the die, and by the wrong side coming up 40 or 50 Board of Trade firms will divide between them an aggregate loss of nearly $40,000.

BALTIMORE, July 9.--Charles A. Hock, alias F.E. Adams, was to-day arrested in this city on information from Boston to the effect that he had stolen $800 from the West Shore Railroad Company, by which he was employed as clerk. Hoch came to this city about a week ago and rented a small house, in which he established two women of doubtful reputation. He was spending money freely, but $240 was found on him.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 9.--The lacrosse match played here to-day between the New-York Club and the Metropolitans, of Ottawa, resulted in victory for the Ottawa men, who took first and second games in 35 and 25 minutes, respectively.
LONDON, July 9.--Mr. Gillig gave a brilliant banquet to the Rev. Henry Ward Beecher this evening at the Metropole Hotel. United States Minister Phelps, Justice Stanley Matthews, ...
Chicago and New-York are gaining on Detroit. The New-Yorks will play in Phildelphia again to-day.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 9.--When the retail liquor licenses expired in this county, on June 30, several wholesale licenses were still in force, some to run three months.
CINCINNATI, July 9.--At a meeting of the International Bi-metallic League to-day, in this city, the Hon. William S. Groesbeck, President, the following resolution was unanimously adopted:

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, July 9.--Some days ago the schooner Sarah arrived at this port from New-York with a cargo of coal for Robert Bayard. He being unable to pay the duty the cargo was placed in bond. Bayard disregarded the bond and coutinued selling the coal. The Collector of Customs thereupon confiscated all the coal remaining in the vessel and all the coal which Bayard had in his warehouses.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 9.--Just before midnight last night the Louisiana Legislature adjourned sine die. There will not be another session until May, 1888, and a State election will intervene.
John Kilion, indicted with three other Bohemians of New-York for attempting to kill Ex-Alderman Patrick Murray on Sunday, June 6, was tried yesterday in the Queens County Court of Oyer and Terminer.

Mary McCaffrey, aged 23 years, of No. 224 Railroad-avenue, Jersey City, was struck by an outgoing train at the Coles-street crossing of the Pennsylvania Railroad in Jersey City last evening and was so badly injured that she died soon afterward.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 9.--The trial of Salt Superintendent P.J. Brumelkamp on charges of malfeasance in office, preferred by Armstrong Maltby, began here before Judge Frank Rice, of Canandaigua, as Referee to-day.
CARTHAGE, Mo., July 9.--The body of Thomas Small, son of Capt. John Small, a prominent farmer, was found in the timber on the verge of the prairie, just south of this city, yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--The days of salary grabs and salary grabbers do not appear to have, passed away, even in this year of economy and reform.

"I suppose," said a TIMES reporter to a Chambers-street hardware salesman, a modest man of about 38 Summers, "that in the course of your glorious career as a traveling man you have narrowly escaped instant death several hundred times."

QUEENSTOWN, July 9.--The Cunard Line steamship Umbria, Capt. McMickan, from New-York July 3 for this port and Liverpool, was signaled off Fastnet at 10 o'clock to-night. Time of passage, 6 days and 9 hours.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 9.--Emily Duryea, who eloped with Alfred W. Nichols from Brooklyn a few days ago, on the pretense that the girl was trying to escape the "horrors" of a home in a charitable institution, was expected in this city this evening.

Regarding recent rumors that have been much discussed in Wall-street, President Benedict, of the Chicago and Atlantic Railroad Company, yesterday made this statement: "It is not true that we have joined the Central Traffic Association.
CHICAGO, July 9.--Judge Blodgett entered a decree this morning in the case of the American Bell Telephone Company against Frederick W. Baird and Frank Dillon.

John O'Brien was fully installed yesterday as Receiver of the Broadway Surface Railroad Company by the execution of an agreement with the Twenty-third-Street Railroad Company to pay him $15 a day from May 6 last to the termination of the litigation for the privilege of running its cars over the Broadway Surface Company's road.

Capt. Edward Bindon, of the steamship Miranda, which went ashore on Point Judith on the night of June 19, is enthusiastic in his testimony to the efficiency and high character of Capt. Knowles, who is in command of the United States life-saving station on the Point.

The contest over the will of James B. Ogden, who is alleged by his son Herman to have been insane, was continued yesterday before Surrogate Lott in Brooklyn. Several witnesses went over familiar ground in describing the peculiar behaviour of Mr. Ogden during his intercourse with them.

In spite of the adverse criticism by Congressmen of the President's action in vetoing so many private pension bills the impression is strong upon the people at large that Cleveland has acted conscientiously in the matter.
Steamship Breakwater, Jenny, Newport News, with mdse. and passengers to Old Dominion Steamship Co. Bark Lugia Raffo, (Ital.,) Terrieino, Trapani 64 ds., with salt to order--vessel to master.

CINCINNATI, July 9.--Allen W. Thurman, son of ex-Senator Thurman, is in the city and said to a reporter to-day that there was no truth in the report that his father had been offered the Attorney-Generalship.
LANSING, Mich., July 9.--Returns received from 780 correspondents, representing 622 townships, 527 of which are from 379 townships in the southern four tiers of counties, ...
Col. John S. Mosby will enter the lecture field. He will appear on the platform in many of the principal cities next Autumn and Winter, and the subject of his discourse will be "Stewart's Cavalry."

Mrs. Holtz, wife of Edward Holtz, the man who attempted to commit suicide on Thursday by cutting his throat and jumping from a train into the Assanpink Creek at Trenton was found in an almost hysterical condition yesterday at her rooms, No. 340 East Twelfth-street.

BOSTON, July 9.--The Mayflower was this morning hauled out on Lockwood's marine railway at East Boston. The additional lead keel cast yesterday was bolted on and the changes in the wooden portion of the keel are being rapidly made.

Milan is the first of Italian cities to turn M. Pasteur's experiences to practical account. On Friday last Dr. Barattieri returned to Milan from Paris, after having spent three months at the Pasteur laboratory, where he has been well initiated into the orthodox method of combating hydrophobia. The doctor brought with him a ...

Two years ago the dry goods merchants of this city protested against the railroad classification of cotton goods. The protest was made to the Board of Railroad Commissioners, and was unanimously sustained.
ALEXANDRIA, July 9.--Full quarantine has been ordered against all arrivals from Austria and Italy because of the increase of cholera in Italy.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 9.--While candidates for county offices were speaking at Rally Hill, Maury County, yesterday two men named Wallace and Henson became involved in a fight growing out of an old feud. Wallace stabbed Henson and the wound proved fatal in a short time.
DEDHAM, Mass., July 9.--Abner A. Kingman, a printer of Brookline, has failed. His liabilities are $26,000 and his assets nominal.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--Senator Hoar, Chairman of the Committee on Privileges and Elections, furnishes, with a request for publication, the following:
LONDON, Ontario, July 9.--A few days ago Mrs. Thurlow, the wife of a farmer in West Missouri, was found hanging in a barn dead. At the inquest a verdict of suicide was returned.

Having come to this country in the Spring for various private reasons, Walter Tomlinson has availed himself of the opportunities of his visit to make a few inquiries in regard to the chances awaiting able-bodied and industrious ...
Chairman H.H. Boody, of Thursday's lively Wabash bondholders' meeting, came down town to his business office yesterday morning with the echoes of his shouting friends still sounding in his ears.

Mr. James C. Duff, seated in his cool, cozy little office at the back of the Standard Theatre's stage, said yesterday: "It is almost decided that Miss Victoria Vokes will come over here with her sister Rosina and company to play Mrs. John Wood's part in 'The Schoolmistress' ...

The Fenian Brotherhood of the District of Manhattan had its twenty--fourth annual picnic in Jones's Wood Colosseum yesterday, but not more than 500, including women and children, got within the grounds.
LOWELL, Mass., July 9.--Victor and Eugene Lafontaine, 7 and 8 years old respectively, went bathing this afternoon in the brook near the Aiken-street bridge.

DAVENPORT, Iowa, July 9.--The village of Wilton, 20 miles west of Davenport, with 500 inhabitants, has furnished 7 suicides since Jan. 1 and 13 instances of self-destruction within two years. It is believed that, in proportion to the population, more deaths have resulted from the suicidal mania in Wilton than in any other village in the United States.

The latest development in the Landgraf boycott is the retirement of Mrs. Landgraf from business as a baker. Her two bakers left Thursday, after the trial of the boycotters was over, saying that they were afraid to stay.
The following address has been mailed to the members of the several Republican county committees in the State and to other leading members of the party:
SARATOGA, July 9.--The Hon. Levi P. Morton, who occupied the Bockes Cottage, on Circular-street, to-day made an extensive purchase of real estate on North Broadway.

ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, July 9.--The most remarkable raft of logs ever put together will leave here for New-York in a few days. It is a cigar-shaped cylinder 400 feet long, with the beam and draught of a sea-going vessel, and contains 3,500,000 feet of logs. Its value here is $35,000.

There was a good attendance at the Brighton Beach track yesterday. The racing was fair. The first race, for a purse of $250, $50 to second, three-quarters of a mile, was won by Joe Murray by half a length.

ALLIANCE, Ohio, July 9.--F.M. Marshall of Stark County, Ohio, is on his first term in Mount Vernon College in this city. Recently he expressed a desire to become a member of one of the various secret societies formed by the students.

Emma Morand, a bright-faced schoolgirl, who has lived with her aunt, Mrs. William Webb, at No. 153 Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, for more than three years, disappeared very mysteriously on Thursday. Mrs. Webb believes that Emma has been abducted by some woman.

PHILADELPHIA, July 9.--Keefe pitched a Strong game for the Giants against the Philadelphia team to-day, and the result was that the representatives of New-York took the pupils of Harry Wright into camp by figures of 10 to 2.

CHICAGO, July 9.--Mrs. Nellie E. Davis dressed herself in white yesterday afternoon, lay down upon her bed in an upper room of a house on West Erie-street, and shot herself through the head with a revolver. She died instantly.
Messrs. Stuart Robson and William H. Crane's repertory next season will include a condensed version of "The Merry Wives of Windsor," in which Mr. Crane will play Falstaff and ...
TORONTO, Ontario, July 9.--The sixteenth session of the Supreme Lodge of the World, Knights of Pythias, will be held here Tuesday, July 13.

BOSTON, July 9.--Joseph G. Lennon, a well known organist and music teacher of this city, while taking his morning horseback ride in the Roxbury district to-day, fell from his horse and suffered a compound fracture of the skull.

A very pleasant little reception was given yesterday on board La Champagne, one of the new steamers of the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique, which sails this afternoon for France. Capt. Traub was in the best of spirits, and with ...

PHILIPPI, West Va., July 9.--There is some anxiety to-night at points along the right of way of the Grafton and Greenbrier Railroad, growing out of a strike by employes to the number 300 for a reduction in working hours from 11 to 10 per diem. Should the contractors put new men to work serious trouble will ensue.
William Horton, a Canadian carpenter, 33 years of age, was charged before Justice Smith at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday with bigamy. On Oct. 21, 1883, he married Margaret Lowery.

BOSTON, July 9.--Within the past year the head bakers of three steamers coming to this port have committed suicide by jumping into the Atlantic. Edward Alcock, the baker of the Bothnia, which arrived here this morning, followed the example of the other two bakers on July 5. He was 33 years old, and a native of Liverpool. He had been on the Bothnia for over a year.

CHICAGO, July 9.--The Chicagos won their second game from the Detroits to-day in the presence of 6,000 people. It was not a very interesting game, because it was one-sided, but here and there some good work was done.

There has been a great deal of talk in the Senate about some of the jobs added by the Senate Committee on Commerce to the River and Harbor bill that came from the House, but the ancient curiosities of legislation embalmed in the House bill have been approved by the score without remark.
The annual report of the Wisconsin Central Railroad for the year ending on Dec. 31 last was seen in Wall-street yesterday for the first time.
LONDON, July 9.--At the Newmarket meeting to-day the race for the Maiden Two-yearold Plate was won by A.B. Carr's bay filly, by Zealot, out of Miss Alice.

The St. Regis Indian lacrosse players started yesterday for Utica, where they play with the Utica Lacrosse Club. The Stuyvesant Cricket Club, a new Brooklyn organization, will play their first match to-day in Prospect Park.

READING, Penn., July 9.--A young woman, either intoxicated or drugged, was found wandering in a maudlin condition about the streets of the city at 2:30 o'clock this morning.

The midsummer meeting of the Monmouth Park Association will begin to-day with a programme of seven races, two of them being stake races--the Atlantic, for 2-year-olds, and the Stockton, for 3-year-olds.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 9.--The last day's encampment of the Twenty-third Regiment, of Brooklyn, was, like all the preceding days, blessed with pleasant weather, and nothing occurred to mar the occasion.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The Bostons won the easiest of victories to-day, the Nationals going all to pieces in the first and second innings and piling up errors with the same ease that the visitors accumulated hits.

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., July 9.--The report of the expert who has been examining the accounts of the Framingham Bank has been submitted to the incorporators. It shows that the bank is practically solvent and that the only loss which the depositors will suffer is that of one year's interest. No trace of dishonesty on the park of Treasurer Adams was found.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 9.--When the 6:45 P.M. accommodation train out of NewYork on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad reached Green's Farms, near Westport, last night, it was discovered that one of the eccentrics on the locomotive had broken.

CHICAGO, July 9.--In the Anarchist trial to-day a man was found who gave the true reason why he and so many others who have been called felt incompetent to try the case fairly. The juror was Henry A. Herzey, and he blurted out: "I don't want to be a juror in this case."

WASHINGTON, July 9.--The Civil Service Commission to-day made public its "opinion on the action of Mr. J. Parker Veazey, as Postmaster at Baltimore, in making appointments for partisan reasons." The document is as follows;

Mrs. Maria Clifford, wife of Thomas Clifford, a glue merchant of this city, who lives in Brooklyn, took five witnesses and a discolored eye into Justice Massey's court yesterday to disprove a charge of assault made against her by her husband.

The sanitary authorities and several of the Central Office detectives are seeking for an illiterate fellow who is masquerading as a sanitary officer and trying to get change for spurious checks, which he tenders in payment of articles ordered.
PARIS, July 9.--The death of Cora Pearl, which occurred yesterday, was caused by cancer. She died in complete poverty.

Lung Ling, a Chinese laundryman, ran out of his washhouse at No. 549 Broadway, Williamsburg, yesterday morning after some boys who were teasing him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9.--Judge Cole has reported to the Governor, after investigating the condition of affairs at Morehead, Rowan County, that the assistance of troops is necessary to the enforcement of law in his court.
District Assembly No. 75, Knights of Labor, met in lower Cooper Union Hall last evening. Eighty-four delegates were present.
Another new move was made yesterday in the Texas and Pacific Railroad reorganization campaign. Messrs. A.M. Kidder Co. made public the plan of the committee of the Rio Grande division bondholders.
There never was so good a day as To-Day, and to-morrow will be better.--Boston Herald. Modesty is very becoming in a fool, but it makes a man appear like a fool--Cincinnati Enquirer.

SANTA CRUZ, June 30.--The Quartermaster of the Aggie returned from a cruise to Monterey this morning, and is glowing with consciousness of his bravery in participating in a whale hunt that resulted in a capture.
ST. JOSEPH, Mo., July 9.--The Grand Jury for the June term of the Buchanan County Criminal Court has finished its business, and adjourned to-day.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 9.--The Post Office was broken open last night and robbed of $20,000 in money and stamps. Mr. Laraway arrived in this city on the early train from Lake Minnetonka and was not aware of the robbery until he arrived at the office.
Only once, it is said, has a bigger shipful of saloon passengers been brought across the Atlantic than that which was landed here last night from the Cunhard steamship Etruria.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 9.--Edward Haddon, an Englishman, who has been keeping bachelor's hall on Chestnut-street, this city, was found dead in his abode this morning with his throat cut from ear to ear, and four fatal wounds in his left breast. A Coroner's jury rendered a verdict against parties unknown.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., July 9.--With the hanging of Sam Archer to-day at Shoals, Martin County, ended the career of as lawless a gang of ruffians as ever inflicted any community or county.

Three boys were sitting on the curbstone of Suydam-street, near Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, at 9 o'clock last evening, when they heard the loud screams of a woman.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 9.--Private advices from Honolulu by the steamer Australia to-day announce the formation of a new Ministry, as follows: W.M. Gibson, Premier and Minister of the Interior; Robert J. Creighton, formerly ...

LANCASTER, N.H., July 9.--Fire started among the brush and timber in the Tealand woods on Wednesday afternoon between the Twin Mountain House and Fabyans, because of the extreme dryness. The fire spread rapidly, and although fought with desperation was soon beyond control.

WASHINGTON, July 9.--Capt. James H. Gillis assumed command of the Hartford at Payta June 18 and was appointed Chief of Staff. Ensign C.S. McLain has been ordered from the Pensacola Navy Yard to the Naval Hospital at Washington for treatment. Passed Assistant Engineer J.G. Toppen (retired) has been granted leave of absence for three months, with permission to leave the United States.
MONTREAL, July 9.--Dr. Samuel B. Ward, of Albany, has just sent a fine lot of trout which he caught on the Mastigouche Lakes, to President Cleveland.

MONTREAL, July 9.--Medical Health Officer Laberge, of this city, who is making inquiries with a view to procuring better protection to the public health by the Government Quarantine service, says that the present quarantine service at Grosse Isle is not at all what it should be. He also believes that the cases of smallpox reported at Detroit were taken into the United States by European immigrants passing Canada.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 9.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 10 cents; telegraphic, 15 cents.

BALTIMORE, July 9.--Henry Myers, an aged shoemaker, quarreled to-night with his son, Henry, over a small amount of money. The son finally struck his father, and the latter picked up a knife and stabbed his son, inflicting wounds from which the young man died in a few minutes. The father gave himself up to the police.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 9.--Major J.T. Callaway and George T. Gunther, two prominent tobacco brothers, doing business on the tobacco breaks at this point, had a pugilistic encounter this morning.

Mayor Grace held a private conference yesterday with Police Commissioner Voorhis, Superintendent Murray, Assistant Corporation Counsel Francis M. Scott, and Excise Commissioners Woodman and Von Glahn, on the subject of the enforcement of the amusement and excise laws as defined by the Court of Appeals in the Eden Musee case.
The Atlantic and the Priscilla had a brush yesterday afternoon through the Narrows and the upper part of the Lower Bay, in a breeze, and and the Atlantic came out the winner.
LONDON, July 9.--At midnight the total number of Unionists returned was 319, and of Gladstonians 210. The total Unionist poll was 1,016,281, and the total Gladstonian poll 949,592.
ALTOONA, Penn., July 9.--Two girls, 2 and 3 years old, respectively, were run down by an engine at the Twenty-fourth-street crossing of the Hollidaysburg Branch Railroad this evening.
TROY, N.Y., July 9.--Reuben L. Armstrong, a young law student, was arraigned in court to-day on a charge of seduction. He was remanded to jail for examination next Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, July 9.--Nearly six hours were spent by the Senate to-day in secret session, and nearly two-thirds of this time was monopolized by the Senators from Virginia.

MOULTONBOROUGH, N.H., July 9.--Frank H. Hemenway, of Philadelphia, who has been sojourning in this town, has been missing for a number of days, and it is feared that he has lost his way in the mountains, as he started to go trout fishing and was unacquainted with the locality.

There is a growing belief that the Republican State Convention, to meet in Little Rock on the 22d inst., will put a full State ticket in the field. We trust this is true.

NYACK, N.Y., July 10.--A few days ago nine of the lawyers of Rockland County issued a challenge to the doctors and teachers in the county to select a nine for the purpose of playing them a match game of baseball at an early date.
RICHFIELD SPRINGS, July 10.--A recent writer has said that "Richfield belongs to the family." That writer wasn't far out of the way.

Joseph Acker, a saloon keeper at No. 259 Rivington-street, gave his two boys 15 cents each on Thursday morning, and told them to go fishing. "Have a good time, and don't come back until night," he said.

FABYANS, N.H., July 10.--The rain of to-day has nearly put out the forest fires west of Fabyans, and they are now under control. The loss is estimated at $45,000, which falls upon J.E. Henry. The sawmills have suspended operations, but will probably be started up again within a short time. The smoke is clearing away.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 10.--There seems to be no immediate prospect of an election of Captains by the Yale University crew and ball nine.
NICHOLASVILLE, Ky., July 10.--Little Johnny Price, a newsboy, was killed by the cars at the Cincinnati Southern station last evening at 5 o'clock.

A meeting of the Directors of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company was held yesterday to consider the relations of the company to the Pacific railroads and the transcontinental railway war.

PHILADELPHIA, July 10.--Bartram L. Bongall, proprietor of the Camden (N.J.) Daily Post, to-day confirmed the rumor that the paper was to be sold to a syndicate, but he declined to disclose who the parties were or the future policy of the paper.
Last night was an exceedingly sultry one in Boston, but fortunately mosquitoes are not troublesome this season, and people did not have to heat themselves in battling tormentors.

Several important changes in the running time of trains on the Erie Road go into effect after to-day. The New-York express, arriving heretofore from Chicago, Cincinnati, and the West at 10:20 o'clock P.M., will now be due at 8:55 o'clock.

A subcommittee of the Executive Committee of the Empire Protective Association, consisting of Messrs. Best, Downey, and Ryan, visited Superintendent Murray at Police Headquarters yesterday and discussed with him the grievance of the association against ...

CHICAGO, July 10.--The prospect that Chicago is to have a regular army post is now thought to be assured. The Secretary of War has transmitted to Congress the proposition of the Commercial Club, of Chicago, to donate land on the shores of Lake Michigan for the purpose.
DETROIT, Mich., July 10.--The product of the Lake Superior copper mines for June was as follows: Calumet and Heela, 2,746 tons; Quiney, 275; Franklin, 200; Atlantic, 192.

The good folk at Twickenham are much interested in the proceedings of Mrs. Langtry, who has hired Meadow Bank for the season. The amusement of the Jersey Lily, I hear, is to convert her lawn into a circus, where her trained horses, which are great pets with her, go through their performances. The worthy proprietor will doubtless appreciate the condition of his turf on his return into possession.
NORFOLK, Va., July 10.--A correspondent of the Virginian, writing from York County, under date of July 8, says that a snowstorm occurred in that county on that day, lasting 15 minutes.

ST. LOUIS, July 10.--The Browns won in the ninth inning after a close and exciting contest. O'Neill and Welch made singles, and Robinson's fine drive over Sommer's head sent both men across the plate.

Nearly all the relatives and friends of the employes of James McCreery Co. congregated yesterday afternoon at the Manhattan Athletic Club Grounds, for the employes were having their ninth annual athletic games.

The Rev. Mr. Nicholson has retired from the Hants Journal, which paper publishes the following: When the editor was in charge of the Methodist church in Windsor some years ago Dr. Walsh was the Catholic priest of the parish. Eight years after this they were both stationed at the same time in Annapolis.

CHICAGO, Ill., July 10.--A mad dog had possession of Halsted-street for the distance of a block last night until he had bitten one boy, stampeded the inmates of a saloon, and finally been killed through the efforts of two policemen.
BOSTON, July 10.--The Grand Jury have indicted Bernard P. Verne and William Hogarty on the charge of keeping ther barber's shops open in violation of the Sunday law. These will be test cases.

Gen. James A. Beaver, the Republican nominee for Governor of Pennsylvania, was offered the nomination for the Vice-Presidency in the Chicago Convention of 1880, after the first place on the ticket had been given to Gen. Garfield.

In the joust, or trial skill by single combat a plaisance, lurks the ancient Germanic notion of courtesy which prompted a host to honor a noble guest by offering him the opportunity of displaying his prowess in fight.

MORGAN, Texas, July 10.--This morning, while the preliminary trial of the negro Sidney Davis, who assaulted the Clifton lady several days ago, was in progress at Meridian, a mob of about 500 men rushed into the court room suddenly, quickly ...

WASHINGTON, July 10.--Senator Cameron gave a box party to Senators Blackburn, of Kentucky; Hale, of Maine, and Butler, of South Carolina, at the National Theatre to-night, and witnessed the McCaull Opera Company's performance ...
ATLANTA, Ga,, July 10.--The excitement around the Kimball House attendant upon the defiance of the prohibition law continues unabated.
"If I were a member of Congress," said Judge Poland yesterday, "I should vote against the bill taxing oleomargarine." "And why?" queried an auditor.
The menhaden steamers cruise continually off Fire Island Inlet, and not a single school of fish endeavoring to get into the bay is allowed to pass the bar.

CHICAGO, July 10.--Messrs. J.C. McMullin, R.R. Cable, and T.J. Potter, the arbitrators for the Chicago Committee of the Central Traffic Association, held a conference this morning to agree upon a final report regarding the application for a reopening ...
FRASER, Penn., July 9.--This is a small station on the Pennsylvania Railroad, 22 miles from Philadelphia. Twenty years ago, when I knew it much better than I do now, it was called Garrett's Siding.

LONDON, July 10.--The returns received up to midnight to-night show that the Conservatives have elected 289 candidates, the Unionists 63, the Gladstonians 149, and the Parnellites 72. The Conservative gain has been reduced by 2.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Boston again outplayed the home club at all points to-day, and won without difficulty. Stemmeyer, though a trifle wild at times, was effective, and the Washingtons seemed alike unable to bat, run bases, or field.
CHICAGO, Ill., July 10.--Mary Mahoney, a young woman employed in the West End Laundry, at No. 849 West Madison-street, was the victim of a peculiarly horrible accident yesterday.

BALTIMORE, July 10.--The remains of the late Hon. William H. Cole reached this city today, and were deposited at his late residence. The Congressional committee accompanied the body. The Funeral will taken place to-morrow at St. Vincent's Church, of which deceased was a member.

At 9 o'clock Friday night an officer on duty on Canal-street, between tho Bowery and Chrystie-street, saw a drunken man throw his arms about a woman who was passing and otherwise act in a disorderly way.

CHICAGO, July 10.--A petition was filed to-day in the case of the J.W. Butler Paper Company against the John B. Jeffery Printing Company by C.B. Cottrell Sons to prevent Receiver George T. Pomeroy from selling the property.
WORCESTER, Mass., July 10.--J.E. Bigelow, finding that the expenses of the regatta would exceed the receipts, has withdrawn the prizes, and possibly the affair will be off.

WASHINGTON, July 10.--The Senate Committee on Appropriations have inserted a paragraph in the Sundry Civil bill appropriating $56,500 for the Bartholdi Statue. This does not include the expense of entertaining guests, and building a new wharf and arches.
A falconer who has the exclusive care of half a dozen trained birds, whether falcons or hawks, or both, finds little time hanging heavily on his hands.

Richard Block and George Weston were arrested by a detective of the Twenty-ninth Police Precinct last evening on a charge of violating the law governing pool selling. Block gave his residence as New-Jersey.

The Brooklyn Athletic Association held their first annual Summer games at their grounds yesterday. The track was rather heavy. Mr. C.T. Wiegand, a member, tried to beat the record in a 220 yards' hurdle ...

We do not hear very much in these days of mummy wheat and barley, but many people firmly believe that the seeds of both plants found with Egyptian mummies, and supposed to be 3,000 or 4,000 years old, will sprout if put in the ground.
Last week the market was closed up with the grand hurrah in Western Union, which made the Street believe that the long expected consolidation with the B. O. had taken place.

HAVANA, July 10.--Advices from Hayti of the 23d ult. say that a conspiracy against the Government had recently been discovered, and that an outbreak was feared. Foreign residents displayed great anxiety, and the presence of men-of-war of their respective nations was much desired.

LONDON, July 10.--A dispatch from Yokohama announces the sailing to-day of a second tea-laden ship whose cargo is to be transferred to the Canadian Pacific Railroad for conveyance across the continent.

Public interest in Myra Clark Gaines, who became famous through her suit against the city of New-Orleans to recover property left her by her father was revived again yesterday by the production in Surrogate Lott's court in Brooklyn of a will alleged to be that of Mrs. Gaines.

BARNESVILLE, Ga., July 10.--There is a trial in progress in this county which is attracting great interest in railroad circles. On the night of Oct. 17, 1884, a spark from a Central Railroad engine fell upon the cotton stored upon the railway platform here.

BALTIMORE, July 10.--Judge Fisher today filed an opinion dismissing the petition of the United Lines Telegraph Company and Edward Stokes to quash writs against the Bankers and Merchants' Company for $15,000 at the suits of F.P. Stevens, W.A. Dunn, and other creditors. He sustains the claims as fully proved, and refuses to open the auditor's accounts.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 11.--John Rice, a ship calker, whose home is in Buffalo, was, with a companion, to-day overturned while sailing on Chautanqua Lake. They were a short distance from shore and attempted to paddle the craft in, but the slow progress dissatisfied Rice, and he started to swim in. He had taken but a few strokes when a cramp seized him and he sank. His body has not been recovered.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 11.--Particulars of the killing of three convicts by their guards, near Pine Bluff yesterday afternoon, have reached this city. A gang of about 80 convicts were working in a brickyard, a few miles from town, and the entire number made a sudden break for liberty. The guards immediately leveled their rifles and fired, killing three of the ringleaders, and mortally wounding a fourth. None escaped.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 12.--Mrs. Caroline Benedict, a well known women, who for many years had resided in the little village of Mottville, in the town of Skaneateles, died recently after a fast extending 53 days. She was the youngest daughter of Ralph Hall, a wealthy farmer of Skaneateles.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 12.--Several members of the Board of Trustees of Washington's Headquarters at Morristown, N.J., visited Washington's Headquarters at Newburg to-day, arriving in the city this morning on the Catskill Mountain Limited Express on the West Shore Railroad at 10:49 A.M.

"Falka" was put on the stage at Wallack's last evening, and will be given there throughout the week. WASHINGTON, July 12.--Rumors about Cabinet changes that begin with the displacement of Mr. Manning follow with the withdrawal of Mr. Bayard and end with the expulsion of Mr. Garland, wing their way into sight here pretty ...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., July 12.--The steamer Oconto, which struck on a reef in the St. Lawrence River, about four miles below Clayton, last Tuesday, and partially sank, slid off the reef on which she lay and disappeared from sight this morning. The wreckers had removed part of her cargo, and what remained on board, as well as the vessel, will probably be a total loss.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 12.--Some time ago the wife of John M. Duvall obtained a divorce and on the same day procured a marriage license and married Jacob H. Jones, a resident of this city. Duvall made no effort to prevent the marriage, nor did he seem to have any objection to it.

WEIR'S, N.H., July 12.--Rattlesnake Island, a large and valuable tract in the centre of Lake Winnepesaukee, about eight miles from here, is on fire to-night. The large growth of wood will be a total loss. The pyramid of flame makes a very pretty sight reflected upon the water for many rods around.

Within the next few months we are likely to hear a great deal about that hitherto hardly known province of Canada bearing the rather romantic name of Anticosti, for the owners of the island are in town and "organizing arrangements for its development."

LONDON, July 12.--Negotiations between Lord Hartington and Lord Salisbury are in progress. It is reported that Lord Hartington has pledged himself to support Lord Salisbury's Local Government bill and to reject all approaches of Mr. Gladstone.
The severe storm interrupted the usual excursion of St. John's Guild on Saturday. One will take place to-day. The following contributions have been received:

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 12.--The Exposition Park races will commence to-morrow and will last four days. The purses aggregate $11,800, and as 90 of the best trotters and pacers in the country have entered rare sport is anticipated. A special match race between Harry Wilkes and Jewett has been arranged. The purse is for $1,000, with $500 added if the best time on a half-mile track--2:16, made by Rarus --is beaten.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 12.--Gustave Frank, of Middletown, was drowned in the Wallkill River at Phillipsburg yesterday afternoon while bathing. Gustave, who was 21 years of age, sank in a hole and made the work of rescuing him an impossible one. Julius Frank, a cousin of the drowned man, came near drowning in an effort to save the life of his unfortunate relative.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Batting honors were about even between the contending clubs to-day, but the far superior fielding of the Bostons enabled them to win their third consecutive victory over the home club.

Unceasing efforts are being made by Assemblyman Tommy Maher to make his coming grand excursion to River View Grove so utterly eclipse the recent effort of the Divver crowd in that line as to be the only one remaining in the memory of second Ward voters on election day.

CHATHAM, Ill., July 12.--A large party from this place and vicinity went out to a lake two miles north of here yesterday to witness the baptism of a number of young people. After the ceremony the horses attached to a carriage containing Mr. J.H. Moore and wife, Mrs. Allsbury, ...

TORONTO, Ontario, July 12.--Thomas J. Brown, the Brighton hotel keeper who escaped when Cummings was arrested on a charge of counterfeiting, was caught at Trenton and taken to Cobourg, where he was examined by a police magistrate on Saturday.

CINNABAR, Montana, July 12.--It is secretly whispered about here that trouble is brewing over the possession of property in the park, though all information regarding the matter is hushed up by those who are in the best position to know.

Several hundred children waiting to be confirmed while the Bishop who has arranged to perform the ceremony is engaged in a State ceremonial six miles off is a sort of spectacle which the Church of England can ill afford at the present moment.
If the Radicals undertake to make a canvass in this State there are several counties in which no nominations have been made that could be captured, and the effort will no doubt be made.
The Sons of Veterans of the Department of New-York will hold their seventh annual State encampment next Tuesday at Grand Army Hall, North Second-street and Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, Eastern District.

ST. LOUIS, July 12.--Both pitchers were hit hard to-day and the 1,200 spectators witnessed a regular slugging match, a close game of its kind. Comiskey and Larkin made long hits to the fence which gave home runs. J. Gleason made some beautiful stops of hard hits, and Larkin and Caruthers's batting were features. NEWPORT, R.I., July 12.--Newport has been quite gay to-day. The morning concert at the Casino and the dance at the Casino Theatre in the evening were well attended, and not a few galled at the Superintendent's office and registered for the season.

ST. LOUIS, July 12.--Murphy, the young St. Louis pitcher, occupied the box for the Maroons in to-day's game. In the first inning he sent five men to bases on balls, which, with some timely hitting by the visitors, netted the latter 6 runs, which won the game. After this, however, Murphy pitched in good style.

CHICAGO, July 12.--Detective Matthew Pinkerton, head of the private detective agency of Pinkerton Co., to-day began a suit against William A. Pinkerton, son of Allan Pinkerton, and head of the National Detective Agency, to recover $50,000 for alleged slander.

MONTREAL, July 12.--The Canadian Pacific Railway Company is about to start a commercial train over its lines to enable merchants here to push their trade in the Northwest. The train will consist of dining, sleeping, and sample cars, the latter to be fitted up with shelves ...
The work of reorganizing the Department of Public Works on a Tammany spoils basis was begun on a wholesale scale yesterday by Commissioner Rapacious Mogul Squire and his Deputy ...
DETROIT, Mich., July 12.--On the 3d inst. a man going by the name of Jones, but whose real name is Thomas J. Walker, was arrested at Ann Arbor, where he was at work in a livery ...

CINCINNATI, July 12.--Frank Dekebach, Treasurer of the Cincinnati Baseball Club, was fined $5, and the nine Cincinnati players who participated in Sunday's game $2 each before Esquire Dichl to-day. It is understood that this action was taken by the management to escape heavier punishment in the police court on account of the riot at yesterday's game.

Col. Locke W. Winchester, commanding the Seventh Regiment Veterans, yesterday received a letter from Major Charles W. Van Zandt, of the Albany Burgesses Corps, offering the services of that body as an escort and the use of their armory to the veterans on the occasion of the Albany Bi-centennial Celebration.
FORT WORTH, Texas, July 12.--This afternoon about 4:30 a terrific windstorm blew from the south and did considerable damage.

At the Leonard-street police station there is a silver communion cup for which an owner is wanted. It was found by Robert H. Boyd, a shoe dealer, in his store at No. 122 Duane-street yesterday morning. As a dozen pairs of shoes had been stolen from the place, Mr. Boyd thinks the communion cup was abandoned there.

John F. Clark, the junior member of the firm of Behman Clark, of this city, and a resident of South Elliott-place, Brooklyn, began a suit in the Supreme Court in that city yesterday for absolute divorce from his wife Mary, on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment.
WASHINGTON, July 12, 1886. The Hennepin Canal amendment to the River and Harbor bill was agreed to by the Senate to-day by a vote of 31 to 22.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 12.--The Army of the Potomac Society will meet here in August. The public meeting will take place on Aug. 2, and the banquet on the 4th. Col. Stuart M. Taylor will be the orator and Frederick Emerson Brooks the poet. Gens. Sheridan, Sherman, Logan, Locke, McMahon, and King and a large delegation from the East will be present.

MOBILE, Ala., July 12.--Steve Renfroe, a desperado who has attracted general attention in the State, and particularly in West Alabama, was arrested to-day at Enterprise, Miss. Renfroe was Sheriff of Sumter County, and, proving a defaulter, was sent to the coal mines, whence he escaped with three other convicts, and was pursued to Birmingham.

CHICAGO, July 12.--Mayor Harrison tonight presented a message to the City Council practically vetoing the ordinance passed a week ago giving the North Side Railway Company the use of the La Salle-street tunnel, and, contrary to the general expectation, no attempt was made to pass the ordinance over his head.

LONDON, July 12.--The Gladstonites have won another consolation stake to-day. They have defeated Mr. Albert Grey in the Tyneside Division of Northumberland, electing Mr. W.B. Beaumont in his place. Mr. Grey was specially obnoxious, for he served as one of the whips of the Hartington Unionists, and he was the only Northumbrian Liberal who deserted the Ministry in the home rule division.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 12.--The great influx of Knights of Pythias from the United States and Canada to attend a grand demonstration in honor of the fourteenth session of the Supreme Lodge of the order continued all day, and up to the present time 20,000 knights, mostly from the United States, have arrived.
OMAHA, Neb., July 12.--At 3 o'clock this afternoon a committee of four from the Western Union Telegraph operators employed in this city, waited on Superintendent Dickey and presented the following:

MONTREAL, July 12.--Sir Roderick Cameron, of New-York, passed through the city today on his way to Ottawa to interview the Minister of Marine in reference to the seizure of his yacht at Buctouche. Sir Roderick has a fishing cottage at Tadousac, where he passes several months every Summer salmon fishing.

When the Railroad Attorneys bill was the subject of debate in the Senate, nearly three weeks ago, Mr. MITCHELL Of Oregon offered an amendment with the object of making the bill ridiculous. He had voted against the bill.

VIENNA, July 12.--In Trieste during the past 24 hours 2 deaths occurred from cholera and 8 new cases were reported. ROME, July 12.--The cholera returns for to-day are: Brindisi, 96 new cases, 35 deaths; ...
BELFAST, July 12.--During the Orange celebration of the battle of the Boyne here today a slight row was occasioned by the passage of the procession through one of the streets. One person was injured.

The Brooklyn Common Council dealt largely in local railroad affairs again yesterday. The franchise given to the Union Elevated Company at the last meeting to gridiron the city was found to be defective in that it failed to provide for the furnishing of a bond. So the action was reconsidered and a clause introduced arranging for the filing of a bond of $200,000.

Everywhere you find people, black and white, who firmly believe in witchcraft and conjuring. A case of genuine conjuring now exists near town, the subject being a colored girl. All the darkies assert that she is laboring under a spell put on her by a young colored man.
Wise, of Boston, is batting heavily this year. The New-Yorks will play in Washington to-day. The ninth inning again proved disastrous to the New-Yorks yesterday.

The Khedive's grandmother died yesterday morning from paralysis of the heart, and her funeral took place in the afternoon. At 4 o'clock the cortege set out, headed by bullocks, which were afterward slaughtered at the mosque and distributed to the poor, with baskets of bread.

Peter Van Pelt, who for 35 years has been a ship news reporter for the Associated Press and New-York Herald, was found lying in the yard adjoining his house, at Tompkinsville, Staten Island, late Sunday night, dead from a bullet wound in his head.

CHARLESTON, West Va., July 12.--Information has just reached here that George W. Beasly killed his wife by cutting her throat last Friday. Her body was discovered on the public highway and Beasly cannot be found.

ST. LOUIS, July 12.--A stranger was found last night wandering aimlessly around on Morgan street, near Seventh, and was taken in charge by the officers of the Third District Station. He was an elderly gentleman, 71 years old, with smooth face and long white hair.

PITTSBURG, July 12.--A terrific mine explosion occurred about 4:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon at Buchtel, Ohio, a shall village about three miles east of Nelsonville, resulting in the instant death of one man and the fatally injuring of several others.

The Board of Estimate and Apportionment yesterday, on motion of Controller Loew, struck out of the final estimate for 1886 the following items: For building the Harlem River Bridge, $750,000; from the fund for local improvements $400,000, leaving $100,000 in the budget, and for the erection of school buildings and the purchase of additional sites $894,000, making a total of $2,044,000.
WASHINGTON, July 12.--The President has pardoned R. Porter Lee, now confined in the Buffalo penitentiary for embezzlement. The following is the President's memorandum in regard to this case:

CHICAGO, July 12.--Nothing further has been heard from E.L. Dwyer as to how he intends to settle up his wheat deal. The Committee of Investigation appointed by the creditors has retained Lawyer Thomas Cratty, and a searching scrutiny will be made into the ins and outs of the deal.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 12.--A squad of officers raided Phil Daly's Pennsylvania Club, at the West End, at midnight last night. The house was crowded with gamesters and the tables were ...

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Brig.-Gen. W.B. Hazen, Chief Signal Officer, has been ordered to New-York, Albany, Boston, and Nantucket on public business. Major R.T. Frank, First Artillery; Capt. John H. Calef, Second Artillery; Assistant Surgeon George H. Torney and Capt. S.M. Mills, ...

CHICAGO, July 12.--To-day's work in the Anarchists' trial consisted of two jurors temporarily kept in the box over Sunday and examining and dismissing 41 additional men. The total number of jurors examined so far is 812. The defense has run through 111 of its 160 peremptory challenges.

There has been of late so much alarmist talk about the exhaustion of our coal fields that it is good news to learn that an inventor, Mr. R. M. Marchant, has at last perfected an engine in which the steam is returned to the boiler and, so to say, used over and over again.

At Washington and Hubert streets at 11 o'clock Sunday night Henry Peterson, a clerk, of No. 685 Third-avenue, who was escorting two young women home from a Sunday excursion, was set upon by a number of young roughs. His clothes were torn, he was kicked all over the street, and his watch, money, and jewelry were stolen.

WATERBURY, Conn., July 12.--Fred Thompson, gardener for Scoville Buckingham, of West Main-street, says that he has been greatly annoyed by midnight prowlers visiting his employer's place on evil errands.
The Central Labor Union at its last Sunday meeting declared in favor of workingmen going into politics as an independent party--an old experiment which has never yet resulted in any benefit.

It was a warm night in the streets of the great city of Gotham, but there was a gentle current of refreshing air moving across the roof of the Casino. Thither repaired two young men of the order known as gilded youth.

Just before ex-Gov. E.D. Morgan died, in February, 1883, his portrait in oil was painted by Healy. It is a handsome piece of artistic work and life-like. Yesterday it was added to the gallery of the Chamber of Commerce, the gift of the old Governor's grandson, Edwin D. Morgan.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Senator Allison, in a speech delivered in the Senate on March 31, 1885, showed how the folly of giving an extra month's pay had grown up in Congress. Prior to 1876 it had been customary to give the extra month's pay to session employes.

LOWELL, Mass., July 12.--John F. Driscoll, formerly a well known baseball pitcher in this city, and subsequently in Louisville and other cities in the Southwest, died at his home in Willie-street yesterday of consumption.

BOSTON, July 12.--Last week the tanners and curriers of Salem and Peabody received a communication from their employes requesting that on and after July 12 a day's labor consist of 10 hours and on Saturdays of nine hours.
When the representatives of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company and the Panama Company met, yesterday, it was found that an adjournment until to-day was necessary.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 12.--Mrs. William Jackson, of Shepherdsville, near Louisville, Ky., went out with her children Friday last to pick blackberries in an old field near her house. As they passed from one clump of bushes to another they came upon a cow in the edge of the woods. The cow made a dash at them and all ran.
PORTLAND, Me., July 12.--Terence O'Hare, who is under arrest here for the murder of his wife, says his wife hid $40 of his money and that they fought about it. His wife was intoxicated and fell.

The Grant Monument Association received yesterday, through the United States Consulate at Malta, the following subscriptions: Theodore B.M. Mason, United States Navy, 1, and the Rev. Canon Don R. Patiniott, 1.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 12.--The Board of Education of Port Jervis has been served with notice of an application for a peremptory mandamus to compel that body to purchase the Riverside school building for $4,000.

DIXON, Ill., July 12.--An electric storm of a very destructive nature, accompanied by hail and rain, passed through this section Sunday night. Great damage has been done to the crops of all kinds, especially the fruit crop, which will be a complete failure. Buildings of different kinds and telephone and telegraph wires have been blown down in various places throughout the county.

An unknown gray-haired man, apparently about 55 years of age, was found sitting on a wall at One Hundred and Third-street and Twelfth-avenue yesterday morning with a bullet hole in his head and with blood oozing from his mouth and nostrils. It is supposed that he committed suicide, as a small revolver was clutched tightly in his right hand. He was poorly dressed. It is thought that he was a homeless wanderer.

Richard Ely Colt died of apoplexy at the home of his daughter, Mrs. Harriet Miller, No. 159 East Ninety-first-street, on Sunday, in his eighty-fifth year. He was apparently in good health during the day. In the evening his daughter found him in the basement sitting in a chair, seemingly asleep. When she attempted to arouse him she discovered that he was dead.

In their domestic relations the Comte and Comtesse de Paris were always as good as they could be. Both of them had and have strong family instincts. He took after his mother in his love of study, and she after the Bourbons of Spain and Naples in her love of hunting and shooting.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 12.--The Ursuline Sisterhood of St. Teresa Church, of NewYork, which recently acquired a fine property in this village, has established a Summer normal school here. Twenty-four cloistered Sisters are here, and all the teachers of the St. Teresa branch will spend the Summer here, receiving special instruction. The property is the gift of a novice who brings $30,000 into the treasury upon taking the vows.

The century is growing old. The other day at Harrow the Head Master somewhat astonished his hearers by telling them of the joy he had experienced that very morning on the receipt of a letter entering a boy for his house, the date of whose proposed arrival at the school will be 1900 A.D.

WASHINGTON, July 12.--Ex-Gov. Thompson, the newly appointed Assistant Secretary of the Treasury, when asked his views on the civil service reform question, said: "I am heartily in sympathy with the stand the President has taken on the matter.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--New-York's Giants again succumbed to Harry Wright's dwarfs this afternoon. It was a grand contest, however, and required 11 innings to decide. The visitors played without the services of capt. Ward, ...

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 12.--About 12 miles from this city, an Wynkoop Creek, this county, farmers became exhausted Friday night, having been since Wednesday fighting forest fires. They were on the point of giving up in despair, when a heavy rain set in and the flames were extinguished. Valuable timber lands two miles long by one mile wide were burned over, entailing a heavy loss.

The annual horse show of the National Association will be held in this city, beginning Nov. 1 and ending Nov. 6. Applications for many loose stalls and boxes have already been made and the prospect is that the entry list will be a large one and the show the best ever held.

BOSTON, July 12.--The anti-Saloon Republican Conference here to-day, called by a few preminent leaders of the part in this State, ostensibly to express sympathty in the new movement and to arrange for representation in ...

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 12.--Anton Dupont, an Alsatian barber, gave poison to his son Willie, aged 8 years, and then took poison himself. Both the father and son were found dead in their bed about noon to-day. Dupont left a letter in which he stated that he intended to kill the child and then himself. Domestic troubles caused Dupont's act.

A long-haired, elderly man calling himself Dr. George R. Harding was arrested yesterday on a charge of practicing medicine without a license. He is the head man of the "Indian village," encamped at Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Twenty-eighth-street, ...

The proceedings before Judge Landon at Schenectady on Saturday next will be chiefly interesting because of the attempt to be made by the Corporation Counsel to have the scene of the contest for the possession of the Broadway Railroad transferred to this city.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 12.--The Council of Administration of the Department of Tennessee and Georgia, Grand Army of the Republic, met to-day and adopted a report to the Grand Encampment at San Francisco. The report stated that Nashville has raised a guarantee fund of $25,000 and invites the Grand Army to hold its next encampment at Nashville.

PEEKSKILL, N.Y., July 12.--Drill was begun by the Sixty-ninth Regiment this morning, in the State Camp, immediately after reveille, in order to get most of the hard work done before the extreme heat of the day set in.

DENVER, Col., July 12.--The property of the Denver and Rio Grande Railway Company was sold at 12 o'clock to-day by Louis H. Meyer and John R. Stewart, Trustees of the consolidated mortgage, who were appointed Special Commissioners by Judge Hallett, of the United States Circuit Court, by a decree entered on May 5 last.

PHILADELPHIA, July 12.--Morton Howard, who for two or three years has carried on business as a jobber in the shoe trade at No. 110 North Third-street, left the city on Saturday, and when some anxious creditors investigated his place of business to-day they found nothing but a few shoes, though last week there were $13,000 worth of shoes in the establishment.

The Duke of ARGYLL is an accomplished and liberal-minded man. He is not only a credit to his order, but he is one of a very few members of his order who would be of some account if they were not Dukes.

CHICAGO, July 12.--The Orangemen of this city had a street parade this morning to commemorate the battle of the Boyne. It was the first parade the Orangemen have had here for many years. About 400 marchers were in line, and, after parading through the business district of the city, they took a train to one of the suburbs, where a formal celebration occurred.
SCHENECTADY, N.Y., July 12.--The cornerstone of the new East-Avenue Presbyterian Church was laid with appropriate ceremonies this afternoon.

CHICAGO, July 12.--There was hardly anything talked of in Western railroad circles to-day but the great meeting of Western railroad managers in this city, which is to finally act on the great scheme of President Cable, of the Rock Island, for the formation of one grand pool to take in all the existing combinations west, northwest, and southwest from Chicago.

The sport at Monmouth Park to-day will be very good, as large fields of horses are to be found in each of the six races. The principal event of the day is the Midsummer Handicap, with 21 acceptances, and probably a dozen of them will appear at the post. The full entry list is as follows:

George Hafner, who resides at No. 216 Boerum-street, Brooklyn, was to have married Maggie Berge on Sunday, but unexpectedly spent that day in Raymond-Street Jail. Yesterday morning he was released on bail by Justice Nacher, who put the hearing down for July 27.

DETROIT, Mich., July 12.--The trouble between the stonecutters and their employers was finally adjusted this morning, and all the yards in Detroit resumed work with full forces, excepting Knapp Avery's, the yard in which the trouble first began.

About 50 persons were present yesterday afternoon in Washington Park, Brooklyn, to witness the beginning of the race between W.M. Spencer the "Mexican cowboy," riding on horseback, and John S. Price and Thomas W. Eck, riding on bicycles.

J. De Rivera Co., sugar commission merchants of No. 117 Pearl-street, made an assignment without preferences yesterday to Francis T. Sargent. The liabilities of the house are said not to be large, but mystery is imported into the case by the fact that Henry C. De Rivera, the head of the house, has strangely disappeared.

PARIS, July 12.--The Duc d'Aumale, who is a General of Division of the French Army on the retired list, has addressed to President Grevy a letter in reference to the striking of his name from the army roll, recently ordered by Gen. Boulanger, Minister of War.

Albany has two varieties of mosquitoes. There is a kind that worry one at night and are persistent in disturbing the night's rest. This species, while minute night hawks and ready at all times to prey upon the innocent victim, yet are not totally devoid of honor.

ERIE, Penn., July 12.--At the Democratic County Convention held to-day the Congression al conferrees were instructed for the Hon. William L. Scott for renomination for Congress. Mr. Scott is the choice in Venango and Warren Counties.
There was a stamping and pounding on board the steamship Persian Monarch as she drew into her dock yesterday morning which filled every lounger within hearing distance with wonder.
FORTRESS MONROE, Va., July 12.--Sergt. John O'Neill, Battery M, Third Artillery, fell from the second story of the barracks last night and was instantly killed.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 12.--The Louisville Club is still keeping up its slugging and they batted Powell to-day for a total of 29 bases, earning 9 of their runs. The features of the game were Cross's home run, bringing in two men, and Wolfe's marvelous fielding. Both clubs played a fine fielding game. The score by innings follows:

Several years ago a citizen of West Chester, Penn., brought into that pretty borough some half a dozen sparrows in the expectation that as they increased and multiplied they would protect the shade trees from the pest of insects.

ELMIRA, N.Y., July 12.--Clara, the 6-year old child of Mr. and Mrs. Marks Dunkleman, was burned to death in the area, back of the family residence, at No. 161 Washington-street, this afternoon. While Mrs. Dunkleman was at a store near by the child took matches and started a fire ...

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 12.--The Metropolitans won a good game from the Pittsburgs this afternoon by heavy batting. The home club were weak at the bat and played carelessly in the field. The attendance was 2,800. The score follows:

NYACK, N.Y., July 12.--The Prohibitionists of Rockland County have a big scheme on hand in the way of a camp-meeting, to be held in a grove at Monsey, in the central part of the county, beginning on Wednesday, Aug. 25, and lasting until Sunday, Sept. 5.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., July 13.--Charles Whitcomb and Lyman Bullard, joint proprietors of the Ocean Clubhouse, were arraigned before Police Justice Morris this morning on a charge of maintaining a gambling establishment. Whitcomb was arrested on Thursday night last, when ...

KANSAS CITY, Mo., July 13.--Whitney was injured last week and was unfit for service today. He started in, however, to pitch for the Cowboys, and held down the Wolverines until the end of the fourth inning. Conway then succeeded him and Dugdale went to centre field.

BUFFALO, N.Y., July 13.--Buffalo has today entertained 40 city officials of Phadelphia, who came up to inspect the water system. They inspected, and then the Aldermen and other officers of the two cities, to the number of 80, went down the river to Falconwood, on Grand Island, and to-night they wound up with a grand banquet at the Genesee Hotel.

LA CROSSE, Wis., July 13.--The State Labor Convention met here to-day with a representation of 114 votes. Only 6 counties out of 68 were represented.

PHILADELPHIA, July 13.--The game between the Philadelphia and Boston Clubs to-day was sharply played, and belonged to neither club until the last man was retired. Both pitchers were effective, but the hits made off Stemmeyer were longer.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 13.--This village has had a long succession of perfect days. As a result everybody is in good humor, and transient visitors hare been induced to prolong their stay. The hotels are all doing well. Mr. Frothingham is back at his post at the States.

PITTSBURG, July 14.--Notwithstanding the threatening weather, nearly 3,000 people attended the second day's races at the Exposition Driving Park. The track was heavy, but the races were close and exciting.

HAVANA, July 14.--Advices from Remedios state that volunteer soldiers encountered the bandits headed by Mirabel, and that in the conflict which followed several men were wounded on both side.

EMPORIA, Kan., July 14.--The State Prohibition Convention assembled this morning in the Opera House. The Committee on Organization reported and H.C. Vrooman, of Osage County, was elected Chairman, and M.E. Tosmot, Secretary.
TROY, N.Y., July 14.--Prof. James Hall, State Geologist, and Mr. Beecher, his assistant, inspected the oil flow in Gen. Carr's cellar this afternoon.

METROPOLIS, Ill., July 14.--Mrs. Karr, a widow, is under arrest here charged with infanticide. The other night some of her neighbors were attracted by a stench preceding from her house. They visited the place and on her house.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 14.--The market for Printing Cloths is very firm at 3 5-16c. for 64 squares and 2 7/8c. for 60X56 Cloths, with a demand of moderate proportions and a better inquiry for odd widths and counts.
ST. LOUIS, July 14.--Hugh M. Brooks, alias Maxwell, convicted of murdering C.C. Preller, was sentenced this morning to be hanged on Aug. 27.

CHICAGO, July 14.--The tenth and eleventh members of the jury to try the Anarchists were captured to-day. They are John B. Greiner and G.W. Adams. Mr. Greiner is a clerk in the freight department of the Chicago and Northwestern Railroad. He is 25 years old, single, and was born at Columbus.

SANDUSKY, Ohio, July 14.--Stephen Saunders, a prominent farmer, living in Oxford Township, this county, was thrown from his wagon last evening by the rearing of his horses, and fell under the wheels of the vehicle. He was run over and killed. He was 52 years old and leaves a family.

ST. LOUIS, July 14.--At noon to-day the Provident Savings Bank closed its doors, and a notice was posted in the window to the effect that the bank had suspended payment. Shortly afterward application was made to Judge Tubke, in Chambers, for the appointment of a Receiver for the institution.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 14.--Four tramps lay down to sleep alongside the Chicago and Alton Railroad track Monday night, and yesterday morning a farmer found them in a heap in the ditch, badly mutilated.
LARCHMONT, N.J., July 14.--The weather here is very stormy, there being a strong easterly wind, with much sea.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 14.--Drafts on NewYork: Sight, 10 cents; telegraphic, 15 cents.

Col. William H. Gilder, after a vain search for bail Tuesday night on the charge of appropriating Dollie Adams's one thousand-dollar Metropolitan Elevated Railroad bond, was returned to the Jefferson Market Court Prison about 9 A.M. yesterday.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 14.--Katie, youngest sister of Abraham Odell, who was sent to Sing Sing Prison for shooting Knapp at Fishkill Village, shot herself through the left lung yesterday afternoon and died at 11 o'clock last night. She was 15 years of ago. She had been shooting at a mark and in unloading the revolver tho accident occurred. The sad affair happened near Hortontown Church, in the town of East Fishkill.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J. July 14.--Officer Hefferty, of the police force, has been suspended for drunkenness, and Officer Mannion is in trouble for refusing to obey an order to arrest Hefferty.

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 14.--Everybody in Washington knew Tom Roy, and everybody believed him to be an old bachelor or a widower without a family, but he was neither the one nor the other.

MERIDEN, Conn., July 14.--Joseph Fredericks, a young and rather good-looking man, ran down Pratt-street yesterday morning with a little girl in his arms, and hurried to the office of Chief of Police Ford. There he found his wife and they both began to ask the child if she wasn't glad to be with them.

SALEM, Mass., July 14.--There is no improvement in the labor situation in Salem and Peabody, rather matters have grown worse since yesterday.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 14.--The trial of McNamara, Glidden, Mulcahey, and Busche, the union printers accused of conspiracy against the Journal and Courier, was begun in the Superior Court, before Judge Stoddard, the second panel having been found sufficient to complete the list of jurymen.
POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., July 14.--There was quite a stir about the Court House to-day, the Brinckerhoff divorce case having been put down for trial this morning in the Circuit Court room.

CHICAGO, July 14.--Two months ago Dr. Smith, of the Eye and Ear Department of the County Hospital, performed a difficult surgical operation on the eyes of a little 3-month-old child which was perhaps the first of the kind ever attempted.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 14.--There is a strong feeling at Butler, Mo., where John T. Leabo is to be hanged on Friday, July 23, that the condemned man is innocent.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 14.--Robert Doblin, dealer in millinery and fancy goods, at No. 89 Water-street, has made an assignment to Marcus Scharps, a clothier, of this city. The liabilities of Mr. Doblin are stated to be less than $10,000.

The State Board for the Equalization of State taxes yesterday visited the Department of Taxes and Assessments and, after a short preliminary conference, proceeded to hear the Tax Commissioner on the subject of the assessed valuation of property in this city.

ALBANY, N.Y., July 14.--Ex-Speaker Erwin, who is here making preparations for a reunion of members of the Legislature on Thursday, July 22, in connection with Albany's bicentennial celebration, says that a large majority of the members of the present Legislature will be here and very many members of former Legislatures.

DECATUR, Ill., July 14.--John Ritchie, who became demented by religious excitement, has been adjudged insane by the County Court. He first began studying the Bible six weeks ago, and became fascinated with its contents to such an extent that he neglected his occupation and soon lost his mental balance.
CONCORD, Mass., July 14.--The eighth session of the Concord School of Philosophy opened at 9:30 o'clook this morning. The little hillside chapel was filled with an audience of distinguished people.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 14.--The funeral of Henry Kirke Brown, the sculptor, who died last Saturday, was held at his late residence at Balmville, near Newburg, this afternoon at 2 o'clock. The services were exceedingly simple. A delegation of members of the National Academy of Design, of New-York, attended the obsequies in a body.

CHICAGO, July 14.--The Western Export Association was in session to-day at the Grand Pacific, and organized the Western Purchasing and Leasing Company, officers of which will be elected Aug. 5.

Forty years ago, when there were only 60 miles of railroad in operation in Ohio, Mr. Henry Howe, then a young man, a native of New-Haven, came on to Ohio for the purpose of gathering materials for his "Historical Collections of Ohio."

LONDON, July 14.--The Times says: "In the Queen's Bench Divisional Court, in London, on the 12th of July, before Mr. Justice Wills and Mr. Justice Grantham, the case of Field against Bennett was heard. This was an action by Mr. Cyrus Field against Mr. James Gordon Bennett, of the New-York Herald, for libel.

FOXBOROUGH, Mass., July 14.--The Union Straw Works, said to be the largest establishment of the kind in the country, was sold at auction to-day by order of the Assignees, who held the property in the interest of several national banks.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 14.--Two hundred acres of cranberries in the vicinity of Tomah, owned by J.I. Case, of Racine, the Baker estate, and Judge Ryan, have been ruined by the recent forest fires. The loss is estimated at $50,000. It will take eight or ten years for the vines to grow again.
LONDON, July 14.--Prince Jerome Napoleon visited the Queen to-day. The Duc d'Aumale arrived in London to-day. He will take up his residence at Twickenham.
WASHINGTON, July 14, 1886. The President to-day sent to the Senate the nomination of George S. Stevens to be Postmaster at Catskill, N.Y.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., July 14.--The Green GlassBlowers' League of the Eastern District continued in session to-day. The committee to which the subject was referred reported in favor of the suspension of the apprentice system for one year. General Master Workman Powderly, of the Knights of Labor, arrived here to-night and will address the glassblowers in secret session to-morrow morning.

The Third-Avenue Surface Railroad Company was not waited upon yesterday by a committee of its former employes and the strikers held no meetings.

DUBLIN, July 14.--During the rioting at Belfast last night between Catholics and Protestants four taverns and a number of dwelling houses were wrecked. The police and soldiers charged the rioters several times, and at last succeeded in clearing the main streets.

CITY OF MEXICO, July 14, via Galveston, Texas.--The Congressional elections have resulted in a large majority for the Government. They passed off quietly in all parts of the republic.

ERIE, Penn., July 14.--A two days' clay and live pigeon shoot terminated to-day, and over $700 in prizes were divided. A. Walker, of Jamestown, N.Y., had the best general average; J., W. Brockway of Ripley N.Y., second; J. Calkins, of Westfield third; J. Wightman, of Cleveland, J. Glass, of Newcastle, C.J. George, of Bradford, were also heavy winners.
ATLANTA, Ga., July 14.--Col. Towers, the principal Keeper of the penitentiary, sat up all last night parleying with the Dade County convicts.

WASHINGTON, July 14.--Capt. David Schooley, Twenty-fifth Infantry, has been appointed inspector of certain unserviceable signal service property at Fort Sisseton, Dakota.

LONDON, July 14.--In the international chess tournament to-day, in the third pairing, Taubenhaus, the French champion, defeated the English champion, Blackburne. Burn defeated Schallop, Mortimer defeated Gunsherg, Hanham defeated Capt. Mackenzie, and Zukertort defeated Pollock.

CONCORD, N.H., July 14.--The Prohibitionists of New-Hampshire met in convention today to the number of about 300, including women, nominated a candidate for Governor and adopted the usual cold water resolutions, sprinkled with condemnation of the leading political parties. CHICAGO, July 14.--About 400 men employed in the quarries of the Chicago and Lemont Stone Company and Brodenschulz Earnshand, at Lemont, have gone on strike because of a reduction of their wages to the figures paid before May 1, on which date an increase of 25 per cent. was granted them.

LAREDO, Texas, July 14.--About 4 o'clock this afternoon the commander of the Fourth Cavalry, stationed here, received orders by telegraph, and in 15 minutes the regiment moved hastily, going down the river. Nothing definite could be learned as to their destination or the cause of their sudden departure. It finally transpired, however, that a revolution had broken out in the vicinity of Mier, Camargo, Guerrero, and the adjacent country.

TROY, N.Y., July 14.--About 4 o'clock this morning Detectives Walsh and Reynolds, of the Troy and Boston Railroad Company, found Robert Carroll and John O'Neil asleep in a freight car in the upper part of the city.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 14.--This day, set apart every year by the French-speaking population for celebrating the anniversary of the overthrow of the Bastile, was observed here as usual.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 14.--The pitchers of the Louisville and Baltimore Clubs fought the battle today and Hecker vanquished Kilroy in a fine contest.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 14.--The drought is telling severely on the crops in this region, and it is seriously affecting the production of dairy goods in the counties of which they are the leading staple.
