ST. JOHN, New-Brunswick, July 19.--As the steamer State of Maine, from Boston, was passing Point Lepreaux at 4 P.M. yesterday, a plainly dressed woman, aged about 60 years, threw herself into the sea.
DETROIT, Mich., July 19.--A prettily played game was that of to-day between the Detroit and Kansas City Clubs.
Trains on the Third and Sixth avenue elevated railroads have been generally reduced within the past week or two from four to three cars each.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--It having come to the knowledge of the Civil Service Commission that in several instances private secretaries of appointing officers have a been nominated to important official positions on Boards of Examiners, the commission to-day issued the following order, addressed to Boards of Civil Service Examiners:
UTICA, July 19.--J.G.T. Elder, of the Chicago Literary Life, was in Utica to-day on his way to Holland Patent to confer with Miss Cleveland.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19.--W.H. Gigger, who shot and killed Capt. J.W. Higgins, of the Internal Revenue Service, at Carthage last month for an alleged insult to Mrs. Gigger, attempted suicide in the Carthage Jail to-day, cutting an artery in his arm. His act was discovered in time to prevent his bleeding to death. Gigger has been very violent since his arrest, feigning insanity, by which plea he expects to be acquitted.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19.--A sensational shooting affair occurred here last night, in which five persons were injured, two of them seriously. P.H. Monohan had been courting Miss Laura Carney for two years or more.
POTTSTOWN, Penn., July 19.--Churchville, in this county, is considerably excited over the clandestine marriage of Elmer Schnack and Miss Minnie Andre.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 19.--A dispatch received from Cornwall this afternoon states that Congreesman Lewis Beach passed a very restless night last night. He was weaker and failing and his condition more precarious than at any previous time during his illness.

BATAVIA, N.Y., July 19.--Mrs. Etta Joslyn, the wife of John Joslyn, a farmer of Wheatville, in this county, and the mother of two children, tried to kill herself Saturday night by means of a revolver.

GENEVA, N.Y., July 19.--J.G. Farwell, a reporter of the Geneva Gazette, while running bases in a game of ball this afternoon, broke both bones of his right leg just above the ankle. He will probably be confined to the house for from two to four weeks.

The last of the sufferers by the slipping of the Columbia's gangplank at Rockaway on Sunday left the Seaside House for this city yesterday morning. All were in good condition and feeling none the worse for the mishap, except little Tommy Jones, whose mother lives in Washington-street, ...

ST. LOUIS, July 19.--On the morning of the 26th of April last a freight train on the Missouri Pacific Road was wrecked near Wyandotte, Kan., and F.B. Horton, the fireman, and George Carlisle, head brakeman, were killed. An examination showed that the train had been deliberately wrecked.
HOBDY'S MILLS, Penn., July 19.--Early yesterday morning, after the hard rainstorm of the night before, the ground in all directions around this settlement was covered thickly with light red lizards.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., July 18.--The United States Secret Service officers know who the Minneapolis Post Office robbers are. There were five in the job. The leader was "The Peoria Kid," alias Jack Quinn, who did the twenty-seventhousand-dollar job in Indianapolis, known as the "orange box robbery."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 19.--The First Baptist Church of this city is agog to-night over the disclosures of correspondence which seriously reflects on the private and ministerial character of the Pastor, the Rev. M.M. Wamboldt.
RALEIGH, N.C., July 19.--The Republican State Committee has been called to meet in this city on the 10th of August. Of the 20 members only three are in favor of calling a State Convention.

CHICAGO, July 19.--Judge Gary's court was crowded this morning when the first witness, Lieut. Stanton, one of the officers wounded at the Haymarket, was placed on the stand. He described in detail the events of the night of May 4, and was also asked concerning the wounds he received.

The "penuchle" business is getting to be a nuisance, and a general complaint has been made by the wearers of white bats as well as by the men who sell them. They claim that the practice of boys yelling penuchle at every white hat they see is a disturbance of the peace and that the police should interfere and break it up.

Samuel Irving, of No. 239 Dean-street, Philadelphia, a bank note engraver, fell from the East Ferry-street bridge, in Newark, last evening, a distance of 20 feet, and fractured both legs. It is feared that he is injured internally and cannot live. He was walking to Newark to get employment at his trade. He was drunk at the time of the accident.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 19.--Patrick Dempsey, an unmarried man, living on what is sometimes known as the old Green Mill road at Black Rock, made two attempts at suicide today. Neither was successful, although the last came near being fatal.

The New-York players presented the Boston men with nine unpalatable "goose eggs" in their contest on the Polo Grounds yesterday, winning the game by 3 to 0, and the members of the unsuccessful team started for their home last night in an unhappy frame of mind.
ROME, July 19.--It is believed that the Pope will revise his biography, which is being compiled by Bishop O'Reilly.

SAN FRANCISCO, July 19.--News was received here to-day of the murder of Capt. F.H. Kohler, a well known mariner of this coast, and his cook, by natives of Bougainville Island, one of the Solomon group, in the South Pacific. The savages also destroyed the trading station Capt. Kohler had established there.
The Newark Club won an exhibition game from the St. Louis Browns in Newark yesterday by fig ures of 4 to 3. The winners scored all their runs in the last 4 innings.
One of the waiters at a hotel in Grenada, Miss., told us that a colored wedding was coming off that evening, and several white people went over to the house designated to witness the affair.

The crowd of children that hovered around the tumbled down flour warehouse, in Roosevelt-street, would have liked to make genuine pies, yesterday, but the police would not let them. Strong planks placed on barrels made a fence that kept back the Fourth Ward, crowd that passed along in a continuous stream.

The house of Theodore Harris, at No. 135 East Fifty-fourth-street, was closed yesterday, and the family left the city after the death of Mrs. Jeannie M. Disbrow, the sister of Mrs. Harris, which occurred on Saturday night.

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., July 19.--Theodore Wheeler was arrested at Cooksville, this county, last night for the stealing and shipping to Chica go of 33 head of fat cattle from Hudson, Ill. He is a cousin of one of the owners of the cattle, 30 years old and a farmer. He failed to obtain payment for the stock and is row in jail here.

HOLYOKE, Mass., July 19.--A boat containing five men was capsized in Moody's Cove, on the South Hadley side of the river, yesterday afternoon, and two Frenchmen, Frank Riverst, aged, 26 years, and Homer Berrard, aged 22, were drowned.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Secretary of the Interior to-day sent to the Senate, in reply to its resolution, the report of Fred H. Wines, Special Agent of the tenth census, on the defective, dependent, and delinquent classes. The report is voluminous and contains a large number of interesting tables respecting the criminal and pauper classes of the United States.

When Mrs. Annie Bowe, who lives at No. 417 Carlton-avenue, Brooklyn, reached her home at about 6 o'clock yesterday evening she was astonished to find her furniture, worth $200, packed up on a van at the door and its removal being superintended by Constable James J. Keenan, ...
BATAVIA, N.Y., July 19.--James Langley, a negro, aged 38, who was employed as a hostler at the Olcott House barns, in Oakfield, this county, got up at 4:30 this morning, as usual, and did his chores.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., July 19.--Bellmore Colliery, operated by S.S. Bickle, suspended indefinitely to-day. The condition of the trade is not such as to justify the operation of the mine. The suspension throws 400 hands out of employment. This is the third colliery to suspend here, the three combined employing 1,300 men.

BALTIMORE, July 19.--Capt. James R. Willing, of the firm of William L. Ellis Co., oyster packers of this city, has left the city with from $30,000 to $35,000 belonging mostly to his friends. No clue to his whereabouts has been obtained.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 19.--The funeral of E.Z.C. Judson, "Ned Buntline," took place at Stamford, Delaware County, yesterday afternoon.
PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 19.--The Rev. Mr. Van Tassel, of the Baptist Church, Hancock, is the hard-working shepherd of a small and not very rich flock.

The fire at Amecameca is 12 miles broad, and is traveling rapidly. The damage so far is incalculable. Great forests have disappeared, which have been worth at least $2,000,000 to the people of the valley and its surroundings on account of their effect on the climate and the rains.
OTTAWA, July 19.--The St. Andrew's Society of Ottawa threaten to bring an action for damages against the State Line Steamship Company for breach of contract.

JAMESTOWN, July 19.--Aaron W. Day lives over the Chautauqua County line, in Cattaraugus County, in the town of South Valley. He is a Justice of the Peace. James L. Connor, of Corry, had him arrested recently on a charge of refusing to pay over moneys collected on a judgment, and after an examination before a Justice of the Peace in Salamanca Day was fined $50, which he paid.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 19.--The dance at the Casino to-night was a very brilliant affair, nearly 200 guests being present.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen to-night a petition was received signed by the 16 members of the Board of Aldermen in 1884 who voted for the settlement of the city's claims against the NewHaven and Derby Railroad.
WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Fortification Appropriation bill, as it passed the House this morning, appropriates $620,000, to be expended as follows:
LOUISVILLE, July 19.--About six years ago John Trotter, a well known Jeffersonville character, jumped from the ferry dock on the Indiana side of the river, and everybody thought he was drowned.
Through all countries an intense interest has been awakened in the habits and condition of the prehistoric man.

EASTON, Penn., July 19.--During a quarrel in Phillipsburg, N.J., this morning, Frank Johnson struck Henry Donnelly, his brother-inlaw, on the month. Donnelly fell against a wagon and struck his head with great force against the hub. He died two hours later. Johnson surrendered himself.

CHICAGO, July 19.--"Jim, the Penman," a drama, by Sir Charles Young, had its first performance in the United States at McVicker's Theatre to-night, under the management of Mr. A.M. Palmer. It was first acted at the Haymarket Theatre, London, April 3, and has since held the stage there continuously.

ALBANY, July 19.--J.T. McKechnie, Thomas Moran, and George McVey, a committee from the Central Labor Union of NewYork, called on Gov. Hill at 10 o'clock this morning to ask for a pardon for Wiltzig, Rosenberg, Holdorf, and Danhauser, who were convicted and sentenced to Sing Sing for boycotting Mr. Theiss, proprietor of the Alhambra Music Hall, on Fourteenth-street, New-York.
Alfred Wagner, the German boy who tried to commit suicide by taking Paris green in the Brooklyn City Park on Sunday, was yesterday arraigned before Justice Naeher.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 19.--This morning W.L. Keister, a commercial traveler for Jacob Hecht, hat dealer of Norfolk, Va., committed suicide in his room at the Central Hotel, this city, by taking chloral. For 10 days he had been on a debauch. His age was about 35. He leaves a widow and child at Norfolk.

JANESVILLE, Wis., July 19.--Henry Zarch, a wealthy farmer, aged 76 years, and his wife, aged 65, living two miles and a half southwest of this city, were murdered last night for their money. They lived alone, and had in their employ a boy about 16 years old. Last night the boy, who resides in this city, came home.

NYACK, July 19.--The thunderstorm which occurred here yesterday afternoon and last night made its presence felt in various parts of Rockland Country in a very forcible manner. In the afternoon, while the lightning was the most vivid and the thunder the heaviest, an interment was being made in a private plot in Oak Hill Cemetery, not far from the edge of the adjoining woods.
SCRANTON, Penn., July 19.--Carl Ernst, a prominent dealer in glass and china ware, committed suicide in his store on Wyoming-avenue this morning.

Members of 12 families living in the fourstory tenemont house No. 551 East Sixteenthstreet were aroused shortly after 12 o'clock yesterday morning by a fire which started in the cigar and stationery store of Gesa Wolf, on the ground floor.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The General Passenger Agents of the Western, Northwestern, and Southwestern lines held a meeting to-day to put into effect the temporary agreement made by the General Managers last week for the restoration of rates between Chicago and Missouri River points and Chicago and St. Paul.
The Civil Service Commission is showing a determination to have the law and the rules applying to appointments in the classified service of the Government strictly carried out.
A story has gained circulation that Sergeant-at-Arms Canaday, of the Senate, has been removing Union soldiers and appointing Confederates.

When the special committee of the French Chamber of Deputies called upon the Panama Canal Company for its balance sheet and for copies of the contracts under which, it was said, the completion of the canal had been assured, M. DE LESSEPS saw danger ahead.

CHICAGO, Jnly 19.--The Lehr and Wehr Verein, of which the witness Waller in the Anarchist trial was a member, and whose plottings against society he detailed to the jury, was organized in 1875, and on April 16 of that year was incorporated under the laws of the State. The incorporators were about 30 German and Bohemian Socialists, whose object was to train ...
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 19.--Middlesex County suffered a considerable reduction in its population by drowning yesterday.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19.--A Winnipeg special to the Pioneer Press says: "Saturday six masked men on horseback and heavily armed robbed her Majesty's mail 400 miles northwest of here.
In "Florian," the operetta by Miss Ida Walter, daughter of Mr. John Walter, which was sung at the London Novelty last week, Miss Gertrude Griswold, the American cantatrice, had the principal part.
LONDON, July 19.--The Pope has created Gideon Ouimet, of Canada, a Commander of the Order of St. Gregory.
WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Acting Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and thirty-ninth call for the redemption of bonds.
MASON CITY, Iowa, July 19.--Great alarm exists in Cerro Gordo and Worth Counties over the discovery of several cases of smallpox in the townships of Barton, Grafton, and Bolan.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 19.--Capt. Herrick, of the schooner Augusta, from Swan's Island, Me., reports that seven miles off Jeddore he passed a schooner, bottom up, held by her anchor. The vessel is of about 90 tons. She lies in the track of vessels bound east or west, and is apt to be mistaken for a ledge.

MONTREAL, July 19.--The fight to a finish which was to have taken place here to-night between H. Stoddart, the champion of New-York State, and John McGlade, of this city, was stopped by Mayor Beaugrand. It is believed that the men are to meet privately in a short time.

PORTLAND, Me., July 19.--This afternoon a score or more of gentlemen identified with the fisheries gave for publication their views in regard to a statement made by Mr. Bayard, who, in speaking of the fishermen, said that many of them are Canadians; that the supplies used on board the vessels are purchased in Canada simply because both men and material can be obtained cheaper than in the United States.
The story told of M. Thiers in connection with the death of the venerable Archbishop of Paris shows how thoroug a knowledge of men was possessed by "le Petit Bourgcois."

WASHINGTON, July 19. Examinations for Assistant Examiners in the Patent Office will soon be held by the Civil Service Commission at several points in different sections of the country. Persons desiring to enter these examinations should at once write to the Civil Service Commission, Washington, for information and blank forms of application.
The basement of No. 27 Cannon-street was broken open on Saturday afternoon and a quantity of crockery ware, vases, and glassware belonging to Mrs. Georgiana Stanton was stolen.

BANGOR, Me., July 19.--Henry, the 15year-old son of J.A. Bicknell, shot and instantly killed his sister Mattie, aged 13, yesterday afternoon. The boy picked up a gun and, not knowing that it was loaded, pointed it at his sister. Of course it was discharged, the contents striking her in the neck, tearing away the windpipe and arteries.

A tourist who was at Brent's Hotel, Rotorua, gives the following vivid description of the earthquake which occurred at a place called Wonderland, about the centre of Auckland, 25 miles from the coast: He retired early and was awakened from his sleep about 1 o'clock on Thursday morning by a shock of earthquake.

PARIS, July 3.--The matrimonial agencies avec tares, the third class ones, which deal with cases where there is always something in the way of a blemish on both sides, are sui generis, and it would require volumes to do justice to the countless turpitudes and infamies which are committed or revealed within their walls.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19.--For months past a gang of horse thieves have been operating successfully in the upper Cumberland counties, many valuable animals being stolen and run into Kentucky and sold.
WASHINGTON, July 19.--The Board on Additional Cruisers have completed their plans for the four vessels authorized by Congress, and will submit their report to Secretary Whitney in a few days.

The boycott against Mr. EHRET'S beer is particularly rascally and particularly cowardly. It is particularly rascally because it was imposed without any pretense that Mr. EHRET was in any way ill treating the men in his employ.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 19.--Judge Thayer to-day refused to grant the petition of the Liquor Dealers' Association for an injunc tion to prevent the County Treasurer from collecting the Dow tax or attaching the penalty. Judge Thayer is a Democrat.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 19.--Last night at 8 o'clock, as three young men were crossing the Hudson River in a rowboat from New-Windsor toward Denning's Point, their boat was capsized and all were thrown into the water.

SANDYSTON, N.J., July 19.--There is a Government tax of 90 cents a gallon on the distilling of apple whisky. Sussex County and the adjoining County of Orange pay nearly $100,000 to the Government every year as tax on the applejack which the two counties distill.

WASHINGTON, Penn., Jnly 19.--Major James P. Sayer, Brigade Inspector, this afternoon reviewed the troops in camp here and witnessed the battalion drill and the dress parade. Extensive preparations are being made to have the men present a fine appearance on Wednesday, when they will be reviewed by Gov. Pattison. Gen. Hartranft, division commander, and his staff will also be present.
LONDON, July 19.--There was some phenomenal shooting in the rifle matches at Wimbledon to-day. Rigby made 15 consecutive bull'seyes at 600 yards.
NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 19.--At a meeting of the Board of Education to-night the report of A.J. Jones, the expert, of the condition of Lewis Applegate, the Treasurer, was read.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--Charles Kingsley, a German, 48 years old, of No. 507 Christain-street, was stabbed and probably fatally injured at his home this morning by an unknown man, whom he believes to be an Italian ragpicker. Kingsley says his wife left the house about 4 o'clock, leaving him in bed. Shortly after her departure he heard a noise down stairs, and on making an ...

HALFAX, Nova Scotia, July 19.--A party of Royal Engineers, under command of Lieut.Col. O'Brien, left here for British Columbia this evening. They go to look over the ground with the view of reporting to the imperial authorities as to the best manner of fortifying the Pacific coast.
LONDON, July 20.--Barrett, the tragedian, appeared last night as Hamlet in the first of a series of farewell performances. There was a full house and the actor was greeted with hearty applause.
TRENTON, N.J., July 19.--The contracts for the rebuilding of the burned part of the State House were awarded by the Building Commission to-day.

PHELPS, N.Y., July 19.--Prof. Brooks, of the Red House Observatory, has just been awarded the Warner prizes for his discovery of the first, second, and third comets of the present year. These three comets were discovered by Prof. Brooks in less than one month, and, with the two Brooks comets of 1885, they make five comets discovered by this astronomer within a period of nine months, a record unparalleled in the history of astronomy.

BANGOR, Me., July 19.--Dennis O'Brien, a Phippsburg farm hand, 55 years old, while drunk last night indulged in a meal of Paris green, which he ate dry from a box. He had swallowed a quarter of a pound of the poison before his strange appetite was discovered. Emetics were speedily administered, and a large quantity of the stuff was thrown off, but he died in great agony at 1 o'clock this morning.

The journeyman brewers are uneasy over the circular issued by the order of the Executive Committee of the Association of the United Lager Beer Brewers stating that unless the workmen employed in breweries and belonging to labor unions, the Brewery Workingmen's Union and the Beer Drivers' Union, would publicly protest ...

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 19.--Information has been received from Franklin, Ky., of the arrest of O.S. Gipson, colored, for a criminal and outrageous assault on the little daughter of William Gillespie, a farme. Gipson fied, but was pursued by a posse, captured, and lodged in jail. There is much talk of lynching him to-night.

Mr. Jeremiah Counsellor, a resident of Newark, N.J., and an ex-member of the NewJersey Legislature, went to Brooklyn on Saturday to visit a relative at No. 111 Clinton-avenue, and yesterday morning started to go to NewYork.
SOUTH CANADIAN, Indian Territory, July 19.--It has been 13 months since a good rain fell in this part of the Territory. Corn and cotton are failures.

MILWAUKEE, Wis. July 19.--In pronouncing sentence upon Frank Hirth, Carl Simon, and Anton Palm, Anarchists, convicted of conspiring to burn the Court House and of inciting people to deeds of violence, Judge Sloan said ...

CHICAGO, July 19.--The first shooting of any consequence thus far in the Lake Shore strike occurred at 3 o'clock this morning at the intersection of Fortieth and Halstead streets. At that hour John Berger, one of the eight "objectionable" Lake Shore switchmen, was at work switching his engine from one track to another, ...

MATAMORAS, Mexico, July 19.--A private express from Solecino Ranch, which reached here to-day, stated that Adolfo Gonzales and Tapias, the revolutionary chiefs, with 60 men, learning that Col. Praejedis Caajos had but 25 men with him at Enciencada, had left to give him battle.
CHICAGO, July 19.--The relations between Duncan C. Ross, the athlete and swordsman, and Robert V. Ferguson,, his advance agent, are somewhat strained.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 19.--The first yacht of the Atlantic Club's fleet poked her nose inside the breakwater off New-Haven Harbor about 4:30 this afternoon, and sped on under full sail toward her anchorage off Morris Cove.

A Frenchman named Max Jox, who has undertaken for a wager of $500 to walk from Galveston, Texas, to New-York City, in 13 weeks, passed here Friday night. He was footsore and weary, but full of pluck and confident of winning.

PHILADELPHIA, July 19.--At 9 o'clock tomorrow morning a convention of retail shoe dealers of the United States will meet in Lincoln Hall, at Broad-street and Fairmount-avenue, out which it is hoped by the projectors will grow a national associa tion, influential and permanent.

ALBANY, July 19.--The fourteenth annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen at Pleasure Island, to-morrow and Wednesday, promises to be the largest and most successful in its history.

The officers stationed at Fort Hamilton met yesterday afternoon and passed resolutions of sympathy with the widow and family of Capt. Gulian Verplanck Weir, of Batters M, Fifth Artillery, who committed suicide Sunday evening.

"Is John Keenan in Paris?" is a question that was gently asked by politicians of one another yesterday who had read all about the homesickness of "Billy" Moloney, who is an exile in the gay French capital. The impression seemed to be general that Mr. Keenan had gone to Paris in the wake of Moloney, Dempsey, and De Lacy.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 19.--The death of the child of John Gore, of Millvale borough, last week, has led to striking developments. This child was found by Humane Agent M.J. Dolan locked up in a box almost dying. He had the father arrested and he was fined $15 for his inhuman treatment of the child.
ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19.--At the National Conference of Charities and Corrections this morning, reports from various institutions and States were received.

President Henry D. Purroy again sat as a Judge yesterday in Firemen's Hall in the trial of Second Assistant Chief John McCabe, who sent out the simultaneous call known as the "three sixes" at the fire in Harlem on July 5. The Chief said, in his defence, he did not leave a great portion of the city really unprotected.

It isn't going to be many a day before New-York stores will support colored salesmen. The black man in the metropolis has never ventured far toward getting a foothold in mercantila circles, but there are indications that point to the turning of his attention in that direction. An instance illustrating this came to my notice yesterday.

SCRANTON, Penn., July 19.--The Lehigh Valley Company has issued orders to the employes at its various collieries to suspend operations in mining until the 1st of August. This action is taken in deference to the wish of the ...
The Vossische Zeitung, the leading organ of advanced Liberalism in this city, contains an editorial article entitled "Gladstone," which deserves attention at the present moment. The writer says:
NEWBURG, N.Y., July 19.--Richard Voas, an aged pensioner of the English Government, was buried at Chatham Centre, Columbia County, N.Y., last Friday.

John P. Boyd is a son of the late Edward A. Boyd, the wholesale glass importer, who died recently, a few days after he was released from prison, where he had been sent for defrauding the customs revenue.

BATH, Me., July 19.--Nearly two years ago John Traynor, a sailor, started in a dory from this city to row across the Atlantic. The boat, which was 13 feet long, was furnished and equipped for the voyage by Dr. R.D. Bibber, of this city, at a cost of nearly $300. Since the unsuccessful attempt of Traynor, who is supposed ...
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., July 19.--The clergymen of this city will not be dependent this year on donation parties to raise their salaries to a sum on which they can live.

The more than genial warmth of the past fortnight has happily been unattended by that train of accidents from sunstroke with which we have been in other seasous but too familiar. We must not, however, on that account, conclude that measures of prevention are not yet necessary.

WASHINGTON, July 17.--At last we succeeded in overcoming Dick's reluctance and our expedition to Luray Cave was a success. When the subject of our going was first broached Dick said he'd be flabbergasted if he was going a hundred and fifty miles and spend $20 for the pleasure of crawling down a hole in the ground and perhaps breaking his neck, but that when he ...

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 19.--The anxiety regarding Capt. Reed, of the whaling bark Petrol, of this port, who, with his first and second mates, are on their way home to be tried here on a charge of cruelty to members of their crew, has somewhat abated. A letter has been received from Capt. Reed giving his version of the trouble.
SUSQUEHANNA, Penn., July 19.--Elijah Pelton, of Hawley, has captured alive this year the largest collection of rattlesnakes ever brought together at one time.

ALBANY, July 19.--With ancient ceremonies Albany this morning threw open her gates and extended a welcome to all of "good fame and honest name." At 9 o'clock, according to the proclamation of Mayor John Boyd Thacher, the following company set forth from the City Hall:

Commissioner Rollin M. Squire is not the kind of man to be forced to rid himself of his friends. He will stick to them so long as he can make the city give them a living. When he asked Uriah Pollard, a Massachusetts ex-convict, to resign as Deputy Water Register, a position to which he had been appointed by ...
On June 9 the body of a man about 55 years old was taken out of the North River at Twenty-second-street.

LONDON, July 19.--Public interest in the Dilke-Crawford case is unabated. In court today Dilke was cheerful--almost frisky. Donald Crawford was sullen and heavy-eyed. Mrs. Crawford was cool and collected, breaking the tedium of the technical evidence by a series of little yawns and twirlings of her handkerchief.

WASHINGTON, July 19.--When the two "sluggers" of the House went out into the lobby a day or two ago to polish each other off for hard words that had passed between them everybody assumed that the branch of Congress nearest the people was asserting an indifference to dignity that the Senate could never be guilty of. But that was a mistake.
PEORIA, Ill., July 19.--The report of the bank expert who has been going over the books of the broken banking firm of H.P. Tracy Co., ...

The Archbishop of Paris died this morning at 10:30. He is eulogized by the French press. For many years he left the business of his great diocese to his coadjutor, Mgr. Richard, who was named his successor in 1875 to make certain that the Republicans should not hand over the Metropolitan See to an ecclesiastic more favorable to new ideas.

LONDON, July 19.--In the seventh round of the chess tournament, which was played today, Zukertort beat Bird, Blackburn beat Schallop, Taubenhaus beat Pollock, and Gunsberg beat Burn, making his score 5 to 1 . The Americans were all paired to play together today, but manoeuvred so cautiously that their games are not yet finished.

CHICAGO, July 19.--The dead body of Capt. Edward Williams, one of the best kown vessel masters on the lakes, and formerly a Captain on salt water, was brought to this city today. Capt. Williams met his death in a curious way.

TORONTO, Ontario, July 19.--At the Supreme Lodge of the Knights of Pythias to-day it was decided to have the Supreme Secretary of the endowment rank and the Major-General commanding the uniform rank officers of the Supreme Lodge, and to have the Major-General appointed by the Supreme Chanceller in future for a term of four years.

For the present, discussion upon Mr. MORRISON'S joint resolution to reduce the Treasury surplus by forced payments of the national debt may be regarded as academical, and we trust that will continue to be the case.

The match between the polo ponies Buckshot and Cedarhurst came off yesterday afternoon at Sheepshead Bay in the presence of about half a hundred ladies and gentlemen. The match had convulsed "hunting society" for the past week, and the betting by the partisans of each pony was very strong.

RESECA, Penn., July 19.--Mrs. William Jacobs, of Sadlersville, Warren County, where she recently went from this place, writes to her sister that on Thursday morning last she went down to the cellar to get some butter for breakfast.

ST. LOUIS, July 19.--Warrants were sworn out at a late hour this afternoon for the arrest of the officers and Directors of the Provident Savings Bank for alleged criminal violation of the banking law.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 19.--At a meeting of the St. Paul Chamber of Commerce to-day Bishop Whipple made an address in behalf of the Leceb Lake and Winnebagoshish Indians. He said in 1880 it was thought necessary to build reservoirs at the head waters of the Mississippi.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 19.--The quarterly convention began here to-day of District Assembly No. 30, Knights of Labor, which takes in the entire State except Lynn, Brockton, and a few other towns, and includes over 300 assemblies, with a membership of 100,000.
GLASGOW, Ulster Count, N.Y., July 19.-- A sad accident occurred yesterday on Esopus Creek, near Howard Finger's Lake View boarding house, in the town of Saugerties.
LONDON, July 19.--The new Parliament will probably be summoned to meet on Aug. 5. It will then, it is believed, be adjourned to reassemble some time in October.
The only witness at the hearing in the Page will contest at Stapleton yesterday was Louis R. Menger, who for many years framed most of the artist's pictures.

According to the promises of John C. Short, President of the American Finance Company, at No. 96 Broadway, a new railroad line to Boston will be opened by the end of the year. The plan is to accomplish it by the construction of a line from Bronxdale, the upper terminus of the Second-Avenue Suburban Road, to Danbury.
Assistant Treasurer Canda said yesterday that his experts at the Sub-Treasury in this city have lately discovered many very skillful counterfeits in silver coins.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 19.--Publication was made on Saturday of the decree of the Supreme Court of Orange County ordering the sale by the Referee named therein, for the benefit of creditors, of the extensive mining and furnace property of the Parrott Iron Company.
A decision rendered by the New-Jersey Court of Errors and Appeals, at Trenton, yesterday, affects the Director at Large of Hudson County.

BOSTON, July 19.--The steamer Gate City, Capt. Hedge, of the Boston and Savannah Steamship Line, went ashore in a fog at 7:15 o'clock last night on Naushon Island, at the entrance to Vineyard Sound, and only about 11 miles from Devil's Bridge, where her sister vessel, the City of Columbus, was lost about two and a half years ago. She had on board 52 passengers, all of whom have been safely landed.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, July 19.--A dispatch received at Forest Ranch from Fort Bowie says the hostiles have sent word that they desire a parley with Gen. Miles. Orders have been sent to Lieut. Park to close the pursuit of the Indians until the result of the parley is ascertained. The dispatch also says that Geronimo is wounded.
James Brooks, Jr., married a young woman several months ago. He soon wearied of her and began a suit for absolute divorce.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 20.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 10 cents; telegraphic, 15 cents.
BUFFALO, July 20.--A motion was made in the Superior Court to-day on behalf of Mr. Henry Richmond, of Clay Richmond, lithographers, for the appointment of a Receiver.

The corporation to which the contract for laying electric wires under ground was conditionally offered by the Subway Commission last week has virtually accepted the conditions, and there seems to be no doubt that the contract will be definitely awarded without delay.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 20.--The quarterly convention of District 30, Knights of Labor, which began its three days' session here in Mechanics' Hall yesterday, is in many respects a remarkable gathering, and its deliberations are of very great importance to the laboring element of New-England.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 20.--Admiral Scott has been temporarily withdrawn from the fisheries protection service, and is to make a tour of the lighthouses and fog stations in order to learn their requirements.
HARRISONBURG, Va., July 20.--S.R. Sterling, the defaulting Treasurer of this county, was to-day arraigned before the County Court for trial. To the 17 indictments against him he pleaded not guilty.

A well dressed and apparently intelligent Englishman, who was willing to renounce allegiance to Queen Victoria, appeared before Judge O'Gorman, in Superior Court, Chambers, yesterday, for naturalization.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 20.--W.E. Ingalls, President of the Cincinnati, Indianapolis, St. Louis and Chicago Railway, said to-day: "Crops around here are in splendid condition, and the railroads are going to have a very prosperous season, which will last for at least a year.

At the meeting of the Municipal Council of the Irish National League in Justice Kelly's court room last evening, the chief business was the appointment of a committee to confer with the Irish Parliamentary Association's committee ...

A story was current at Police Headquarters yesterday that some one in the Police Department is making a good thing by buying up the claims of policemen for their shares in the police relief fund. This fund consists of deductions of $2 per month from the pay of policemen.
The veterans of the old Nineteenth Army Corps made a day of it at Manhattan Beach yesterday.

The Philadelphia-Wistar committee of the Texas and Pacific Railroad Company met yesterday and voted to extend the time for receiving deposits of securities under their plan of reorganization until Sept. 20. Originally the time limit was July 15.

ALBANY, July 20.--The attractions in Albany this afternoon in connection with the Bicentennial Celebration seem to have been greater than at Pleasure Island, where the first day's races of the annual regatta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen were rowed. Although many thousands of strangers have ...

CHICAGO, July 20.--East-bound freight shipments from Chicago last week prove to be smaller than has been estimated by about 2,000 tons. The official statement of east-bound shipments of all classes of freight, (excepting live stock) ...
McKEESPORT, Penn., July 20.--William German, who has been backing Teemer this season up to the present time, returned from Baltimore to-day and in an interview said: "I am done.
BOSTON, July 20.--Inspector Pinkerton, of the Police Headquarters, arrested late this afternoon Mrs. Marcella Cooper, of Somerville, on a charge of embezzling $14,000.

CLINTON, Mo., July 20.--M.B. Buskirk, a dry goods merchant of this city, has fled, taking with him all of his available assets, amounting to about $4,000, and leaving behind him debts to the amount of $6,000.

The threat of the Portland fishermen to "lay the greatest boycott of the age upon all Canadian productions, including fish," must depend somewhat for its practicability upon the extent to which the people of the United States, but particularly of NewEngland, will espouse their cause.

The Phelps-Rosebery convention extending the provisions of our treaty of extradition with Great Britain marks a distinct, though not radical, advance in the doctrine and practice of extradition between the two countries.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 20.--Work will be begun in a few days on a memorial chapel in the Island Cemetery. The building, which is to be entirely of stone, will be erected by Mr. and Mrs. August Belmont, of New-York, in memory of ...

The Pedro Segundo American Telegraph and Cable Company, organized to furnish a direct cable between the United States, Venezuela, and Brazil, formally opened its executive offices in this city yesterday at Nos. 44 and 46 Broadway.

WASHINGTON, July 20.--The statement of crop conditions on the 1st day of July, prepared by Prof. Dodge, the statistician of the Agricultural Department, is to-day supplemented by a fuller report giving additional facts and figures of an interesting character. In this report the Professor says:
GUATEMALA, July 20, via Galveston.--A duel has been fought between ex-Minister Aparicio and Senor Pilona. After firing six shots each at 20 paces the ex-Minister fell seriously wounded.

The Empire Yacht Club tried to sail its tenth annual regatta yesterday. Twenty-eight yachts finally succeeded in covering the course, but not in quick enough time to constitute a race except in the class for catboats under 20 feet in length.

LONG BRANCH, July 20.--W.K. Dugan was arrested at the Turf Club to-day while engaged in pool selling, on a warrant sworn out on the complaint of W.G. Wimpfheimer, the student detective who is still collecting evidence in disguise.
BUFFALO, July 20.--Private advices received here state that Joe Drinker has escaped from the insane asylum at Bloomburg, Penn., and is roaming at large in the forests of Northern Pennsylvania.

CONCORD, N.H., July 20.--Political interest in New-Hampshire centres at the present time in the canvass for the Republican nomination for Governor by Mr. Goodell and Col. Sawyer. The latter publicly announced his candidacy a short time ago, but he is an intimate ...

SANTIAGO, July 20, via Galveston.--The bill promoting Rear-Admiral Goni to the rank of Vice-Admiral was approved by the Senate yesterday by a vote of 19 to 8, and that raising Capt. Oscar Viel to the rank of Rear-Admiral by a vote of 16 to 11.

BOSTON, July 20.--A special train will leave Boston for San Francisco to-morrow afternoon, conveying Abraham Lincoln Post, No. 11, G.A.R., of Charlestown, and a detachment of Dahlgren Post, No.2, of South Boston. A NewHampshire delegation will join the party at ...

At Monmouth Park yesterday one of the best days' racing of the season was had. The interval between the heavy storm of Sunday night had not been long enough to completely dry the track, so that fast time was not expected, ...

ALBANY, July 20.--When Albany received its charter from Gov. Dongan sturdy Dutch burghers formed the population of the place. In these latter days, however, the sons of Holland no longer rule the town.
LAREDO, Texas, July 20.--Intense excitement prevails on the Mexican side of the Rio Grande concerning the status of the revolution which has broken out in the State of Tamaulipas.

BALTIMORE, July 20.--The case of John Stone, demanded by the Canadian authorities for shooting his niece, Maud Hodge, at Beamville, Ontario, on Jan. 5, was again up before United States Commissioner Rogers to-day.
BIG SPRING, Texas, July 20.--Miss Sarah Winstanly was a pretty English girl of about 18 years, who came here recently from Manchester, England.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., July 21.--The Gibson Lee stove works shut down to-day on account of the refusal of 50 employes to work with George Gibson, a non-union man, who taught negroes the molding process during a former strike at Baldwin's foundry.

Harper has unusual popular interest this month. Mr. Edmund Kirke contributes the opening paper--an account of Detroit--and Detroit has a history of great interest; moreover the paper is very agreeably written.
LONDON, July 20.--A messenger to the Queen conveying the formal resignations of the Ministers has left London for Osborne. The resignation was decided on at a meeting held this afternoon.
CHICAGO, July 20.--A few of the creditors of E.L. Dwyer Co., the Board of Trade firm which recently bought 5,000,000 bushels of wheat and failed to protect the contracts, held a meeting to-day.

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 20.--The Tenth Regiment, at Camp Pentecost, will be in excellent condition to receive Gov. Pattison and staff and other notables who are expected to arrive on a special train early to-morrow morning.

LONDON, July 20.--The court was crowded to-day, and the hot weather alone prevented anything resembling demonstrations. To-day's evidence was decidedly the most interesting yet given in the trial. Mrs. Crawford testified without hesitation.

The committee appointed by the Central Labor Union to devise means for taking independent action in the coming elections and to issue a call to the public, met last evening and prepared a report and call.

TRENTON, N.J., July 20.--A secret convention of operative potters was begun in Cooperative Hall, in this city, to-day. There were 48 delegates present, representing Trenton, Baltimore, Boston, East Liverpool, and one or two other cities in which there are potteries.
VINITA, Indian Territory, July 20.--News has just reached here of a murder in Delaware District, Cherokee Nation, near Mayville, Ark.

By general orders issued here yesterday Commodore Elbridge T. Gerry, of the New-York Yacht Club, announces that he assumes command of the squadron and appoints William Krebs Fleet Captain.

BUFFALO, July 20.--The official papers in the case of R. Porter Lee, ex-President of the defunct First National Bank of Buffalo, pardoned by President Cleveland July 10, were received from Washington at the Erie County Penitentiary at noon to-day. Lee was immediately set at liberty.

PARIS, July 20.--In Marseilles last evening mobs attacked the offices of the royalist papers. Gendarmes defended the buildings successfully, preventing the rioters from carrying out their purpose of sacking the premises.
NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., July 20.--The steamship Gate City remains at Naushon Island. The tide rises and falls in her fore and aft.

Capt. H.C. Chester, of the United States Fish Commission, died at Noank, Conn., on Monday last.

SACRAMENTO, Cal., July 20.--It is asserted by many of the members of the Legislature that the extra session, which was called to consider the question of irrigation, will not adjourn without electing a United States Senator to succeed Senator Hearst.

PHILADELPHIA, July 20.--The Allotment Committee of the coal combination agreed upon an output of 2,500,000 tons for August. The meeting was harmonious, and it was agreed that no company should exceed its quota.
CHICAGO, July 20.--Col. P. Donan, the Dakota extemporizer, is here and telling a story about a concession which he has obtained for the establishment of a national bank in Honduras.

READING, Penn., July 20.--Two Hungarians, Andreas Guydisch and Mike Marton, workmen engaged at the Emaus Pipe Works, got into an altercation about a Hungarian woman, a recent arrival, who does the cooking for a number of her country people.
PHILADELPHIA, July 20.--The Retail Shoe Dealers' National Convention met here to-day. The assembling of this body represents the joining together of a hitherto divided trade organization.
NEWBURG, N.Y., July 20.--Lewis Dick, a farmer in the town of wallkill, Orange County, is rather eccentric and cannot either read or write.
PAWTUCKET, R.I., July 20.--In the District Court to-day Judge Stone rendered a decision of not guilty in the case of James A. Marchant, charged with keeping liquors for sale.
BOSTON, July 20.--The order of the Civil Service Commission, issued yesterday, will affect somewhat the composition of the Board of Examiners at the Boston Custom House.

ROCHESTER, July 20.--Michael Viergiven, a shoemaker, jumped off the Vincent-place bridge last night and fell about 120 feet. He struck on his back in the water and was badly bruised, but no bones were broken. He will probably live.

BUFFALO, July 20.--William P. Miller, a New-York Central sleeping car conductor, was killed to-day at Suspension Bridge while trying to get aboard a rapidly moving train. His run was from New-York to Chicago via the West Shore and Grand Trunk Roads. He lived in NewYork.
NEW-HAVEN, Conn., July 20.--The Atlantic Yacht Squadron got underway and set its course for New-London about 9 o'clook this morning, with a strong northeast wind blowing.
PORT TOWNSEND, Washington Territory, July 20.--On Saturday night several tugs coming up to Cape Flattery were struck by a tidal wave of a very dangerous character.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 20.--The Norwegian bark Speranza, Capt. Nillsen, which sailed from Economy yesterday, struck on the rocks at the entrance to Economy River about 9 o'clock last night.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 20.--The sidewheel steamer Charlotte Vanderbilt, of the NewYork and Catskill Line, which was run into and sunk by Belden's iron steam yacht Yosemite in the Hudson River near Rondout in July, 1882, was raised by wreckers to-day.

LIMA, July 20, via Galveston.--The law recently enacted by Congress calling for a reduction of salaries and a reorganization of the public offices is being strictly carried out by the Executive, and all possible economy consistent with good and efficient service is the subject of constant consideration.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 20.--The worst accident that has taken place on the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad since the famous Norwalk bridge disaster 30 years ago occurred in this city this afternoon an eighth of a mile below the station.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 20.--The Georgia Democratic State Convention meets in this city on the 28th. The membership is 350. The primaries now completed show that the vote will be divided as follows: Gen. Gordon, 250; A.O. Bacon, 84; uninstructed, 12; contested, 4.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, July 20.--Prefect Oposura, of Sonora, and four companions are reported to have been killed by Apaches last week while on their way to examine mining property near that place. They had an escort of 15. The others escaped. It is said that 80 bucks were seen in the fight.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, July 21.-- About 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon several parties were drunk at John Terrell's, near Tahle quah, drinking from a keg of whisky. OTTAWA, Ontario, July 21.--Frederick William Wendenberg, of Bagenz, Prussia, has made application to the Canadian Government for a patent for a process of manufacturing cattle feed from sawdust and also to have patented the use, application, and employment of the same in Canada.

DANVILLE, Va., July 21.--Reports from the tobacco crop in this section are discouraging. Continuous rains have put the crop in bad condition, and no doubt it will be cut short. The indications now point to a small crop and but little bright tobacco.

A little boom was imported into the stock market late yesterday afternoon by a report that the Baltimore and Ohio and Jersey Central Railroads had just made a traffic contract by which the former was to come into New-York over the Jersey road's tracks for the next two years. One of the circumstantial statements accompanying the report was that the Baltimore and Ohio had ordered 15,000 Jersey Central tickets into New-York for Western passenger business.
LANCASTER, Penn., July 21.--Carl Ernst, a prominent dealer in china and glassware of Scranton, during the latter years of his life frequently expressed himself in favor of cremation.

CHARLESTON, Ill., July 21.--George Simmins, of Westfield, Clark County, accidentally shot his mother-in-law early yesterday morning, mistaking her for a burglar. She was moving about the kitchen when Simmins was aroused, and, thinking some one was trying to force an entrance to the house, fired his revolver. The woman will die.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 21.--The Randle Dugan Machinery Company, at No. 109 East Front-street, have made an assignment to Harry Hughes. Preferences were given to the First National Bank of Covington for $2,225; to the Union National Bank of Cincinnati for $4,172; to Helen Dugan for $6,000, and to a few others for small amounts. The liabilities are estimated at $50,000. No statement of the assets has been made.
NEW-ORLEANS, July 21.--Major F.F. Hilder, of St. Louis, has paid two visits to Honduras within the last six months. The first time president Bogram granted him a concession for a national bank.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--In the House to-day the concurrent resolution providing for the final adjournment of the session next Wednesday, the 28th inst., was agreed to, after some discussion, by a vote of l45 to 36.
BOSTON, July 21.--The Washingtons were shut out here to-day. Shaw was batted hard, while Radbourn proved a puzzler for the visitors.

WORCESTER, Mass., July 21.--To-day's session of the Quarterly Convention of District No. 30, Knights of Labor, was almost entirely taken up with the election of delegates to the National Convention, at Richmond, in October. George E. McNeil, the Secretary and Treasurer of the district, insisted on the acceptance of his resignation of both offices, and Henry M. Nelson, of Georgetown, was chosen his successor.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 21.--A meeting of the Republican State Executive Committee was held here to-night for the purpose of making preliminary arrangements for the holding of the State Convention in this city on Aug. 25.

The Sunday school of the Mount Horeb African Methodist Episcopal Church is to have a great time at its first anniversary to-night, in Mission Hall, No. 1,552 Third-avenue.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, July 21.--The Hawk Eye publishes to-day special reports from numerous points in Southern and Eastern Iowa regarding the drought and the crops. With the exception of a few light local showers there has been no rain for six weeks.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 21.--Last night was an exceptionally good one for Congressman Beach, who is ill at his Cornwall home, and his condition was better to-day than it had been this week. Hopes of his ultimate recovery are stronger to-night than they have been for some days.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 21.--Several days ago 11 miners employed at Elmwood Colliery, at Mahanoy City, operated by the Philadelphia and Reading Coal and Iron Company, were discharged for interfering with non-union men.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 21.--Reports received to-day from the scene of the terrible collision near Duck River Station, on the Decatur, Division, of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad, last night show that the disaster was even more frightful than at first reported. The red flag of the Sheriff's auctioneer hung limp and dripping in front of Purssell's bakery and restaurant, at No. 910 Broadway, yesterday morning, and fully 400 persons pressed in when the doors were opened. The sale began with the wine cellar, and the first lot, a cash of claret, was sold for exactly, $1. Nine bins of assorted liquors went for $200, while 31 cases of Chablis and champagne brought only $67.
Commodore D.B. Harmony has been designated to act as Secretary of the Navy in the absence of Secretary Whitney.

CHICAGO, July 21.--Arthur P. Seymour, the late manager of the Chicago Sun, who is under arrest on a charge of embezzlement preferred by the late bookkeeper of the company, said today: "It is all spite work, and the charge that I have embezzled any of the funds of the paper is as absurd as it is false.
LONDON, July 21.--The steamship Oceanic, (Br.,) Capt. Thompson from San Francisco June 22, arr. at Hong-Kong to-day.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., July 21.--Mrs. E. P. Bond has resigned as speaker of the Free Congregational Society, at Florence to accept a position in the College of the Society of Friends at Swarthmore, Penn.

One of the friends of George Ehret, the boycotted brewer, tells me that that man is one of the most downcast mortals on the globe just now. No, he is in no humor for a surrender. He has got lots of fight in him and promises to spend a good deal of money before he puts out a white flag. But George Ehret has always had one special pride up to this time.
CHICAGO, July 21.--A young man who claims to belong to the Swiss aristocracy was yesterday sentenced by Judge Williamsen to 60 days' imprisonment in the county jail. The name he gives is Joseph Gmur.

GREENSBURG, Ky., July 21.--Clem Bishop, aged 70 years, was married to Retta Boston, his ward, aged not over 9 years. Bishop is a backwoods doctor and preacher. His wife died about two weeks ago, and the neighbors threatened to take Retta, whom he had adopted, from him.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21.--Counsel for Charles L. Webster, of New-York, and Samuel L. Clemens, of Connecticut, the owners of the copyright of Gen. Grant's Memoris, applied to Judge Butler, in the United states Circuit Court, to-day for a preliminary injunction to restrain a dealer of this city from selling the book, on the ground that it is a subscription book and not sold in the book trade. The court will hear the argument Aug. 3.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., July 21.--The Rev. Dr. Talmage, with his wife and family reached here yesterday for the Summer. He will preach next Sunday evening on the Battery Park Grounds.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 21.--Nobody in Bridgeport talks of anything but the collision near the New-York, New-Haven and Hartford Railroad station yesterday afternoon, and the scene of the accident has had hundreds of visitors to-day.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., July 21.--Gov. Marmaduke has granted a respite to John T. Leabo, who was to have been hanged on Friday next, until Aug. 6. The Governor will in the meantime examine into the case, and determine the truth of the charge that the man murdered his wife. Many believe that he is innocent.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., July 21.--In the Sanga mon Circuit Court to-day in the suit of the people against the Illinois Central Railroad Company, on the charge of unjust discrimination in charging a higher rate of fare from Chicago to Kankakee than to Mattoon, the jury returned a verdict against the railroad, and a fine of $1,000 is imposed.

CHICAGO, July 21.--Both Western and Northwestern freight affairs are being rapidly straightened out. Much less difficulty is being found by the General Freight Agents and the Commissioners in getting matters into good shape again than was anticipated.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 21.--Gen. Henry N. Frisbie, lately convicted of attempting to defraud the Government by presenting a false pension claim, was to-day released from custody. Judge Billings fined him $1,000.

The Queen has recently fitted up a private chapel at Osborne, for use when it is inconvenient to attend service at Whippingham Church, and above the altar three new pictures by Sir Noel Paton, which he has painted by her Majesty's command, are to be placed.

ROCHESTER, July 21.--The veterans of the Twenty-seventh New-York Volunteers, the regiment originally commanded by Gen. H.W. Slocum, and which was recruited in Western New-York, held its reunion and celebrated the twenty-fifth anniversary of the first battle of Bull Run to-day. Congressman Charles S. Baker is President of the association. A banquet was served to-night, and to-morrow the veterans will go to Charlotte.

LIMA, July 21, via Galveston.--At a public meeting held here on Sunday last it was resolved to petition the Government to expel the Jesuits from the country. The feeling against this class is daily becoming more intense. El Comercia recommends that the Government take the matter in hand and treat it in a spirit of moderation and justice.
The second annual report of Messrs, E.P. Wheeler, E.L. Godkin, and E.R. Robinson, the Supervisory Board of Commissioners of the New-York Municipal Civil Service, has just been published.

The Committee on Construction of the Aqueduct Commission yesterday reported in favor of reorganizing the force of the chief engineer. Under the plan proposed the engineering corps is to be divided into five divisions, to be in charge of the principal assistant engineers and five assistant engineers.

PHILADELPHIA, July 21.--At the meeting of the Retail Boot and Shoe Dealers' Association of the United States to-day, J.K. Brown, of Worcester, was eleeted President, S.J. Arkush, of New-York, Secretary, and George Cantrell, of New-York.

OTTAWA, Ontario, July 21.--Frank Hawken, Assistant Postmaster of Ottawa, has returned from Newfoundland, where he was sent at the request of the Colonial Government to reorganize the postal service of the island. He reports that the Newfoundlanders are clamoring for more frequent mails with England and the United States. Hawken also observed that NewYork and Boston merchants were rapidly taking the import trade away from Halifax and Montreal houses.

CHICAGO, July 21.--Several Board of Trade men met with the Railroad and Warehouse Commissioners yesterday and asked that Turkish wheat and red wheat be graded in the future so that a certain percentage of the Turkish could go with the red wheat. The matter was taken under consideration by the Commissioners.

ROME, N.Y., July 21.--William Pierce, of Gloversville, a horsethief, and John Kockiser, of Booneville, a forger, escaped from the jail in this city last night by cutting a bar out of a window grating in the corridor. A scaffolding allowed them to get over the high fence surrounding the jail. The prisoners' cells were not locked. George Penner, of Sauquoit, the only other prisoner confined, preferred to remain.
I find that the Presidential nominations in 1888 are becoming matters of general interest all over the country, and that people are talking of candidates and their prospects.

PORT JERVIS, N.Y., July 21.--The lasters and finishers of the Buckley Shoe Factory, of this place, struck yesterday against a proposed reduction in the prices paid for some parts of their work. LONDON, July 21.--Mrs. Crawford resumed her testimony to-day in the Crawford divorce case. Mrs. Crawford asserted that she believed that it was Mrs. Rogerson who wrote the anonymous letters accusing the witness of adultery with Capt. Foster, and that her object was to screen Dilke.

NEW-ORLEANS, July 21.--Last saturday Detectives Gastor and Cain arrested a young man who represented himself as the Rev. H.J. Nethercott, of Honduras, and claimed to be a duly ordained and commissioned Episcopalian clergyman.

DETROIT, Mich., July 21.--Another case of smallpox has been discovered in this city. Miss Mary Arnold, of Clinton-street, is the victim. She has been working in Leonard Lawrence's picture frame factory, and 40 girls working with her have been exposed. Health Officer Wight fears an epidemic.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 21.--James C. Frink, residing here, has been held in $2,000 bail for the action of the United States Grand Jury for obtaining a pension on fraudulent affidavits. CHICAGO, July 21.--The supply of Cattle today was in excess of the demand, and at the close fully 2,000 head remained unsold. POTTSVILLE, Penn., July 21.--A year ago, when Bettie Keefe's head was chopped off by Sallie O'Neil, her nephew's wife, the act was so horrible that there was but little difficulty in acquitting her on the ground of insanity. She has been getting worse ever since, and has been confined in the county prison. To-day she was taken to the State asylum at Harrisburg for treatment. She is believed to be a hopeless maniac.

Lyon, charged with keeping his barber's shop open on Sundays by the Barbers' Protective Association, was dismissed by Police Magistrate Jenysh this morning. It was a test case. BOSTON, July 21.--Alfred A. Marcus recently lost a package containing $5,000 worth of diamonds. It was found in the Tremont House by the Rev. C.W. Scott, Principal of an academy at Greenwich, R.I., and advertised. On recovering his gems Mr. Marcus presented Mr. and Mrs. Scott each with a gold watch valued at $100 and $100 in cash.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 21.--The hop at the Congress Monday night was the largest of the season. The master of ceremonies estimated the number of people present at "500 men and women and one dude." The floor was inconveniently crowded.

FARMINGTON, Me., July 21.--Thomas Vachon, a Frenchman, aged 32 years, and Charles Gould, aged 22 years, were drowned in North Pond, Wilton, yesterday afternoon. Vachon got beyond his depth and Gould went to his aid and, in a struggle, both sank. The bodies were recovered.

DELHI, N.Y., July 21.--A personal encounter on the principal street of the village between two foremost members of the county Bar and the suit for $15,000 damages growing out of the affray formed the chief topic of conversation in all circles hereabout.

The Executive Committee of the Association of the United Lager Beer Brewers of NewYork City and vicinity met in the association's building at No. 2 Irving-place at noon yesterday. Henry Clausen, presided. George Ehret, upon whose business a secret boycott is doing heavy damage, is one of the committee, and was in attendance.

It was Coney Island's dull day yesterday. The rain kept the customary crowds away and few visitors were on the island. Most of those who were there gathered in groups on the broad piazza of the Hotel Brighton, opposite which the surf and Cappa's Band ran opposition concerts.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--The bill for the increase of the naval establishment, which the House will be called upon to consider to-morrow, has been modified in several important particulars since its introduction, all but one of the changes being in the direction of retrenchment.

ALBANY, July 21.--Gov. Hill and a party of friends enjoyed the races of the concluding day of the annual regetta of the National Association of Amateur Oarsmen, at Pleasure Island, this afternoon. The attendance was much larger than yesterday. A strong south wind blew up the stream, making fast time impossible, but not spoiling the condition of the water. The races were all well contested.
HOHOKUS, N.J., July 21.--Joe Jefferson, with his wife, has just returned from a salmon fishing trip up in Canada, where they had the finest of sport.

WASHINGTON, July 21.--The President sent the following nominations to the Senate today: Eugene Potter Stone, of Massachusetts, to be an Assistant Surgeon in the navy; First Lieut. Seldan A. Day Fifth Artillery to be Captain Second Lieut. J. Walker Benet, Fifth Artillery, to be First Lieutenant; Additional Second Lieut. G.W.S. Stevens, Fourth Artillery, to be a Second Lieutenant; First Lieut. David B. Wilson, Twenty-fifth Infantry, to be Captain.

The Dwyers only started one horse during the day.

BOSTON, July 22.--Boston defeated Washington to-day by heavy batting. The visitors put in Fuller, their new pitcher, and he was batted for 19 total bases.

BALTIMORE, July 22.--Thomas Conway, 17 years old, died to-day from the effect of rat poison which he took yesterday. A few days ago his father told him that he must go to work and learn to make a living for himself. He said he would die before he would go to work. His father was determined, so Thomas took the poison.
WASHINGTON, July 22.--Ensign Thomas Worthington has resigned from the navy, and his resignation has been accepted, to take effect June 30.

DECATUR, Texas, July 23.--There is now, near Chico, in Jack County, about 10,000 head of cattle drifting or being driven toward the southeast, down the West Fork of the Trinity. The citizens of Wise County, on West Fork, are organizing preparatory to resisting and driving the cattle back.

The following notice was posted on the bulletin board of the Sub-Treasury yesterday: "On and after Aug. 1, 1886, all gold coin below legal weight will, under instructions received from the Secretary of the Treasury, be stamped 'light,' as the same is presented at the Sub-Treasury."

BOSTON, July 22.--Mr. John Boyle, O'Reilly said to a reporter last night: "I regard the treaty, as drafted and signed by our Minister in London, as an abominable document, which I do not believe the Senate will pass, and which I trust will relegate the secretary of State to the private position which his performance of his public duty has earned for him."

ALBANY, July 22.--This is the biggest day Albany has ever seen. From the break of day, when a bicentennial salute of 200 guns ushered in the new century of municipal life, until nearly midnight the place has been thronged with visitors to witness the great list of attractions. The railroads hare had more passengers than they can handle.

LAPORTE, Ind., July 22.--A boat capsized in Pine Lake this afternoon, and Frank Malloy and Mrs. Rose Stern were drowned. Young Malloy was a son of Mrs. Emma Malloy, temperance advocate. Mrs. Stern was the daughter of Jacob Wile, of Laporte.
NEWPORT, R.I., July 22.--Good weather continues and Newport is prospering despite the fact that the hotels are not filling up as expected.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., July 22.--Coroner Holt to-day made his investigation into the cause of the collision of the Boston express and the gravel train on Tuesday. Andrew Canfield, conductor of the gravel train, testified that the signal was set for him to go ahead, and for the express train to stop.

BOSTON, July 22.--The news of the suspension of the Bridgewater Iron Company yesterday caused much surprise in Boston. This corporation was one of the oldest in the country and was formerly very properous. For many years an annual dividend of 40 per cent.

GREENVILLE, Texas, July 22.--Harry Childress, of this place, is in receipt of a handsome medal from the English War Department, in recognition of service in the Soudan campaign of 1884 and 1885. MILWAUKEE, July 23.--B.G. Plummer, one of the principal lumbermen of the Wisconsin River committed suicide yesterday by blowing out his brains with a shotgun. His body was found in his room this morning.

READING, Penn., July 23.--Howard Drumm, 7 years old, with several other boys, went swimming in the Schuylkill this afternoon. He became separated from his companions, going further up the stream. His absence was not noticed until his body floated down the river past them. He was probably seized with cramps.

BOSTON, July 23.--The steamer Merrimac, of the Boston, Halifax and Charlestown Line, completed her second trip of the season last evening, anchoring off Boston Light about 9 o'clock. The Merrimac made the run from Halifax to Boston Light in less than 29 hours, beating all previous records by nearly five hours.

BERLIN, July 24.--The trial of the Socialist Deputies, Bebel, Stollmar, Viereck, Frohme, and others, will open at Freyberg, Saxony, on Monday next. They are charged with having organized a secret society whose aim is to impede the execution of the laws.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July 21.--George Stalter, a cooper by trade, who has been out of employment for some time, was arrested last night by Game Warden Ward and fined $25 by Justice Rezner for shooting robins. An investigation confirmed his story.

MEDINA, N.Y., July 25.--This town is excited over the attempted suicide of Mrs. Charles Reynolds, aged 25. She was married but a few years ago and her husband's brutality and dissipation broke her heart. Last night she took an ounce of laudanum and endeavored to thwart all efforts to resuscitate her, but she will probably be saved. She threatens to repeat the attempt at the first opportunity.

BUENOS AYRES, July 25, via Galveston.-- Sarah Bernhardt, the French actress, made her first appearance on the stage here last night and again appeared to-night. She received tremenous ovations at each performance. The ticket office receipts amounted to over $11,000 per night. For the series of 20 plays for which Miss Bernhardt is engaged the sale of tickets so far has realized about $85,000.

ST. LOUIS, July 25.--Judge-Advocate J.J. McGarry, of District Assembly No. 101, of the Knights of Labor, has been nominated to contest the Congressional district which the Hon. John M. Glover now represents in the House of Representatives. There are 17 Knights of Labor assemblies in the district, the 5,500 members of which have pledged themselves to vote for the Judge-Advocate. The total number of voters in the district is about 17,000.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., July 25.--Considerable excitement has been occasioned by the discovery of rich copper mines in Searcy County, this State.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 25.--A new and important question has been raised under the local option law since liquor was voted out of Raleigh Township. The law makes it unlawful to sell liquor until the result of said elections has been reversed by an election.

CHICAGO, July 25.--Gov. R.A. Alger and staff passed through this city to-day on their way to California. His guests comprised Senator and Mrs. John A. Logan, Mrs. and the Misses Alger, and several lady relatives of the family.

Since the first appearance of the cholera in Japaa this year, and up to June 20, there have been 10,276 cases of the disease, 7,803 of which have been fatal. The average death rate per 100 has been 75.93. The total number of cholera cases which occurred throughout the country, from Aug. 23 to Nov. 30, last year, was 11,927, of which 7,152 proved fatal, the death rate being 59.96.

EL PASO, Texas, July 25.--The excitement on both sides of the river among Mexicans as well as Americans has been so great that both Governments have concluded, for the purpose of allaying it, to conduct further negotiations without publicity. For that reason Consul Brigham had no further official advices yesterday on the all-absorbing subject of the Cutting imprisonment.

LONG BRANCH, July 25.--It is unquestionably cottage life that makes this place the great Summer resort that it is. The hotels still do a large business, and always will because of the easy accessibility of the place, and because it is on the line of travel around the chain of watering places.

PITTSBURG, Penn., July 25.--Thomas Dallard, a colored miner of McDonald, Penn., died to-night from the effects of injuries received a week ago in a quarrel with his wife.

Capt. E.O. Smith, of the police boat Patrol, started out yesterday morning determined to stop violations of the excise law on excursion boats. He detailed officers to go aboard each of several barges and remain throughout the day, and then he cruised patiently about, awaiting the return of the excursions.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 25.--The widespread disintegration that exists in political affairs in this State is exemplified in the recent coalition of a portion of the Republicans of Craven County and the Democratic Party of that county.

MOUNT WASHINGTON, N.H., July 25.-- The great snow arch, which remains intact until late in the Summer in the depths of Tuckerman's Ravine, is always one of the features for White Mountain visitors, and many parties visit it daily.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--The Central Labor Union met at Sixth and Walnut streets today and passed a resolution requesting all the members of the various unions to discontinue drinking George Ehret's beer.

A statue of Diderot, in which he is represented in his dressing gown and sitting as if en gaged in a familiar and argumentative conversation, was unveiled to-day in the Place Saint Germain des Pres. The Municipal Council and Prefect of the Seine attended the ceremony. The sculptor Gautherin was inspired by Houdiot's portrait and a sketch of the encyclopedist in one of Grimin's letters.
The Cigarmakers' Progressive Union held one of the liveliest mass meetings ever known in its history yesterday morning at the Germania Assembly Rooms.

LONDON, July 25.--The twelfth round in the International Chess Tournament will be played to-morrow, and it is almost certain to decide the contest for the two highest prizes. It is now believed that the winners will be Blackburne and Taubenhaus.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 25.--A CourierJournal special says: "In Graves County, Ky., the two Crittenden boys, under arrest for stabbing Alvin Wheeler, attempted to escape by knocking Constable Milton down. Milton shot and killed one man and mortally wounded the other. The Crittendens attacked and cut Wheeler seriously for reporting them for selling liquor without a license."

DANVILLE, Va., July 25.--Some time between midnight last night and this morning Charles Lund, a tailor from Stockholm, Sweden, but who had lived in Boston and other cities of this country, committed suicide by drowning in the Dan River. Drink and a discharge from work was the cause.
At Arctic Park yesterday the Senator Baseball Club won a game from the Orchard Club by a score of 9 to 6.

Vague rumors are already afloat to the effect that after the electrical subways are constructed under the supervision of the Commissioners the western Union Telegraph Company will decline to make use of them and will go into court on the plea that the act of 1885, under which the commission was appointed, is unconstitutional.

LONDON, July 25.--Discount was quiet during the week at for three months and for short. Business on the Stock Exchange was inactive, except in American railway securities, in which a brisk business was done, the market displaying a buoyant tone.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 25.--The refusal of the majority of saloon keepers in the State to pay the tax imposed by the Dow law in the absence of a decision upon the constitutionality of the law has already had the effect of awakening the people.
GAINESVILLE, Texas, July 25.--Information reached here to-day of an outrage upon a little girl, which occurred near Dexter, in the northeast part of this county, last Friday evening.

He will, instead of going to Congress, start a bank. Just at the present time the corrupt bank officials are holding up their end about as well as corrupt politicians, either in or out of Congress.

CHICAGO, July 25.--Mr. Palmer's Madison-Square company closed its engagement of seven weeks at McVicker's Theatre last evening, and departed for San Francisco, where it is to open next week.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 25.--The Canadian Government will send a steamer from Quebec to the coast of Newfoundland and Labrador to carry such donations as charitably disposed persons may desire to send to the starving people there.

PHILADELPHIA, July 25.--Augustus Bryrd, 17 years old, of Atlanta, Ga.., was struck by a passenger train on the New-York Division of the Pennsylvania Railroad, in the northern part of the city, last night, and instantly killed. He had stepped from one track to another to avoid a train, and did not notice the second train coming from an opposite direction.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., July 25.--With the temperature at 100 in the shade and climbing higher, about 2,000 perspiring singers of the 2,500 who were to have taken part in the elaborate Saengerfest parade planned for to-day discreetly remained away.

LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 25.--Robert Hamilton, a soldier in the Twenty-eighth Regiment, New-York Volunteers, and Fifteenth Cavalry, New-York Volunteers, in the late war, committed suicide this morning at 6 o'clock at his residence in this city.

CHICAGO, July 26.--What threatened to be a tie-up of the north side street car lines was happily averted to-day by mutual concessions, asked mainly for changes in some offensive regulations.

BOSTON, July 26.--The steamer Gate City, which ran ashore on Naushon Island July 18, came slowly up the harbor this morning under her own steam and convoyed by the tugs Steam King and Confidence. The huge canvas boot under her bow worked to perfection, and but little effort was required to keep her free of water.

BOSTON, July 26.--The labor troubles at the great pork-packing establishment of John P. Squire Sons, at Cambridge, reached a climax to-night when Mr. Squires discharged every one of his 750 employes. Several weeks ago the workmen asked for an increase of about 30 per cent. in their wages.
