MONTE CHRISTI, San Domingo, July 6.-- The Colonel has demanded that I make him an abject apology for a grave sin of omission, and I hereby and most cheerfully make it. The obese but valiant Colonel is married.

A trip which was made by the Brazilian Prince, Dom Augusto Leopoldo, to Coney Island yesterday was begun auspiciously, but the party was thrown into great excitement and disorder by the finding of a lighted bomb on the boat on which the party returned.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 26.--A dense, damp fog hangs over the city to-night, but the day has been unusually pleasant. The sad, mysterious death of Gen. James H. Van Alen has cast a gloom over the place. The New-York papers were eagerly read for the latest news regarding the affair, which was the sole topic of discussion in society and by the local residents, who knew and respected the deceased.

CHICAGO, July 26.--A dynamite bomb, 18 inches long and 2 inches in circumference, was found yesterday secreted in a barrel of straw on the fourth floor of Wilbur Allen's crockeryware house, No. 23 East Washington-street.

LONDON, July 26.--The Standard, commenting on the proposed convention extending the extradition provisions of the treaty of 1842 between England and the United States, says: "The fact that it will be in the power of the United States to make the surrender clause inoperative is all the more a reason why the United States should not refuse us this slight proof of sympathy in difficulties which may soon be her own."

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 26.--Advices from Comanche County state that a mob hanged the negro boy who recently murdered Mrs. Stephens. The mob was bent on burning him, but the mother of the murdered woman pleaded for a less barbarous punishment. Just previous to the hanging the boy confessed the crime.
CHICAGO, July 26.--Officer Timmons, of the town of Lake police, was shot and seriously wounded yesterday by Joseph Steffen. Two Germans were assaulted and beaten by three Bohemians.

ESCANABA, Mich., July 26.--John E. and Sidney Mills, nephews of A. Booth, of Chicago, were drowned Saturday off Manistique. They were on a tug on their way from Thompson to Manistique, and in the heavy sea running Sidney fell overboard. His brother jumped in after him, and both were drowned. Every effort was made to rescue them, but the sea was running so high that it was useless.

CHICAGO, July 26.--The following table shows the vissible supply of grain in the United States and Canada on July 24, and the increase or decrease compared with the previous week's report: Wheat, 32,187,444 bushels; increase, 2,948,170 bushels; Corn, 9,450,093 bushels; increase, 132,445 bushels; Oats, 1,147,243 bushels; decrease, 906,703 bushels; Rye, 301,234 bushels; increase, 59,174 bushels; Barley, 213, 978 bushels; decrease, 6,261 bushels.

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 26.--Hess No. 2, an oil well owned by the People's Light and Heat Company, was set on fire this afternoon by a stroke of lightning. Two tanks, containing 1,000 barrels of oil, were consumed, as were also the derrick and several thousand feet of cable. The company's loss will be not less than $2,500, on which is an insurance of but $500. Several stacks of hay were also destroyed.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26.--Two seamen on the brig Isabella Balcom, which sailed to-day for Rio Janeiro, deserted when off Chester. One of them apparently succeeded in reaching shore, but the other was drowned. Capt. Peters and the first mate of the ship Favorita, (German,) which sailed from this port on Saturday for Fiume, were assaulted by one of the sailors. The latter was brought back to Philadelphia by a waterman and arrested.

MORRIS, Conn., July 26.--All last night the body of murderer Lockwood lay in an old shed which used to be utilized as a pig pen, and this morning the visitors who came to find out what was going on in the case found very few developments.

FABYAN HOUSE, N.H., July 26.--Willie Gleason, aged 14 years, a bellboy at the Mount Pleasant House, was left in charge of the elevator this morning. He climbed to the top and started the elevator. His head was caught between the beam and the ceiling and crushed. He was dead when found.

NORFOLK, Va., July 26.--Demetrius G. Maximos, a prominent cotton buyer of this city, on Saturday hired a boat to go crabbing. He did not return, and his boat was found to-day with his clothing in it. He had tied the anchor to his body and jumped overboard. No cause is assigned for the suicide.

Previous to May, 1886, a party desiring to obtain a review by the Court of Appeals of a decision of the City Court of New-York was required to appeal to the General Term of the Common Pleas and then, if permission was granted by the latter court, to the Court of Appeals.

MILFORD, Mass., July 26.--J.R. Spanlding Co. have failed. Their liabilities are $16,000. Their assets are scattering. The firm failed a year ago and compromised. The present creditors think that there were fraudulent preferences in the previous failure.

ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 26.--Further particulars of the distress among the fishermen of Labrador have been received. The seventy Esquimaux who demanded food from the stores at Mugford, which could not be given them, owing to the needs of the inhabitants and the small supply, made a rush for the harbor storehouse, where the flour and fish were stored.

NOGALES, Arizona, July 26.--The trouble growing out of the Medina-Cutting affair at El Paso del Norte has undoubtedly been amicably settled. The Supreme Judge of Chihuahua, the only Supreme Judge of the Mexican States, ordered the arrest and confinement of Editor Medina and the liberation of Editor Cutting.

CHICAGO, July 26.--According to a publication made here this afternoon the continued lack of rain in many portions of the country is awakening serious alarm. While not unprecedented, the drought already is of more than ordinary length and severity.
BOSTON, July 26.--The first half of a cricket match between the Longwoods and Montreals to-day resulted in a score of: Longwoods, 282; Montreals, 68.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 26.--The coldblast pipe leading from one furnace to another at the Pennsylvania Steel Works, at Steelton, exploded this morning with a terrific report, which was heard in this city.

The new war vessel Atlanta is just at present a scene of bustle and apparent confusion. She lies at her dock at the navy yard finished to all appearances on the outside, excepting as to rigging.
CHICAGO, July 26.--The full force and meaning of the testimony of the Pinkerton men in the Anarchists' trial will hardly be understood until more of it is put in. There is more of it to come.

Anton Flath, of No. 371 Bedford-avenue, Brooklyn, shot himself in the head with a revolver at his home yesterday afternoon, and died last night at the Eastern District Hospital. For some time Fiath had been worried over business troubles, and it is supposed that he committed suicide while temporarily insane. He leaves a wife and six children.

The Cigarmakers' Progressive Union and the Cigarmakers' International Union, which for many years have been at swords' points with each other, have concluded a peace, and the probabilities are that before many days the former will be amalgamated with the Internationals.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 26.--Sight drafts on New-York, 10; telegraphic, 15.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26.--The Athletics could not hit Hecker to-day, and so the Louisvilles scored an easy victory. Hart, formerly of the Chattanoogas, was given a trial as pitcher by the local club, and he did far better than any of the Athletic's recent experiments.
RONDOUT, N.Y., July 26.--The official investigation of the collision between the steamer City of Kingston, of Rondout, and the schooner Mary Atwater of Wilbur, near Fort Montgomery.

The Cincinnati Club won a game from the Metropolitans on the St. George Grounds yesterday by figures of 4 to 1. The Mets led in the batting, but they lost several chances to score by poor base running.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The Senate Committee on Appropriations this morning finished its work upon the Fortifications Appropriation bill, and the measure was reported by the Chairman to the Senate. It contains a number of important amendments. A provision appropriating $50,000 to continue the sea wall around Governor's Island has been added.

The capture of a brigand near Bocchigliere, a hamlet situated in a remote part of the Calabrian highlands, has revealed the existence in that region of an extensive sect remarkable alike for the wildness of its tenets and the nefarious character of its practices.
PARIS, July 26.--A violent anonymous attack has been made here on the Panama Canal enterprise. The attack is made in a pamphlet, strongly written, and containing 70 pages.

Attorney-General O'BRIEN'S refusal to ask the courts to dissolve the corporation known as the Consolidated Gas Company will surprise no one, for his remarks during the hearing upon the application indicated what his decision would be.

The Grant Monument Association yesterday received through the New-York Evening Post $100 from "cash," making the total to date $122,575.94.

The creditors of M.H. Green, printer, electrotyper, and binder, Nos. 326, 328, and 330 Pearl-street, were not in a very happy frame of mind yesterday after they found that the firm had left the city without making provision for the payment of any debts.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The New-York ball players took ample revenge for Saturday's defeat by administering a tremendous thrashing to the home club to-day. Keefe pitched skillfully, and was supported in an almost faultless manner, a missed third strike by Deasley in the ninth inning and a passed ball by O'Rourke being the only errors.

Charlotte Barkels, 38 years old, who has been engaged as a cook at No. 20 East Sixtyseventh-street, shot herself yesterday afternoon, inflicting a serious wound just below the heart. She was taken to the Presbyterian Hospital and transferred thence to Bellevue.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 26.--John Hays, the young man charged with assault with intent to kill upon the person of Edward Russell on June 24, was held to await the action of the Grand Jury by Recorder Waring at Newburg today. The request of defendant's counsel that his client be admitted to bail was denied, and he was again remanded to jail.

Railroad earnings for the third week of July were reported in Wall-street yesterday, as follows: Northwest, $476,200, an increase of $3,300 compared with the same period last year; Omaha, $109,900, an increase of $7,500; Buffalo, ...

TROY, N.Y., July 26.--Sanford Lott, aged 14 years, was killed this morning in the carding department of the Mount Ida Cotton Mill. In attempting to adjust a belt his clothing caught in the machinery and he was whirled round a shaft going at the rate of 150 revolutions a minute for four minutes before the machinery could be stopped.

Miss Sharpe--Are you fond of waltzing, Mr. Slimdood? Mr. Slimdood--Oh, excessively! I could waltz forever in a dream of enchantment.

SHENANDOAH, Penn., July 26.--A serious riot took place between two gangs of Italian and Hungarian laborers on the new Pennsylavania Schuylkill Valley Railroad, between Delano and Hazleton, this afternoon.

PHILADELPHIA, July 26.--President Gowen, of the Reading Railroad Company, was at his office to-day, and appeared to be in the most sanguine state of mind possible. While in NewYork he had long conferences with his backers, ...

Last Saturday the Philadelphia Press presented a statement showing that out of 3,887 Post Offices in the State of Pennsylvania "after sixteen months of an Administration violently addicted to civil service reform, 2,040--nearly 53 per cent.--were in the hands of Democrats."

LONDON, July 26.--In the twelfth round of the masters' chess tournament, which was played to-day, every game was an important one. Mackenzie was defeated by Lipschutz and thereby lost his chances for any of the prizes. Taubenhaus was beaten by Burn and thereby lost his chance for the first prize.

MILWAUKEE, July 26.--Last night a heavy rainstorm set in and it lasted until an early hour this morning. The rain is reported to be quite general throughout the State, and will save the crops in many sections.
Steamship Leipzig, (Ger.,) Christoffers, Bremen July 10, with mdse. and passengers to Oelrichs Co. Bark Nimbus, (of Windsor, N.S.,) Smith, London 46 ds., with mdse. to order--vessel to C.W. Bertaux.

The Electrical Subway Commissioners will meet to-day at 3:30 P.M. to hear the report of the Consolidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company as to the construction of the contract provisionally entered into, and to finally sign, seal, and deliver the contract if the report of the company should be deemed satisfactory.

A certain collector of prints, whom it will be safe to call A, is little liked by his fellow-collectors, who affirm that he buys prints he does not wish simply to annoy the people who do want them, and that he is perfectly capable of all sorts of underhanded practices to gain an advantage.

It is singular that while the name of JOHN KELLY is known to every citizen of the United States who takes any interest in politics the fame of HUBERT O. THOMPSON should almost be confined to this city. Yet Mr. THOMPSON was a boss in the same sense and to the same extent as Mr. KELLY.

WASHINGTON, July 26.--The House will be asked to-morrow by its conferrees on the River and Harbor bill to vote upon the Hennepin Canal, Sturgeon Bay Canal, and Portage Lake Canal amendments, and it is expected that there will be a renewal of the contest over the NewYork Harbor appropriation.

CHICAGO, July 26.--Benjamin F. McNeill filed a bill in the Circuit Court to-day against the World's Pastime Exposition Company to foreclose a trust deed made to him of the leasehold interests and personal property of the company at Cheltenham Beach, and also asking the appointment of a Receiver.

RICHMOND, Va., July 26.--Charles C. Crutchfield, a car inspector at the Richmond and Petersburg Railroad station in this place, was killed to-day by being caught between a locomotive tender and a car while attending to some of his duties.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 26.--One of the results of the action of the Senate in refusing to investigate the charges as to the purchase of the seat occupied by Senator Payne will probably be the election of Gen. Robert P. Kennedy to Congress in the Eighth Ohio District.

PITTSBURG, July 26.--The damage by this morning's storm was much greater than was at first supposed, and will probably reach $350,000. The storm appears to have been confined to Western Pennsylvania, and was the most severe known for many years.
There was a sweepstakes race for catrigged boats, under 20 feet in length, over the Pavonia Yacht Club's course yesterday. The contest was arranged by Murphy Brothers, of Communipaw.

GALENA, Ill., July 26.--Conrad Wiseman, a farmer living in the town of Hanover, this county, was arrested to-day on a charge of murdering his son, a lad about 12 years of age, and after examination held for the next Grand Jury without bail. From the testimony it appears that the child was kicked and pounded Saturday by his unnatural father in punishment for some slight disobedience, and died yesterday from the effects of his injuries.

The late Cardinal Archbishop was a type of old-fashioned Catholicism. He hated rosewater devotion, and practiced what he preached in mortifying the body and giving every centime that he did not spend on his few personal wants to the poor.

PARIS, July 9.--The funeral of Daniel Douglas Home excited no curiosity here. The Russian chapel in the Rue Daru was brilliantly lighted, and about 20 persons, in the gorgeous display of full evening dress, assisted at the ordinary ceremony.

NORFOLK, Va., July 26.--Edward Howard, Assistant Postmaster at Suffolk, Va., has been arrested for a shortage in his accounts and for making false returns to the Post Office Depart ment.

STILLWATER, Minn., July 26.--Mary Smith is a six-foot amazon, who conducts a large and flourishing farm a few miles from here. When she plows she wears men's breeches, and her physical aspect is always intimidating.

ROCHESTER, July 26.--Large numbers of lodges of Knights of Pythias arrived in the city to-night, preparatory for the State convention tomorrow, and were tendered a reception by the local lodges. Fully 1,000 Knights are expected here to-morrow.

On account of the recent annexation of the town of New-Lots to the city of Brooklyn the Volunteer Fire Department of New-Lots will be mustered out of service on Saturday next. To commemorate the event the department had a parade yesterday, in which all the old firemen took part. The town was in holiday attire.

ATOKA, Indian Territory, July 26.--Joe Hampton, a Choctaw, was arrested here to-day by United States Marshals Field, Lefler, and Serrell for the murder of Lewis Berg, a white man, at Cane Switch, 12 miles below here, on the 19th inst.

Benjamin W. Tomlinson, a well known journalist of this city, died yesterday morning at Hanover, Mass. He was a native of Massachusetts and in his forty-second year. During the war he served in the Massachusetts Cavalry, was repeatedly promoted for gallantry, and rose to the rank of Major. PITTSBURG, Penn., July 26.--The chimney and pressed glass factories which have been closed since July 1 for the usual Summer suspension will resume operations next Monday. The prospects are unusually bright, and it is predicted that the output of the coming year will be the largest in the history of the trade.
For some days the employes of the Dock Department have gone to their posts fearing that before night their official heads might roll into the basket.

LONDON, July 27.--Negotiations are proceeding between England and France looking to the withdrawal of French troops from the NewHebrides.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., July 27.--Coroner Van Woert continued his investigation to-day of the death of John Elmer, whose body was disinterred yesterday. Many witnesses were examined, but no light was thrown on the matter.

Having passed a civil service examination and got higher marks than any other competitor for the place, John O. Conway thought he was absolutely entitled to the post of Captain of the steam tug Manhattan, owned by the Dock Commissioners.

WILMINGTON, Del., July 27.--Peninsula growers will commence marketing their peaches in about 10 days. There has been much speculation indulged in concerning the yield, which estimates from very reliable and experienced sources place at upward of 3,000,000 baskets. This is somewhat less than an average crop, but enough to meet all demands.

We are all familiar with the white, blue, and red ensigns, and with the union jack which occupies the upper quarter nearest the flagstaff. The white ensign has the red cross of St. George in addition to the union jack. Without the jack this white ensign with a red cross represents our old national flag as it existed from the time of Richard I. until the death of Elizabeth.

BOSTON, July 27.--The good people of Salem were somewhat startled this morning on finding a bottle off Baker's Island containing a paper on which was written a story that a yachting party was dying of starvation.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 27.--At the first day's meeting of the State Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias, held here to-day, the degree of Past Chancellor was conferred upon a large number of candidates.

MONTREAL, July 27.--From an early hour this morning the streets between Notre Dame Church, where the pallium was conferred on Archbishop Fabre, and the wharf at which the steamer bearing Cardinal Taschereau and party was moored were alive with people. Bolton, Superintendent of the Bureau of Second Class Mail Matter in the Chicago Post Office, and Chief Weigher Stuart would be found to have robbed the Government of well on to to $100,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--The American Baptist Publication Society will meet to-morrow and make formal announcement of the embezzlement of many thousand dollars of the society's funds by William P. Pierson, the head bookkeeper.

The Irish Parliamentary fund was increased yesterday by the following contributions: Citizens of Danbury, Conn., $212; citizens of Perth Amboy, N.J., $32; total, $244.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, July 27.--Reports from 50 stations along the lines of the Burlington, Cedar Rapids and Northern Road show that most of the small grain has been harvested with better results than had been anticipated.

NEWBURG. N.Y., July 27.--Yesterday afternoon, as James Terry, of Middlehope, was leading a bull with a staff attached to a ring in its nose, the staff became unfastened.

Acting District Attorney James Fitzgerald is always ready for a good, hearty laugh, but he was in a very serious mood yesterday when a tall gentleman of solemn appearance entered his office and declared that his mission was one of great importance.

Jaehne, now in Sing Sing Prison under a sentence of nine years and ten months for accepting a bribe of $20,000 for his vote in the Board of Aldermen in 1884 in favor of granting the Broadway Surface Railroad franchise.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--Atkisson was sick today and Hart was again pitted against the batters from Louisville.

BOSTON, July 27.--Gustave Liebman, the operator at the signal office at Cottage City, disappeared mysteriously on the 19th inst. and has not since been seen. His accounts at the signal office are all straight.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--United States District Attorney Valentine brought suit to-day in the Circuit Court to recover a penalty of $1,000 from William Braun, the Manager of Ridgway Park, for a violation of the United States laws relative to the importation of foreign musicians into this country under contract. This case has been before the public once before dur ing this season, and the supposition is that this case will be conclusive.

A lockout in 11 of the 13 brickyards at Verplanck yesterday morning put nearly 900 hands out of work. This meant that the slender income of that community has fallen off $1,000 and will continue to be witheld at that rate per day, until a better underatanding shall be reached than has lately prevailed between the bosses and the men.
MARBLEHEAD, Mass., July 27.--Nothing had been seen of or heard from the English outter Galatea up to 11 o'clock this evening.
SAN FRANCISCO, July 27.--Frederick Reutschler, Vice-President and manager of the Indianapolis Manufacturing Company, committed suicide to-day by shooting himself through the head with a rifle.

The committee of Broadway property owners who are opposed to the construction of the arcade railway, under the provisions of the act passed by the last Legislature, is taking steps to prevent the beginning of the work, and the courts are to be applied to very soon to wind up the Arcade Company, on the ground that the law granting its franchise is unconstitutional.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--By spending six hours in secret session to-day the Senate made some progress toward disposing of the "contested" nominations, which have been pending since last December. The proceedings were again of the very secret order, committee clerks, telegraph operators, and everybody else being driven from the entire upper story of the Senate wing.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--The Executive Committees of the Lehigh and Schuylkill Coal Exchanges met to-day and decided to make no change in the line and city and harbor prices of coal during the month of August.

PHILADELPHIA, July 27.--While the German ship Favorita was being towed down the Delaware yesterday Eric Norgood, a Finn sailor, sprang out of the forecastle and made a dash at the Captain with the intention of killing him.

WASHINGTON, Penn., July 27.--The Royal Gas Company has completed its lines and is now furnishing gas to the glass houses and other manufacturers in Steubenville, Wellsburg, Mingo, and Brilliant, Ohio.

LONDON, July 27.--The Marquis of Salisbury, Lord Randolph Churchill, and Sir Michael Hicks-Beach had a long conference this afternoon. It is reported that Lord Salisbury is having great difficulty in the work of filling the post of Chief Secretary for Ireland, no suitable man desiring to take the office under the new Government.

Whether the Anarchists really attempted to blow up the steamer Sylvan Stream and her passengers with a bomb on Monday night, or whether the whole thing was a grim practical joke, was the subject of a good deal of discussion yesterday.

MANAQUA, Nicaragua, July 27, via Galveston.--Four officers, hostile to the Government, combined with revolutionists and attacked the artillery barracks. The attempt failed, and the officers and the greater part of the revolutionists were arrested. They will be severely punished.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--Barr's pitching to-day gave the New-Yorks another opportunity to increase their batting averages, which they turned to good account, hitting him safely 17 times for a total of 24 bases. Welch proved very effective, five scattering hits only being made off him.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 27.--Just before noon to-day John Koehler shot and killed John Carter and probably fatally wounded Peter Hough. The tragedy occurred in a small twostory frame house in the alley between Main and Market and Preston and Jackson streets, a door below the latter street.

COLUMBIA, S.C., July 27.--Ben and Nat Taylor, sons of Dr. P. W. Taylor, aged respectively 14 and 12, were shooting doves this afternoon on a plantation near here. Nat was kneeling in the long grass, and his brother stood a few feet opposite him. Ben discharged his piece at a flock of doves, and simultaneously Nat arose and received the load in his head, killing him instantly.

FALL RIVER, Mass July 27.--The crew of the schooner Emiline E. Birdsall, which arrived here to-day, report that on last Thursday night, about 20 miles from Barnegat, they saw an unknown two-masted schooner, apparently loaded with kerosene oil, on fire. Both masts had fallen. The schooner Sarah Cullen was near the vessel, and had apparently rescued the crew.

CANAJOHARIE, N.Y., July 27.--The last ray of hope entertained by the hop growers throughout New York State vanished this morning. During the night a heavy rain occurred.

CHEYENNE, Wyoming, July 27.--Reports from various sections of Wyoming Territory indicate that an unusally dry season has followed a snowless Winter. Up to July but little rain had fallen in any part of Wyoming. During the last two weeks there have been many cloudbursts and copious rains in the eastern part of the Territory, filling streams bank high.

VALPARAISO, July 27, via Galveston.--The Presidential Electors chosen in the elections of June last met yesterday throughout the republic and elected Balmaceda President for the next constitutional term, beginning Sept. 18.

READING, Penn., July 27.--Mrs. Catharine Deem, a demented lady, who escaped from St. Joseph's Hospital, this city, four days ago, was driven to shelter from the thunderstorm yesterday in a farmhouse some six miles from here. Her friends were notified and she was taken home. She says that she subsisted on nothing but berries, and often was within sight of her pursuers, whom she managed always to elude.

Some of the names in our list [of men of letters who were married] are not those of authors who depended or depend--for some are still living--on their writings for subsistence, but nearly all depend on their writings for their reputation.

BALTIMORE, July 27.--The west-bound freight train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad broke into two near Mount Airy to-day and the rear part ran down the steep grade, coming into collision with another freight train. The engine of the rear train and several loaded cars were badly wrecked and the tracks blockaded. Passengers here transferred around the wreck to other trains.

BALTIMORE, July 27.--To-day's game was won from the St. Louis champions by the home club with the assistance of Robinson, whose error in the fourth inning let in two runs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, July 27.--The attendance at the opening day of the races was the largest numerically in several years. This is deemed a good omen for the success of the season. A.B. Miller has left his position at the Grand Union to accept one at the Barrett House.

Charles Engle, alias Charles Warren, enjoys the reputation of being one of the most noted second-story thieves in this country. He was arrested at 11 o'clock on Monday night, at Chicago, by Superintendent William A. Pinkerton, of the Western Division of Pinkerton'S Detective Agency.

OMAHA, Neb., July 27.--This morning's Union Pacific train for San Francisco had four carloads of Grand Army people from the departments of New-Jersey and Iowa. This evening a special train of six Pullman cars, a dining car, and a cooking car passed through, having on board S.S. Burdette, Commander-in-Chief, and staff, and escort from posts in the District of Columbia, Virginia, and Maryland, and Gen. Black, Commissioner of Pensions.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 27.--Judge McPherson to-day handed down an opinion that defines the law of 1885 concerning the tax on manufacturing companies. The act of June 30, 1885, abolished the tax on the capital stock of manufacturing companies.

LIMA, July 27. via Galveston.--The Government has declared the resolution of Dec. 16. 1884, which gave the Jesuits public property for use as schools to be null and void, and it has further declared that there being no documents showing that the Jesuits have acquired the right to be recognized as a religions order the Government declines to recognize them as such.

NEW-HAVEN, July 27.--The Morning Newspaper Yacht Club, of New-York, arrived here to-day on the yacht Commodore, and were shown about the city by New-Haven friends. At 2 o'clock to-morrow morning the Commodore will sail to the eastward.

ERIE, Penn., July 27.--The McKean Carriage Works, owned by George S. Wright Co., were closed this evening by the Sheriff on executions amounting to $15,000 issued at the instance of the Dexter Spring Works and others. Adam Brabender, late President of the Erie County Savings Bank, and now in the penitentiary, is believed to be interested in the carriage works.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--The report of Capt. E.E. Potter, commanding the South Atlantic station, who investigated the charges preferred by United States Consul Siler, at Cape Town, against Paymaster Hobbs, of the Juniata, and Paymaster Thompson, of the Lancaster, of fraudulent practice in the purchase of naval supplies at Cape Town, was made public to-day.

LAWRENCE, Mass., July 27.--William B. O'Connor, who brutally hacked to pieces Hannah B. Coway on Sunday, was arraigned in the Police Court this morning. "I give my life for hers, and I am going before my God on that issue," he said. When asked to plead to the charge of willful and malicious murder O'Connor replied: "I am guilty of it."

MATTOON, Ill., July 27.--Frank Kagy, Jr., of Effingham, surprised his freinds on Sunday by returning from a business trip to Washington accompanied by a newly wedded wife.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., July 27.--Jonathan Vail, President of the Citizens' National Bank of Yonkers, died yesterday at his country resiidence, near this village, of pneumonia, aged about 60 years. He was a native of this county, and spent his Summers at his old home. He leaves a widow and son and daughter. His remains will be taken to Yonkers for interment.

BOSTON, July 27.--It has just leaked out that the most intense opposition to the nomination of Congressman Allen in the Eighth Massachusetts District has recently developed in Republican ranks, and from a most peculiar cause.

The atmosphere about Monmouth Park yesterday was heavily laden with moisture. The track was heavy and holding, and the "mud larks" had much the best of it, so that only two favorites succeeded in getting to the front. There were several horses scratched in consequence of the state of the track.

CHICAGO, July 27.--The buildings, stock, and machinery of the Charles W. Allen Manufacturing Company, makers of plug, fine cut, and smoking tobacco at Monroe and Canal streets, was this afternoon taken possession of by a Deputy Sheriff on two confessions of judgment aggregating $120,150.

MADISON, Wis., July 27.--The Prohibition State Convention will convene in this city tomorrow. The Capitol House, which is the headquarters of the Executive Committee, is already packed with delegates, and every train during the night and morning will bring more. It is anticipated that them will be fully 400 in tomorrow's convention.

LOUISIVLLE, July 27.--A report of the death of Dr. High Trigg, who formerly lived near Harrod's Creek, but lately of Westport, reached the city this morning. Friday afternoon he started out to see a patient, remarking that he would be back home shortly.

NEWPORT, R.I., July 27.--Refreshing rains came to hand to-day. The rain was needed and was generally acceptable except to the transient visitors. Quite a number of the cottagers entertained to-day, among whom were Mrs. Hugh T. Dickey, who gave a reception.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, July 27.--The body of a man was found Sunday near the station of the International and Great Northern Railway with a bullet hole through his head. The body is supposed to be that of J.L. Holcomb, of Palestine, Texas, a jail builder and contractor, who was to have met his partner here on Tuesday last with $6,000, but failed to appear.

The bill creating a board to take in charge all matters relating to the protection and improvement of New-York Harbor will not become a law at this session of Congress, for action upon it in the House has been postponed until December. The appropriation of $750,000 for the harbor is in conference.

The contract between the Electrical Subway Commission and the Consalidated Telegraph and Electrical Subway Company, which was provisionally awarded a short time ago, was yesterday formally signed, sealed, and delivered in triplicate, the company retaining one copy and the Commissioners the others.

WASHINGTON, July 27.--Secretary Bayard said to-day, in speaking the Cutting case, that he had no doubt whatever that the Mexican authorities would do what was right in the matter. The somewhat unsettled condition of Mexican affairs just at present might, he thought prevent prompt action in the case, but he had no doubt that pending negotiations will have a satisfactory termination.

PORTLAND, Oregon, July 27.--Jack Dempsey, the middle-weight champion pugilist, was married this morning at St. Francis's Catholic Church, in East Portland, to Miss Maggie Brady, the Rev. Father Veerhaag officiating. Mr. and Mrs. Dempsey will leave to-morrow for San Francisco on a bridal tour. Dempsey announces that he has permanently retired from the prize ring, and that he will engage in business here on his return.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 27.--John Cardwell, a white man, who was to have been hanged at Wilksborough on the 30th inst. for an outrage upon his own daughter, was rescued by a mob of friends, who raided the jail at that place on Monday morning and spirited him away. His whereabouts are unknown. Cardwell was twice respited, but the execution was set finally for the 30th.

MORRIS, Conn., July 27.--There was nobody to weep over the grave of Charles Lockwood, the murderer of Mattie Randell, and the relatives of the dead man made no application to the Litchfield authorities to obtain possession of the body, although they had been notified that it was at their disposal.

The lawyers so far returned to Parliament are about the same in number as were returned last year, but the party divisions are altogether different. There has been considerable slaughter among the Gladstonian lawyers, of whom 38 barristers only have survived, as against 75 Liberal barristers last year, while there are 82 Conservative barristers, as against 55 last year.

J. Beavor-Webb, the designer of the Galatea, arrived in this city from England yesterday afternoon on the steamship Wyoming. Mr. Beavor-Webb went to the Victoria Hotel and spent most of the evening in the rooms of the New-York Yacht Club. As his arrival was not expected there were very few members present to welcome him.

SALEM, Mass., July 27.--Gen. B.F. Butler has been secured as counsel by William B. O'Keefe and Peter McGough, members of the Executive Board of District Assembly No. 77, Knights of Labor, arrested on a warrant for conspiracy in boycotting the leather manufactured by Charles Harrington Co.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 27.--A dispatch from Fort Assiniboine says: "A terrific storm here yesterday blew the Quartermaster's store down. The loss is $50,000. The buildings all rocked as if in an earthquake."

Pincin, of East Monmouth, has lately been visiting her sister in Auburn, and is a woman perhaps 40 years old, of fine physique, and, as recent events have proved, abundantly able to take care of herself. DENVER, Col., July 27.--Andrew Green, colored, was hanged here to-day in the presence of 15,000 people for the murder of Joseph C. Whitnah, a street car driver, on May 19 last. The murder was committed for the purpose of robbery. Kansas Withers, an accomplice, was sent to the penitentiary for life. Green was 24 years old, and confessed his crime from the gallows. Owing to faulty apparatus he died of strangulation.

Galvin's pitching was hit safely 15 times for a total of 19 bases by the Metropolitan players in their contest against the Pittsburgs yesterday, and the result was that the latter were beaten 8 to 1. Roseman led in the batting.
Kate Clancy, an Irish girl about 18 years old, came over on the Devonia from Glasgow. She was not a bad-looking girl, and not much attention was paid her until she was landed at the Garden yesterday.

OWEN SOUND, Ontario, July 27.--A Canadian Pacific special freight train consisting of 22 cars ran off the track this morning at a place called "Sink Hole," 18 miles south of here, causing a general smash-up. The cars were loaded with steel rails, and 10 of them went over an embankment, the rails with which they had been loaded being twisted in every possible shape. The loss is heavy.

The arrangements for the funeral of Hubert O. Thompson were completed yesterday. LONDON, July 28.--A farmer named Whelan has been murdered near Callan, in Kilkenny County, Ireland. The deed was committed with a hatchet and was the result of agrarian troubles. One arrest has been made in connection with the affair.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., July 28.-- Charles R. Brayton, the Chief of the State Constabulary, spent Sunday at the Mount Hope House, but the visit was not apparently made in an official capacity. As far as may be seen upon the surface the Pier is just as well off without the sale of ardent spirits as it has formerly been with it.

Every day furnishes proof that the boycott has some of the qualities of the boomerang or of a gun that kicks. For example, a fund was raised for a permanent exhibition in Minneapolis, and buildings were planned upon which hundreds of men would have been employed.

BOSTON, July 28.--Edward Hanlan has arranged the final details of the regatta at Nantasket on Aug. 9. The purse of $1,100 will probably be divided as follows: Seven hundred dollars to the first, $300 to the second, and $100 to the third. The race will be three miles, with a turn.

Robert Melville, a carpenter, and his wife, Eliza, were arrested at their home, at Deanstreet and Sackman-avenue, East New-York, last night, on a warrant issued at the instance of the Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children.

Among the passengers on an up-town elevated road train on the Third-avenue line yesterday morning was a lady who had with her a bright little girl of 5 or 6 Summers. GOLDSBOROUGH, N.C., July 28.--At the Democratic Convention of the Third Judicial District held here to-day. E.T. Boykin was nominated for uperior CoSurt Judge and H.O. Allen for Solicitor.

BURLINGTON, Vt., July 28.--Gen. William Wells, Collector of Customs for the District of Vermont, has sent his resignation to President Cleveland. Gen. Wells was suspended July 25, 1885, and the nomination of his successor, Bradley B. Smalley, and Gen. Wells's conduct of his ...

CHICAGO, July 28.--Mr. Phil Armour appeared at his office to-day for the first time in several weeks, looking about as hearty and robust as usual. Mr. Armour has been having a hard time of it with rheumatism. When his glue factory burned he was wet through, and the disease settled in his arms and ankles.

WABASH, Ind., July 28.--The Common Council to-day awarded the contract for the construction of a system of water works in this city to Samuel R. Bullock Co., of New-York. The works will be completed Jan. 1, 1887, and will cost $120,000.

Robert Fleming, the rich Scotchman who is representing British holders of the securities of the Texas and Pacific Railroad Company, goes to Philadelphia to-morrow to confer with the Wistar reorganization committee regarding his cash offer for its $8,000,000 of Eastern Division consolidated bonds. The reorganization plan of the Texas and Pacific stockholders' committee is to be made public to-day.

At length definite charges have been formulated against ROLLIN M. SQUIRE, Commissioner of Public Works of this city, and he has been notified to appear before the Mayor on Wednesday next for the purpose of a hearing thereon.
LANCASTER, Penn., July 28.--The damage by last night's storm was not so widespread as was anticipated, the territory affected being comparatively small, but within it sad havoc was wrought.

There is as little of the milk of human kindness in the oleomargarine business as of that of the domestic cow. The case of Mr. ALLEN, a Representative in Congress for the Eighth District of Massachusetts, exhibits the rancid and rancorous aspects of beef suet in a strong light.

HARTFORD, Conn., July 28.--The State Prohibition Convention was held at Unity Hall, in this city, to-day. The attendance was large, and the speeches showed great dissatisfaction with both political parties and at sometimes considerable bitterness.

The Aqueduct Commissioners yesterday discharged their Secretary of the commission, James W. McCullch, and, on motion of Mr. Ridgway, appointed John C. Sheehan, a brother of Assemblyman Sheehan, of Buffalo, to the position, the removal and appointment to take effect Aug. 1.

Ex-Alderman Nicholas R. O'Connor, of this city, is interested in many enterprises, chief among which is a gaslight company which illuminates the greater part of New-Jersey. Besides being a member of the Union Club, Secretary of a lawn tennis society, and the leader of the german in Harlem, he is an amateur photographer, second only in skill to the son of Mr. Arnold, of Arnold, Constable Co.

Capt. Randle, of the steamship Westernland, which arrived yesterday from Antwerp, reports that at 2 o'clock on the afternoon of July 25 he passed a sloop-rigged yacht, which was undoubtedly tho British cutter Galatea.
ROCKLAND, Mass., July 28.--The Abington National Bank will not reopen on Aug. 1, as was expected, as Bank Examiner Gatchell has not completed his report.

George Arensberg, an employe of THE TIMES composing room and one of the most rapid and skillful compositors in the world, died at Bellevue Hospital, in this city, yesterday. His death was due to a complication of disorders.

PITTSBURG, July 28.--The Sheriff to-day closed the Atlas Foundry on execution attachments aggregating $20,000. The attachments cover the stock and movable fixtures only. There are other attachments against the machinery, , which have not yet been served. Andrew Carnegie is the principal creditor.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The weather to-day was very warm, the track fast, and the attendance good. The day passed away with great satisfaction, with the exception of the accident to Miss Nelson and Mollie Bawn in the first race. "D.D."--Certainly he can. The picnic and concert of the La Armonia Sociedad Espafiola will be held in Harlem River Park on Saturday.

ROCHESTER, July 28.--At the session of the Grand Lodge, Knights of Pythias, now in session here, Thomas B. Isham, of Brooklyn, was unanimously elected Grand Chancellor; Anson S. McNab, of Rochester Grand Vice-Chancellor and David J. Auchmody, of Kingston, Grand Prelate.

PARIS, July 28.--A great sensation was caused on the Bourse and boulevards to-day by a report that the Emperor William was dead, and crowds of excited men could be seen everywhere discussing the rumor. Rentes fell to 82f. 75c., but on the report being officially denied the market recovered.

The employes of the Belt Line Road complain that the company is violating its agreement made with the Empire Protective Association four months ago. They assert that union men are being gradually weeded out, thirty of the old drivers and conductors having been discharged.

CHICAGO, July 28.--The Barker Tobacco Company recovered a judgment by confession yesterday for $75,000 against the C.W. Allen Company. To-day a wholesale tobacco manufacturer filed a creditor's bill based on this judgment.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 28.--Another question under the local option law has arisen in Shelby, which has been a dry town for the past seven years. There is no exception allowed by the law for any purpose, but the physicians of the town hold that they have a right to issue ...
ST. JOHN'S, Newfoundland, July 28.--A dispatch from White Bay says that a large number of arctic bears, driven south by starvation, have crossed over from Pennyland and are devastating the country.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., July 28.--Two negroes, named Ben Hicks and Tom Hayes, near Jasper, Marion County, got into a difficulty over a quarrel between their wives.

CHICAGO, July 28.--August Heun, a printer in the employ of Vehr Klein, corner of Market and Randolph streets, was the first witness in the Anarchists' trial to-day. He set up a portion of the circular calling for the Haymarket meeting. Witness obtained the copy of this circular from Mr. Klein, and he got it from the defendant Fisher, who came to the printing office about 7 o'clock on the morning of May 4.
MONCTON, New-Brunswick, July 28.--The schooner N.J. Miller arrived at Hopewell Cape, New-Brunswick, on Thursday, and was seized Saturday by customs officials for an infraction of the customs laws.
LOCKPORT, N.Y., July 28.--About 8 o'clock to-night a steamboat, in passing through the Erie Canal west of the locks in this city ...
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 28.--Drafts on New-York--Sight, 10 cents; telegraphic 15 cents.

ERIE, Penn., July 28.--C.W. Mackey, who was nominated in the Republican Congressional Convention last evening in Corry, is in the city, and is in conference with friends to-night. He has not accepted the nomination as yet, inasmuch as one-third of the convention revolted.

There was a queer gathering of secondhand dealers in furniture and a few aged women in black in the old brick dwelling at the northwest corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Lexington-avenue yesterday morning. This is the house in which Adrian and Lucy Crucy, brother and sister, killed themselves a short time ago.

Sixteen amphibious men, in various stages of sunburn, dangled their 32 feet over the Hamilton-avenue pier, in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, and craned their brown necks to catch a glimpse of the ferryboat Atlantic as she left Hamilton Ferry bound for this city.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, July 28.--The Ohio wheat crop has all been harvested, and as a rule the quality is of the very best. The Secretary of the State Board of Agriculture estimates the yield of Winter wheat at 33,480,063 bushels, the average yield during the past seven years ...

LONDON, July 28.--The Board of Trade has awarded a silver cup to Capt. Ringk, of the North German Lloyd steamer Fulda, for his services at the sinking of the Cunard Line steamer Oregon off Fire Island.
WASHINGTON, July 28, 1886. The Senate to-day passed the Fortification bill, with the amendments proposed by the Senate Committee.

LIMA, July 28, via Galveston.--The installation of the Ordinary Congress took place this afternoon. Dr. Garcia Calderon was elected President of the Senate and Dr. Alejandro Arenas President of the Chamber of Deputies. The sixty-fifth anniversary of the independence of Peru is being celebrated to-day with much enthusiasm.

The statement which the committee of the Knights of Labor read on Tuesday in the cigar factory of Levy Brothers, declaring that the firm would employ only Knights of Labor, was the result of an understanding between District Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor and the Cigar Manufacturers' Association. The latter had joined with the Knights in an effort to break up the Cigarmakers' Progressive Union.

Reports from all over Northern Texas show that the Cutting case is the absorbing topic of conversation.

CANTON, Ohio, July 28.--The delegates to the State Prohibition Convention here have been gathering to-day. The apportionment provides for 495 delegates. There will not be that number in attendance, but Prohibitionists who are not delegates are arriving in considerable numbers.

ATLANTA, Ga., July 28.--When the State Democratic Convention was called to order at noon to-day the most noticeable feature was the absence of the average politician. The men who ever since 1872 have been reognized as the party "bosses" were most conspicuous for their absence.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., July 28.--H.C. Sackett, aged 84 years, was found hanging from the limb of a tree at Manlius, N.Y., this morning. He had committed suicide.

FALL RIVER, Mass., July 28.--Two hundred weavers at Durfee Mills Nos. 1 and 3 struck at 1 o'clock this afternoon, and 1,600 looms are idle. The cause of the strike is given as the poor filling used, which increases the work of the weavers while it lessens their pay.
FORT WORTH, Texas, July 28.--The Texas crops as a whole this year are better than last. There have been exceedingly severe droughts in certain sections in Western Texas, mostly in the cattle region.

CHICAGO, July 28.--Work upon the investigation of Col. W.H. Bolton's accounts has been temporarily suspended, and Inspectors Keeder and Bassett left the city this evening to attend to other matters in their department. So far the checking of the accounts has covered the entire period since Oct. 1, 1884, for the News and for the Western News Company.

CHICAGO, July 28.--A final decree of foreclosure was entered to day before Judge Gresham in the case of the Central Transit Company against the Lake Erie and Western Railway and others.

NEWBURG, N.Y., July 28.--The village of Otisville, Orange County, is filled with excitement and interest over the fact of one of its well known citizens having just been caught in the act of robbing the hen roost of Squire Charles Loomis. The thief proved to be Samuel E. Raymond, formerly a hotel keeper at Otisville.

There is likely to be at no distant day an extensive emigration of our colored population into Northern Mississippi. Extraordinary inducements are being held out to them in that quarter. More than 70,000 acres of magnificent land are offered them on easy terms, such as they can, for the most part, comply with.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, July 28.--There were three convictions to-day of ward politicians who were concerned in the big and bold frauds at the October election. These are the first convictions which have occurred. The Grand Juries were at first packed in favor of "the gang," and no indictments could be secured.

LONDON, July 28.--Owing to the unsatisfactory result of the chess tournament the managers decided that the ties should be played off instead of dividing the honors, as has generally been done. In this final bout Blackburne defeated Burn and therefore wins the first prize. Tanbenhaus drew with Gunsberg, and must play again to-morrow.

QUEBEC, July 28.--N.R. Martineau, a merchant of Fall River, Mass., was the delegate from the French Canadians of New-England at the installation of Cardinal Tascherean. YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, July, 29.--At the meet of the Inter-State Bicycle Association here to-day W.H. Barber, of Rochester, N.Y., lowered the world's one-mile unicycle record by 10 seconds, his time being 3:41. W.A. Crawford, of New-Castle, won the two-and-one-half-mile inter-State championship.

CHARLOTTE, N.C., July 29.--George Moore, colored, was hanged in the jail in this city this morning for outraging his own daughter. On the scaffold he made a brief speech protesting that he was innocent of the crime. The drop fell at 10:55, and 20 minutes later he was pronounced dead. His neck was not broken by the fall.

MONTREAL, July 29.--The famous suit in connection with the Tournai frauds was decided in Belgium a few days ago in favor of Bishop Duroyseau. A large amount of the bonds are in possession of parties in Montreal, and action will likely have to be taken to recover them.

A certain amount of excitement has been caused in the east end for some days past by a very strange phenomenon occurring at No. 323 Beaudry-street. There lives in that house a young girl named Onesime Aubin, who has been ...

LONDON, July 29.--It being decided that two games should be played between the prize winners who had tie scores, Blackburne won his first game with Burn and drew the second. This gives the first prize to Blackburne and the second to Burn.

Ten innings were required to decide the NewYork-St. Louis game on the Polo Grounds yesterday afternoon, which was won by the local players by a score of 2 to 1. The winners played without the services of Connor and Dorgan, and in the absence of these men the chances of the local players appeared very slim.

CHICAGO, July 30.--In the Spring of 1885 the Swedish Government made discoveries of corruption and fraud in its revenue service by comparison with which America's own Babcock ring exposure some 12 years ago was a trifle. It was found that during the three years prior the crown had been robbed of nearly 8,000,000 kroners, a sum approaching $2,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, July 30.--The experience of the people of this city with the three-headed street car syndicate, Kemble, Widener, and Elkins, has been painfal enough. The syndicate have disregarded the law as thoroughly as they have disregarded the comfort of their passengers or the condition of the streets through which they run.

ST. PAUL, Minn., July 30.--The Pioneer Press will say to-morrow: "The weather in the Northwest has been superb since the harvest began. A few light showers have fallen in various portions of Minnesota and Dakota, but the weather has generally remained warm and dry,...

As invitations to Marlborough House are regarded in the light of "commands" by those who are fortunate enough to receive them, it is only reasonable to expect that care and consideration should be shown in their issue. The careless way in which matters were managed ...

On April 9 Lawyer Ira Shafer employed as clerk James J. Bennett, of No. 145 East One Hundred and Twentieth-street. Six years ago, when Mr. Shafer was District Attorney of Albany County, Bennett was a practicing lawyer, with an office in North Pearl-street, Albany.

ST. PAUL, July 30.--A special from Cinnabar, Montana, to the Pioneer Press says: "Last Monday a stage driver and two tourists while near Yellowstone Lake claimed to have seen an enormous reptile, which while running through the grass carried its head 10 or 15 feet above ground.

CHICAGO, July 30.--Gen. Francisco Naranjo, of the Mexican Army, and a leader in the recent revolutionary troubles in Northern Mexico, whose movements, according to the dispatches, are the cause of no little uneasiness on the part of the Mexican Government, has been in this city for the past two days.

Sir Robert Hart, K.C.M.G., the Inspector-General of Customs, has prevailed upon the Chinese Government to adopt a very progressive measure, viz., a postal system, which, though at first on a small scale, it is anticipated will eventually lead to the incorporation of the "Middle Kingdom" in the Postal Union.
DAYTON, Ohio, July 30.--The Board of Trustees of the Ohio Soldiers and Sailors' Home met here this evening and voted to locate the home at Sandusky.
LANCASTER, Penn., July 30.--The camp meeting to-day is the largest in the history of the association. The Tabernacle meeting at 6 this morning was led by the Rev. Mr. Ziegler.

DETROIT, July 30.--News of a terrible railroad accident on the Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Road, in which four men were killed, reaches this city to-night. A wild freight train, consisting of an engine and 35 empty cars, was proceeding westward early this forenoon, when, ...
CLEVELAND, July 30.--There was a good attendance at to-day's Cleveland Driving Park races. The weather was good and the track in prime condition. Following are the summaries:

POTTSTOWN, Penn., July 30.--The Glasgow Iron Works, where upward of 60 men were stricken with serious illness on account of bad drinking water, closed this morning. There were not enough men left for single turn duty.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--The Secretary of State has received a report from United States Consul Lynn in regard to the case of Francisco Rasures, the naturalized American citizen who was surrendered to the police authorities at Piedras Negras, Mexico, as a horse thief and summarily executed by them.

WILKESBOROUGH, N.C., July 30.--"Was John Cardwell lynched or was he taken from jail by his friends?" is the question now agitating the people of this county. Cardwell was to have been hanged to-day. There was terrible feeling against him. It is now believed that he was taken out of jail by a lynching party and drowned in the Yadkin River.

Norwegian Liberalism, like English, is now completely split into rival factions, and there is not much prospect of their speedy reunion. The division first came openly to the front in the debate upon a yearly pension for the poet Kjelland.

Edward W. De Grove, for 50 years a searcher in the Register's office, died last Thursday after a short illness. He came of a family which was among the earliest settlers on Manhattan Island. He was a son of Adolph De Grove and was born Dec. 4, 1799, in a house on ...
Eugene Kelly has issued a call for a special meeting of the Sub-Executive Committee of the Irish Parliamentary Fund Association, to be held next Friday at the Nassau-street headquarters.

TORONTO, July 30.--Reports from Manitoulin Island, Lake Huron, state that bush fires that have been raging there during the past week have wrought great destruction. Many acres of most valuable timber limits in Canada have been consumed and whole settlements have been laid waste.

Many a garret in the Eleventh Ward will be ransacked during the coming month to bring to the light and mend, shake and hang in the sun what may be left of the uniforms of Live Oak Engine Company No. 44, or "The-3-sixes," as ...

The Maine Senators in Washington have invited Congressmen Hiscock, of New-York; Burrows, of Michigan; McKinley, of Ohio; McComas, of Maryland, and Goff, of West Virginia to take part in the coming Fall contest in this State. It is likely that all will accept.

CHICAGO, July 30.--A final decree was entered to-day by Judge Gresham in the foreclosure case of Brown and Paton, Trustees, against the Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad. This was a bill to foreclose the first mortgage for $4,500,000 on the road, given May 22, 1880.

NYACK, N.Y., July 30.--Charles T. Small, of New-York City, is a guest at one of the Summer hotels in this village, going to and from the city daily on the cars. Yesterday afternoon he came up on an earlier train than usual for the purpose of enjoying a bath in the river and taking a subsequent rest.

GALVESTON, July 30.--Conrad Seabaugh, the County Clerk of Comal County, who disappeared 20 years ago, astonished his children and friends by turning up here alive to-day, after having wandered all over the globe. Some time after his disappearance a skeleton supposed to be his was found and interred in the family plot in the burying ground and his estate administered upon according to law.
NEW-HAVEN, July 30.--Three young men, who gave their names as Robert G. Davan, Harry Lee, and William Sullivan, were arrested by the police early this morning on suspicion.

CHARLESTON, N.C., July 30.--It has leaked out here since the execution of Jack Lambert on the 9th inst. that there was a conspiracy to save his life notwithstanding the public hanging. The last request made of the Sheriff by Lambert and his friends was that the "drop" should be made as short as possible. In fact, the fall was only 12 inches.

The new grounds of the Staten Island Cricket Club, at Bard-Avenue, Staten Island, put on a somewhat unwonted appearance yesterday. Fashionable equipages lined one side of the ground near the tennis nets which were occupied by ladies in light Summer costumes.
PORTLAND, July 30.--Jay Gould's steam yacht Atalanta, with Mr. Gould and his family and a party of friends on board, arrived here today, bound for Bar Harbor, Me.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., July 30.--The Police Committee of the Board of Aldermen met this evening to hear charges against three police officers. Officer Hefferty pleaded guilty to absence from the city without leave and to being intoxicated.

ROCKAWAY BEACH, Long Island, July 30. --A vessel said to be a four-masted steamer is supposed to be ashore at Rockaway Point, fourmiles from here. Rocket signals have been fired from the vessel. No particulars are obtainable to-night.

WOODBURN, Ky., July 29.--To-day a gentleman who had just come from Hyden, Leslie County, communicated the disappointing intelligence that there was no truth in the reported killing of French and Eversole in Perry County.
MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, July 30.-- J.W. Jourdan, who was employed by the Cherokee Nation to keep the Indian Territory free of intruders, came in to-day.
When Dr. Charles Griswold visited his patient Henry Pugsley, at No. 301 Hudsonstreet, Brooklyn, at 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, he found the door of his room locked.

LONDON, July 30.--In the Mincing-lane markets the demand for beet sugar has subsided, and prices have declined; German is quoted at 11s.@11s 3d. The season's supply promises to be the largest hitherto reached.

The final action of the Senate upon the Morrison resolution as amended is, in one sense, encouraging, since it shows that the Senate is not quite so far gone in folly as the House. But as the resolution in the form in which it was adopted is still a vicious measure of financial legislation, its passage by a vote ...

NEWPORT, July 30.--The weather to-day was damp, foggy, and unusually sultry, with frequent showers in the morning. There was a thunder shower, accompanied by lightning, which struck a barn, burning it together with its contents. The loss was about $2,000.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--The plans adopted by the Board of Additional Vessels for the Navy for the construction of the four vessels authorized in March, 1885, have from time to time been briefly described, but the detailed descriptions of them are now for the first time made public.
CINCINNATI, July 30.--The Republicans of the Fourth Ohio District have nominated T. W. Brotherton, of Wapokoneta, for Congress.
It is sometimes nearly exasperating to contemplate not simply the rascality of the men who embezzle from their employers, but their downright foolishness, their lack of common sense.

FORT WORTH, Texas, July 30.--Isaac Dahlman, owner of the great refrigerator works here, returned to-day from New-York, and says that at last all matters connected with an English syndicate are perfected and work begins in September. Messrs. Hill and Beck, two Englishmen, representing the London men who ...

MEMPHIS, Tenn., July 30.--Peter Noonan, head cook of the Peabody Hotel, was picked up in an insensible condition at 2 o'olock this afternoon on Second-street and conveyed to the office of the Board of Health, where the doctors pronounced ...
ROCHESTER, N.Y., July 30.--The State Grand Lodge of the Knights of Pythias to-day finished the routine business of the five days ses sion and adjourned.

Two historic mansions in the Faubourg Saint-Honore are now disappearing beneath the pickaxe of the demolisseur. One, facing the Elysee Palace, was the hotel of the Countess de Beaumont, daughter of the great surgeon Dupuytren. The other, near the Rue d'Anjou, was, until her death last year, occupied by the wife of Marshal Suchet, Duchess of Albufera.
HARRISONBURG, Va., July 30.--William Finchum has been on trial in the County Court for murder since Monday morning. He was today found guilty of murder in the first degree.

Dressed in the same pretty brown dress in which she ended her life on Thursday, Mrs. John Clairmonte's body was yesterday incased in a plain rosewood coffin, and, attended only by her heartbroken old parents, was buried in Greenwood Cemetery. No religious ceremony was observed. The funeral was held from Undertaker Crandell's place, in West Fifty-sixth-street.

WASHINGTON, July 30, 1886. The President to-night approved the Legisla tive, Executive, and Judicial Appropriation bill. The President has withdrawn the nomination of Henry Stowell to be Postmaster at Seneca Falls, N.Y.

NEWBURG, July 30.--Miss Ollie Brower, the 16-year-old daughter of Henry Brower, of No. 49 South-street, Middletown, N.Y., mysteriously disappeared from the home of her parents on Tuesday evening and has not since been seen or heard from. Fears are entertained by the young girl's relatives and friends that she has been foully dealt with.

NEWBURG, July 30.--The case of William J. McGowan, charged by William H. Parsons, of Parsons Co., commission merchants, of No. 27 State-street, New-York, with grand larceny, came before Justice Denniston, at Cornwall, this afternoon. McGowan waived examination, and his case was sent direct to the Grand Jury. The bail was fixed at $300, which was promptly furnished by Mrs. Kinsett, and the prisoner was set at liberty.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 30.--The Norwegian brig Sandnaes, Capt. Christiansen, from Boston for Sheet Harbor, Nova Scotia, to load deals for the United Kingdom, ran ashore yesterday on Pumpkin Island Ledge, near Beaver Island Light, east of Halifax.

CHICAGO, July 30.--A Fort Worth (Texas) special says: "Ever since the terrible shooting affray which took place on the Missouri Pacific Railway, near this city, between armed train guards, commanded by Jim Courtwright, and a party of unknown men, the officers of Tarrant County and Fort Worth have spared no ...
ROCKAWAY BEACH, Long Island, July 30. --Great damage was done here to-night by the storm. The wind blew a hurricane for half an hour and the surf washed up to the hotel.

NAUGATUCK, Conn., July 30.--For a long time James Davy and his wife, of Union City, have lived unhappily together. Both were addicted to the use of intoxicants, and as a result quarrels between them were frequent and violent. Some days ago Davy got tired of going to his home, and he left his wife to support herself and their four children.

ELMIRA, July 30.--The little hamlet called Harrison Valley, Tioga County, Penn., has been stirred from centre to circumference over the alleged faith cure of two young ladies. Some time ago a young lady whose illness seemed to be fatal placed herself in the hands of the Lord, ...

DETROIT, July 30.--William Wolff and Herman Kern, junior partners of Kauffman, Wolff Co., manufacturers and jobbers of clothing, whose difficulties were mentioned yesterday, this morning filed a bill in Chancery in the Superior Court to wind up the business.

BOSTON, Mass., July 30.--A St. John's, Newfoundland, special to the Advertiser says: "Hergenatis Yer, one of the the Esquimaux who arrived here on the Nancy Barrett from Okkak, Labrador, says that the population of that settlement was nearly 130, yet when he left with his wife not a soul remained.
The postal returns for Berlin in 1885 give the number of letters, post cards, and printed matter passed through the Post Office of that city in 1884 at 52,500,000 and the receipts at 840,000.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 30.--At a full meeting of the Board of Trustees of the Wake Forest College to-day J.R. Duggan, Ph.D. and Fellow of Johns Hopkins, was elected Professor of Chemistry; George W. Manly, Ph.D. of Leipsic, Professor of Latin, and W.H. McHael, A.M., of West Virginia, Assistant Professor.

There are the very best reasons for supposing that the action of four of the Aqueduct Commissioners in discharging James W. McCulloh, the efficient Secretary of the commission, was dictated by Gov. Hill and Aqueduct Contractor John O'Brien. The movement to get rid of Mr. McCulloh was begun soon after the election last Fall.

MERIDEN, Conn., July 30.--The Meriden authorities recently began a raid upon the liquor dealers who were suspected of keeping their places open on Sunday, and as the result 33 warrants have been served upon as many saloon keepers, the last of the batch being arrested today.

RALEIGH, N.C., July 30.--Mr. Thomas Dixon, of Cleveland County, flashed up in the political campaign of 1884 like a meteor, and gave promise of a successful career as a politician. He had been well educated and had studied for the stage.

The suicide of an octogenarian, Mr. John Merriman, 82, is reported from Pembroke Dock. The deceased gentleman, who formerly carried on an extensive iron foundry in the town, cut his throat with a razor and afterward fell from his bedroom to the pavement below. He had been much troubled in mind and had delusions at times.

SYRACUSE, July 30.--The Cortland Democrat of to-day says: "Col. D.S. Lamont and family arrived home for their Summer vacation on Tuesday last. We understand that Mr. Lamont is quite ill, and has been under the doctor's care ever since his arrival. Yesterday it was said that he was threatened with fever."

E.C. Montgomery, who resides at Clifton, Arizona, came home from a little trip through the country the other day and brought with him the head of an Apache. He had been attacked by three; he killed two and took the head of one as a souvenir. He was able to do this because he was not a soldier and could fight Indians Indian fashion.

OTTAWA, July 30.--The Militia Department has received a memorial from the Montreal volunteers, who were called out during the Fenian raids in 1866 and 1870, asking that they be placed on the same plane of reward and resignation as those under Gen. Middleton's command in the late Nortwest rebellion.

PITTSBURG, July 30.--Two more deaths occurred at West Elizabeth, Penn., to-day, from the epidemic which has been raging there for several weeks. No new cases have developed within the last 24 hours, and many of the worst cases show signs of improving. A number, however, are still in a dangerous condition. The physicians pronounce the disease typhoid fever.

Mahmud Hussein, the copper turner; Radha Bullub, the weaver, and Nazir Hussein, the poet and miniature painter, will return to India next month with the proud distinction of having seen more of the Queen than any other of her humble subjects.

Politicians, notwithstanding the weather yesterday, talked only of the thunderbolt fired into tho camp of Rollin M. Squire and Maurice B. Flynn, and it was generally conceded that it was a "cold day" for those distinguished gentlemen. Commissioner Squire was at his office as usual, but Mr. Flynn might have been classed among the "mysterious disappearances."

CHICAGO, July 30.--Leander Moody was lynched at Seymour, Ind., last night for outraging a 10-year-old girl named Lissem. Moody evaded arrest two weeks, but was captured last Saturday near Sbelbyville, Ill.

DETROIT, July 30.--For the past year trouble has been brewing between Prof. Johnson, teacher of agriculture in the State Agricultural College, and the pupils in his class. Some time ago the trouble culminated in the boys procuring a quantity of sulphuretted hydrogen, ...

OTTAWA, July 30.--On Monday next A. F. McIntyre, barrister, will present an application to the Exchequer Court asking for the discharge of Sproule, the American, now under sentence of death at Victoria, British Columbia.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 30.--At a picnic of the Band of Hope Temperance Society to-day between 30 and 40 persons were poisoned. Many of them are seriously ill, but no fatal results are anticipated. It is not known what the cause of poisoning was, but it is generally believed it was meat which had been prepared several days ago.

On her trip up the Hudson River on Wednesday night the Mary Powell was running under "one bell," off Cornwall, when a woman raised a cry that a man had jumped overboard. The boat was stopped and a rowboat was sent out, but no man was found.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--What little prospect the Morrison surplus resolution ever had of becoming a law has been ruined by the Senate, and it is hard to find a person in Washington to-night who believes that the President will have a chance to veto the measure this year. When it went to the Senate from the House of Representatives ...

Proverbial as is the passion of the average bartender for the display of a sparkling shirt front, it is not often that one meets a man who makes liquor selling a business with a weakness for rare stones simply to gratify a love for the curious and antique and with an aversion to display rather than a desire for it.

LONDON, July 30.--This was fourth day of the Goodwood meeting. The race for the Nassau Stakes was won by the Duke of Hamilton's bay filly Miss Jummy in a canter by two lengths. Prince Soltykoff's bay filly Argo Navis was second and Lord Calthorpe's chestnut filly Sainie Alvere third.

Prof. Orr gives the school statistics of Georgia for 1885 as follows: Enrollment of white children, 190,346; of colored, 119,248; of both races, 309,594. The per centum of attendance is as follow: White, 72; colored, 49; white and colored, 61. The total of expenditure for schools was $722,608 Dec. 29.
John Ellinsohn, the young German who drowned himself in Central Park because his fiancee danced with another man, will probably find a grave in Potter's Field.

The Hon. George H. Pendleton, in a private letter to a friend in Clifton; says he has re ceived very many telegrams and letters of sympathy and good-will from Cincinnati, Covington, and Newport, which have touched him very deeply; ...

ROCKY POINT, Pender County, N.C., July 30.--Mr. W.J. Montgomery, Judge of the Superior Court of the Eighth Judicial District by recent appointment of Gov. Scalcs, is a candidate for nomination and election.

Decisions were announced yesterday by the Police Commissioners on over 50 complaints against members of the force which had been tried, some of them as long ago as January last. Hugh Foley, of the Leonard-street station, was dismissed for intoxication.

WASHINGTON, July 30.--Commander William Gibson has been ordeded as Navigation Officer at the Washington Navy Yard, Sept. 1; Lieut. A.C. Dillingham to the Tennessee; Lieut. J.M. Roper has been detached from the Bureau of Navigation, Aug. 31, and ordered to the Naval Academy, Sept. 1; ...

ST. LOUIS, July 30.--The taking of depositions in a case of interesting details has been commenced in this city. It is that of the AEtna Life Insurance Company, of Hartford, Conn., against the American Surety Company, of NewYork, in which the former claims from the latter the amount of $6,000.

LOUISVILLE, July 30.--Special Bailiff Stringer arrived in this city this morning with a notorious counterfeiter named Clark, alias Edward Buett. Stringer got Buett at Livingston, Ky., where some of the citizens had him under guard.

HARRISBURG, Penn., July 30.--The strike of the employes of the American Tube Iron Company, at Middletown, has been declared off and the men will return, to work on Monday. Mr. Barry, of the Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, arrived in Middletown and ...

Trees were shivered to splinters and farming implements destroyed. Henry Bois, a German, 25 years old, employed on the farm of George Miracle, ...

ALBANY, Ga., July 30.--A frightful assassination took place in Lee County Thursday night. Lum Miller was sitting upon his doorstep eating a watermelon. The discharge of a pistol and the death groan of Miller attracted his family.

CHICAGO, July 30.--The court room in which the anarchist trial is in progress was so dark this forenoon as to require the lighting of the electric lights to enable the newspaper reporters to transcribe their reports. The room was crowded, as usual, and was close and hot. The proceedings were begun by a continuation of the reading of articles in the Alarm.

SARATOGA, July 30.--This was the third extra day of the race meeting here. The weather was warm and clear, but the attendance only fair. The track was in good condition. Ben Ali, who is ready, according to report, to meet all comers in a match race of one and one-half miles or over, secured an easy victory in the ...

LOUISVILLE, July 30.--A.W. Randolph, who is a candidate for re-election as Surveyor of Jefferson County, enjoys the distinction of perhaps being the only man who ever counted himself out in an election. It happened about 12 years ago.

PITTSBURG, July 30.--Reports from the coke regions show that there is trouble at number of the works there. At the Pennsville works of Abraham Sherrick on the Southwest road the men have all been paid off and considered discharged by the owner because they struck to have the wages of a pamper advanced.

BOSTON, July 30.--Judge Colt, of the United States Circuit Court, to-day sent down an opinion in the matter of the bill in equity of Lewis M. Price, Receiver, against the Directors of the Pacific National Bank, seeking to hold them personally responsible on the ground of their alleged neglect in the management of the affairs of the bank.

EL PASO, Texas, July 30.--Preparations for the final trial of Editor Cutting are in progress at El Paso del Norte, although it was given out several days ago that the case had been transferred to a higher court.

Counsel for Charles L. Davis, the muchbegemmed actor, moved bofore Judge Peckham, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, for the vacation of the order of arrest procured against him in the suit of Jennie Davis for an absolute divorce from him.

The Jersey City Board of Finance fixed the appropriations for the several governing boards as follows at a late meeting Thursday night: Board of Finance, $969,443; Board of Education, $236,499; Board of Aldermen, ...

Thomas Mallady, an applicant for appointment on the police force, was examined by the Police Surgeons about a month ago. He was found to be below the standard in weight and chest measurement, and was rejected. He made application recently to the Board of Police for a re-examination.

The Red Star Line withdrew yesterday from the Continental Steamship Conference, and will begin a cut-rate steerage war on Monday. Its agents have not yet announced the figures of the cut. The North German Lloyd, Hamburg, French, Netherlands, and Carr Lines reorganized agents say that they are prepared to fight the Red Star Line.

President Michael Coleman, of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, yesterday drew the attention of his colleagues in the Board of Estimate and Apportionment to a law which had been surreptitiously rushed through the Legislature, which now has the title of chapter 679 of the Laws of 1886.
