PITTSBURG, July 30.--At the reunion of the United States Christian and Sanitary Commission at Valley Camp to-day addresses dealing principally with war reminiscences were made by Col. B.F. Hardin, of Ohio; the Rev. Barton ...

In the death of John C. Booth, of Waterbury--announced in THE TIMES'S dispatches yesterday--Connecticut loses one of her most notable citizens. In many ways he was a man of consequence. He had ideas, and the ideas brought him millions of money. Push, enterprise, persisting, these traits were his to an extent that was distinguishing even in a community where they were virtues that everybody boasted.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, July 30.--Forepaugh's circus train parted in two places after crossing Foley Bridge this morning. Several cars separated from the tail of the train, slowed up, and were stopped.

NORWALK, Conn., July 30.--There are ugly reports that in giving out the contract for the new armory building to be erected in the town there has been some decidedly crooked work and the interested parties are bound to get at the truth in the matter.
The members of the Staten Island Athletic Club began their first lawn tennis tournament yesterday on their new grounds at West Brighton.

We are in the habit of saying to each other that the world is growing very small. So, indeed, in many ways it is. The increased facility of communication for which our generation is perhaps more noteworthy than for any other achievement has brought unnumbered blessings in its train.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., July 30.--Drafts on New-York--Sight. 10 cents; telegraphic, 15 cents.

CHICAGO, July 30.--A special dispatch from Fort Worth, Texas, says: "Many exaggerated reports have been sent out from North and West Texas in regard to the suffering of cattle from drought in Western Texas. Unusual droughts have existed in the different sections of West Texas, but these have all been broken by good rains within the last two weeks.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., July 30.--The Daily Chronicle was sold yesterday by order of the Chancery Court to satisfy claims amounting to several thousand dollars. It was bid in by R.W. Austin, representing a New-York company, and will be continued as a Republican paper.
CAMBRIDGE, Md., July 30.--William Frazier, once a leading politician of Dorchester County, 90 years of age, committed suicide today at Spedden's Wharf, on the Little Choptank River, near his house.
American merchants doing business with Spain are much gratified at some concessions which have just been made to shippers by the Spanish Government, and which are to go into effect after Aug. 1.

Ross Raymond, wilted and despondent, was arraigned twice at the Jefferson Market Police Court yesterday. On the first occasion papers were made out on the complaint of E. Kopp, manager of the Belvedere Hotel, in which Raymond was charged with passing two spurious checks.

LONDON, July 30.--Mr. Gladstone went to Osborne and submitted to the Queen a list of the honors that it is customary for a retiring Premier to bestow. The following were recommended for elevation to the peerage: Sir Thomas Brassey, Sir Michael Bass, Bart., the brewer; Mr. John Glencairn Cartel Hamilton, who failed ...

BERLIN, July 30.--The Prussian Railway Department has proposed to the Russian and Austrian railway authorities that the three nations effect a junction between their respective railways and enter into a railway convention for mutual tariff concessions. The object is to relieve depressed trades and industries.

T.B. MAGUIRE, presumably the dictator or autocrat of District Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor, has issued a mandate ordering all the local assemblies within his bailiwick to appear in force in Union-square this evening. The issuing of the order and the circumstances which call it forth are worthy the attention of all American workingmen and of citizens generally.

GUNNISON, Col., Aug. 1.--In the District Court yesterday afternoon Frank Mason, charged with murder, who has been on trial for a week, was acquitted by the jury, which was out one hour. It appears that the murdered man applied opprobious epithets to Mason. The jury in its report declared that any one who called another such names deserved killing.

PANAMA, July 24.--The celebration of the anniversary of the independence of Colombia took place on the 20th inst. The festivities really commenced on the 19th and did not actually terminate until the 21st. There were electric lights, fireworks, a military review, illuminations, eloquent speeches, and a great display of bunting every where.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 1.--The lease of the Danbury and Norwalk Railroad to the Housatonic Railroad Company for ninety-nine years, the Housatonic to pay interest on the Danbury and Norwalk bonds and 5 per cent. per annum on the stock, has been agreed upon by the two parties, and will in due time be ratified by the shareholders of the two companies.

WILLCOX, Arizona, Aug. 1.--William Williams, a cattleman, of Arrivipa, this afternoon shot and instantly killed J.B. Collins, a prominent merchant and Government contractor of Maxey. The deed was the result of a dispute over some unsettled business matters. Williams escaped.

Judge Oliver S. Phelps, of Portland, Oregon, who is on a visit to the Connecticut home of his ancestors, is a hale and vigorous man of 70, with a face indicating character and native power. HALIFAX, Aug. 1.--Reports from Bank fishermen are most encouraging. The schooner Myrtle, of Clarke's Harbor, arrived home yesterday from her second trip with 1,450 quintals of codfish. The catch averaged 85 quintals per day. The catch averaged 85 quintals per day.

CHICAGO, Aug. 1.--The Chicago Chief of Police received a dispatch this afternoon from the authorities at Erie, Penn., giving as complete a description as possible of the man found in the river there and supposed to be Schhaubelt, the bomb thrower.

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 1.--It has been fully developed that there will be no opposition to Gen. Gordon's candidacy for Governor by the Independents or Republicans. The papers in Georgia which opposed, Gen. Gordon largely because they were committed against him before the announcement of his candidacy are all coming to his support.

POUGHKEEPSIE, Aug. 1.--The annual meeting of the Dutchess County Peace Society was held at Wylie's Grove to-day and there was a large gathering. The President, Charles B. Deyo, and the Rev. R.B. Howard, Secretary of the American Peace Society, made addresses. The latter said the society was established in New-York in 1816 and moved to Boston in 1828.

ALBANY, Aug. 1. Following are extracts from the official semi-annual reports of eight of the savings banks of the city of New-York, as made to the Superintendent of the Banking Department, showing their condition on July 1. The number of banks in operation in the State is 124, 24 of which are situated in the city of New-York.

There were only 61 arrests yesterday for violations of the excise law, a large falling off compared with last Sunday; on which day 103 were reported.

NEWPORT, Aug, 1.--The following was printed on the bill of fare of the Ocean House today: "As the sale of wine is prohibited by law, the proprietors will furnish claret or sherrv free of cost to guests at dinner, but cannot provide any other liquors. Guests having their own wines can have them served at the table."

Ettie Bailey, a young silk weaver, who lives with her sister, Mrs. Stuart, at No. 132 East Forty-fourth-street, had a good deal of trouble with her sweetheart on Saturday night. Yesterday morning she was not exactly accountable for her actions. She walked down to Pier No. 40 North River, and going out to the end threw herself into the water.

Upon resigning his position as General Superintendent of the New-York City and Northern Railroad, to take a place on the Baltitimore and Ohio Railroad, Frank S. Gannon on Saturday sent to the officers and employes of the road a letter thanking them for the integrity and energy with which they had performed their duties during the past five years.

MUNICH, Aug. 1.--Prince Bismarck to-day visited Prince Regent Luitpold and the other Princes and the members of the Cabinet, who returned his visits. All were present later at a banquet given by Prince Luitpold.

DENVER, Aug. 1.--Mr. John T. Raymond closed the season here to-night at the Tabor Grand Opera House, in his new play by D.D. Lloyd, entitled " A Woman Hater." It was the first production of the drama, which was well received by the public. The company started for New-York this morning.
HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 1.--The American steam yacht Yosemite sailed westward to-day., She will proceed as far as Prince, Edward Island.

Gen. Boulanger served under the Duc d'Aumale in Algeria. The Duke, in one of his reports, appended the following note: "Boulanger, good, intelligent officer, but ill-bred." Now that Boulanger commands the army it would be interesting to know his opinion of the Due d'Aumale.

NORRISTOWN, Penn., Aug. 2.--The body of an unknown man was found near Jenkintown in a pond yesterday. The back of his head was crushed, and it is supposed to be a case of murder. There is no clue to the perpetrators.
AMSTERDAM, Aug. 2.--The Burgomaster of this city has forbidden the sale of newspapers in the streets, "because they inflamed the populace during the recent riots."

BLOOMINGTON, Ill., Aug. 2.--The will of the late David Davis was offered for probate today and sent to Washington for verification of signatures.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 2.--L.R. Early, W.B. Bickel, and P.Y. Hite to-day entered suit against Andrew Kaul and J.K.P. Hall to recover $300,000 damages.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--In the closing hours of the House the Republicans are managing to rally the Democrats a good deal by pokingfun at them for having spent eight months in doing next to nothing.

Thayer County, Neb., was the scene of a marriage last week in which the blushing bride of 40, Mrs. Jane Studley, weighing 374 pounds, took as her companion for life her hired hand, John Bell, aged 22, and weighing 125 pounds. The wife is possessed of $50,000.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 2.--A TimesUnion special from Enterprise, Fla., says that John Bonie, the Postmaster at St. Sebastian, Indian River, was found dead in his office last Wednesday. A cut on his head showed he had been murdered. The office was robbed, but the amount taken is unknown. Nathan McDonald and Ed Benham, colored, were arrested on suspicion and lodged in Titusville jail.
BOSTON, Aug. 2.--The Hon. John E. Fitzgerald this morning assumed the duties of his office as Collector of Internal Revenue for this district.
UTICA, Aug. 2.--United States Marshal Walter H. Bunn, of Cooperstown, took possession of a number of rooms in the City Hall today, under the direction of the Attorney-General.

A number of caterers and restaurant keepers went to Fulton Market yesterday, their epicurean imaginations aroused by the prospect of woodcook, which succulent birds were left unprotected by the game laws on Sunday. The caterers and restaurant keepers were grievously disappointed.

BUFFALO, Aug. 2.--The American Dental Association will convene in annual session at Niagara Falls to-morrow, Dr. W.C. Barrett, of Buffalo, presiding. The headquarters will be at the International Hotel, and the business meetings will be held in the Casino. It is expected that over 300 delegates will be present.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--The second game between the Kansas Citys and the Washingtons developed into a regular slugging match in which the hits were even, but the home club had a little the better of it in total base hits.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 2.--The Puritan came off the ways at Fairhaven to-night and will sail for Naushon to-morrow, and thence for Newport. Capt. Crocker arrived to-night. He will accompany the yacht and will sail her in the race for the Goelet Cup.

John J. Owens, of Orange, N.J,, the husband of the woman who died Thursday last from injuries received in consequence of the explosion of a lamp, was arrested yesterday on a charge of manslaughter. On her death bed the woman stated that her husband threw the lamp at her. Owens was held in $5,000 bail. The in quest on the death of Mrs. Owens will begin on Wednesday.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2.--Articles of incorporation for the new northwestern line of the Illinois Central were filed at Springfield, Ill., and Madison, Wis., yesterday afternoon.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 2.--The case of John Baird, the alleged insane millionaire, came before Justice Barnard again this morning. He came here this morning from Troy in company with his brother, Hugh Baird, and the latter's counsel, Robert H. McClellan, of Troy.

BELFAST, Aug. 2.--There was more rioting here this evening. Crowds assembled on York-street and awaited the return of Catholic excursion parties, upon whom they made a fierce attack. The sufferers were chiefly women.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 2, 1886. The public debt statement shows a reduction during July of $9,049,103.

PINE HILL, N.Y., Aug. 2.--A case of assault and battery of the third degree has been on trial here to-day before Judge Sagendorf and a jury. The complainant was one Angelena, an Italian missionary, a protege of the Rev. Dr. Howard Crosby.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 2.--George Roe, a 17-year-old boy employed by Elmer Pierce as a farm hand, died last night from the effects of a horse's kick.

PROVIDENCE, Aug. 2.--Augustus D. Wheeler, of Midvale, N.J., a student of Brown University, in the employ of the Continental Steamboat Company at Rocky Point, was drowned there at noon to-day while bathing.

HEIDELBERG, Aug. 2.--Every hotel and inn as far as Maunheim is crowded with visitors who have come to take part in the celebration of the five hundredth anniversity of the foundation of Heidelberg University.

VIENNA, Aug. 2.--The Hungarians are still much excited over the Gyulai-Janski affair. Last June the Austrian soldiers at Buda-Pesth decorated with flowers the monument erected in that city to Gen. Henzi, who was killed while defending the city from the Hungarians in 1849.

KINGSTON, Ontario, Aug. 2.--The yacht Atlanta, which once essayed to win the America's Cup, took first place in the Kingston Yacht Club regatta to-day. While watching the race three A Battery men, named Cliff, Patton, and Sheeley, were thrown into the water by the capsizing of their skiff. Patton, being a good swimmer, reached the shore, but the other two were drowned.
CHICAGO, Aug. 2.--Mrs. Maggic Hieland, a Mormon woman, aged 27 years, was shot by her husband, Theodore Hieland, yesterday, while in a shooting gallery.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 2.--A man named Goring, who lived at Kingston, was working in a cornfield on Thursday last when he scratched his arm against a cornstalk. He paid no attention to his wound until his arm began to swell, and then he called in a physician, who, however, could do nothing to alleviate Goring's sufferings. The man, who was large, strong, and in good health before Thursday died Sunday in horrible agony.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 2.--Col. Clough, counsel for the Northern Pacific, has returned from the Pacific coast, and expresses the opinion that there is something to the reported sale of the Oregon Navigation to the Union Pacific.

CRANFORD, N.J., Aug. 2.--By the recent erection of a dam across the Rahway River at this place a large part of that pretty stream has been turned into a clear, smooth lake, shaded on both sides by old forest trees and with sufficient depth to afford fine boating and fishing.

Having completed his "Thirty Years in the Senate," the last chapters of which were written when he was physically very weak, in bed, and suffering acute pain, Col. Benton sent for several old friends to bid them farewell.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Aug. 2.--The election passed off quietly to-day. But three full tickets were voted. Thomas Seay, Democratic candidate for Governor, and the full Democratic State ticket are elected. Their majority can only be estimated, as the full returns from interior counties will not be received until to-morrow night.

HARTFORD, Aug. 2.--Two reasons are assigned for the suicide of Station Agent Dickinson at Deep River. He has had many unhappy moments since, two years ago, he married a pretty blonde, Mattie Croft, a Swede, who had lived in Deep River from early childhood.

CLYDE, N.Y., Aug. 2.--This morning at 9:30 a pocket blew out of engine No. 392, of the Lyons coal train, when within half a mile of Clyde, on the New-York Central Railroad, and forced the hot water, steam, and fire into the cab.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 2.--Judge Lubke, in Chambers, to-day, rendered a decision on the proposition of the sureties of Almon B. Thomson, absconding Cashier of the Provident Savings Bank.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 2.--R.B. Stewart, stock broker, arrested a few days ago on the charge of having embezzled upward of $1,900, money of Frank WaLker, was discharged to-day. The complainant stated that he swore out the warrant of arrest under a misapprehension, and a nolle prosequi was entered.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 2.--Attorneys for the Harlem Commons syndicate say that they will be ready to bring suit in the United States Circuit Court of New-York, about Sept. 1, to establish their right to 1,500 acres of property lying along the Harlem River between Ninety-fourth and One Hundred and Fifty-fifth streets, NewYork. The value of the property is said to be $15,000,000.
WATERBURY, Conn., Aug. 2.--Elisha Levenworth, of this city, has sent to the managers of the Waterbury Industrial School a check for $10,000.

OTTAWA, Aug. 2.--Joseph Atchison, of New-York, was in town to-day en route for British Columbia. He will superintend the construction of a telegraph line from Port Moody, the Pacific terminus of the Canadian Pacific, to San Francisco. Operations will be commenced in a few weeks.

Michael Warren and wife, of Arthur, a few miles to the northwest of Mattoon, Ill., have one of the largest and perhaps the healthiest families on record. They have nine sons and five daughters, and all but four are married and settled down near the old homestead. There has never been a death in the family. The youngest child is a rosy-cheeked girl aged 14.

READING, Penn., Aug. 2.--Fred Haage, a young slate roofer, fell from the top of a twostory house to the ground below, this afternoon, breaking his neck and dying in 15 minutes thereafter. He was the support of an aged father, who was crippled by several falls while roofing.

Some excavations lately carried out at Flonheim, near Worms, have brought to light some most interesting specimens of Frankish antiquity. In and around the old Romano-Gothic church Franconian chiefs and nobles had their burial places.

MATTOON, Ill., July 31.--Gen. Grant's old regiment, the Twenty-first Illinois, that was mustered in at Mattoon early in 1861, will hold its reunion in this city Sept. 25.

AMSTERDAM, N.Y., Aug. 2.--George Lascelles, an actor and playwright, aged between 60 and 70 years, was found dead in his room at an East Main-street lodging house yesterday morning. He was a member of Col. Eding's dramatic company, playing at the Potter Opera House. Death was caused by strangulated hernia. The expenses of the funeral will be defrayed by the Actors' Fund of New-York.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 2.--Reports received from various parts of the Wyoming Valley show that the storm which prevailed in this region last night and this morning has caused serious damage.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 2.--A special from the Indian Territory announces the death of the Hon. William Harnage, a politician and leader, and one of the oldest and most respected citizens of Going Snake district. He died of cholera morbus on the 14th of July. He was a true friend to his people and much beloved by them, and the whole nation mourns his loss
KOKOMO, Ind., Aug. 2.--A fatal shooting affair occurred Saturday about 10 miles out of town. It appears that some time ago Elmer Harrell killed a turkey belonging to a neighbor named David Condo.

A large contingent of the Fourth Ward went on the excursion of Shamrock Council of the Legion of Honor yesterday to Pleasant Grove. The steamboat Blackbird and two barges conveyed the excursionists.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 2.--Later reports show that only a small part of the rice crop in Georgetown County is lost, and the accounts of distress are believed to be exaggerations.
PARIS, Aug. 2.--The Monarchists were defeated once more in the elections for the General Councils, which were held yesterday in all the departments of France, that of the Seine alone excepted.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 2.--The Philadelphias defeated the Detroits to-day in an exciting ten-inning game. The home club scored three in the first inning on singles by Andrews, Ferguson, Irwin, and Farrar, and a muff by Crane.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 2.--Most of the weavers in Durfee Mill No. 1 returned to work this morning. There was no disturbance and the rest of the weavers are expected back to-morrow. The Barnard Mill spinners are still on strike, but the other departments of the mill are running as usual.

With the Camden and Passaic Stakes on the programme to-day at Monmouth Park and two good handicaps, the sport promises to be very exciting, as the fields are large, while the track will be in fair condition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 2.--Four men are under arrest here who are supposed to be the perpetrators of the recent fifteen-thousand-dollar stamp robbery in Minneapolis, Minn. Two men offered $4,000 worth of stamps for sale to-day at 60 cents on the dollar.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Postmaster-General Vilas is able at the close of the first fiscal year of his administration of the Post Office Department to show some figures which speak well for the care with which the affairs of that department of the Government have been managed.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 2.--The heavy rain of Sunday made plenty of mud on the Landisville camp meeting grounds, and to-day the worshipers kept indoors as much as possible. To-morrow will be temperance day in camp.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 2.--John Sherwood was put in Danbury Jail on Nov. 15, 1884, on what practically amounted to a judgment for $140 for a debt. He has just been released by an order from Judge Stoddard, of the Superior Court.

ASBURY PARK, Aug. 2.--Fully 50,000 people lined the shore of Wesley Lake to witness the grand carnival that was given by the lake boys. Two bands of music led the carnival. The decorations on the boats and on the buildings along the lake were the finest ever seen here. Hundreds of people come from Long Branch, Hollywood, and Spring Lake to witness the procession up and down the lake.

BOSTON, Aug. 2.--A large number of capitalists, editors, farmers, c., and their wives left here at 9 A. M. to-day under the direction of the Hon. NEWPORT, Aug. 2.--The Newport season has "boomed" in earnest to-day. There were many arrivals, mostly at the cottages. In the way of amusement there were polo games and a well attended dance at the Casino in the evening. The weather was very hot, but none too much so to suit the hotel keepers.

MARION, Ind., Aug. 2.--Two other fatalities have been added to the list caused by Friday morning's Toledo, St. Louis and Kansas City Railroad disaster at Bluffton. John Sipple, the engineer, expired last night, and his brother-inlaw, Bruff Williams, the fireman, died at noon yesterday. The condition of Joe Fankboner, the fourth man and only survivor, who went down on the wreck, is worse, and the chances are against his recovery.

WORCESTER, Aug. 2.--Edward Hanlan, the oarsman, has been offered $500 in case he breaks the single-scull three-mile record, and he will make the attempt on Lake Quinsigamond on Thursday, Aug. 12. If he should not succeed in this attempt he has the privilege of trying again on Aug. 13 and 14.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 2.--Five new cases and three deaths from typhoid fever were reported to the Board of Health to-day. The disease is spreading rapidly notwithstanding the efforts of the health officers to check its ravages.
ROMNEY, West Va., Aug. 2.--Miss Ann Offner, the 18-year-old daughter of a farmer living near here, yesterday shot and killed Benjamin Brooks, a dissolute fellow, 43 years of age.

NEW-HAVEN, Aug. 2.--Relics of the Lockwood tragedy are in great request. Leaf, limb, bark, and trunk of the fatal chestnut tree are rapidly disappearing. Canes cut from its wood sell at 50 cents apiece. Chips of the bough from which the body hung sell at 75 cents, and a 4-inch bit of the rope retailed at $1.

A church at Cornwall, Ill., has long been inhabited by swarms of bees. They finally became so plentiful that they drove Pastor and congregation out of the church. MILLEDGEVILLE, Ga., Aug. 6.--Frank Humphreys was to-day found guilty of murder and sentenced to death. Three months ago he induced by false statements his sister-in-law and niece, Miss Carrie Raines and Miss Eila Humphreys, to go home with him. On the way he assaulted them and then shot them dead. His wife and three children were present during the trial. Humphreys paid no attention to them whatever.

Richards, in the presence of a throng of clergy and people. The Rev. J. Fewsmith, D.D., of Elizabeth, N.J., delivered the principal address. It was announced that the contributions to the building fund amounted to $6,500. The plans contemplate a handsome edifice of modernized Gothic style, to cost about $20,000.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 8.--A dispatch from Rio Grande City, Texas, says a heavy force of Mexican revolutionists crossed the river into Texas on Thursday night. A troop of the Eighth United States Cavalry was ordered yesterday from Ringgold Barracks to pursue and disarm them.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 8.--President Cleveland keeps his own counsel for the present regarding the time when the resignation of Collector of Customs Hedden will be formally accepted, and his silence allows free play to the imagination of the numerous interested politicians who are wondering who the new Collector will be.

GLOUCESTER, Aug. 8.--Several large fares of fish arrived here to-day from the Grand Banks. The schooner H.B. Griffin brings 375,000 pounds of codfish, the largest fare received here this season. The schooner Orient, from the bay brings 600 barrels of mackerel, the largest mackerel fare of the season. During the past 24 hours a total of 1,700,000 pounds of codfish and 1,450 barrels of mackerel from the bay and 150,000 pounds of halibut have arrived.

Charles A. Minton, financial editor of the Herald, died of heart trouble at his home, No. 30 East Thirty-third-street, at 8 o'clock last evening. Mr. Minton came of an old New-York family. He was born in this city in 1825.

When Postmaster John Flanagan, of Astoria, saw three strange men idling about the Post Office building on Tuesday evening last he thought it likely that they were waiting for a chance to break in and steal something. He reported the facts to Inspector Dorser, of the NewYork Post Office, the next day.

BELFAST, Aug. 8.--The excitement here is unabated. This morning rioting broke out in Old Lodge road, and the police were obliged to fire in order to disperse the rioters. This afternoon the rioting was renewed with great violence in Old Lodge, Grosvenor, and Springfield roads.

Mrs. Drenkhaln, a widow living south of Lewiston, Winona County, Minn., has 700 acres of grain. She runs four self-binders with five horses attached to each, and a full crew of shockers, and oversees the whole outfit herself.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 8.--Dr. Gerner, President of the State Board of Health, is in the city investigating the causes of the typhoid fever epidemic now raging on the south side.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Aug. 9.--The International Temperance Camp Meeting was formally opened here to-day. Prof. Hopkins, of New-York, was one of the principal speakers. The Templars were formally welcomed by Mayor McKay.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The eightysixth birthday of Mrs. Ann Scott, familiarly known as Aunty Scott, was celebrated at the residence of Dr. Thomas Millspaugh and wife, at West Walden, on Saturday afternoon.
Wadsworth Post, No. 77, G.A.R., gives a picnic at the Atalanta Casino, Eighth-avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-fifth-street, this evening.

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 9.--At 7 o'clock this morning the yachts of the New-Haven Club got under way at Stony Creek, and soon after set their course for this harbor. Once outside the Thimble Islands the inevitable race from port to port commenced.

Following the example of several of the County Conventions the District Convention heartily indorsed President Cleveland and his policy of civil service reform. There is no doubt as to the determination of Southern Democrats to support the President in this matter.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--Mr. Gladstone, who was returned to the House of Commons by both Midlothian and Leith-Burgs, Scotland, has chosen to sit for the former district. The World says that Mr. Gladstone will not visit Ireland during the approaching recess of Parliament.

Commissioner of Public Works Rollin M. Squire and Maurice B. Flynn, his accomplice, were shown up in their true colors by City Chamberlain William M. Ivins in the hearing before Mayor Grace yesterday. Neither Squire nor Flynn was brave enough to stand the light shed upon them by Mr. Ivins, and no one who knew either of them wondered at their absence.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 9.--Fred Carroll, the catcher of the Pittsburg Baseball Club, has been suspended for quarreling with Otto Shomberg, the new first baseman.

LOUISVILLE, Aug. 9.--Samuel Reedy was fortunate enough to win considerable money on the recent election and a large amount of it was paid to him last night. On his way home and when near the old western cemetery at Sixteenth and Jefferson streets, he was met by two men who told him ghouls had opened one of the large vaults and desecrated it.

Zip and Nero are two big Russian wolf hounds who appeared last season in the play of "The Planter's Wife." They are nearly 3 feet high, and have mottled coats of white and black, looking something like immense coach dogs. They weigh 105 pounds each, and together make a fine pair.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--The stock of the Allen Tobacco Company, which failed some time ago, was put up for sale to-day by the Sheriff on the first judgment of the court for $50,000 in favor of E. C. Allen, of Beloit, Wis., father of C.W. Allen, who was said to have put in over $60,000 to start the establishment.

BERMUDA, Aug. 4.--When approaching Bermuda, between 8 and 9 o'clock on Sunday night, the steamer Flamborough, from NewYork, got ashore on the northeastern reefs. At the time she was in charge of a pilot, who supposed he was in a safe position. Rockets were fired and other signals of distress made, which after a time brought assistance from the shore.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--P. Elder, of the Elder Publishing Company, and proprietor of Literary Life, the magazine which Miss Rose Cleveland, the President's sister, has undertaken to edit, confessed judgment to-day in favor of James J. West, of the Western Publishing Company, in the sum of $10,000. On Saturday evening Mr. Elder gave Mr. West a judgment demand note in the amount named.
Three more witnesses were examined yesterday in the course of the inquisition to determine whether John Baird is insane, and, therefore, incompetent to care for himself and his large estate.

NEWPORT, Aug. 9.--The Brazilian frigate Almirante Barroso, with Prince Leopoldo on board, sailed hence to-night. Salutes were exchanged with the Government station here as he left. The frigate goes direct to sea.

SYRACUSE, Aug. 9.--A leak was discovered this afternoon in Lock No. 47, on the Erie Canal. This is one of the double locks, and it is situated at the head of the short level, just west of the tunnel, in this city.

DETROIT, Aug. 9.--Among the delegates elected to the Greenback State Convention from Clinton County is Miss Martha Strickland, a woman lawyer of St. John's. She is a daughter of the late Randolph Strickland, who was a Representative in the Forty-first Congress from the then Sixth District.

The Journeymen Barbers' Union has declared war against District Assembly No. 49 of the Knights of Labor. It had been reported that the Knights had ordered the union cards in the shops to be taken down, and that a Knights committee had called on the bosses and had promised to supply them with cheap Knights, who would also work longer hours than did the union men. About one-fifth of the union harbors are also Knights.

ERIE, Penn., Aug. 9.--The Grand Legion of the Select Knights of the Ancient Order of United Workmen of Pennsylvania are here in annual conclave. Legions are arriving on every train, and by tomorrow there will be 2,000 Select Knights here. Supreme Commander W.W. Reed, of Topeka, Kan., was serenaded to-night at the Reed House. The grand parade will take place Wednesday.

The fast of Ab, or "black fast," as it is sometimes called among the Jews, began last night at sundown and will last until this evening. This fast is one of the most solemn occasions in the Hebrew worship, and is scrupulously observed by orthodox Jews.

TORONTO, Aug. 9.--A meeting of cotton manufacturers of Canada was held here to-day when every factory in the country was represented. Scales of prices for cottons and yarns were adopted, and other arrangements were made.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--The Executive Committee of the Parnell Aid Association and the Delegate Reception Committee will meet at the Palmer House this evening to begin operations against the Sullivan-Egan party. It is expected that the Eastern delegates who will co-operate will arrive in a few days, and it is intended to gives them a hearty welcome.

BELFAST, Aug. 9.--During the rioting which occurred here from Saturday evening to an early hour this morning, 11 persons were killed and 130 seriously wounded. The majority of the injured persons have shot wounds. The rioting was renewed to-day and a fierce encounter took place between the soldiers and the mob, in which several persons were wounded.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug 9.--A large number of the Grand Army of the Republic members went in a body to-day to Oakland, where they were received by the Mayor and citizens. A reception given them by the school children was an interesting feature of the occasion.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The widow of Mr. John Brown, who for many years was a merchant in Newburg, died in this city yesterday at the age of 95 years. Mrs. Brown was a daughter of the Rev. Mr. Wilson, for some years a prominent clergyman at Newburg of the Covenanter denomination. She was one of three daughters, all of whom lived to good old ages.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--The steamship Palestine, (Br.,) Capt. Whiteway, which arr. at Liverpool Aug. 8 from Boston, lost 45 head of cattle on the passage. The Inman Line steamship City of Chestar, Capt. Condron, from New-York July 31 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head to-day at 9:20 P.M.

Members of the Cigar Manufacturers' Association had rather a stormy conference with the Knights of Labor yesterday, at Lenox Hall, at Third-avenue and Seventy-second-street. District Assembly No. 49 was represented by District Master Workman T.B. Maguire, Master Workman Wolf, John Daly, and Messrs. Bliss and Ely.

LITTLE ROCK, Aug. 9.--Col. W.B. Haxton, Republican candidate for Representative from Washington County, while making a canvass became insane. He will be placed in the asylum here this week. Haxton has been a prominent citizen in the county named since the war. He came to this State from Indiana.

The telegraph lines of the Canadian Pacific Railway Company have just been completed from Montreal to Richford, Vt., and connected with the lines of the Postal Telegraph Company. Canadian points are thus brought in direct tele graphic communication with the United States over lines competing with the Western Union, and also with Europe by the Commercial Company's cable.

TOMBSTONE, Arizona, Aug. 9.--Three different reports have been received relative to the Indian raids near Ures last week. One was that they killed 11 teamsters, all Americans, and 40 mules. Another report said seven Mexicans and two Americans were killed.

The vessel owners and shippers of the Produce Exchange held an adjourned meeting yesterday afternoon and adopted rules which will be submitted to the Board of Managers in a few days. They also decided to be governed by the Baltimore charter party except in cases of special contract. The rules adopted are intended for the government of steamship trade.

When General Master Workman POWDERLY finds time to look into the affairs of the Knights of Labor in this vicinity he will discover that District Assembly No. 49 stands greatly in need of discipline and reorganization.

PEABODY, Mass., Aug. 9.--Singular scenes have marred the quietness of this New-England village to-day, but the staid inhabitant breathes easier to-night when he realizes that a day of intense anxiety has passed without bloodshed. It is an anxious time for all concerned, but the ...
LANCASTER, Penn. Aug. 9.--The Prohibition County Convention to-day nominated N.S. Wolle, of Litiz, for Congress. They also nominated a full legislative and county ticket.

LONDON, Aug. 9.--The returns issued by the Board of Trade show that the imports for July decreased 2,150,000 as compared with the same month last year, and that the exports decreased 690,000 as compared with July of last year.
DETROIT, Aug. 9.--The July output of the Lake Superior copper mines was: Calumet and Hecla, 2,746 tons; Quincy, 301 tons; Franklin, 203 tons; Atlantic, 201 tons.
ALBANY, Aug. 9.--The report of the NewYork, Lake Erie and Western Railroad to the Railroad Commission for the quarter ending June 30, 1886, compared with the same quarter last year, is as follows:

The triennial housecleaning of the Custom House and bonded warehouses was begun yesterday. Wilmerding, Hoguet Co., auctioneers, began the sale of 716 lots of goods, which have been in bond for three years and more.

The Fairfield (Me.) Journal says that Mr. A.P. Williams, the new Senator from California, was born in Maine in 1830, received a common school and academic education, taught school, and in early manhood went to Fairfield, where, after acting as clerk in a store for a time, he went into trade on his own account.

DUNGANNON, Ulster, Ireland, July 19.-- The cable apprises New-York as quickly as it does the London papers, and with much more impartiality, of the phases of the elections now closing. It describes the Orange riots minutely and the peaceable as well as forcible efforts of the Nationalists to meet intimidation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--Collector Hedden's successor at the head of the New-York Custom House will be named within the next 24 hours. The choice was made by President Cleveland during a long private conference between himself and Acting Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild, held at the White House to-day.

As the sun was making a determined effort to bridge the kill west of Staten Island yesterday afternoon the crack lacrosse players of Toronto, Canada, were engaged in a lively tussle with those of the New-York Lacrosse Club, which resulted in a decided victory for the former.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 9.--The day was clear and bright, with a spanking southwest breeze, for the run of the New-York Yacht Club squadron from Newport to this ancient whaling town. The yachts were alive with preparations in Newport harbor at an early hour, and got their large sails set in readiness for the start.

The General Committee of the Prohibition Party for the city and county of New-York held a meeting at Demarest's Hall, in Fourteenthstreet, last night. When the Assembly Districts were called it was found that all except three had elected delegates to the Congressional and County conventions.
"A.W."--Connor, of New-York. His record was .371. "J.D.S."--Yes. The pitcher should be credited with an assist.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9.--The Philadelphians had an easy time with the Chicago champions today, batting hard and, barring two bases on balls, fielding perfectly.

GASTEIN, Aug. 9.--The Emperor Francis Joseph to-day visited the Emperor William and Prince Bismarck, spending half an hour with each. Count Kalnoky, Austro-Hungarian Prime Minister, and Prince Hohenlohe, Governor of Alsace-Lorraine, called upon Prince Bismarck and subsequently Count Kalnoky visited the Emperor William and had an interview with ...

RED WING, Minn., Aug. 9.--Cheldon Co.'s elevator at Eggleston, Minn., was burned Saturday night. The burning debris fell upon the railway track and the up freight train was thrown from the track after the engine had passed, and 17 cars, loaded with merchandise, machinery, and ties, were burned.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 9.--The Prohibition Party of Lancaster County held a convention here to-day for the election of delegates to the State Convention, the nomination of a county ticket, The Hon. James Black called the meeting to order, and the Rev. J.B. Turner, of Little Britain Township, was elected Chairman.

Mr. Tilden's will was read yesterday at Greystone. Anticipations that it would be an extraordinary document were fully met. It was voluminous, explicit, and full of details, showing the hand of the master in those respects, and yet it left such wide discretion to John Bigelow, Andrew H. Green, and G.W. Smith, Executors ...
The brewery of G. Feigenspan Co., on Cypress-avenue, near Ridgewood Park, Long Island, caught fire from some unknown source at 6 o'clock last evening and inside of two hours was in ruins.

WINDSOR, Ontario, Aug. 9.--All efforts to stamp out the hog cholera which broke out in Essex County last Fall have been futile. Just now it is raging in a very virulent type in West Sandwich and is killing hogs by hundreds. One farmer lost 23 last week, another 17, and another 13.
The news that papers of reconciliation have been drawn up by Col. Clark, of the Seventh Regiment, and Col. Winchester, of the veteran Corps, is favorably received everywhere.

David Gossard, of Washington County, Md., has just been celebrating the birth of his twenty-fourth child, a bouncing 13-pound baby girl, who has been named Frances Folsom Cleveland Gossard. No. 23, a boy, born the day President Cleveland was inaugurated, was named after the President. There are 15 boys and 9 girls in the family, but they are not the children of one mother. Fourteen were by the first wife and 10 by the second.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9.--The season is booming in earnest, and to-day, despite the departure of the yacht fleet, Newport has been unusually lively, the leading events being the polo games, numerous private entertainments at the cottages, and the dance at the Casino tonight. There were not many arrivals at the hotels, but this is usually the case on Monday.

The consolidation of two gas companies, which supply the lower section of Jersey City, was reported yesterday. The companies are the United Improvement Company, a Philadelphia concern which succeeded the Jersey City Gaslight Company, and the Consumers' Gas Company.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 9.--Wallingford was an excited town to-day, and the citizens did little but discuss the finding of the headless trunk of a man in a box in the Parker farm swamp. Coroner Mix, of this city, went to Wallingford to-day to help the town authorities to investigate the case, but curiously enough the murder seems to-night more completely shrouded ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9.--Judge Butler, in the United States District Court, rendered a decision to-day in the application of Samuel L. Clemens (Mark Twain) in behalf of C.L. Webster Co., of Hartford, Conn., for a preliminary injunction to restrain sale of copies of Gen. Grant's personal memoirs in this city by John Wanamaker Co.

PANAMA, July 31.--There are various reports in circulation in reference to the canal, and although a cable message has been received that M. de Lesseps, on behalf of the Directors, has again declared that it will be finished by June, 1889, doubts are very generally entertained on the subject, and confidence has not increased in the ultimate success of the project under the present company.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Aug. 9.--Scattering reports from the Southwest, where some thrashing has been done, are generally encouraging. In many places in the James River country, where the crop was supposed to be very badly damaged, wheat is turning out fairly well.

QUEBEC, Aug. 9.--The Captain of the steamer Colina reports that while passing Amour Point he noticed ashore in Forteau Bay what appeared to be a steamer with a black funnel with a white stripe. There is no telegraphic communication with this point, and no particulars can be learned at present.

John Burke, aged 32 years, a dissipated teamster, residing on Morgan-street, Union Hill, N.J., was committed to the Hudson County Jail for 30 days on July 19. After his incarceration Burke persistently refused to take food of any kind, and announced his intention of starving himself to death.

A two-story brick building, fronting on Willis-avenue and extending along One Hundred and Thirty-fourth-street for two-thirds of the block toward Alexander-avenue, owned and occupied by the New-York Lumber and Woodworking Company, was with its contents destroyed by fire last night, involving a loss of nearly $100,000.

A few weeks ago the Brooklyn Board of Assessors fixed the value of the Union Ferry Company's houses along the East River water front at $132,000. The ground upon which these houses are built is owned by the city of New-York, the authorities of ...

NEW-LONDON, Conn., Aug. 9.--The Quinnipiac Fertilizer Company, of this city, is embarrassed. William P. Baker, of Boston, has been appointed Assignee. The Bank of Commerce, the National Union Bank, and the City National Bank, of this city, each lose $20,000. The liabilities are $211,000. The assets are unknown.

The Cleburne (Texas) Telegram threatens to secede. It say: "Texas entered the Union under the proviso that her citizens and property would be protected. If the Union fails to carry out her part of the contract then that contract is null and void.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 9.--The polo games for the Westchester Polo Club's cup were witnessed to-day by a large number of the elite of Newport. Seldom has the playing been livelier or the riding harder or more skillfully executed. The drawback was the disregard for the rules shown by some players and the consequent fouls.

MILWAUKEE, Aug. 9.--The forest fires which are now raging in Northern Wisconsin and Michigan promise a repetition of the calamity which happened 15 years ago, except that the losses and sufferings will be much greater, as the territory, then almost a wilderness, is now dotted with scores of thriving towns and villages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--Major Theodore Schwan, Assistant Adjutant-General, has been ordered to repair to Washington and report to the Adjutant-General for duty in his office. The following named engineer officers (recent graduates) will, upon the expiration of their present leaves of absence, report to Lieut.-Col. Cyrus B. Comstock, Willet's Point, N.Y., for duty; Second Lieut. Henry C. Newcomer, additional ...

Samuel Miln, 19 years old, of No. 49 Seigel-street, Brooklyn, was arrested last night as a witness in the Pfister murder case. He had been overheard to say that he knew something about the matter, but when he was arrested he said he was only joking.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal. Aug. 9.--Sight drafts on New-York, 10; Telegraphic, 15.

Judge Potter has appointed Peter McAleer Receiver of the property of Peter Lamb, owner of the Tremont House and other cheap east side lodging houses. Jeremiah Sullivan sued Lamb for an unprovoked assault committed on him in the Tremont House, A jury in the Supreme Court awarded Sullivan $500 damages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 9.--It is believed at the State Department that the Cutting case will be disposed of in a satisfactory way without resorting to extreme measures. Secretary Bayard's peremptory demand for Cutting's release has neither been withdrawn nor modified, but now that Cutting has been tried and convicted ...

Radical as is the reorganization of the National Guard of New-York effected by General Order No. 21, the soundness of its principle seems to be conceded; and were it somewhat less sweeping in scope, it would command almost universal acceptance.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--The single scull race between Edward Hanlan, George H. Hosmer, James Ten Eyck, and John McKay, off Nantasket Beach this evening, was won by Hanlan, with McKay second, Ten Eyck third, and Hosmer far in the rear. Hanlan was in superb form and easily demonstrated his superiority.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--August Spies and Michael Schwab were both on the witness stand to-day. The rumor had been current that Spies would take the stand, and served to attract the largest crowd that had thus far visited Judge Gary's court. After long consultation between counsel for the defense Schwab was called as the first witness.

OTTAWA, Aug. 9.--One thousand French Canadians left here to-day by the Canada Atlantic Railroad en route for the famous shrine of Ste. Anne de Beaupre, below Quebec. They included scores of cripples, invalids, and blind persons.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--A special dispatch from Oakland, Ill., says: "Never since the time Lincoln and Douglas met in joint debate at Mattoon has there been such a large crowd of people gathered here as that which met on the Murdock camp meeting grounds yesterday.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 9.--The Springfield Bicycle Club will hold their annual tournament Sept. 14, 15, 16, and 17. The chief feature will be a one-mile international world's championship race, for amateur riders with a record of 2:45.

As police officers Dingle, Faulkner and Travers, of the southern harbor patrol, were passing Locust Point Ferry Saturday night they heard the cry of "Man overboard!" After a moment's work they fished out of the water a wet but indignant gentleman, who refused to give his name. They laid him out on the wharf, and labored with him until he had fairly recovered.

MOREHEAD, Ky., Aug. 9.--There is a strong probability that the famous Rowan County troubles are at an end. For years the feud has given Kentucky a bad name throughout the country, and the prospect of a settlement would be hailed with satisfaction everywhere.
Justice Duffy had a big day yesterday, and settled nearly 300 cases; yet he spent a few moments with a namesake, who was brought before him in the afternoon.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 9.--A few days ago Mrs. Kyte, widow of the Rev. Felix Kyte, of Eldred, Sullivan County, N.Y., felt a peculiar pain in her right arm, which increased to such an extent that Dr. N.B. Johnson, of Barryville, was called in. He found that there was some foreign substance in the arm, and, making an incision ...
The racing to-day at Monmouth Park will be extremely interesting, as all of the six races have numerous entries and several animals of high class will take part in the fights for the rich prizes.
SARATOGA, Aug. 9.--This was the sixth extra day of the race meeting here. The weather was pleasant, the attendance fair, and the track in good condition.

WHEELING, West Va., Aug. 9.--Laughlin Nail Company to-day signed the Amalgamated Association's nailing scale. The mill is now full of non-union workmen who are to remain by the agreement, but the company's factory No. 2, recently burned, will be immediately rebuilt and the machines given to the striking nailers.

Hanlon, of the Detroit Club, batted a ball to Esterbrook, of the New-Yorks, on the Polo Grounds about sundown last evening and it was thrown to first base before the runner could reach that vicinity. INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Aug. 9.--Only a few of the leading Democrats have arrived at the capital, but already the candidates are here. Senator Voorhees is expected here to-morrow, when the work will begin in real earnest.

The delegation from the Irish Parliamentary Party, consisting of Messrs. O'Brien, Redmond, and Deasy, which is coming to attend the Chicago Convention of the Irish National League of America, to be held on Aug. 18 and 19, sailed on Sunday afternoon on the Cunard steamship Servia from Queenstown.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 9.--Mayor Russell, of Cambridge, has successfully acted the part of mediator between John P. Squire and his looked-out employes. The result of his labors will be shown to-morrow, when many of the workmen will go back to work, the rest following as soon as the works are in readiness.

In reference to the false reports about famine and suffering in Labrador so freely sent abroad last week there is room for the Great Northwestern Telegraph Company to rise and explain. WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 9.--The Democracy of Washington County are in extremely bad shape. A nominating convention was held to-day, being the second called, for the purpose of putting candidates into the field.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--A storm which prevailed in the Northwest yesterday was remarkable for the number of lightning strokes accompanying it.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--While the employes of the Swift Company's packing house were at a picnic at Cedar Lake, Indiana, yesterday, a party of five went out in a rowboat. When in the middle of the lake some of the party began rocking the boat.

THOUSAND ISLAND PARK, N.Y., Aug. 9.-- The meetings of the International Missionary Union are all largely attended and much interest is manifested in them. To-day's exercises were opened with a discussion of denominational courtesy and the union of churches of a similar creed and policy.
Coroner Messemer and his deputy, Dr. Herold, went to the Chambers-Street Hospital yesterday morning to view the body of little Sarah Schoenberger, 8 years old, who died at 3:30 A.M.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--Kansas City defeated Boston to-day in a ten-inning game. Radbourn and Whitney were the pitchers and both were batted freely, the visitors slightly excelling in the number of safe hits.

SOUTH FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Aug. 9.--It is generally thought that the difficulties at the works of the Para Rubber Shoe Company have been practically settled, and that the works will be again in full operation by Monday, Aug. 16. At a meeting on Saturday night the workmen expressed a desire to return to work as soon ...
The Canadian Cricket Club, I. Zingari, played their first game against the strong team of the Staten Island Club yesterday, and, much to the astonishment of the spectators, won a victory easily.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 9.--The Builders' Exchange has ascertained on reliable authority that the bricklayers' strike in this city, on account of the employment of non-union hodcarriers, is in obedience to an order from the International Amalgamated Union.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 9.--To-day's game between the Louisvilles and the Metropolitans was one of the finest fielding exhibitions ever seen on the home grounds.

Collector Hedden is still rusticating. Information to this effect seemed to exert a dispiriting influence upon a large number of persons who called at his office yesterday. They simply wanted to know if he had resigned his position.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 9.--While conveying a prisoner named Blackwell to jail this afternoon Chief of Police Green Williams was fired upon, the ball entering the leg just above the knee, and causing a painful wound. The Chief returned the fire, striking Blackwell in the side. Blackwell, who lives in North Danville, ran after the firing, but was pursued by the Mayor and other officials, captured, and lodged in jail.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 9.--The El Paso correspondent of the Globe-Democrat telegraphs tonight as follows: "The only news in the Cutting case is the fact that he was brought before the court again to-day and told that his attorney had appealed his case to the Supreme Court of the State, and that the appeal had been granted.

An inquest in the case of John J. Murray, of Long Island City, who was found dead with a crushed skull on the trestle of the New-York, Woodhaven and Rockaway Railroad, near Rockaway, on Aug. 2, was begun by Coroner Everitt, in Jamaica, last evening.
A tramp whom William Kinzey, of No. 765 Communipaw-avenue, Jersey City, refused to give 25 cents poured a bottle of turpentine down Kinzey's throat. The tramp escaped. Kinzey is in a bad condition.

CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--A special dispatch from Indianapolis, says: "One week ago last Saturday some of the people living at Birdseye, Dubois County, and the surrounding country, gave a picnic, which was largely attended.
CHICAGO, Aug. 9.--The following are the entries and weights for to-morrow's races at Washington Park:

The steerage passengers of the disabled North German Lloyd steamship Werra, which put into Boston on Saturday, arrived here yesterday morning. They came by rail as far as Mott Haven and were transferred from there to Castle Garden by the steamer Fletcher.

DETROIT, Aug. 9--For some time past the extreme western parts of Ontario have been flooded with $1 and $2 American bank notes raised to $10 notes. Three or four arrests have been made, but the prisoners have been speedily discharged, being entirely innocent.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The monthly circular of the New-York Milk Exchange, (Limited,) just issued to producers on the principal lines of supply, gives notice that the price of milk for August is fixed at 3 cents a quart, less freight and ferriage, which makes the net price to the farmer 2 cents.

Frederick D. Gardner, a young fruit dealer in Middletown, Conn., left that place on July 28 for this city to collect bills and make purchases for his establishment. Mr. Gardner spent several days in reaching the city, as he stopped at many small places on his way to collect small bills owed to him. Arriving in New-York he went to stay at the Bancroft House, making purchasing tours each day.

CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y., Aug. 9.--There was a large attendance and much interest at the devotional meeting this morning led by Dr. B.M. Adams, of New-York. At the Hall of Philosophy Prof. Barden P. Bowne, of the Boston University, delivered his first morning lecture on the "Philosophy of Theism."

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 9.--The citizens of Gloucester City, N.J., were shocked to-day over a report, widely circulated, which charged the late City Treasurer, Albert J. Greene, with being a defaulter, and that the city was bankrupt. The rumor was started last week, when the Finance Committee met on two separate evenings and transacted business with closed doors.

Quarantine would have gone to sleep in the sun yesterday with extreme willingness on the ground that there was nothing to do and plenty of time to do it in if it had not been for the machinations of a pretty little yacht, which sailed up to the dock at noon and took possession of everything--dock, nude boys, nurses with children, and Summer resorts.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 9.--The contract for building the iron bridge across the Seneca River for the new Baldwinsville and Amboy Railroad was to-day awarded to Daniel Candee, of this city. The bridge is to be 350 feet in length. The new railroad is to connect Baldwinsville with the New-York Central system at Amboy and is to be run in opposition to the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western.

UTICA, Aug. 9.--The property of the late Abijah J. Williams, manufacturer, of this county, is reported to inventory nearly $2,000,000. The will makes a few bequests to servants and grandchildren and divides the rest of the estate into five equal parts.

BOSTON, Aug. 9.--P.F. Williams, lumber dealer, No. 70 Kilby-street, and Russell, Sheen Co., lumber delears, No. 13 Doane-street, have failed and the following firms being involved in their affairs have also failed in consequence: Allen Noble, hardware dealers, No. 127 Washington-street; Gerrish O'Brien, furniture dealers, No. 175 Blackstonestreet; Thomas F. Brown Co., furniture, No. 17 ...

Mrs. Martha R. Doxey, of No. 159 Charlesstreet, reported yesterday at the Bureau of Vital Statistics that a girl baby, which had been left with her a short time ago under peculiar circumstances, had died.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 9.--The steamer Mariposa, which arrived last evening from Australia, brings further details of the great volcanic disturbances which lately occurred in New-Zealand. Heavy earthquakes were still felt in the Farawera and Sulphur Springs Districts, and severe shocks continued in the Rotoli District. A relief party that was sent out reported that Lake Farawera had fallen considerably.

BURLINGTON, Iowa, Aug. 10.--The meteorologist, Prof. Foster, will say in the Burlington Hawk-Eye to-morrow that one of the greatest storm periods of 1886 will begin on Aug. 16 and continue till the 27th, during which the great drought will be completely broken by heavy rains, ...

Judge George S. Jenks qualified as SolicitorGeneral this morning, and entered on the discharge of the duties of that office. He also relieved Assistant Attorney-General Maury of the duties of Acting Attorney-General, which he has performed since the departure of Mr. Garland.

CHAUTAUQUA, N. Y., Aug. 10.--The attendance to-day is extraordinary. In addition to the 10,000 Summer visitors several hundred members of the American Society of Microscopists are in session here. The international institute for preserving the units of the AngloSaxon weights and measures is holding an annual convention here to-day.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 10.--The rowdyism that ruled in the Democratic County Convention yesterday, in which a number of free fights were indulged in, was beyond all precedent. A like gathering had never before disgraced any party in Ohio. But the climax was reached to-day in the Judicial Convention.

HAVANA, Aug. 10.--Advices from Hayti of the 23d ult. say that the commercial distress prevailing in that republic could not possibly be worse. Coffee was quoted at 7 . American gold was quoted at 40 per cent., and was scarce. The country was quiet politically.

John Roach's steam yacht Yosemite, which was chartered by Washington E. Connor for the cruise of the American Yacht Club and a subsequent cruise in Eastern waters, arrived in this port yesterday morning and later in the day was formally transferred to the Canadian Government.

PEABODY, Mass., Aug. 10.--The outbreak of Saturday and Monday seems to have spent its force in a great measure, and the lawless element, which captured a citizens' meeting on Sunday and kicked a workman nearly to death ...

FALL RIVER, Mass., Aug. 10.--The Spinners' Union held a meeting to-night. Visitors were present from the Knights of Labor assemblies in Lynn and other places. Secretary Howard reported that he had a conference today with Superintendent Hart and Treasurer ...

Steamship Nevada, (Br.,) Douglass, Liverpool July 31 and Queenstown Aug.1, with mdse. and passengers to A. M. Underhill Co. Bark Galeota, (of Glasgow,) Reid, Port Spain 19 ds., with sugar to George Christal--vessel to master.

PARIS, July 20.--There can be no doubt of the intense love of every French man, woman, and child for the bright buttons, the red trousers, and all the prestige of the soldier lad. Nothing can bring out the working classes in such decent, dressed-up order; the most tired, worn-out apprentice ...

On Saturday night Joseph Brown, of Cohoes, bought a circus ticket of a speculator at Troy, who said it was "60 cents in silver or 50 cents in paper." To save 10 cents Brown gave the man a ten-dollar bill, who folded it and put it in his pocket.

The coffin and skeleton of the famous Bishop Courtenay, who was Lord Privy Seal to Edward IV., who was present at Bosworth and is mentioned in "Richard III.," has been discovered built up in masonry in the crypt of Winchester Cathedral. The remains are to be reinterred in an altar tomb in the Lady Chapel, which has just been redecorated. Mr. Kitchin, the son of the accomplished Dean of Winchester, is designing the proposed tomb.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 10.--A report was in circulation here early this evening that Congressman Lewis Beach had died at his home in Cornwall at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--From Lander, Wyoming Territory, to-day comes a story which is of curious interest to the sporting community. It is to the effect that John Gaylor, a well known hunter and trapper of the Wind Mountains, has slain a white buffalo bull or one so gray that it can very easily be called white.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--In the Anarchists' trials to-day the defense called W. A. S. Graham, a reporter on the Times, to impeach the testimony of Gilmer, one of the witnesses for the State. Before Graham was examined, however, Gilmer was recalled for cross-examination.

ALBANY, N.Y., Aug. 10.--James W. Davis, son of Joseph Davis, formerly Postmaster here, returned yesterday afternoon from the Utica Insane Asylum, where he had been since March. His family protested against his release, but ...

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 10.--Mr. and Mrs. H. Victor Newcomb, of New-York, attended the Casino dance last night, and upon returning home Mr. Newcomb seated himself in his study and called for a luncheon, which was brought to him by his butler.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 10.--A switch engine exploded in the Union Pacific yards, West Kansas City, to-day. Charles Haige, fireman, and Edward Colestock, foreman of the yards, were dangerously hurt. Robert Wilson, engineer, and Abe Laughlin, switchman, were also badly wounded.

Mr. Tilden's will was not filed yesterday. The Trustees wanted to settle contain matters before taking this step, and they felt there was no need of haste in the matter. The questions discussed by them affected procedure mainly, and upon some of them they yet need advice, ...
Miss Kate Claxton is acting in "Arrah-naPogue" at the Boston Museum, supported by Mr. Charles A. Stevenson as Shaun the Post.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10.--Since the official correspondence in the case of A.K. Cutting was sent to Congress by the President eight days ago there has been no further official communication on the subject between the United States and Mexican Governments, except verbal communications between Secretary Bayard and Minister Romero.

The first international lacrosse match ever played here between representatives of this country and Ireland took place yesterday on the St. George Grounds, Staten Island. The grand stand was fairly well filled, but the attendance was not so large as at the Toronto-New-York game on Monday.

Custom House circles were relieved yesterday, not so much by the discovery that Mr. Magone had been appointed Collector as that all doubt regarding Collector Hedden's resignation had been removed. Mr. Hedden was not at his office, but his resignation was. The following is a copy of it:

BOSTON, Aug. 10.--Boston took another game from Kansas City to-day. Every Boston player made at least one safe hit, and only for brilliant work by Radford, Myers, and Donnelly, Conway's punishment would have been far worse.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 10.--The builders' lock-out continues, and nearly everything in that line is at a standstill. The large brickyards just outside the city, as a consequence of this state of things, have shut down, and, they say, will not open again this season. This affects 400 families and 2,500 persons.

GALVESTON, Aug. 10.--The State Democratic Convention assembled here at noon today for the purpose of nominating a State ticket. Chairman Barry, of the State Executive Committee, called the contention to order. After prayer Chairman Barry congratulated the convention on the triumph of the Democracy, extolled the wisdom and patriotism of President Cleveland, and counseled moderation.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 10.--The preliminary meetings of the several districts for the Democratic Convention to-morrow were held to-night, and all passed off harmoniously, with the exception of the Third District, where the HowardStockslager trouble broke out in the election of a member of the State Central Committee.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Aug. 10.--Among the speakers at the International Temperance Camp Meeting to-day were B. B. Johnson, Mayor of Waltham, Mass.; Axel Gustafson, of Sweden; L. E. Dudley, Secretary of the Law and Order League of the United States, and C. C. Bonney, of Chicago. President of the Law and Order League. The recent dynamite outrages in revenge for the enforcement of the Scott temperance act were condemned by the meeting.
MYSTIC, Conn., Aug 10.--The American branch of the Universal Peace Union has decided to hold its annual convention here on Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday of next week.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 10.--Daniel Magone, of Ogdensburg, Samuel J. Tilden's trusted adherent in bygone days and a warm personal friend of Acting Secretary of the Treasury Fairchild, is the new Collector of the Port of NewYork.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Aug. 10.--The Department of Agriculture has received 257 special reports, covering every County in the State, on the condition of the crops, and furnishes the following summary: The reports of the cotton crop with few exceptions are unfavorable.

The leaders of the Home Club of District Assembly No. 49 picked out a number of the most muscular car drivers they could find yesterday and put them on picket duty at the cigar factories in opposition to the union pickets. Six strapping fellows were statfoned around Jacoby's factory and two near Levy's factory. They found the union pickets on the ground and amused themselves chasing the latter from one point to another.
CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--Early this morning Charles Martindale, of Hermosa, a village in the town of Jefferson, was walking across a stretch of prairie when he suddenly came upon the dead body of a woman.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 10.--A special to the Times-Democrat from Biloxi, Miss., says: "The British bark Excelsior, the arrival of which at Ship Island Quarantine was mentioned in yesterday's dispatches, has 10 men sick out of a crew of 16. Four of these are diagnosed by Dr. Murray as yellow fever cases. The others are fevers of various kinds. All the sick are doing well."

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10.--This was the last day of the first Summer race meeting here. There was a large attendance. The weather was warm and clear, and the track was fast. Mollie McCarthy's Last, in the second race, and Islette, in the fourth, were scratched.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 10.--The much-talked-about firemen's tournament is in progress. The proceedings were opened this morning with a grand procession of the city and visiting firemen in uniform in line. Each division was represented by hose, reel and steam engine. These were elaborately decorated.

BOSTON, Aug. 10.--Walter H. Balch, lumber dealer on Federal-street, has failed. He is trying to settle with his creditors. This failure is connected with the failure of P. F. Williams, lumber dealer of Kilby-street, which involved six other firms in financial difficulties.

Among the various political rumors that were floating around the City Hall yesterday was one that Postmaster Henry G. Pearson had resigned. The rumor was quite specific. It stated that Mr. Pearson had "forwarded his resignation to the President at 11 o'clock in the morning."

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--A settlement has been effected with the creditors of A.P. Elder, proprietor of Literary Life, and the custodian placed on the office of the magazine has been released. It is stated by Mr. Elder that the seizure yesterday would have been obviated had he received sufficient notice, and that the publication of the periodical would proceed as usual.

HAVANA, Aug. 10.--San Domingo advices of the 27th ult. say that the District of Vega has revolted under Gen. Casimiro Moya, who was a candidate for the Presidency in the last elections, and that the whole republic has been declared in a state of siege.

Commissioner Rollin M. Squire and Maurice B. Flynn, the Department of Public Works conspirators, were brought up with a round turn yesterday. Squire was arrested in the Mayor's office and Flynn was arrested in Chambers-street while on the way to the District Attorney's office to give himself up. The fact that both of these worthies were under arrest created a stir such as was witnessed in the days of the fall of the Tweed regime.

LONDON, Aug. 10.--Mr. James Baillie Hamilton was married to-day in Westminster Abbey to Lady Evelyn, fourth daughter of the Duke of Argyil. Mr. Hamilton is well known in New-York and Boston. The ceremony was witnessed by a large assembly of distinguished persons.
PARIS, Aug. 10.-- Another collision has occurred between the striking waiters and the police. Several arrests were made.

During the last three years G. T. Young, near Atglen, has killed 13 copperhead snakes and 1 viper. His son killed a horned or hoop snake this Summer, a species nearly extinct; only one other has been known in that locality in 50 years.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 10.--About a week ago Joe Massarang, who keeps a saloon at No. 3,838 Easton-avenue, engaged a scavenger to clean out the vault in the rear of his premises. Work had scarcely been commenced when a pair of shoes were brought out and in the shoes were some small bones.

NASHVILLE, Aug. 10.--The Democratic State Convention, which will meet in this city at noon to-morrow to nominate a candidate for Governor, will be attended by 1,800 delegates. MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 10.--A dispatch to the Evening Wisconsin from Lake Mills says the boiler of a thrashing machine exploded on the Foster farm, near Jefferson, Wis., to-day, killing five person instantly--Anthony Klein, the engineer, and his son; Joseph Lester and his 10year-old boy, and Joseph Hass. Another of Lester's sons, aged 8 years, and a man named Fisher were fatally scalded, while several other persons received scalds.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 10.--The second annual grove meeting of the Universalists of Vermont opened at Queen City Park to-day with 600 in attendance, including over 100 Universalists from Boston and vicinity and prominent representatives of the denomination from all parts of New-England.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--The constant supply of flowers to the Anarchists on trial has been a great source of curiosity here. Each day since the beginning of the Anarchists' trial one or more of the prisoners has been embarrassed by a bouquet of flowers, which they hardly know what to do with.

Thomas H. Dudley, Camden; the Hon. William S. Taylor, Burlington; the Hon. N. S. Rue, Cream Ridge; the Hon. Thomas N. Lawrence, Hamburg; the Hon. A. W. Cutter, Morristown; Dr. M. H. C. Vail, Newark and Peter Henderson, Jersey City.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug. 10.--At the Republican County Convention of Lackawanna, held here to-day, Joseph A. Scranton was renominated as candidate for Congress in the Twelfth District. Resolutions were adopted approving the State ticket and platform.

District Assembly No. 75, Knights of Labor, held a secret meeting at No. 359 Fultonstreet, Brooklyn, last night. The principal business of the meeting was the election of delegates to the General Assembly, to be held in Richmond, Va., in October.

ROCHESTER, Aug. 10.--The grand circuit trotting races opened here to-day. There was a good attendance for the first day. The weather was perfect--clear, hot, and without wind--and the track was fast.

OTTAWA, Aug. 10.--Sir Hector Langevin, Minister of Public Works, on view of the enormous trade which will spring up between the Dominion and the East, is considering the advisability of enlarging the graving dock recently completed at Esquimault, British Columbia.
LONDON, Aug. 11.--The steamship Caspian, (Br.,) Capt. Barrett, from Baltimore July 27 for Liverpool, passed Brow Head yesterday.

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Aug. 10.--The Prohibitionists of the Twenty-sixth Congressional District to-day nominated the Rev. G. Dwight Williams. Pastor of the Methodist church at Cazenovia, for Congress. There were 225 delegates present.

SANDWICH, Mass., Aug. 10.--After a six weeks' shut down the fires were lighted in the furnaces of the Boston and Sandwich Glass Works last night, and work will be resumed as soon as the furnaces are sufficiently heated.

COTTAGE CITY, Mass., Aug. 10.--At 8:30 this morning the Royal Northern Yacht Club, of which Lieut. Henn is a member, was saluted by the New-York fleet at New-Bedford. The flag was hoisted on the Electra and a salute was fired. At 9 A. M. Commodore Gerry paid his respects to the Galatea.

PORTLAND, Aug. 11.--Among the orators invited by the Prohibitionists to take part in the coming campaign are ex-Gov. St. John, who will speak at Calais, Presque Isle, and Houlton; John B. Finch, Col. R. S. Cleves, Prof. A. A. Hopkins, Frank T. Sibley, the Rep. C. W. Stiles, and George W. Penmman. A Prohibition ticket will be run in every county.

The Directors of the American Agricultural and Dairy Association held a meeting yesterday afternoon at No. 169 Chambers-street to congratulate themselves upon the passage of the Oleomargarine bill by Congress and to map some future work. There were present J. H. Reall, James H. Seymour, F. B. Thurber, James Anderson, Charles N. Chase, R. J. Dean, and William I. Young.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Aug. 10.--Two men who were evidently under the influence of liquor, in an attempt to cross the track at Key East, were struck by a south-bound train this evening. They were conveyed to Asbury Park. Dr. Kenmonth, who had charge of them, found a number of serious bruises about their faces and limbs. Their names could not be ascertained.

CHICAGO, Aug. 10.--The reports of fires in the pineries and lumber regions close to the Chicago market have filled with dismay many dealers who draw their supplies from this point. Telegraph and postal directions duplicating previous orders were received in great numbers today. They were promptly filled at card rates.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 10.--Christopher Evans, President of the Miners' National Association, has declined the nomination of Secretary of State tendered him by the Greenback Labor Party, of Ohio. Charles Bonsall, of Salem, Ohio, has been named by the State Central Committee to fill the vacancy caused by Mr. Evans's refusal to run.

BELFAST, Aug. 10.--The city is tranquil. There are no indications of a renewal of the rioting. It is believed that the worst is over. During the morning of a few minor disturbances occurred. There was some spasmodic bring of revolvers in the streets; enough, in fact, to make walking out of doors more or less dangerous.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 10.--A Well attended meeting of the Democratic State Committee was held here this morning. It was voted to hold the State Convention in New-Haven on Tuesday, Sept. 28.

BOSTON, Aug. 10.--That portion of East Cambridge containing the immense pork packing establishments of John P. Squire was fairly bubbling over with happiness to-day. The great works presented once more a scene of busy activity as the workmen began their customary occupations.

LONDON, Aug. 10.--The House of Commons adjourned this afternoon until Thursday, the 19th inst. The Queen's speech on the reassembling of Parliament will be of remarkable brevity. Beyond a reference to foreign relations probably no subject of importance will be touched upon, and the speech will be confined to the business of the session.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 11.--The overall manufacturing firm of Sweet, Orr Co., who have large manufactories at both Newburg and Wappinger's Falls, have adopted a new plan to reward faithful service and good workmanship by their hundreds of employes.

Deacon "Jim" White, of the Detroit Baseball Club, has a very mournful look, and all the players of the nine appeared like members of the White family as they left the Polo Grounds yesterday. The reason for their gloom was the fact that the third successive defeat had just been administered to them by the New-York Giants.
