CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 11.--Six weeks ago Miss Sadie Nichol, of Sturgeon Bay, Wisconsin, accompanied by a maid came to board at the Cape House. About a week ago the maid left and Miss Nichol declared her inability to pay her board.

CHILLICOTHE, Ohio, Aug. 11.--The Democrats of the Twelfth Congressional District today nominated Gen. James W. Denver.

A career, wonderful for the ingenuity shown in devising plans for the avoidance of honest toil and the capture of wealth, closed yesterday at the Northern Indiana Penitentiary, at Michigan City, Ind. Information of the death of "Gib" Yost was received here by Detective Robert A. Pinkerton.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11.--The Chicago theatre managers who agreed to put no lithographs in windows are already in trouble with engaged traveling companies.

OTSEGO LAKE, COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 11.--It was a desire of the great novelist who first made Cooperstown famous that his native place should one day become a favorite resort to which the overworked and heated people from the cities along the Atlantic coast might turn for recreation, health, and rest during the sultry Summer months.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 11.--The withdrawal of Gen. Keifer as a candidate for the nomination in the Eighth Congressional District has created a decided political sensation.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11.--First Lieut. R.E. Thompson and Second Lieuts. J.A. Swift and F.W. Ellis, now on duty at Fort Myer, Va., have been ordered to report in person to the Chief Signal Officer for duty in Washington. Second Lieut. J.H. Wilbur, Signal Corps, will proceed to Wood's Holl. Mass., and take charge of coast telegraph lines in that vicinity.

PITTSBURG, Aug. 11.--Two freight trains on the Buffalo, Rochester and Pittsburg Railroad came into collision near Falls Creek, Penn., at an early hour this morning. Both trains were badly wrecked, and Engineer Edward Arms was instantly killed. The conductor and brakemen escaped by jumping.

The Chicago newspapers seem to feel a little sore, not unreasonably perhaps, because the theatrical managers of that city have publicly announced the abolition of the system of free passes for the press so long in vogue there.
The whereabouts of General Manager Charles J. Campbell, of the Steinway and Hunter's Point Horse Railroad Company, who disappeared a week ago yesterday, is still a mystery.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 11.--The fast steam yacht built at John Bigler's yard, Newburg, the Dagmar, owned by George A. Bech, made a 16-mile trial trip this evening. She has been already fully described.
LOUISVILLE, Aug. 11.--Floyd Hayes, aged 13 years, was admitted to the City Hospital today. The drum of his right ear is burst. Hayes has had a thrilling experience.

BELFAST, Aug. 11.--The city was quiet last night. The wounded are improving. A petition, which has received numerous signatures, has been handed to the Mayor demanding the appointment of a royal commission to investigate and report upon the causes of the disorders which have occurred here since June. John Malonan died in a hospital here to-day from a gunshot wound.
PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 11.--Capt. Webber, of the schooner J.G. Craig, just arrived from the Grand Banks, brings additional particulars of the mutiny on board a three-masted schooner on the Banks.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Aug. 11.--A yard engine exploded this evening in the Louisville and Nashville yard here. William Speaker, the engineer, was killed, his leg being blown off. Peter Daley, the fireman, had a leg nearly blown off, but the doctors think he will survive.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 11.--A perplexing domestic romance was brought to a climax within a few miles of the corporation limits last evening.

PEABODY, Mass., Aug. 11.--That the lawless element among the striking tanners has not been subdued, if repressed for the time, is demonstrated by the outbreaks which occur at unguarded points or when the officers' backs are turned.

LONDON, Aug. 11.--All the new Ministers have now been re-elected to the House of Commons, every one unopposed. Mr. Matthews, Home Secretary, was re-elected for East Birmingham to-day, the Liberals at the last moment withdrawing their candidate, Alderman Cook, leaving the field clear for Mr. Matthews.

Mr. Fred Noble informs us that their party in coming from Evanston last week captured an immense black eagle over on the Sandies which measured 15 feet from tip to tip. The bird was on the ground at the time, and the breeze was not sufficient to enable him to rise and fly away, hence he was easily taken.

After a long and painful illness, during which he showed a remarkable amount of fortitude, Frank Hastings Hamilton, M.D., LL. D., died yesterday morning, just before 11 o'clock, after having spent almost 73 years in putting himself among the foremost American surgeons.

NORFOLK, Aug. 11.--Mrs. Virniza Wyatt, 72 years old, in a fit of insanity committed suicide by hanging herself to the head of her bed at her home in this city to-day.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 11.--Pleuropneumonia has appeared among another herd of cattle in Manor Township, this county. Dr. Bridges, of Philadelphia, State Veterinarian, yesterday killed four head on the farm of Cyrus Mann and inoculated the remainder of the herd. The other herds infected are improving.

LONG BEACH, Long Island, Aug. 11.--Gov. Hill this evening said in relation to the appointment of Daniel Magone as Collector of the Port of New York: "I think the appointment of Mr. Magone as Collector of the Port of New-York an eminently good one, in fact one of the best made by President Cleveland. The many friends, in Albany and elsewhere, of Mr. James C. Matthews will be glad to learn that the President has commissioned him as Recorder of Deeds for the District of Columbia, the office for which he was nominated but rejected by the partisan Senate.

The bulls and bears who occupied the loan corner of the Stock Exchange enjoyed an exceedingly sensational half hour yesterday afternoon. One excited, but apparently sane, grizzly bid 40 per cent. for the loan of $10,000.

SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11.--Reports have reached here of the discovery of a rich oil belt five miles from Livermore, in this State. Competent authorities pronounce the surface indications the finest ever discovered in this country. A company will be formed to develop the field.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 11.--This is the first day of the lockout in the cotton factories here. The following mills are in the league: Augusta, Enterprise, King, Sibley, Algernon, Shamrock, and Riverside. All is quiet in the factory settlements.

The Republican State Committee decided yesterday by a vote of 18 to 9 against holding a State Convention this year. The representatives of the Long Island and Brooklyn districts were in favor of a convention, those of this city were solidly against it, and from the rest of the State there were but five members of the committee who voted for a convention to ten against it.

The cruise of the New-York Yacht Club has confirmed the impression made by the race for the Goelet Cup that the Mayflower must be selected to compete with the Gala tea for the America's Cup. The trim of the "big four" has already been arrived at.

CHICAGO, Aug. 11.--A little before 10 o'clock this forenoon the defendants in the Anarchists' trial marched into Judge Gary's crowded court room headed by August Spies. The prisoners all looked smiling and comparatively unconcerned, and greeted their lady friends with smiles.

A Meriden man had a horse for which another man made repeated offers which were refused. The other day the horse died of colic, and while his owner was looking at the body some one offered him 10 cents for it and he took it.

MONTREAL, Aug. 11.--A man named Formauze, from Rouen, France, arrived here recently with the intention of starting in business as agent for French and Belgian manufactures. He brought with him $9,770.

Antonio is a dirty-looking and vindictive Italian, about 63 years old, and lives in a dirtier habitation in East Boston.

BOSTON, Aug. 11.--The suicide at Lawrence of a young school teacher, Hattie P. Stevens, brings to light a sad and romantic story. When Hattie disappeared, a few days ago, she was tracked to the Merrimac River.

GALVESTON, Texas, Aug. 11.--The Court House at Hardin, Hardin County, Texas, was destroyed by fire Sunday night. All of the county records were destroyed. The loss is incalculable, and much litigation is anticipated in consequence thereof.
CHICAGO, Aug. 11.--The weather was fair, though threatening in the forenoon, at Washington Park to-day. The track was fast and the attendance large.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 11.--The first step toward a division of the town of which Long Branch is a part was taken this morning. Judge Walling granted the petition of the seceders, and ordered an election to be held on Aug. 25.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 11.--J.D. Spencer, of the firm of Spencer Brothers, was arraigned in the County Court of Henry County yesterday, charged with the murder of J.K. Terry in a street fight at Martinville several months ago.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., Aug. 11.--There is some excitement here, caused by the exhibition of specimens of gold which was discovered 75 miles north of here, by J.V. Newell, of this city, and which assays $80 to the ton.

LAWRENCE, Kan., Aug. 11.--J.K. Purrington escaped from the County Jail at this place last Winter. He was confined on the charges of forgery, obtaining money under false pretenses, bigamy, and manslaughter.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 11.--The Newburg Board of Education has just voted to adopt the system of manual training and to establish a school of design in connection with the public schools of that city. The system is to be taught in a part of the new academy, which is to be completed, at a cost of $75,000, by Sept. 1.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11.--One of the chief uses of the secret session system of the Senate, during the session just closed, was the manufacture of campaign material by the Republican majority out of the nominations sent to the Senate by the President.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 11, 1886. Arrangements are being made at the Treasury Department for a large call of bonds, in addition to the usual monthly call of $4,000,000, to meet the requirements of the sinking fund. The exact date and the amount of the call have not been determined. It will, however, be issued in a few days. The amount will be either $10,000,000 or $12,000,000, most probably the former.

The inquest into the death of Frederick Pfister, who was found murdered in a wagon in Williamsburg, was continued last night by Coroner Hesse in Justice Naeher's court room, at Humboldt-street and Montrose-avenue.

LONDON, Aug. 11.--A banquet was given by the Lord Mayor this evening. The usual loyal toasts were proposed and responded to. Sir J.P. Caron, Canadian Minister of Defense, who responded to the toast to the army and navy, referred amid loud cheers to the Canadian assistance sent to Egypt.

Four children in one family in Virginia City, Nev., died recently from diphtheria. The family purse was exhausted by the drain during the sickness, and last Tuesday the roof fell and what little they had was destroyed by fire.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 12.--The Democratic State Convention completed its work today, Robert L. Taylor, United States Pension Agent at Knoxville and ex-Congressman from the First District, being nominated on the fifteenth ballot for Governor.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 12.--A dispatch from Watkins, N.Y., says: "The severest gale of wind ever known along Seneca Lake occurred about 7 o'clock last night. The whole region north of this village seems to have been reached by the storm.

DETROIT, Aug. 12.--Anonton Strokely, the noted pedestrian, of East Saginaw, has matched himself against George Hecks's bay horse George H. for a fifteen days' race, go as you please, for a purse of $1,000.
MADRID, Aug. 12.--The Spanish Government will subsidize in July, 1887, new lines of steamers to South, Central, and North America, Asia, The Panama Canal will be used if opened.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--The following army officers recently promoted have been ordered to report to the commanding Generals of the departments as designated for assignment to stations: Lieut.-Col. Horace Jewett, Third Infantry, Department ...

ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 12.--Mary Brooks came here from Macon four years ago. She has been renting rooms from Sarah Beasley for some time, where she lived with her 10-year-old granddaughter, Lizzie Summons.

Andrew H. Green, with Lewis Cass Ledyard, of the law firm of Carter Ledyard, for company, went to White Plains yesterday morning and, almost as soon as the Surrogate's office was opened, filed, with Mr. Tilden's will, a peti-....
TRENTON, N.J., Aug. 12.--John S. Carey, the proprietor of the United States Hotel in this city, was several years ago the lessee of a hotel and grounds at Wilkesbarre, Penn.

MUSKOGEE, Indian Territory, Aug. 12.-- E.R. Harrison, United States Examiner of Surveys, has just completed an examination of the survey between the Seminole and Creek Counties and has discovered a mistake of from 15,000 to 20,000 acres in favor of the Creeks.
John M. Coman, chief clerk in the District Attorney's office, and Deputy Assistant District Attorney, resigned his position last Saturday at the request of District Attorney Martine.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 12.--Mrs. Emma Francis Shaw, while on her way from San Francisco, committed suicide here to-day by taking strychnine.

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--At the Convention of the Association of American Bankers to-day the following officers were elected: President--Logan C. Murray, of New-York; First Vice-President--Lowell H. Camp, of Milwaukee; Vice-Presidents--James H. Mason, of Mobile, Ala.; M.W. ...
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Acting Secretary Fairchild this afternoon issued the one hundred and fortieth call for the redemption of bonds.

SACRAMENTO, Aug. 12.--A banquet was tendered last evening by the Mayor and citizens to the members of the Grand Army of the Republic now visiting this city. The members of the Legislature, new in session, attended in a body. Speeches were made by Gen. Logan, Commander-in-Chief Fairchild, and others.

There was a meeting yesterday, at No. 96 Broadway, of the Wabash, St. Louis and Pacific Railway Company's bondholders, to hear the plan of reorganization formulated by a committee appointed for the purpose on July 8.

When William Lang, who lives at No. 1,241 Washington-avenue, returned from a recent business trip to the West he found that 11 checks. amounting in all to $66, had been presented at the Germania Bank, all of which were forgeries.

Dr. Henry Mayers, of East Branch, Delaware County, has a story to tell of how he was treated at Coney Island last week. Dr. Mayers was spending a few days in New-York, and having heard a great deal of the famous Summer resort in the full swing of the season he took his young nephew down there from New-York.

Controller Loew has decided to pay the amount due Fifth-Avenue Pavement Contractor Mathew Baird for the second section of the work.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--The Philadelphias defeated the Washingtons to-day in a generally uninteresting and one-sided game.

DEFIANCE, Ohio, Aug. 12.--The Democrats of the Sixth Congressional District to-day held a large but not harmonious conveniton. The Hon. W.D. Hill, who has served three terms in Congress, was opposed by four candidates.
DETROIT, Aug. 12.--The Wolverine baseball aggregation beat the Cowboys with ease to-day. Wheidman was hit hard and often, while the visitors could do very little with Smith.
ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12.--This afternoon's game between the Browns and the Baltimores was the dullest and most uninteresting exhibition of ball seen here this year.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12.--A sharp shock of earthquake was felt at Ste. Marguerite, Ste. Adele, and St. Sauveur early yesterday morning. A barn belonging to Mr. Godniers, a farmer of Ste. Marguerite, was thrown down and other buildings were slightly damaged. The shocks lasted about six minutes. Violent wind and hail storms followed.

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--About 2,200 people saw the New-Yorkers defeat the home team to-day. The New-Yorkers played an errorless game with the exception of Gerhardt, while the Bostons made 11 errors, of which 6 were charged to their battery.

Since the adjournment of Congress a number of Western and Southern Democratic Senators have called upon the President to talk over political matters, his civil service policy, and the prospects of the campaign.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--The Chicagos outplayed the St. Louis at every point and batted Healey for a total of 13 bases.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 12.--The Coroher's jury in the case of Edward Russell found that he came to his death from blows inflicted by John Hays.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--Formal complaints were presented to Commissioner Blanchard today that the Vanderbilt lines have not withdrawn the cut rates. Evidence was produced to show that these charges were well founded.

Lord SALISBURY has announced with much dignity, as the London newspapers seem to agree, that his recipe for the troubles in Ireland is simply the enforcement of the laws.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 12.--The police have been investigating for a day or two past what now seems to have been a horrible murder. Jacob Maserang, a saloon keeper of Easton-avenue, while cleaning his vault found human bones and various articles of clothing, a pair of trousers, a shirt, and a coat.

Commissioner SQUIRE yesterday refused, under advice of his counsel, to submit to cross-examination in the proceedings before the Mayor in regard to the charge based upon the corrupt bargain with FLYNN and THOMPSON on the ground that he is now under indictment on the same charge.
LANDER, Wyoming, Aug. 2.--An old trapper and hunter known as "Mountain Sam" is doing a land office business killing huge mountain sheep for their heads and horns.

The exhibition of Japanese artists at the Saint George grounds, Staten Island, was opened last evening for the first time.

The schooner yacht Rambler left her anchorage at Bay Ridge at 4:30 P.M. yesterday, bound eastward on a cruise. She had on board Henry Irving, the actor, and his friend J. C. Parkinson, E. A. Buck, whose guests they were, Mr. Buck's sons, and one or two other friends.
DUBLIN, Aug. 12.--The Irish Times (Conservative) states that it is informed that Lord Randolph Churchill is engaged in drafting a bill intended to solve the Irish problem. The skeleton ...
DETROIT, Aug. 12.--The Democratic County Convention for this city and county, to chose delegates to the State Convention, was held to-day and was a reasonably civilized affair.

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--At an informal meeting of the stockholders of the Bridgewater Iron Company to-day the investigating committee reported, showing liabilities, exclusive of capital stock, of $331,979, to which must be added the damages in a patent suit, an item of unknown amount.

PEABODY, Mass., Aug. 12.--The only new feature of the labor question was the reposting in the tannery of Newman Perkins of the manufacturers' circular. On Monday Mr. Perkins took down the circular at the demand of the Knights of Labor, and his men returned to work.
HARTFORD, Conn., Aug. 12.--The entries for the races at the charter Oak Park meeting, from Aug. 31 to Sept. 4, have been completed and arranged.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 12.--This morning as the Erie way freight train was passing the milk station, two miles above Middletown, an employe saw the dead body of a man lying in a cattle guard.
Count Saigo, Secretary of the Navy of Japan, arrived in the city yesterday from San Francisco and is at the Windsor Hotel.
The cricket match which comes off at Seabright to-day and to-morrow between representative teams of the United States and Canada will be one of the most interesting of the series.

The Bankers' Convention adjourned yesterday without adopting the remarkable resolutions which Mr. DANA HORTON advocated before them on the previous day.

DANBURY, Conn., Aug. 12.--Amos Morris, the oldest resident of this town, died yesterday, aged 96 years. He served in the war of 1812, and made himself locally famous when the first passenger train was started over a railroad running into Danbury. The single car couldn't be got up they grade until Uncle Amos hitched his oxen to it and pulled it up the incline. This feat earned a picture in Harper's Weekly.

George P. Lies, of East Eightieth-street, is about the only cigar manufacturer who still trusts in the Home Club and District Assembly No. 49, Knights of Labor, to make good their promise to fill cigar shops with Knights, and yesterday he still employed muscular Knights of Labor car drivers to scatter the pickets of the striking cigarmakers.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 12.--Richard Boettger, a gunsmith, aged 20 years and unmarried, who was employed by Fred Koenig, cutler and gunsmith, was fatally injured by the accidental discharge of a revolver this morning.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Six thousand persons were on the Driving Park Grounds to-day, the third day of the grand circuit trotting races here, and speculation was very lively.

BOSTON, Aug. 12.--The first reports of wholesale poisoning in Somerville were received with utter incredulity, but the revelations of today have been of a startling character, and interest in the case has been intensified by the death early this morning of William J. Robinson, the son of the accused woman.

Representative free traders from various States met at the headquarters of the American Free Trade League, No. 39 Nassau-street, yesterday afternoon, in pursuance with the call of the National Committee to decide upon a course of action for the Fall campaign.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 12.--A terrible triple tragedy occurred at Graysville, on the line of the Cincinnati Southern Railway, 20 miles from this city, last night.

GEORGETOWN, Del., Aug. 12.--C.H. Treat Co. confessed judgment yesterday for $25,000 in favor of the Farmers' Bank. This action was called for by the failure of New-York and Eastern parties, on whose paper they were indorsers for a similar amount.
SARATOGA, Aug. 12.--This was the first regular day of the second Summer race meeting here. There was a very large attendance.

CINCINNATI, Aug. 12.--The opposition to John C. Biley's confirmation as Postmaster of Cincinnati, which prevented the Senate Committee from reporting on the appointment, grew out of the fact that Riley has been closed as a coaloil Democrat.
Ex-Gov. John L. Beveridge, of Illinois, and Lynde Harrison, of New-Haven, are at the Murray Hill Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Mr. Frank Howard, of Ithaca, N.Y., a recent graduate of Cornell, who came to Washington a few weeks ago to visit his brother, was found last evening in his room lying at the point of death from a bullet wound in his temple. His surroundings indicate that the occurrence was purely accidental.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--The office in the lower story of the Wood Building, at Fourth and Chestnut streets, is being fitted up for a local freight office of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 12.--Fannie McCulloch, aged 17 years, escaped from the State Industrial School last night by scaling the wall which surrounds the grounds. The girl was received from Geneva on Jan. 22, 1885, after having been convicted of petit larceny.

GALVESTON, Aug. 12.--The third day's session of the Democratic Convention was a stormy one. The Committee on Permanent Organization reported the Hon. R.M. Wynne, of Tarrant County, for permanent Chairman, and William Lambert, of Travis County, for Secretary.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--Between 200 and 300 meat handlers in the packing house of Robert Warren Co., at the stock yards, quit work this morning.
MINNEAPOLIS, Aug. 12.--The convention of the International Association of Traveling Passenger Agents at Minnetonka decided to hold the next meeting at Old Point Comfort, June 2, 1887.
Splendid cricketing Weather favored the return match between the Staten Island Cricket Club and the Canadian I Zingari team on the grounds of the Staten Island Club yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--Herr Herman Mohr, the Royal Musical Director at Berlin, arrived in this city on the 6 o'clock train this evening from Baltimore. He was-met at the station by President F.W. Schladneky, of the Liederkranz of this city, and others.
The Hamburg American Packet Company has followed the example of several of the other Continental lines which are fighting the Red Star Line by making extensive cut in its steerage rates.
A cursory examination of the accounts of Charles J. Campbell, the missing General Manager of the Steinway and Hunter's Point Railroad Company, shows a defalcation of $3,200.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--Senators Plumb and Ingalls during the last month of the late session of Congress charged distinctly and with much emphasis that the Democratic majority of the Civil Service Commission had so manipulated the examinations for special pension examiners as to enable Commissioner Black to make no mistake in selecting Democrats for that grade in the classified service.
PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 12.--The firm of Bradley Co., of this city, have had a bill in equity filed against them in the United States Circuit Court on behalf of Laura C. Holloway, Brooklyn, N.Y.
DETROIT, Aug. 12.--The union ship carpenters at Trenton, 18 miles down the river from this city, are again at loggerheads with John Craig Son, owners of the large shipyard at that place.

St. Ann's Church, at Morrisania, was so crowded yesterday morning that people had to stand up in the aisles and lean against the doors, and a hundred or more gentlemen who wanted to hear the funeral services over the body of Richard March Hoe, the printing press inventor, had to stay outside on the grassy slope.

MONTREAL, Aug. 12.--The Irish Lacrosse team will arrive here to-morrow morning and will on arrival be presented with an address by the Acting Mayor on behalf of the city.
NEWPORT, Aug. 12.--Lieut. Henn stated this morning that the Galatea will probably remain here until Saturday. She is attracting much attention from the citizens.
LONDON, Aug. 13.--The steamship Phoenician, (Br.,) Capt. McKillop, from Montreal July 28 and Quebec 30th, for London, passed the Lizard yesterday.
PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 12.--The home team was outbatted this afternoon, but won on the errors of their opponents, who played a miserable fielding game.

TITUSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 12.--Oil was struck on the farm of C.H. Ames, of this city, at selkirk, six miles from town, this afternoon.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12.--The Westchester Cup, spite of all prognostications to the contrary, was won by the Meadow Brook Club today.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 12.--Forest fires in Northern Wisconsin are dying out, material on which to feed having become exhausted. The vicinity of Green Bay is one subject to danger, but only in the event of high winds.
WASHINGTON, Penn., Aug. 12.--A new boiler at the Coast Sons' well, on the W.W: Smith farm, exploded this afternoon with terrific violence.
CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--A boycott resulted in a suicide in this city to-day. Anton Kabock, a Hungarian, started a bakery on Cottage Groveavenue last Spring. His business grew rapidly ...

The great Omnibus Stakes has been run and won and victory has perched itself upon the colors of Mr. Cassatt; and it was a proud moment for him when The Bard ran to the front amid the plaudits of the assembled thousands.
Matthias Clickener was a prisoner in Justice Walsh's court, in Brooklyn, yesterday, charged with forgery and grand larceny. The prisoner said he had no home.

The first regular synagogue in this country ever devoted to the use of Hungarians was dedicated yesterday afternoon. The building, which is at No. 146 Norfolk street, near Houston, is large enough to seat 1,500 people.
Messrs. Lester and Allen's Minstrels, assisted by talkative Mr. Henry Kernell, will occupy the Star Theatre next week.
A. J. Loewenstein, a peddler of fancy goods, who lived for a time with his family at One Hundred and Forty-seventh-street and Willis-avenue, in the annexed district, moved away in May last.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 12, 1886. The President to-day appointed William C. Hall, of New-York, to be United States Consul at Prescott, Canada.

A collision occurred on the North River last night between the ferryboat New-Brunswick, of the Pennsylvania Railroad Company, and the Moonarchie, of the Hoboken Line. Both boats were going toward New-York, the Moonarchie being bound for Barclay-street and the New-Brunswick for Desbrosses-street. Both boats were badly damaged, but no one was hurt.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 12.--The only live issue in Vermont politics this year is the reelection of Senator Edmunds, and over this question is being waged the most desperate contest that this State has seen for years.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 12.--A letter has been received at the Hydrographic Office from Capt. Trant, of the steamship Venetian, which vessel recently picked up the disabled Werra in midocean and towed her into port.
Counsel for the New-York Cable Railway Company recently asked the General Term of the Supreme Court to recast their order declaring that corporation to have no right to build a railway in this city.

FORT KEOGH Montana, Aug. 12.--News has reached here that the new town of Lusk, in Northern Wyoming, near the Montana border line, was visited by a terrific storm of rain and hail last Sunday which virtually swept it out of existence.
CHICACO, Aug. 12.--It was pretty hot outside this morning, but the sunny side of the street was comfortable in comparison with Judge Gary's court.

Commissioner Squire and Maurice B. Flynn were arraigned to plead before Judge Cowing in Part I. of the Court of General Sessions, at 11 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. Squire was accompanied by his counsel, John H. Strahan, and Mr. Flynn by Lawyer Newcombe.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Aug. 12.--The steamer Resolute, of the Baker Wrecking Company, Norfolk, Va., sprang a leak and foundered at sea off Elbow Key, 200 miles south of St. Augustine, at 1:30 o'clock Sunday, 8th inst.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 12.--Exchange-- Sight drafts on New-York, 10; telegraphic, 15.
Health Inspector H.W. Burnard, of the Brooklyn Health Department, handed in his report in the Municipal Building yesterday and then stepped into a vault to get something.

The committee of seven, appointed at the Cleveland Special Assembly of the Knights of Labor, to investigate charges against the Home Club of District Assembly No. 49, met at the Occidental Hotel yesterday.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 12.--Newport has been very lively to-day. Many of the cottagers entertained, and there was a musicale at the Casino Theatre in the morning. The arrivals at the Casino, at hotels, at cottages, and at private boarding houses have been numerous.

BUFFALO, Aug, 12.--Superintendent Dobbins, whose valuable addition to life saving apparatus have won him well earned distinction, is engaged on an improvement to the metallic life car now in use at life saving stations the world over, which no doubt will come into general favor.

WORCESTER, Mass., Aug. 12.--Edward Hanlan, the ex-champion oarsman, made the first of three trials on Lake Quinsigamond this afternoon to beat the best time on record over a three-mile course with a turn and was successful, lowering the record of 19:54 made by Gaudaur to 19:23.

CHICAGO, Aug. 12.--Nicholas Capell, one of the striking switchmen of the Lake Shore Road, is locked up in the Englewood Police Station for trying to shoot a switchman and the engineer of a switch engine, and for having a bomb in his possession.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 12.--The funeral of Congressman Lewis Beach will take place from his late residence, at Cornwall, to-morrow afternoon at 2 o'clock. The sermon will be preached by the Rev. W.E. Snowden, Rector of St. John's Episcopal Church, Cornwall. The body will be taken to New-York for interment in Greenwood Cemetery on an early train Saturday morning.
PITTSBURG, Aug. 12.--Michael Metz, the Italian convicted of the murder of his friend, Rocco Cassident, was hanged at 2 o'clock this afternoon in the county jail yard at Uniontown, Penn.
BOSTON, Aug. 12.--During a thunderstorm this afternoon a sloop yacht and a coasting schooner were capsized in Boston Harbor, and all on board the former were drowned.
RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The phenomenon known as mirage was witnessed at 7 A.M. Thursday from Woolsey's Commons and from Weinberg, in Rondout. The "wonder" presented was a rural landscape.

A correspondent writes to us as follows: "In reading your journal of July 8 I see you rather praise up Anticosti as a place for emigration. I have a right, I think, to give my say on the subject, having once spent six weeks with two Indians on it, and once four months with two friends and six Indians.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The quality of the hay this season is unsurpassed. Owing to the very low condition to-day in which meadows and pastures are from Wisconsin to Kansas, Kansas to Nebraska, and Nebraska to the Ohio River, the great majority of farmers are obliged to feed new hay and have been for more than 20 days.

It is a common mistake of aspiring politicians down East to regard Western Republicans as a compact body of silver extremists.

Both Mr. A.C. Gunter and Mr. Richard Mansfield deny that they have had any dispute about the payment of royalties to Mr. Gunter as author of "Prince Karl." Mr. Gunter writes: "My financial arrangements with Mr. Mansfield are perfectly satisfactory to me and my royalties paid up to date."

TORONTO, Aug. 13.--George McIneerney, the yardman for P. Burns, surrendered himself to the police to-day and was bailed. This completes the arrest of the alleged conspirators.

Some of the philanthropic citizens of Brooklyn have conceived a plan whereby the fear of being buried alive, which haunts the minds of many persons, may be removed, and are about to bind themselves together as an incorporated company.
The committee having in charge the reception of the Irish delegation, which is coming to attend the Chicago Convention of the Irish National League, has nearly completed its arrangements.
M. Victorien Sardou, who is now in his pleasant country house at Marly, is hard at work on a new spectacular piece for the Porte Saint Martin.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--Henry Miller, aged 39 years, was arrested here to-day on an indictment warrant charged with stealing six horses valued at $1,750, the property of Leonard Humphrey, of Newark, N.J.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 13.--What might have been, under other circumstances, a serious railroad accident occurred on the Cape Vincent Branch of the Rome, Watertown and Ogdensburg Railroad, in this city, at 5 o'clock this afternoon.

OTTAWA, Aug. 13.--The Hon. G.E. Foster, Minister of Marine; the Hon. Mackenzie Bowell, Minister of Customs, and Major Anderson, Chief Engineer of the first-named department, leave to morrow morning by the Canadian Pacific Railway for British Columbia.

The liquor dealers of what was known as East New-York, but was recently merged into Brooklyn as the Twenty-sixth Ward, are greatly dissatisfied at having to close on Sunday and to pay a license fee of $5 for each billiard table and bowling alley.
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 13.--The difficulty between the Susquehanna Rolling Mill Company and its employes at Columbia has been satisfactorily arranged and the men have returned to work.

DETROIT, Aug. 13.--Kansas City again went down before the Wolverines to-day through their inability to hit Baldwin and because Whitney was pounded. The visitors' errors were few and costly, and generally their play was very fine, Lillie doing wonders in left, accepting all of eight chances, some of them very difficult.
CINCINNATI, Aug. 13.--Umpire Kelly did wretched work to-day, and practically gave the game to the home club. One of his worst decisions cost the Athletics 6 runs in the third inning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The State Grain Inspector's branch office, at Centre-avenue and Sixteenth-street, narrowly escaped being destroyed, and the occupants of the building narrowly missed being killed by a thunderbolt during the rainstorm this morning.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 13.--Drafts on New-York--Sight. 10 cents; telegraphic. 15 cents.
LONDON, Aug. 13.--The steamship Hibernian, (Br.,) Capt. Brown, from Montreal Aug. 3 and Quebec 5th, arr. at Glasgow to-day.
HANCOCK, N.Y., Aug. 13.--A New-York City lawyer has spent two days in town searching for proofs of the marriage of John Hotchkiss and Maria E. Cunningham, which, it is alleged, occurred here in 1866.

Cries of "Help !" coming from the ocean in front of the Pimlico Pavilion at West Brighton Beach, Coney Island, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning attracted the attention of Special Officers Drummond and Owens.

MACON, Ga., Aug. 13.--Miss Mamie Little, from Savannah, reached this city on Saturday evening and asked ex-policeman Moore for directions. He procured a hack for her and, getting in himself, put his pistol to her head, and compelled her to accompany him to two assignation houses, keeping her under cover of his pistol.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The Washington Park races have been postponed on account of rain to-day.
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 13.--Horse thieves have been busy in this county for some weeks, and every few days the newspapers record the disappearance of a valuable animal or two.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The attendance at the grand circuit races to-day was small, as a heavy shower came up before the first race was called. Trotting was delayed two hours, and then the track was a little heavy.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 13.--A leading weekly grain circular says: "The weather is unsettled. The tone is firmer. Dry, warm weather is much needed. Provincial markets are stiff, and in some cases prices are dearer.

Dr. Charles Woodhouse, of Rutland, has recently obtained from an Albany gentleman who fell heir to some of the correspondence of the New-York Committee of Correspondence and Safety, in 1775, two very interesting letters of that date.

How few know anything of "The National Road?" It has been so eclipsed by railways that many well informed people don't know that such a structure was ever built. The Rev. W. H. Baugh, until recently Pastor of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church, Knoxville, furnished some interesting reminiscences about it to the Tribune. The Rev. Dr. Howard, of the Cumberland Presbyterian, also knows a good deal of it.
When Alderman Robert Spitzer, of Brook lyn, disappeared, a few days ago, it was hinted that his absence was caused by the fear of arrest on a charge of raising a check from $6 25 to $60 25.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 13.--Inspector Leggett to-day arrested William Parker, alias William Pritt, on the charge of housebreaking. On the night of Aug. 9 the residence of the Catholic clergyman in Lexington has entered and jewelry to the value of several hundred dollars taken. On the day following the case was reported to the Boston police, and Inspector Leggett found some of the stolen property.

Diederich Tragman, a plumber, of No. 68 Grand-street, Brooklyn, in the Harlem Court yesterday charged Edward Farrell and William McCann, delegates of the Plumbers' Union, with extortion.

"Poor's Manual of Railroads of the United States" for 1886, which has just come from the press, shows that the number of miles of railroad "constructed in the United States in 1885 was 3,131, the aggregate mileage for the whole country completed at the close of the year being 128,967; the rate of increase during the year being 2.4 per cent.

OSWEGO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The usual quiet village of Sandy Creek is greatly excited over a horsewhipping episode that occurred there a day or two ago and several suits for assault that have grown out of it and that are still on trial.

If the proprietors of the Hotel Brighton at Coney Island could have draped that caravansary with black yesterday at a moderate cost they would have done it. The principal dining room in the house had been hired by the mournful, the melancholy, the lugubrious, and the funereal.
FORT MONROE, Va., Aug. 13.--The schoolship Constellation, with the Annapolis cadets on board, arrived to-day. Cadet Schley, of Indiana, fell from aloft on Aug. 3, and was killed.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The Lake Shore Railroad people emphatically deny the report that charges have been preferred against them for cutting east-bound freights, and say they have faithfully maintained the tariff rate since the restoration last week.

PARIS, Aug. 13.--Christine Nilsson was married to-day to Count de Casa Miranda, of Spain. The marriage was performed in this city, and the ceremony was as private as possible. The couple start for Spain to spend their honeymoon.

HOUSTON, Texas, Aug. 13.--At noon yesterday, during a rainstorm, a party of men were standing in front of James Lyle's saloon, in the Fifth Ward. Toward the close of the storm a bolt of lightning struck the corner of the building.

Mr. Mortimer Compton, formerly a well known lawyer in New-York City, lives in retirement on a small farm on the Rockaway road at Jamaica, Long Island. Yesterday afternoon Mrs. Compton hired Henry Poole, colored, aged 17 years, to pick peas.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--Patrick Egan, President of the Irish National League, arrived in this city to-day. Michael Davitt, owing to an unforeseen delay en route, did not reach Chicago until this evening. Mr. Egan was asked to-day if he expected much trouble at the coming Convention.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--It is quite evident that all is not pleasant between the management of the Niagara Falls Reservation and the citizens of Niagara Falls. In fact, ever since John C. Level, a Buffalo man, was permitted to contract with the Commissioners to establish a line of vans running through the reservation grounds there have been mutterings of thunder in the horizon.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 13, 1886. There will be no further appointments of Presidential Postmasters until after the return of the President from his Summer vacation in the Adirondacks.

Judge Cowing, of the Court of General Sessions, Foreman Knevals, and two members of the Grand Jury, and District Attorney Martine and Assistants Nicoll and Fitzgerald held a long consultation yesterday.

NEW-ORLEANS, La., Aug. 13.--The main building of the Exposition is proving a death trap to the laborers engaged in tearing it down. Yesterday and to-day several terrible accidents occurred to men at work removing the timbers from the roof of the immense structure.

The committee appointed to draft resolutions by the South Carolina State Convention failed to report a resolution approving civil service reform because it did not wholly approve the civil service policy of the President.

A meeting of the Trunk Line Committee will be held at Commissioner Fink's office on Wednesday. Although rumors of rate cutting are rife all the roads deny that there is any truth in them, though each company is careful to speak only for itself. The general opinion is that rate cutting will not be indulged in in the immediate future.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--If Mrs. Sarah Jane Robinson is guilty of one-half the crimes of which she stands accused or is suspected she has a record unexcelled in the criminal annals of the country. Evidence is coming in thick and fast, and the number of persons who always thought Mrs. Robinson was a poisoner, or who possess corroborative evidence of her guilt, is legion.

It would be extremely difficult to define the issues which at present divide political parties. PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--Herman Mohr, Royal Musical Director at Berlin, who is the guest of the united singing societies of this city, was to-day shown over the interesting portions of the city.

LONDON, Aug. 13.--The Cabinet met this afternoon and remained in session two hours and a half. All the Ministers were present except Lord Ashbourne, Lord Chancellor of Ireland. It was decided, among other things, to appoint a royal commission to inquire into the Belfast riots.

NARRAGANSETT PIER, R.I., Aug. 13.-- Three waiters at the Casino and William Billington, L.A. Briggs, Hugh McGuire, and Herbert Barker were arrested here this afternoon on charge of violating the new prohibitory law.

PLAINFIELD, Aug. 13.--Howard Wilson and Carl Oblinger were to-day held in bonds to await the action of the Grand Jury of Somerset County on account of a free fight in the easy Western style which took place at Oblinger's last night.
TRIESTE, Aug. 13.--Seventeen new cases of cholera and 5 deaths were reported here today.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The packing firm of Robert Warren Co., at the stock yards, did not take back their men to-day who struck yesterday. There were plenty of others who were out of employment and they were engaged.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 13.--A member of the New-York Conference who is at present in the Catskill Mountain Assembly grounds, which is intended to be a national camping ground for Methodists, writes that the camp this year is a failure.
CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The Lake Shore Company continues to do its work at the Union Stock Yards under the protection of Winchester rifles.

Charles H. Blair, of No. 49 Broadway, the attorney and one of the Trustees of the Bedlow estate, writes to THE TIMES to say that the name of the island to be made famous by the statue of Liberty should be spelled Bedlow, not Bedloe.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--First Lieuts. D.D. Mitchell, Fifteenth Infantry, and E.W. Howe, Seventeenth Infantry, have been granted four months' leave of absence. Troop M, First Cavalry, Capt. Moses Harris, has been ordered from Fort Custer, Montana, to do police duty in the Yellowstone National Park.

NEWBURG, Aug. 13.--The funeral of Congressman Lewis Beach, who died on Tuesday evening, took place this afternoon from his late residence, Knoll View, Cornwall.

Mary Murray, a dissolute young woman living on the top floor of the tenement house No. 208 Mulberry-street, attempted to commit suicide yesterday afternoon by swallowing a quantity of creosote and supplementing this dose by the contents of a bottle of shoe polish.

CHICAGO, Aug. 13.--The members of the Western Export Association succeeded to-day in perfecting their new pool, although the Nebraska City Distillery did not enter it. A committee was selected to wait upon the proprietors at Boston and try again to win it over.

BELFAST, Aug. 13.--Rain continues to fall, keeping the streets clear of people. The authorities intend to order all the taverns closed at 5 o'clock this evening and keep them closed until 10 o'clock Monday morning.

FORT WORTH, Texas, Aug. 13.--In response to the appeal of Gov. Ireland in behalf of the people who are destitute in consequence of drought a movement has been started in a quiet way in most cities of the State to raise funds for the relief of the sufferers in the Western part of the State.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--There is trouble with the labor problem in the prohibition city of Millville, one of the largest manufacturing centres of South Jersey. In the iron foundry of R.D. Wood Co. the foundrymen were receiving, several months ago, $1 50 per day for making 14 12-inch pipes daily.
The operation known to surgeons as laparotomy was performed on Thursday night at the Chambers-Street Hospital upon Dennis Mahoney, a sailor.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 13.--The Democratic State Executive Committee will meet next week to make arrangements for the coming Gubernatorial campaign.

Charles Chase, formerly a traveling agent for the Orange Judd Publishing Company, in Union-square, has lived with his wife, Delia, and three children, the oldest 11 years, at No. 313 Tenth-street, Brooklyn. Chase was a finelooking man, about 30 years of age, while his wife, a stout, matronly-looking woman, was six years his senior.
PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 13.--The funeral of the Rev. Dr. John McLean, the distinguished ex-President of the College of New-Jersey, took place in the Second Presbyterian Church to-day.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Aug. 13.--At the Universalist grove meeting at Queen City Park today the Rev. A.A. Miner, D.D., of Boston, delivered an address on "The Church and Temperance."

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 13.--Andrew Johnson, known throughout the State as a desperate and lawless fellow, is probably now dead or in the hands of Federal officers. Several weeks ago Johnson met on Laurel Mountains, near Pineville, Special Bailiff Peter Hinkle, who had in charge a Federal prisoner.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 13.--A violent windstorm, which was almost a hurricane, passed over the city last evening. The storm came from the north, and passed down the river, lasting for about half an hour. The air was filled with clouds of dust, which made it impossible to see a block distant.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 13.--There was no apparent change of weather yesterday afternoon, yet for some reason the water in the harbor lowered about 2 feet in a few minutes.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 13.--The hot wave is evidently here to stay, and it is bringing many guests to Newport. The city has been more than lively to-day.

CATSKILL, N.Y., Aug. 11.--At the Major's suggestion we took up lawn tennis and have played every morning and afternoon this week. The Major said last Sunday that he thought we ought to take more exercise in the forenoon, so that our scientific studies at hearts and poker in the evening would be less injurious.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 13.--The Philadelphias again defeated the Washingtons to-day in a close game. The fielding was clean, but the batting was light. Hines made the only run for the visitors by knocking the ball over the fence in the third inning. Irwin scored for the Philadelphias in the fourth on a hit, a steal, and a wild throw by Houck.

BOSTON, Aug. 13.--Being anxious to take at least one game from the New-York Giants the Bostons again put Radbourn in the box against the heavy hitters from the metropolis to-day. Radbourn is a clever twirler and has an unlimited stock of shoots and curves, but his skill did not annoy the visitors in the least.

The Masonic fraternity in North Adams are interested in the antics of one E. Spaulding, who threatens to expose their secrets and also to confer the degrees in his house for $2, unless his appeals for help are heeded.
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 13.--Human remains were discovered to-day in the barn destroyed at Strasburg on Wednesday night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 13.--Ex-Senator McDonald, accompanied by Representative Matson, of Indiana, arrived in Washington to-day. They were preceded by a press dispatch from Indianapolis to the effect that Mr. McDonald had been called here suddenly and was to be offered a Cabinet office by the President.

The remains of the late Rev. Dr. Rufus W. Clark reached this city last night from Siasconset, Nantucket, where he died Aug. 9. The casket-bore the inscription: "Rufus W. Clark, Died Aug. 9, 1886 aged 72 years, 8 months."

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 13.--The days of village domination over the cottage colony at the Summer capital are numbered. This is not a certainty yet, for it needs the sanction of the people at an election to be held Aug. 25 before it becomes a fixed fact.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 13.--The racing today was of an interesting character, but the enjoyment was marred by a delay of an hour and ten minutes in starting the first race. BALTIMORE, Md., Aug. 16.--The firm of Gaddess Brothers failed to-day for $106,000, the entire amount of which is due them by I. Parker Veazey, who until a few months ago was Postmaster of Baltimore. The election will occur a year hence.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 16.--At the village of South River, on Sunday night, two brickyard employes, who had been enemies because of a quarrel of two weeks' standing, met at an eating room. One of them, Charles Brown, without the slightest provocation jumped at the other, a man named Fisher, and stabbed him half a dozen times in the back and sides. Fisher's injuries are considered fatal. Brown has been committed to the county jail.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 17.--Last night's storm was very severe. The rain fell in torrents and the wind blew a hurricane. There were but few traces of the storm to-day, and society was on the go as usual, the leading events being the arrival of the English polo players, a catboat race, with young society gentlemen as skippers, and several cottage entertainments.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Aug. 17.--A Holstein cow, Clothilde, owned by Smiths, Powell Lamb, of this city, closed her 6-year-old record to-night. She has given during that time a little more than 26,000 pounds of milk, or about 70 pounds a day. SHERMAN, Texas, Aug. 18--A very peculiar and pernicious disease has made its appearance among the cattle in the Western suburbs of this city, and several head have died in the last few days. The cattle are stricken with blindness, followed by high fever. They refuse to take food of any kind, and die about the second or third day. The disease appears to be confined to one locality, and every case has proved fatal.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 18.--T. H. Coussens, one of the leading druggists of this city, was fatally stabbed this evening by Robert Morton, a clerk, whom he had discharged. Coussens had missed some money, and quarreled with Morton concerning its disappearance.

Boston made four in the second inning, after Wood had slipped up on an easy chance for a double that would have retired the side.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 18.--The Metropolitans succeeded in shutting the Pittsburgs out today. The game was close and exciting, and was won by the Indians bunching their hits. Both pitchers were very effective. The fielding was sharp and replete with brilliant plays. TRENTON, Aug. 18.--The Prohibitionists of this county held a convention at Hamilton Square to-day and nominated Capt. James H. Withington for State Senator. Prof. Macloskie, of Princeton College, was Chairman of the convention.

MONTICELLO, Ill., Aug. 18.--During a thunderstorm that passed over the southern part of this county yesterday morning Jacob Peck, a respectable farmer, who lived near La Place, arose and attempted to stop a flue to keep the rain out, when he was struck by lightning and instantly Killed. His wife was so several injured that it is extremely doubtful if she will recover.

CRESTON, Iowa, Aug. 18.--Gen. Sheridan reviewed a long procession of veterans here today, after which addresses were made by Col. Clark E. Carr, of Galesburg, Ill.; Gen. Sheridan, Gen. Strong, and Col. Sheridan. This was followed by a levee, thousands shaking hands with Little Phil, who also joined the campfire tonight.

VERMONTVILLE, Mich., Aug. 18.--A boiler explosion occurred yesterday near this village. E. Darrow and Leonard Garringer were instantly killed. The body of the latter was blown to fragments. A piece of the boiler, weighing 1,500 pounds, was thrown nearly 40 rods. Darrow leaves a large family very poor. Garringer was unmarried. The cause of the explosion is unknown. The boiler was used to generate steam for a thrashing machine engine.

Acting Captain Richard Latty, of Brooklyn, who wears seven gold bars on his coat sleeve, obtained a warrant yesterday for the arrest of Col. John D. Graham, the manager of the manufacturing firm of Eugene Berri Co., whose offices are in the Stewart Building.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug 18.--In a brickyard at Ephrata this afternoon Levi Killian, aged 45 years, was engaged in undermining a bank of earth when it caved in, and buried him beneath tons of earth. When his fellow-workmen reached him after two hours' labor life was extinct.

ROUND ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 18.--Twentythree clubs are represented at the camp of the American Canoe Association on Grindstone Island, including the New-York and Knickerbocker Clubs, of New-York, and the Brooklyn clubs.
BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The consolidation of the Highland and Middlesex horse railroads was consummated to-day, when the stockholders of each company voted almost unanimously in favor of consolidation.
DENVER, Col., Aug. 19.--Canon Bagot, spiritual adviser to the Queen in Ireland, arrived here last night.

WILCOX, Arizona, Aug. 19.--Gonzalez, a scout, reports when near Frontierez, Geronimo, Natchez, and three Mexican scouts came up to him, called out that then were peaceable, and said they were going into Frontierez to try and make terms of peace with the Mexican authorities so that they might raid into New-Mexico and Arizona.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 19.--Philadelphia had an easy time to-day in defeating New-York. Ward gave a comprehensive exhibition of how not to field in the sixth inning, when the Phillies made 4 unearned runs.
BELFAST, Aug. 19.--The magistrates of Belfast are in a quandary as to how to proceed in view of a verdict of willful murder found against nine policemen at a secret sitting to-day.

NEW-BEDFORD, Mass., Aug. 19.--The schooner yacht Peerless, of the New-York squadron, has been sold by Francis Hathaway, of New-Bedford, to John V. Lewis, of Cincinnati, who makes Norquitt, on Buzzard Bay, his Summer home.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Aug. 19.--The Knights of Labor have settled the difficulty at the Perth Amboy Terra Cotta Works, where the men were preparing to go on strike because of the discharge of their foreman and the engagement of a new man. The firm consented to take back the old employe.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19.--The Democratic State Convention, which remained in session until 2 o'clock this morning, reassembled again at 10 o'clock. As early as 9 o'clock red-eyed delegates began to put in an appearance. At 10:13 o'clock the Chairman rapped the convention to older and announced that the roll would be called on nominations for Supreme Judge.

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--Rumor to-day had it that the financial irregularities of William Gray, Jr., had for some time been suspected, if not actually known, by several employes in his service. It is still a mystery where the vast sum of money involved went to, and rumors of rash and heavy speculation have been current.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Judson Co., the carpet dealers, who yesterday confessed judgment on notes aggregating $72,000, and probably owe $100,000 more, have been in business here since 1877.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19.--M.J. Lasar, a diamond broker, of Nassau-street, New-York, came here two days ago in search of Alexander Fulda, an employe, who had decamped with about $15,000 worth of diamonds and jewelry.
Dr. Albert R. Ledoux, the chemical expert of the Electrical Subway Commission, tested various samples of asphaltic concrete yesterday at the Fairbanks Testing Works, No. 84 Thomas-street.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--The Acting Secretary of the Treasury this afternoon issued the one hundred and forty-first call for the redemption of bonds.

No. 3 Henry-street, Newark, is a dilapidated frame building in which reside several poor families. Mrs. Ellen Ross, an aged widow, lived on the top floor of the house. On Wednesday night Mrs. Ross and several other women living in the house sat in the hallway and drank beer which was brought to them in a can by a man named Thomas McCormack, who was a frequent visitor at the house.
A call for an Anti-Saloon Republican State Convention, prepared by Gen. Thomas H. Conway and Henry H. Brown, officers of the recent anti-saloon meeting in Brooklyn, has been issued.

MONTREAL, Aug. 19.--Some idea of the fanaticism which animates the handful of ultras in Quebec to see the cloven foot, as they style it, of Freemasonry in almost everything can be gained from a case which Cardinal Taschereau has just been called on to decide.

The striking boatmen held a long meeting yesterday at Foley's Hall, at Thames and New Church streets, and the committee of their association hold a long oonference with the committee of the Coal Exchange.

Whether or not it be a settled fact that the American Opera Company is to go to Europe next year and visit Paris, in accordance with a rumor stated to be afloat in the Gallic metropolis, the possibility is one to be contemplated by the citizens of this country with mingled feelings of pride and apprehension.
The members of St. Joseph's Union of Deaf-Mutes and a large number of their friends held a picnic yesterday afternoon and evening at Schuetzen Park, in South Brooklyn.

DENVER, Col., Aug. 19.--A special from El Paso states that the Cutting case is in statuque. Envoy Sedgwick has not yet arrived. Medina, the person who had Cutting incarcerated, sent the following letter to the El Paso Times yesterday:
David Crawford, 10 years of age, who lived in Bissville, was struck by a west-bound train while playing on the Long Island Railroad track yesterday afternoon, and died shortly afterward.

Lawyer Newcombe made another distressed appeal for delay in pleading to the new indictment against Commissioner Squire and Maurice B. Flynn in Part I, of the Court of General Sessions yesterday morning.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19.--A dispatch from Washington this morning stated that W. H. Swallow had been arrested in that city for obtaining money under false pretenses.
PROSPECT HOUSE, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The President captured a six-pound salmon trout today, and the ladies got badly sunburned.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--Capt. John S. Wharton, Nineteenth Infantry, has been ordered to report to the Army Retiring Board at Governor's Island for examination; First Lieut. Orin Mitcham, Ordnance Department, to the Superintendent of the Military Academy for duty.
BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The resignation of Samuel R. Payson as President of the National City Bank was received and accepted to-day by the Board of Directors.

ST. LOUIS, Aug. 19.--H.B. Miller, familiarly known as "Buffalo," of South Bend, Ind., President of the weak-kneed whisky pool, is in the city to adjust local differences that are being repeated in other cities and threaten the disruption of the pool.

The unexpected arrival of JAMES PIERCE WEAVER in Atlanta solves a curious problem which the courts of Georgia have been studying, and completes the history of a remarkable case of mistaken identity.
LONDON, Aug. 20.--Referring to the Irish contention at Chicago, the Daily News says: 'The convention is becoming slightly ridiculous.

Thomas Congdon, a window cleaner, employed by Janitor Heath, of the Standard Oil Building, fell from a window, probably on the tenth story, to the roof of the four-story building No.73 New-street some time Wednesday night.
The Sing Sing Methodist camp meeting, which has been in session for the past 10 days, came to a close last evening after a successful season.
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 19.--Henry Eby, a son of Jonas Eby, who resides near Pennville, no doubt thinks there is some good in adulteration after all.

CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--The supposition that proceedings in the trial of the Anarchists, as far as counsel were concerned, would end to-day drew a large crowd to the court room. State Attorney Grinnell concluded his argument during the forenoon.

POTTSVILLE, Penn., Aug. 19.--As announced in THE TIMES to-day, word has been received here of the death of Thomas Hurley in Colorado. To a New-Yorker this announcement may mean nothing, but to the residents of this lower anthracite region it is of deep interest.
CHICAGO, Aug. 19.--Richards, Maynard Co. filed a bill in the Superior Court to-day against the Lake Shore and Michigan Southern Railroad Company to recover $250,000 for alleged breach of contract.
Before leaving Cincinnati last week Mr. Murat Halstead communicated with Col. W.G. Terrill, of Washington City, and requested his presence in New-York.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The convention of the American Bar Association reassembled at 10 A.M. President Butler introduced Thomas J. Semmes, of Louisiana, who delivered the annual address, which was in the main an able review of the various codes based on the Roman law, notably the French and Prussian Codes. He advocated a general codification of the laws in all the States.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 19.--The recent order of President Cleveland, as construed into preventing Pension Agent Taylor, of Knoxville, Tenn., from attending the convention which nominated him for Governor, has thrown the Federal officials here into much perplexity.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 19.--Eliza Woods, colored, was taken from jail at Jackson, Tenn., to-night by a mob and hanged. She poisoned her employer, Mrs. Jessie Woolen, a few days ago.

Joshua Limerick was the plaintiff and Thomas Johnson the defendant in a queer suit tried yesterday in Judge Dayton's court in Jersey City. Both men are residents of Hoboken and are known as politicians.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--As I left the House of Commons to-night Mr. J.J. Claney, of Dublin, was saying: "The Irish will not let the session lapse without a determined effort to find out what Ireland's fate this Winter is going to be."

PARIS, Aug. 7.--Unlike the London season, which usually runs into July, what may be called the Parisian season comes to an end before the June roses have fairly bloomed.

ALBANY, Aug. 19.--The report of the Third-Avenue Horse Railroad in New-York for the quarter ending June 30, 1886, just made to the Railroad Commissioners, shows the effect of the recent strike.

READING, Penn., Aug. 19.--The 4 o'clock freight train from Harrisburg as it passed the Keystone Furnaces, two miles west of this city, crossed several rotten sills.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 19.--James Munger, a well-to-do Madison farmer, started to drive to his meadows at East River this morning. Near his destination he had to cross the track of the Shore Line Railroad.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Miss Winnie Claffy, the 16-year-old girl whose mysterious disappearance from her home at Port Jervis last week caused such a stir, returned to her father's home at Middletown last night.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 19.--The Foreign Mails Office of the Post Office Department has perfected an arrangement with the Pacific Mail Steamship Company to carry the United States mails to China, Japan, and Panama, sailing from San Francisco, and to Aspinwall, sailing from New-York, the compensation to be the sea and inland postage on the mails conveyed.
DECATUR, Texas, Aug. 19.--Four miles northwest of Decatur this morning Mr. Lee Jones, a farmer and carpenter, shot and killed old man Nathan Tipton and fatally wounded his son, J.M. Tipton.
Washington Booth, of Baltimore, is at the St. James Hotel. Senator Henry W. Blair, of New-Hampshire, is at the Astor House.
Lawyer James R. Carmichael is in Ludlow-Street Jail. He was the trusted attorney of Henry Clair, the Cape May hotel keeper, but he is so no longer.

The second conference of trades unions, called by the Central Labor Union to decide what to do in city politics this Fall, brought together at Clarendon Hall last evening 508 delegates, representing 115 trade organizations.
Mrs. Margaret Shaw began a suit in the Supreme Court, Brooklyn, for absolute divorce from her husband, Christopher, on the ground of cruel and inhuman treatment, and yesterday Shaw put in his answer.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 19.--The case against ex-Assistant City Treasurer R.H. Frost, of Jackson, charged with the theft of $2,500 from the City Treasury, was discontinued to-day, the prosecuting attorney frankly admitting that investigation showed no good ground for the original charge.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 10.--The attendance at the races to-day--the fourth regular day of the second Summer meeting--was very large. The weather was delightful, but the track is still heavy and sticky. Following were the events:

BOSTON, Aug. 19.--Albert B. Wood, the son of Samuel Wood, a prominent East Boston yacht builder, has been missing from his home for two weeks. Some very strange circumstances are connected with his disappearance, which the police are trying to unravel.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 19.--William H. League, aged 15 years, shot himself in the head with a cat rifle this afternoon. He was at the house of some relatives on Pratt-street, and while playing remarked that he was tired of life, and, walking into a shed in the rear of the premises, fired a shot which is thought to be mortal.

The racing at Monmouth Park yesterday was full of interest, and the large crowd present became enthusiastic as the sport progressed. The enthusiasm was especially marked during the running of the Select Stakes, the third race on the programme, in which the great King Fox, brother to Ban Fox, Alcalde, Kingston, and Belvedere were the principal competitors.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, Aug. 19.--Ellsworth Disbrow, aged 18, recently taken from the Reform School by Farmer Phillip Thompson, of Prospect Plains, yesterday assaulted his employers' 4-year-old daughter. He was arrested and locked up in the jail in this city.

MOUNT CARMEL, Ill., Aug. 19.--Allen Stout, whose son was murdered Tuesday morning by Emmons, the ex-convict, died yesterday from wounds received in the same affray. Emmons, the double murderer, to escape lynching committed suicide. His body was found in an old shanty.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--Lord Iddesleigh, Foreign Secretary, has written to the International Arbitration Association saying that he concurs in the belief of his predecessor, Lord Rosebery, that the moment is inopportune to receive a deputation to discuss the subject of opening negotiations with the United States for the establishment of an Anglo-American tribunal, whose duties shall be to consider international questions.

Charles E. Bishop, of Gardiner, Me., who is said to have come to this city for the purpose of jumping from the big bridge, or from a balloon 50 feet higher than the bridge, had not been seen about the bridge entrance up to 1 o'clock this morning.

LONDON, Aug. 19.--Parliament reassembled to-day. A depressing and persistent rain was falling, and the crowd gathered about the Westminster buildings was small.

NEW-CASTLE, Penn., Aug. 19.--Four masked men entered the house of Farmer William Manning, in Shenango township, early this morning, and at the point of the revolver compelled the old gentleman to give up $3,000 which he had collected yesterday. The robbers then departed and have not yet been captured.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 19.--Last evening a girl 20 years old, who gave her name this morning as Katie Many, attempted to jump into the Hudson River from one of the Newburg docks.
BOSTON, Aug. 19.--The examination of Sarah Jane Robinson and Thomas R. Smith, charged with poisoning Willie Robinson, was continued in the Somerville Police Court to-day.
READING, Penn., Aug. 19.--For some months a strike has existed among all the molders of the Mount Penn Stove Works, in this city, because two men who did not belong to the union were put to work.
LONDON, Aug. 19.--The steamship Cameo, (Br.,} Capt. Ross, from Montreal Aug. 4 for London, passed the Isle of Wight to-day.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 18.--Graham made his second successful trip through the Whirlpool Rapids this afternoon. The barrel was the same as that used in the first trip.

BUFFALO, Aug. 19--The convention of the National Association of Union ex-Prisoners of War came to an end to-day. The meetings have been well attended, and some men whose prison experiences are known the country over were in attendance.
JOHNSTOWN, Penn., Aug. 19.--The Cambria Iron Company is making a quiet but determined war upon the Knights of Labor.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 19.--The cold-blooded murder of Murphy by Judge Ford and his adherents nearly two years ago is still bearing fruit. Two men were hung and three are in the penitentiary as principals.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 19.--The Prohibition Congressional Convention for the Sixteenth District, held here to-day, nominated Walter Farrington, of this city, and adopted reslutions in favor of the holding of a constitutional convention, in order to secure prohibitory laws.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Senator A.H. Colquitt, of Georgia, addressed a large audience on the subject of prohibition at the Newburg Opera House to-night. He will speak at the temperance camp meeting at Innes Grove, Orange Lake, to-morrow afternoon.

RICHMOND, Va., Aug. 20.--It seems to be pretty well settled that Senator Mahone will be nominated by the Republicans of the Petersburg district, to succeed Representative James D. Brady. Although it is conceded that Col. Brady has made an effficient Representative considerable opposition has been developed to his renomination.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 20.--A most remarkable suicide was that of Robert Pappenheimer, a wealthy young man, recently from New-York, who took his life in his apartment at Miss S.A. Jarvis's fashionable boarding house, No. 713 West Chestnut-street, at an early hour this morning.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The racing today was of an indifferent character. The participants were few, the exception being the race for non-winners at Saratoga this season. There was but a fair attendance, fully one-half of the spectators being ladies. The favorites had the usual Saratoga racing luck, only two out of five coming in winners.

LAREDO, Texas, Aug. 20.--News having been received here that the Mexican authorities have fortified a small town some 50 miles up the river, called Pau, and placed a detachment of 60 troops there, the commandant of Fort McIntosh, Col. Bernard, detailed a body of 20 men from this post, who left here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20.--Second Lieut. A.C. Blunt, Fifth Artillery, has been relieved from duty at the Artillery School, Fort Monroe, and ordered to temporary duty in connection with the annual rifle competition in the Division of the Atlantic.

BUFFALO, Aug. 20.--This has been the great day of the Firemen's Convention. It was not until last evening and to-day that the red-shirted, white-hatted, true blue fireman made his appearance, but when he did so he came with a rush and kept coming until there was no keeping track of him.

BALLYSHANNON, Ireland, July 29.--The contempt of the old language which has prevailed in Ireland, and unfortunately continues, a contempt springing from the hatred of the higher orders for the lower, has made havoc with the names of places.

MONTREAL, Aug. 20.--Messrs. Faber Gravel, booksellers, are in difficulties with the Customs Department. Some days ago these merchants were notified that a case of merchandise addressed to them was awaiting removal at the Custom House.

ERIE, Penn., Aug 20.--A large overhanging ledge of rocks at one of the Lebouf quarries was dislodged to-day and came crushing down. The quarrymen all managed to get out with nothing more than slight injuries excepting Frank Kellison.
NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The brothers Charles and William Greene and Manus Turner, of Unionville, were arrested this morning at Tuxedo Park by Deputy Sheriff Edward Beattie.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 20, 1886. Consul Greenbaum, of Samoa, who turned up in Washington yesterday, will not return to his post, at least officially. He will resign.

ROUND ISLAND, River St. Lawrence, Aug. 20.--A cold rainstorm at the beginning of the week chilled all the guests here and frightened all the hotel proprietors. Fires were built in the fireplaces and everybody moped indoors.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug 20.--A man named A.L. Tifferman was found dead this morning in his berth on a train, on the East Tennessee, Virginia and Georgia Railroad, near Cleveland, this State.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 20.--John Elmore, of East Grand-street, some time ago hired a 15-year-old boy, James Healy, to watch his drove of cows. The animals were valuable, and Mr. Elmore soon began to notice that they were apt to come home at night bearing curious-looking wounds.

The well known pioneer Edward P. Cranch, who was admitted to the Bar 54 years ago, was seen yesterday by an Enquirer reporter and sounded on his "recollections of a busy life." The venerable old man is in his seventyseventh year, and has been a resident of this city for over half a century. He is remarkably well preserved.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 20.--The children's fete, given at the Casino this afternoon by the Summer residents for a local charity, was a very enjoyable affair, and was a success financially.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 20.--Information was received to-day by Havana (N.Y.) relatives of the bank defaulter Elbert P. Cook that the latter and his 13-year-old daughter, Thankful, had been assassinated, and that Mrs. Cook was severely wounded.

QUEBEC, Aug. 20.--Among the subjects discussed by the Canadian Medical Association, in session here, was the supplementary quarantine regulations issued for the Dominion this month.

ROUND ISLAND, N.Y., Aug. 20.--The American Canoe Association cruised to-day under the command of Rear Commodore Parmelee, of Hartford, Conn. The route was to Halstead Bay, on the Canadian shore, and back, a distance of 10 miles. The wind was light.

EATONTOWN, N.J., Aug. 20.--The authorities of Monmouth County, N.J., are no nearer to a discovery of the lynchers of Mingo Jack than they were in March last, and seem to have abandoned all effort to find the murderers.

LIVERPOOL, Aug. 20.--The Philomathic Society gave a banquet to Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes this evening. Responding to a toast to his health, Dr. Holmes recalled his first visit to Liverpool, in 1834, when he made his first railway journey to Manchester and back, "just to see what railway traveling was like."

BOSTON, Aug. 21.--Interest in the Somerville poisoning case, obscured for the time by the startling financial revelations of the last week, was revived to-day in an unexpected manner, but in a way that offers a solution to one or two very mysterious features and strengthens the case of the prosecution on points where it was weak.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 21.--The Nanticoke mine disaster has again been recalled by a letter from Gov. Pattison to the officers of the Susquehanna Coal Company, in which he states that he is in daily receipt of appeals from the relatives of the victims urging him to request the company to renew their efforts to recover the bodies.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 21.--The week just closing was one long to be remembered. Newport prospered far beyond her expectations. Dark shadows, however, were cast over the gayeties, and not a few events, including the polo games this afternoon, were postponed ...

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 21.--Connecticut children have been proving this Summer that they can go through a wonderful amount of rough experiences and come out alive and well. Clifford Howe, a youth of 4 years, is the latest to prove his endurance.
