Lewis, a manufacturer of Racine, Wis., to consider means of abolishing the present system of convict labor and devise other means of employing the prisoners con fined in penitentiaries.

John P. won first money in the 2:45 class.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 27.--Deputy United States Marshal W. L. Day brought to the city and lodged in jail this morning Jordan Combs. Combs is one of the most notorious moonshiners in the country. He has killed several men in this State and several in West Virginia.

WINDSOR, Vt., Aug. 27.--The condition of Senator Evarts is improving. He rested well the greatest part of the night and is able to take light food. His ankle troubles him but little and his nervous system and pulse are about normal. He is full of hope that a few days' rest will entirely restore him to health.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Aug. 28.--Another shock of earthquake was felt here this morning, at 4:48 o'clock. It extended as far north as Summerville, 25 miles from here.

GREENVILLE, Texas, Aug. 28.--The sentenced prisoners in the county jail--John Smith, 11 years, for horse stealing; Tom Cain, 3 years, for stealing money; Charles Adams, 7 years, for burglary and horse stealing; William Cyble, 2 years for burglary, and Jim Crack, a negro, 2 years, for burglary--escaped last night.

MONTREAL, Aug. 28.--One of the grandest games of lacrosse ever witnessed in Montreal took place here this afternoon when the Montreal and Toronto Clubs met in the championship series.

ST. LOUIS Mo., Aug. 28.--The games between the Browns and Louisvilles and the Maroons and New-Yorks were postponed to-day on account of rain.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 28.--The officials of the West Shore Road ridicule the report, published yesterday, that the imported switchmen now employed on that road were about to strike because the company would board them no longer. The officials deny the statement that the men have been allowed $1 a day for board, and say that as far as they know the men now at work are satisfied.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 28.--While entering the harbor this morning the steamer Nova Scotian ran into the schooner Bertha, bound from Port Medway for Halifax, and broke the latter's main boom, davits, and boat, and sprung her mainmast.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 28.--Gen. W.F. Rogers, who was a candidate for Public Printer, said to-day that he was much disappointed at not receiving the appointment.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Aug. 28.--There has been a round of gayety here during the entire week, and while many of the recent guests have returned home or gone to other places, yet very little diminution in numbers is apparent at the hotels, and there have been very few vacant rooms during the week for any length of time.

MONTREAL, Quebec, Aug. 28.--Alphonse Labelie, wholesale confectioner, is known to be in Detroit, and endeavors are being made to get him to return. His creditors are willing to compromise.

MOREHEAD, Ky., Aug. 28.--The sending of Craig Tolliver and Cook Humphries from this (Rowan) county does not seem to have entirely eliminated the murderous element. To-day there was a falling out between two members of the old Tolliver faction, culminating in a fight that will result in one death.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Aug. 28.--About six miles from this city, in South Carolina, a colored woman named Jones was very ill in her house, with no one at home except two small children. The house caught fire from the stove and all perished.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 28.--The Knights of Labor of this county, 12 assemblies, met in convention to-day in this city and nominated candidates for the State Senate, State Legislature, and three Aldermen for the city. This is the first action of the kind taken by the order in the South.

TORONTO, Aug. 28.--The cricket match between the Ontario Association and the Western Association, of Chicago, was resumed here this morning. The Westerns continued their second inning and were all disposed of for sixtyseven runs.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 28.--The Englishmen gained another brilliant victory at polo today. The games at the close of the afternoon stood 14 goals of the Englishmen and 2 for the Americans. The latter seemed to be playing without heart and against hope.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 28.--There seems to be considerable mystery about the almost fatal assault on John Irving, of Bay City, Mich, at the railway station at Niagara Falls yesterday.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 28.--David Peyton, who to-day completed 10 years' service in the Maryland Penitentiary, was this morning delivered to the custody of a Boston officer, to be returned to the Massachusetts State Prison, from which he escaped prior to his conviction in Baltimore. He is highly spoken of by the officers of the prison here, and his good conduct obtained for him a commutation of two years. He left for Boston immediately.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Aug. 28.--Several bicycle records were broken, to-day, at the Woodside-Day-Morgan tournament, at Hampden Park. Woodside reduced the five-mile professional record of 14:23 3-5 to 13:50 1-5, with Morgan as pacemaker.
SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Aug. 28.--Keane Brothers, dry goods dealers on Kearney-street, made an assignment to-day to Daniel Meyer. Assets nominally the same as the liabilities.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 28.--Officers of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad, in this city, this morning announced that arrangements had been made for an express and immigrant line between New-York and the West.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Aug. 28.--Francis Hungerford, arrested on the charge of making and passing bogus coin, was this morning released from State prison, having furnished bail. GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., Aug. 28.--Ernest Schmiedicke, aged 35 years, living at No. 16 West Broadway, on the west side, took his own life last night in the presence of his family by drinking the contents of an ounce bottle of carbolic acid. Schmiedicke was employed as a bookkeeper.

READING, Penn., Aug. 28.--The lockout of cigarmakers in this city, which lasted 16 weeks, has been declared off. Vice-President Gill, of the International Cigarmakers' Union, who has been here several weeks making efforts to gain recognition, lent his influence, finally, to this end.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 28, via Galveston, --Mr. A.G. Sedgwick, Secretary Bayard's special envoy to Mexico, has been here since last Monday. He called upon Minister Jackson, to whom he explained that he had been sent as a legal expert to look up the law and the facts in the Cutting case, but presented no credentials.

LONDON, Aug. 28.--Beach, the champion sculler, is in splendid health, and his chances of winning in next week's races are considered excellent. In the betting he is the favorite, five to four being offered against him.
Mrs. W.T. Sherman is at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Gen. John G. Parke, United States Army, is at the Brevoort House.

WILKESBARRE, Penn., Aug. 28.--The fire at the Nottingham slope, Plymouth, was extinguished to-day. It is impossible yet to tell what the loss will be. A large force of men are at work removing the debris from the slope. When this is completed work will be resumed.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 28.--A bad wreck occurred on the Pennsylvania Railroad at Elizabethtown, this county, this afternoon. The day express, a fast train which leaves Harrisburg at 3:40 o'clock, and makes no stops until it reaches Lancaster, ran into the Dillerville local freight train.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 28.--The American seiner, A.B. Crittenden, Capt. Graham, Gloucester, from North Bay for home, with 430 barrels of mackerel, was seized by Collector Bourinot, last night at Port Mulgrave. He remained on board, bringing her here this morning.

Visitors to Col. McCanll during the past week have found him in Wallack's Theatre in his shirt sleeves earnestly supervising the rehearsals of "Josephine Sold by Her Sisters," and aiding Mme. Cottrelly with wise suggestions in regard to the stage business, which is under that lady's sole supervision.

What objection exists among dry goods merchants to acceting the special freight rate recently established by the Trunk Line Executive Committee on cotton piece goods, and which went into operation on Thursday last, seems to come from commission merchants.
The new Catholic Church of St. Rose of Lima, at Hammel's Station, Rockaway Beach, was dedicated yesterday. Four weeks ago the spot was covered with a dense grove of cedars.

Such work of a varied character as is undertaken by The United States Fish Commission, and carried on over so wide an extent of territory, precludes the summarizing of it before a certain amount of time has elapsed, and when this material is prepared for public information, before printing it a year or two passes by.

SANTIAGO DE CHILI, Aug. 29, via Galveston.--The Las Augustinas Convent and the church of the same name in this city were much damaged by fire this morning. The fire brigades after three hours' work got the names under control. One of the firemen was slightly injured.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--The bark Naomi, from New-York for Stettin, oil laden, put into this port this morning disabled. She was out in the terrific storm of Sunday last, during which she lost her bulwarks, stanchions, foretopgallantinast, and jibboom. Her deck was swept and her cabin completely destroyed. She is leaking badly, and will have to discharge.

ELMIRA, N.Y., Aug. 29.--This afternoon party of Italians living in the northern part of the city, employed on the Erie Railway ballasting, got drunk and then had an altereation, resulting in the death of Philip Pastori and the fatal injury of Tomasso Deorrio.

BUCHAREST, Aug. 29.--Prince Alexander arrived here with his brothers Francis and Louis at 9:30 o'clock this morning. He was welcomed at the railway station by Prime Minister Bratiano and other members of the Cabinet, Sir William A. White, British Minister to Roumania, and a Bulgarian deputation.

The World describes the granduncle of the present Lord Lonsdale, who died in 1872, as "wicked," and adds that Thackeray drew him as Lord Colchicum. I would vastly like to know what is Edmund's authority for the statement, which, in my opinion, is simply a freak of his imagination.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 29.--Information is received of the death at Wytheville, Va., of the Rev. Alexander Marks, Rector of Trinity Church of Natchez, Miss. He was a native of this city, and a son of Isaac N. Marks, a leading citizen. He was born in 1841 and was a student at Princeton College when the war broke out.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 29.--Ben Jones, an outlaw of East Tennessee, was arrested today for the murder of Mrs. Harginai, of Harlan County, Ky. It is said that she was slain because she would not aid Jones to escape from a posse. He is charged with five murders.

In divers old English plays and stories is to be found the irate father with a scapegrace son whom the former threatens "to cut off with a shilling." There was a special significance attaching to the menace of old, and the shilling provision was a shrewd device of the lawyers.

Every opening in the pier tunnel of the Sunard Line was crowded yesterday afternoon when the Aurania steamed up the North River and swung into her dock. There were many personal friends of the 695 passengers, but all were friends of one, Dr. Oliver Wendell Holmes, and many had come down for the expres purpose of catching a glimpse of the genial "Autocrat."

The question as to how the Dominion fishery restrictions are enforced has lately taken an odd turn. The Yantic and Galena report to the Navy Department, as the result of their investigations, that the American fishermen are doing very well, and are interfered with very-little by the officers of the Canadian cruisers, who are courteous and considerate.

The Roman correspondent of the Corriers del Mattino says that, in spite of the law suppressing convents and monastic colleges, there were 32 houses constructed at the expense of monks and nuns from 1884 to 1885 at a cost of above 18,000,000f.

Card playing in Paris has become an absolute passion among all classes. Cards are played at all hours of the day and night. In all the cafes, from the Cafe Riche to the Taverne de Bagne, the game goes on uninterruptedly.

The Live Oak Exempt Firemen's Association was organized two or three years ago as a benevolent society by the members of old Live Oak Engine Company No. 44. The association has its headquarters in a cozy little room at No. 123 Cannon-street.

Delegates from 235 lodges of the Brotherhood of Railroad Brakemen of the United States and Canada arrived in Jersey City on Saturday night and Sunday. They held a convention yesterday afternoon at Cooper's Hall. The principal business transacted was the formation of a Mutual Insurance Association. Each member will receive $600 in case of permanent disability or the same amount will be paid to his hairs in case or his death.

To swim across a river over a half a mile wide, and which has a current of over four miles an hour, is a feat which even a strong man and expert swimmer might be proud of, yet yesterday a 17-year-old girl accomplished the task.

John Kylian, whose connection with the Kohout arson case has been recently discovered, was arraigned at the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning. With him, in the custody of two detective Sergeants, were Henry and Edward Kohout, now serving life sentences at Sing Sing, who had been brought down to give evidence.
CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--Every theatre in town except Hooley's has been running during the past week, and they have all done a good business, in spite of the unusually hot weather.

ESCANABA, Mich., Aug. 29--Mr. Michael Davitt addressed an enthusiastic meeting of Irishmen and others last night. Ha said in brief: "I am here to explain to American people the causes and aims of our movement in Ireland.

Luke Collins, 25 years of age, of No. 463 Carroll-street, Brooklyn, went in bathing at Coney Island, yesterday afternoon, and was drowned. The deceased was a friend of Supervisor Lyman, of Brooklyn. A carrier pigeon conveyed the tidings of Collins's death to Lyman's house, at Brooklyn, from which place the relatives were notified. The body has not been recovered.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--In the twinkling of an eye Laflin Rand's powder magazine, in the outskirts of Chicago, was this morning swept from the face of the earth by a bolt of lightning and a consequent explosion of powder and dynamite.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29.--Frank Hoffner, a mason, living at No. 171 Prince-street died at his home early this morning from injuries inflicted on him on the night of Aug. 14 by T.W. Durham, the sexton of St. Paul's Episcopal Church.

A representative congress of all the bicycle clubs of Germany was opened this morning in the Thiergarten by a procession of all the riders on their various machines, numbering no fewer than 600, which is about the strength of a German cavalry regiment on a peace footing.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Senator Harris and Commissioner Joseph E. Johnston, parties defendant to the Pan Electric Telephone suit brought by J. Harris Rogers against AttorneyGeneral Garland and others, yesterday filed demurrers to the plaintiff's bill, setting forth the bill as being bad in substance and lacking equity.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29.--The police raided the saloon of L. Mendels, at Springfield-avenue and Bedford-street, to-day, and arrested 10 men and the proprietors. They are charged with gambling. They are all young men and sons of business men. The complaint was made by Isaac Moke, a young man who is said to have been refused admittance to the game. The prisoners acknowledged that they were gambling but said it was only for 10 cents ante.

Mrs. Mackay, the latest American star is the ever-changing social firmament, has succeeded in capturing the Prince of Wales both in London and at Cowes, and I hear that she is so much inspired by her success that she is anxious that her spouse should purchase Houghton Hall from Lord Cholmondeley.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29.--The Anarchists of this city, being refused permission to hold a mass meeting in the public park, gathered this afternoon in Favorite Hall and talked about the Chicago verdict. One of the hitherto leading spirits refused to preside, and the Chairman who accepted accused him of cowardice.

BOSTON, Aug. 29.--The bark Joseph A. Ropes, of New-York, Capt. S.W. Seabury, 101 days from Madagascar, went ashore to-day inside of Minot's Ledge Light, off the Cohasset shore. For two days the Captain reports she had been in Massachusetts Bay in a thick fog ...

Constable John Freeman, of Queens County, who is also Captain of the Ridgewood Park police, was aroused at 3:30 o'clock yesterday morning by a woman who cried for help in front of his house. He recognized the voice as that of Mrs. Singer, wife of a milk dealer in the vicinity.

A heavy mist hung over Coney Island early yesterday morning, and the groans of the hotel keepers and proprietors of bathing houses, photograph galleries, merry-go-rounds, coasters, clam stands. , were plainly heard at that most charming home of the Jumbo mosquito and Mark Lannigan, known as Sheepshead Bay.

A large balloon, recently constructed in the imperial technical manufactory at St. Petersburg for the purpose of conducting a series of experiments bearing on the use of balloons for military objects, was dispatched a few days ago from St. Petersburg for Cronstadt.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 29.--Two men, who gave their names as Thomas Huggins, of No. 30 Oliver-street, New-York, and James Hader, of No. 15 Cedar-street, Brookyn, were arrested here late last night for passing counterflet silver dollars. It is not known how many of the spurious coins they disposed of, but the number is put at 30. The men were held for examination.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The wife of Paymaster's Clerk Myers, of the United States steamship Iroquois, who left his vessel two months ago at Callao, Peru, with about $4,000 belonging to members of the ship's crew, yesterday received a cablegram informing her of the death of her husband.

Since the mysterious disappearance of A. J. Stuart, the cashier in the Pennsylvania Railroad freight station in Jersey City, startling revelations have been made concerning his moral character. He disappeared suddenly about two weeks ago, and his whereabouts are not known.
Gen. Queseda and Pablo de Escandon, of Mexico are at the Victoria Hotel. Charles T. Russell, United States Consul at Liverpool, is at the New-York Hotel.

It is announced definitely that the company to which the Subway Commission has awarded the contract for laying the electric conduits will begin work on Sixth-avenue this morning, and that the first practical step toward burying the wires which have so long been an unsightly nuisance in this city will then be taken.

WILCOX, Arizona, Aug. 29.--Col. Wade has rounded up all the Chrickahuas and Warm Spring Apaches, numbering 420. He has them under guard, and will, unless some accident occurscarry out Gen. Miles's plan of moving them out of Arizona Territory. Capt. Lawton is in close proximity to Geronimo, who has asked far better terms than an unconditional surrender.
LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 29.--Joseph Weise, the 14-year-old son of John Weise, of Columbia, went down to the Susquehanna River to bathe yesterday afternoon.

Higginson's account of the sea Captains of old Salem is a valuable chapter of local history. Lewis F. Allen's account of Shorthorn cattle is an excellent paper of its kind.

The English astronomers who went below the equator to observe the eclipse of the sun, which was total in the upper part of the Southern Hemisphere yesterday, had with them the hopes of scientists the world over.
No five volumes can be selected from the shelves now groaning under the weight of Mr. H.H. Bancroft's library of history which contain more useful material than these.

Her Majesty's grandsons are not to be classed yet as among the "Historic Boys," but Prince Albert Victor, otherwise "Eddie," and Prince George were middies on the Bacchante, under the charge of their tutor, the Rev. Mr. Dalton, and the party made two cruises on a fine ship, visiting all parts of the world with the exception of the United States.

BAKERSFIELD, Cal., Aug. 29.--Three well dressed strangers, who arrived here yesterday, were detected in passing bills on the Consolidated Bank of Montreal, which did not bear the signatures of the officers of the bank. The bills were of the denomination of $10. A police officer who attempted to arrest them was shot through the arm, and the three managed to escape. A party of citizens started in pursuit.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Aug. 29.--Frederick Roeske, of No. 296 Green Mount-avenue, Baltimore, and his 15-year-old son were drowned this morning while bathing. Roeske went to assist his son, who was beyond his depth, and both were carried under and drowned. The body of the father was recovered.

The French steamship La Bourgogne arrived yesterday morning, after a qiuck passage of a little less than eight days. Capt. Frangeul reported that the vessel left Havre at 2 P.M. on Aug. 21, and reached Sandy Hook at 8:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Mr. N.T. Robertson, the well known bicyclist, of this city, and two friends went to Cabin John Bride to-day to ascertain the truth of the story published a day or two ago of the riding of a bicyclist across the bridge on the coping.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Joseph A. Reall, President of the American Agricultural and Dairy Association, called upon President Cleveland to-day to convey an invitation to attend the National Agricultural Convention which meets in Philadelphia on Sept. 14.
BELFAST, Aug. 29.--This evening there was some firing of pistols and throwing of stones, and a few persons were injured.

The adventures of a wandering follower of Col. OLCOTT and Mme. BLAVATSKY in the latitude of Ocean Grove and the Freehold Jail tend to prove that those exceptionally favored persons who are on intimate terms with Mahatmas and less powerful in America than they are said to be in India.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 29.--Reports from Labrador are to the effect that the cod fishery in those waters for 1886 will be short of the average.

A deck hand employed on one of the Troy steambeate, saw a woman walk out to the end of Pier No. 51 North River on Saturday night and cast herself into the water. He gave an alarm, and search was carried on until 7 o'clock yesterday morning when the body was fished out. It was that of a German woman, about 45 years old, with blue eyes and auburn hair.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--The last number of the Siberian Gazette, published in the city of Tomsk, Western Siberia, gives the following particulars with regard to Lieut. Schuetze's journey to the mouth of the Lena River with gifts and rewards for the officials and natives who aided the survivors of the arctic exploring steamer Jeannette:

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 29.--Nicholas Kehoe, only 18 years old, lies in a cell in Moyamensing Prison charged with murder. The body of his 19-year-old victim; William McHale, lies in a rude pine box in the parlor of an humble frame dwelling at No. 2,651, Fisherstreet.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--A party sent out by the Geological Survey, under the command of Capt. Clarence E. Dutton, United States Army, has succeeded in reaching and making a complete survey of Crater Lake, in Oregon, a body of water whose shores, with the possible exception of one point on the south, have never before been touched by the feet of white men.

Though misfortune overtook Broker Frank Savin in his fisticuff encounter with Broker John Goodchild down at the Stock Exchange portals the other day, still he is not altogether an unlucky citizen. NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29.--The funeral of sugene Keteltas, of New-York, brother-in-law of Gov. Wetmore, and that of Mrs. Rebecca H. McPheeters, the mother-in-law of E.M. Padelford, of Philadelphia, were held here to-day. Both were attended by many cottagers.

JACKSON, Miss., Aug. 29.--The Prohibition campaign in Mississippi has been one of the hottest for many years, and bloodshed has resulted in several instances. Each side accused the other of bulldozing and bribery.

KNIGSTON, N.Y., Aug. 29.--The large and elegant steamer Daniel Drew, of the New-York and Albany Day Line, was numbered among the list of vessels of the past this afternoon, being totally consumed by fire.

Third in the line of foolhardy Fourth Warders anxious to jump off the Brooklyn Bridge was young Daniel Collins, of No. 67 Oliver-street. Ever since he saw Brodie sitting under a gaudy canopy in a Bowery dime museum he has said to his companions that he would one day occupy as prominent a niche in the temple of fame as that newsboy pedestrian.

There is good news for the victims of big gas bills. The South Metropolitan Gas Company has lately reduced the price of its gas by 2d. per 1,000. The reduction was equivalent, if the consumption remained stationary, to a diminution of 40,000 a year in the company's income;

LONDON, Aug. 29.--Discount closed 1 for three months and 1 for short. The advance in the Bank of England rate, it is believed, will be sufficient to prevent a renewal of the American gold demand for some weeks.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Aug. 29, via Galveston.--President Santos has requested the legal authorities to suspend their investigations into the matter of the recent assault upon him, and to set at liberty the persons detained for supposed connection with the outrage. None of the persons so detained have been found guilty of complicity in the assault on the President.

I am afraid that the cholera in Northern Italy will make sad havoc with the harvest of the hotel keepers on the Italian lakes. In September there is no more enjoyable place. The hotels are well arranged and well kept and the climate is perfect--neither too hot nor too cold.

ATHENS, Aug. 29.--The area of the earth disturbance in Greece yesterday was phenomenally wide. At least six towns were entirely destroyed and a score of others partially destroyed. On the mainland much damage was done, but there was little loss of life.

A most successful attempt has been made to introduce into England the popular Canadian sport of " Toboganning." The first toboggan slide has been erected at the Liverpool International Exhibition and has been patronized to a surprising extent 7,500 persons having passed the turnstiles on Monday, Aug. 2, Bank Holiday and 136,591 persons have availed themselves of this amusement during the 50 days the slide has been open.

There has been but little rain in the fruit country which supplies this city during the past 10 days. Along the Hudson there has been but very little rain during the past month, and some of the fruits have already been injured by the drougt.

At St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday the high mass was celebrated by the Rev. Micheal J. Mulhern, and the sermon was deliverd by the Rev. William J. Daly. The music was sung by a volunteer choir under the direction of the Rev. Anthony Lammel.

Yesterday's meeting of the Central Labor Union was somewhat more harmonious than the gatherings of that body have been for some time. A member of the Law Committee said that he had a consultation with Col. Ethan Allen regarding the question of collecting a fine from an employer in return for removing a boycott from his business.

It is plain from the address of the Free Trade League, which we publish this morning, that that organization means business, and serious business. The gist of the address is an appeal to all who believe in the policy of tariff reform to unite in their several Congressional districts and vote their convictions.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Aug. 29.--After an illness of ten weeks Commodore Billard, of the New-Haven Yacht Club, died in this city to-day. He, more than any one else, helped to found the New-Haven Yacht Club, and to build it up. He was one of the best known men in New-Haven, popular and genial.

SEABRIGHT, N.J., Aug. 29.--The Seabright Inn is to be closed on Tuesday morning after breakfast, and a hundred and more loiterers by the seaside will then have to seek shelter elsewhere.

LONG BRANCH, N.J., Aug. 29.--The boy crowned here yesterday was not the son of exCollector Thomas Murphy, but was the son of James D. Murphy, builder, of No. 200 Broadway, New-York, and who lives at No. 225 East Eighty-first-street. The body of the boy has not yet been recovered.

Manager Gustave Amberg, of the Thalia Theatre, arrived yesterday on the steater La Bourgogne after a long trip abroad, made for the purpose of securing attractions for the coming season at the Thalia.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Aug. 29.--A TimesUnion Fernandina special says that three ladies from Leesburg, Fla., while in surf bathing got beyond their depth. Men went to their assistance and saved Mrs. Moore, but the two Misses ...

The annual swimming races at Sand Koenig's swimming academy at the foot of East Fifty-fifth-street occurred yesterday afternoon. Leo Picard won the 500-yard race for boys and Fd Pollak the 800-yard race for men.

Eighteen-year-old Katie Miller, of No. 206 Maujer-street, Brooklyn, complained to Justice Nacher yesterday that Joseph Heisenberger, a young man to whom she was engaged to be married, had left the city after obtaining from her $15 under false pretenses.

LONDON, Aug. 30.--In the House of Commons this evening Sir J. E. Gorst, Under secretary for India, defended the annexation of Burmah on the ground that it was necessary for the safety of India.

The new North German Lloyd steamship Saale was ready for public inspection yesterday afternoon. Invitations had been generally distributed, and the result was that a very large crowd of sightseers boarded the vessel.

TROY, N.Y., Aug. 30.--James F. Ashley, a prominent merchant of this city, attempted to commit suicide at Round Lake last night. Mr. Ashley was suffering from pains in his head which have often made him insane, and as usual under the circumstances he had been taking opiates to allay his sufferings.

Ryan, Collector of Customs here, in connection with the Walters case, in which he expresses surprise at the Collector having said in an interview that the firm had not paid the fine of $147,000 imposed ...

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 30.--Emanuel Lawrence, a teamster, employed by County Com missioner Hartman, in West Lampter Township, was kicked in the stomach by a mule yesterday, receiving injuries which resulted fatally this morning. He was 30 years of age and resided in this city.
Recent cable dispatches from England allege that large iron and steel orders are reported from America, and that trade reviews show a briskness in yarns, wool, and cotton goods.

Lawyers Newcombe and Strahan did not make before Judge Churchill, in Supreme Court, Chambers, yesterday, the motion for the transfer from the Court of General Sessions to the Court of Oyer and Terminer of the indictments against Maurice B. Flynn and Rollin M. Squire. The motion was adjourned until to-day, the District Attorney consenting.

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 30.--The body of S.W. Carr, of Germantown, Penn., who was drowned at Ocean Grove on Thursday last, was to-day picked up at Deal Beach, four miles away. The body was found up Rusesll White. It was terribly discolored. It was brought to this place by Deputy Coroner Sexton. The inquest will probably be held to-morrow.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Aug. 30.--A dispatch from Lunenburg says that the schooner Prize, 92 tons, of that port, went ashore on Hound's Ledges, on the northern side of Cross Island, Sunday morning.
Those who love the oyster and know what a good oyster is will rejoice to hear that the outlook for Rockaways and Blue Points was never better than now.

Clara Eiseman, only 4 years of age, leaned too far out of the fourth story window of No. 247 Wayne-street, Jersey City, last night and lost her balance. She fell to the sidewalk and received fatal injuries.

The charges of corruption made by Plumber G.F.F. Williams against Supervisors Christopher Larkin, Lawrence Carroll, and John Gallagher, of Brooklyn, on Saturday, resulted yesterday in the arrest of the Supervisors on the charge of conspiracy to defraud Kings County.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--The Chicagos won the game in the first two innings, and came near losing it in the last two by the poorest sort of play possible. They piled up four errors that gave the visitors 6 runs.

CHICAGO, Ill., Aug. 30.--The folllowing was the visible supple of grain on Aug. 28, as reported by the Secretary of the Board of Trade; Wheat, 41,297,906 bushels; increase, 1,467,494. Corn, 11,769,681; increase, 837,672. Oats, 4,245,353; increase, 1,129,709. Rye, 570,705; increase, 138,286. Barley, 585,200; increase, 171,140.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 30.--St. Louis is about to offer aid to the inhabitants of the drought-stricken districts of Texas, whence come reports of great suffering for the ordinary means of sustaining life.

In view of the recurrent and deplorable politico-religious outbreak in Belfast and other North of Ireland localities, it might be well to dissipate some erroneous or inadequate impressions as to the condition and constitution of that part of the country which exist in many minds otherwise well informed.

VICKSBURG, Aug. 30.--Advices from Jackson state that Barksdale's friends concede the Seventh Congressional District to Col. Hoover. In the Fifth District singleton's renomination is considered certain.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 30.--Information is just received from Morehouse Parish, in the northern portion of the State, of an attempted outrage followed by swift retribution in Gum Swamp. A negro named Frank Mansfield worked on the plantation of Mr. Doss.

ST. ALBANS, Vt., Aug. 30.--Before daylight yesterday Congress Hall, a Summer hotel at Sheldon Springs, was broken into and $1,500 in cash, bonds, stocks, and notes mere stolen from one of the guests, W.L. Lincoln, of Chicago. There is no clue to the thieves.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 30.--The case of Allen O. Myers against W.S. Cappeler, on the charge of bribing certain members of the Hamilton County delegation at the recent Republican Convention, came up before Justice McFadden for hearing to-day. No witnesses appearing, the case was dismissed.

The Stampa of the 9th inst. gives the following account of the present state of the Pope's health: "It is perfectly true that the other night the Pope had an intestinal disturbance which alarmed the Vatican.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 30.--Canon Ovet, an Arabian, arrived here to-day from Milwaukee, in search of his two children, who were stolen from him in the western States some time ago by showmen. Ovet's children were in Toronto about two weeks ago.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Madge Dolaro, a Chicago girl, accompanied by her backer, Terry Costello, passed through here to-night for New-York, where she will make an attempt to jump from the Brooklyn Bridge for a purse of $1,000.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 30.--Last evening W.W. Kennoch, chief of the United States Secret Service for this State, arrested a counterfeiter named William Wandsor, of Vermont, one of the most desperate shovers of the queer in the country.

Railroad earnings were reported in Wallstreet yesterday as follows: St. Louis, Arkansas and Texas, for the third week of August, $34,291, an inerease of $10,817; Memphis and Charleston, for the third week of August, $27,694, ...

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--Farmer Kann, who was driving by Laflin Rand's powder magazine when the structure was struck by lightning and its contents blew up, died this morning at the hospital, whether he was taken.

NYACK, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The monument to the memory of Lieut.-Commander Gorringe was raised to its position in Rockland Cemetery Sparkill, this afternoon. The shaft is made after the model of the obelisk which Commander Gorringe brought over to this country, and the whole body of granite in position weighs about 40 tons. It is located in a very attractive part of the cemetery, and will doubtless draw many visitors thither.
LONDON, Aug. 30.--To-night I learn details of what the world is likely to learn, much to its excited interest, within a few days.
ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 30.--For the first time this year the St. Louis Maroons, to-day, managed to defeat the New-York Giants at Union Park. The local men played a strong game.

A meeting of the Ancient Order of Hibernians was held last evening in Kasefang's Assembly Rooms, Seventh-avenue and Twenty sixth-street. Michael Kennedy, the State Delegate, presided, and there were present Maurice F. Wilhere, the National Delegate; P. H. McNelis ...
It has been four months since Dr. Edson, of the Health Department, made his last inspection of the milk that the guileless Jersey farmer furnishes for New-York.
H.P. Grover is the name of a young man who serves just now as an example--not a good example--on the Produce Exchange. Mr. Grover has acted foolishly.

The examination of Mrs. Charlotte Erwin, of New-York, for obtaining goods under false pretenses from various merchants in Orange and East Orange, was held yesterday at Newark. In all the cases the complainants decided not to press the suite, as the complaints were illegally drawn, and Mrs. Erwin was discharged.

LONDON, Aug. 30--The Mark-Lane Express, in its weekly review of the British grain trade, says: "The week's splendid harvest weather has materially altered the position. Much grain has been secured. The crop in early sown districts is in fine condition, while late sown crops are rapidly maturing.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Aug. 30.--Return tickets to Cincinnati, over the Pittsburg, Cincinnati and St. Louis Railroad, were sold on the streets of this city last night and to-day for 25 cents. This is the lowest rate ever known, the regular fare to Cincinnati being $9 50, and is ...

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--Charles S. Wolfe, the Prohibition candidate for Governor, was in the city to-day on his way home from Chester County, where he had addressed a meeting on Saturday night. He made his headquarters in Room No. 3 Girard House, and had many callers.
The two yachts Galatea and Mayflower lay at anchor at Bay Ridge yesterday morning and looked at one another. Gen. Paine's crew took a little drill at handling their spinnaker boom.
Notwithstanding the heat the English cricketers arose bright and early at the Brunswick yesterday and hied them away to the Staten Island Cricket Club ground.

NORWALK, Conn., Aug. 30.--As Mrs. Lewis, wife of the Rev. A.N. Lewis, of Trinity Church, Westport, who with a party of friends are camping out on Cockenoes Island, was looking out upon the Sound she saw what looked to be a large log or raft floating upon the water about a mile and a half away.
BERNE, Aug. 30.--The Italian frontier district has been officially declared free of cholera.

The will of the late Balthasar Kreischer, of Kreischerville, was admitted to probate by Surrogate Stephens, of Stapleton, Staten Island, yesterday afternoon. The estate is valued at $2,000,000, and is divided, share and share alike, between four daughters and three sons. William Steinway and George Kreischer are the executors.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30--Ex-Clerk of the New-Jersey Legislature Thomas G. Bunnell, editor of the Newton (Sussex County) Herald, having been appointed Postmaster of Newton by President Cleveland, has sold his paper to Thomas Kays, a well known Democratic politician of Northern New-Jersey. It is understood that Mr. Bunnell retires from journalism in order to obey to the letter the President's instructions as to obtrusive partisanship on the part of office holders.

WILMORE, Penn., Aug. 30--Three trackmen employed on the Pennsylvania Railroad were struck by an engine near Summer Hill this morning and instantly killed.

BELLEVILLE, Mich., Aug. 30.--Benjamin Ellwel, a well-to-do and aged farmer living three miles south of this place in the Township of Sumpter, was the victim of a daring robbery last Saturday midnight.

Mayor Grace and Gen. John Newton, the newly appointed Commissioner of Public Works, walked across the City Hall Park at noon yesterday and entered the offices of the Public Works Department at No. 31 Chambers-street.

DANVILLE, Va., Aug. 30.--W.K. Terry, who was shot in the Spencer-Terry affray at Martinsville, Henry County, Va., last May, and who has been lingering on since, being thought at one time to be out of danger; died at Martinsville last night.

Judge Churchill decided yesterday to admit John C. Stott and Charles J. Everard to bail pending their appeals from conviction in the Court of General Sessions. Stott was convicted of abduction and assault. His bail is fixed at $6,000. Everard, who is known as "Mash Market Jake," was convicted of forgery. His bail is to be $7,500. Stott has beon sentenced to imprisonment for two years and a half and Everard for 10 years.

NEWPORT, N.H., Aug. 30.--Austin Corbin left for New-York to-day with the body of Count Rene Cheronnet Champollion, his son-in-law, which will be forwarded to Paris. Funeral services were held in the Catholic church here.

SAN ANTONIO, Texas, Aug. 30.--Cypriano Seras met Antonio Rodrigues in Espinosa's saloon yesterday morning and invited him to drink. They drank together, but when George Gibson, the barkeeper, demanded the money for the drinks Seras declined to pay.
The steamer Sylvan Glen and the Staten Island ferryboat Middletown came into collision with each other shortly after 7 o'clock last evening off the foot of Whitehall-street.
BOSTON, Aug. 30.--A meeting of the creditors of R.G. Williams, the lumber dealer, of No. 70 Kilby-street, was held here this morning. The meeting was private and only creditors were present.

James Fitzgerald, aged 12 years, of No. 1,889 Third-avenue, was held in the Harlem Court yesterday for examination on the charge of aiding two other boy's to break open a chest near some new buildings. They stole castings and tools valued at $52 belonging to James Madden, the contractor, who was working in the neighborhood.
A declaration of principles was issued last night by the County Committee of the New-York County Democracy at its meeting in the Cooper Union.

The British drumbeat has so long announced the encircling of the earth by the sun in his daily journey that all loyal Englishmen feel that it is time something be done that shall astonish that great celestial luminary.
The Subcommittee of the Central Labor Union's Political Committee met last evening as No. 141 Eighth-street. The committee is composed of one member from each Assembly district in the city.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--The Philadelphia schooner Frank McDonnell, Capt. Richard P. Cannon, which sailed from here on Aug. 7, for Palatka, Fla., with a cargo of 425 tons of iron, has never been heard from.

LANCASTER, Penn., Aug. 30.--The Lancaster County Fair was opened at McGrann's Park this morning. Everything was in confusion until evening, when the exhibits that had arrived were placed in position. It promises to be a big show.
LONDON, Aug. 31.--The steamship Suppicich, (Br.,) Capt. Meate, from Philadelphia Aug. 2, arr. at Bisceglia Aug. 27.

PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 30.--In an old tumble-down stone lockhouse owned, but long since deserted, by the Pennsylvania, Railroad Company at Betzwood, opposite Port Kennedy, on the dge of the Schuylkill River, on Saturday evening, Mrs. Thomas Wood was found lying almost dead.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 30.--Sight drafts on New-York,12 ; telegraphic, 20.

"Has it ever occurred to you." asked a traveling man of a reporter for the Free Press at the Michigan Central Passenger Station yesterday, "that the women who travel outnumber ... the men in about the proportion of four to two?"

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Aug. 30.--A serious accident occurred to-day on the Queen and Crescent route near Georgetown, Ky. Meagre reports received say that the engine of the southbound express jumped the track. Engineer Drone was killed and the fireman and baggage master both seriously hurt. Several passengers from this city were also injured, and as no particulars of the wreck can be received intense interest prevails.
Engine No. 28, of the Third-avenue elevated railroad, left Chatham-square with a train for the City Hall terminus at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--A wild sort of story of a successful attempt to blackmail Charles J. Singer, of the well known Board of Trade firm of schwartz, Dupee Co., was afloat on 'Change to-day, and was printed in all its wildness in an evening paper.

Cherbourg is to have a near statue. It already possesses one put up to the memory of the First Napoleon, to whom the town owed its selection as a miliary port; the second will be erected bg another generation to a very different man.

Assistant Superintendent Gideon W. Young, of the New-York Maritime Exchange, who lives at No. 17 Gallatin-place, Brooklyn, applied to the police yesterday for assistance in finding his 15-year-old son Alfred, who disappeared on Saturday.
NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 30.--After the international polo games last week the games this afternoon were considered rather poor imitations of the sport.
ATLANTA, Ga., Aug. 30.--A singular case has just been finished in the Forsyth County Superior Court, in which one brother sent the other to the penitentiary.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., Aug. 30--"They fish with fish lines six miles long in Winnebago Lake, Wisconsin, and use 20,000 hooks on every line," said a resident of this place who had been out there, "and if they don't haul up 2,000 fish every time they call it indifferent luck.

No mattor how good a programme may be offered by a racing association it is difficult to get out a big crowd on Monday, and thus the second day's races of the Brooklyn Jockey Club's meeting were but poorly attended. The racing was very good throughout and there was no delay in sending away the horses. The sport was over at 5:30 P.M.

The new-cruiser Boston, the sister ship to tho Atlanta, went up to the navy yard yesterday morning from Upper Quarantine, where she arrived Sunday evening.

MONTREAL, Aug. 30.--In a letter to the clergy of his diocese against political meetings on Sunday and feasts of obligation Cardinal Taschereau says: "Political passions are inimical to the meditation necessary to the observation of Sunday, and are proper to make Christians ...

ASBURY PARK, N.J., Aug. 30.--The second carnival of the season was held on Westley Lake this evening. The lake, which is a mile in length, was covered with boats decorated with Chinese lanterns and fancy colored fire. The shore was lined with people to witness the procession on the water. The houses along the lake were handsomely decorated with Chinese lanterns, and there was a big display of fireworks.
ATHOL, Mass., Aug. 30.--The expected lockout at Lee's shoe shops took place this morning, when the employes, on coming to the shops, found the doors guarded by policemen.

CADILLAC, Mich., Aug. 30.--This afternoon Mrs. Brass, who, with her lover, James W. Croft, is in jail here waiting trial for the killing of her husband, Milo I. Brass, made a confession of the crime to Sheriff Dunham.

NASSAU, New-Providence, Aug. 26.--A hurricane swept over this island on the night of the 22d inst. The gale came from the southeast, and blew with great violence for several hours.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--Mrs. Elizabeth Rodgers has been appointed Master Workman of District No. 24, Knights of Labor, vice J.B. Murphy, deceased. She is the first woman to receive such distinction. Mrs. Rodgers is the wife of George Rodgers, who has figured in labor matters in Chicago for a number of years.
LONDON, Aug. 30.--A portion of the trial heats to decide who shall be the contestants in the international sculling sweepstakes on Wednesday were rowed to-day. The weather was scorchingly hot.

At a meeting of the Master Plumbers' Association, held Yesterday afternoon at No. 54 Union-square, Chairman Byrns read a letter which had been published in THE TIMES protesting against the tyranny of the union in preventing young men from learning trades.

CHICAGO, Aug. 30.--Louis Juhl, a tailor living at No. 576 West Seventeenth-street; Henry Batzel, a stone mason, of No. 586, and William Kloth, a cooper, of No. 588, the same street, were arrested yesterday and locked up in the Hinman-street station, charged pith conspiracy to do an unlawful act.
WASHINGTON, Aug. 30.--First Lieut. William M. Medcalfe, Ordnance Department, is ordered to East Lyme, Conn., in connection with the erection of a battery at that place.

NEWARK, N.J., Aug. 30.--A result of the encampment of the Second Brigade of the NewJersey National Guard at Sea Girt, which ended on Saturday, may be the preferment of grave charges against Quartermaster-General Lewis Perrine.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Aug. 30.--Irwin, a stranger to the St. Louis public, was put into the box for the Cincinnatis to-day and did fairly well. The Browns won after a long and tedious game. Caruthers was hit in the breast by a ball from Corkhills's bat in the seventh inning and went to right field, Foutz taking his place. Both did effective work.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Aug. 30.--As Mrs. R. A. Willamson, of Niles, near here, was driving along in her husband's butcher cart this afternoon, the horse became frightened at the cars and ran away, throwing her out and breaking her neck. Several hours afterward her dead body was found in the road. Her husband was away from home and did not learn the news until late to-night.
A correspondent of the Corriere del Mattino, of Naples, publishes, among others, an interesting letter from Bellini to a friend in Palermo.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The Orange County Teachers' Institute, under the direction of Dr. J.H. French, of Rochester, and Prof. L.B. Nowell, of Westport, began a five days' session at Grammar school No. 2, Newburg, this morning. Sessions are to be held morning, afternoon, and evening. There was an attendance of more than 90 Orange County teachers on the first day of the session.
ALBANY, Aug. 30.--Chairman John O'Brien, of the Democratic State Committee, reached here this afternoon at 2:40, and driving post haste to the Capitol was closeted with Gov. Hill for a short time.

Without advertising or previous public notice of any kind the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad Company sent out its first train from Jersey City to the West at 8 o'clock last evening. Only immigrants were carried as passengers. Seventy-five of them made themselves comfortable in the two cars provided for them.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Aug. 30.--Aside from the lively interest which is taken in the renomination of Gov. Rusk and the indorsement of his firm stand against the rioters in Milwaukee last May political interest in Wisconsin for the last two months has centred in the Democratic Congressional contest in the Second District.

A remarkable surgical operation was described at the meeting of the British Medical Association, held on the 13th inst., by Surgeon HORSLEY, of the Bloomsbury National Hospital for the Paralyzed and Epileptic.

On Sunday morning, when Sergt. McLaughlin went into the prison of the detective office, he saw John Kylian, the accomplice of the incendiary Henry Kohout, dart from the door of his cell and go to his bed.
NOGALES, Arizona, Aug. 30.--Geronimo has sent word to Gen. Miles that he will meet him at the San Bernardino ranch to arrange terms of surrender.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Aug. 30.--The Washingtons won their first game for the season from Kansas City to-day, and did it by superior playing all around. The visitors' work was characterized by some exceptionally brilliant fielding. The score by innings follows:

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Aug. 30.--The New-Jersey Labor Congress, composed of all the labor organizations in the State, met in this city to-day and began its ninth annual session. One hundred and fifty delegates were present. They represented 50,000 workers.

"Josephine Sold by Her Sisters," a new comic opera in three acts, the libretto by Messrs. Ferrier and Garre, and the music by Victor Roger, was produced last evening at Wallack's Theatre before an audience that for Summer was remarkable in size and enthusiasm.
DETROIT, Aug. 30.--The home team could not place the ball safely to-day, and the visitors had the game their own way after the fourth inning.

SCRANTON, Penn., Aug.30.--The Fairlawn Colliery, situated a short distance from the heart of the city, was the scene of a thrilling disaster at 8 o'clock this morning, by which five men were instantly killed and one so badly burned that his death is inevitable.
ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The most severe thunderstorm ever known in this city came up at noon to-day. There was a slight rain last night, followed by a puff of intensely hot air all over the city.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett began his engagement at the Star Theatre last evening in "Yorick's Love," a remarkably strong and interesting play, and one that contains a character admirably suited to Mr. Barrett's forcible and sincere manner.

CITY OF MEXICO, Aug. 30, via. Galveston. --In an interview this afternoon Mr. Sedgwick, the American special agent, emphatically denied the stories against him in circulation in the United States, the substance of which has been cabled here.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Aug. 30.--In October, 1880, Chris Berman was murdered with an axe at his home on Jenings-street, in this city. The affair was a most mysterious one, no clue being obtainable at the time to the murderers. The tragedy was a horrible one and created no little excitement at the time.

BALTIMORE, Aug. 30--Jonathan W. Scott, foreman in the office of the Price Current, was found hanging this morning from one of the shafts of the machinery in the office. He left home yesterday having provided himself with a cotton clothes line, with which he accomplished his end. He was a quiet man. The office having recently changed hands he became depressed, but no one suspected any such intention on his part.
The lock-out of the clothing cutters, who had insisted that the clothing manufacturers should discharge all non-union men and apprentices, began yesterday. About 800 cutters were thus locked out.

RONDOUT, N.Y., Aug. 30.--Fifteen minutes before the steamboat Daniel Drew caught fire on Sunday afternoon a sea serpent was seen in the Hudson River between Coddington's Dock and Kingston Point by a number of Rondout boatmen and boys who were in swimming.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Aug. 30.--The President's party left Saranac Inn this morning for the upper lake region for a few day's' hunting and fishing in that remote territory. With them went Col A.H. Belo, of the Galveston News, and Harry W. Brown, of Philadelphia.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 31.--While many of the cottagers to-day were enjoying themselves with various diversions, not a few drove over to the East Cliffs, where the Berkeley Memorial Chapel was consecrated by Bishop Clark, who hastened his return from Europe in order to be present.
SAUK CENTRE, Minn., Aug. 31.--Three young ladies were crossing the trestlework near here yesterday afternoon when a Manitoba east-bound train came along.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, Aug. 31.--On Monday, Aug. 23, William Weir Sons began boring an artesian well at the intersection of Beech and Washington streets, Belle Plain, on the flat about four blocks south of the Burley House.

COLUMBUS, Aug. 31.--The Republican State Central Committee met this evening and selected an Executive Committee for the purpose of conducting the campaign. The Hon. W.S. Cappeller, of Cincinnati, was elected Chairman, and will have direct charge of the conduct of the work. The Hon. J.K. Brown was chosen Secretary. The work of thoroughly organizing the State will begin at once.

PARIS, Aug. 31.--Dispatches from Madagascar say that the Hovas are raising objections to the demands of Frenchmen for the restoration of property. The French Resident at Tananarivo has been ordered to insist upon the strictest enforcement of the treaty between France and Madagascar.

A message was sent to the Twentieth Precinct Station House on Saturday morning by Jacob Sayles, a negro bully and fiddler, of No. 247 Nest Thirty-second-street, that his wife, Hannah, died suddenly at 6 o'clock. He desired to know if it would be necessary to send for a Coroner.

The locked-out clothing cutters had their parade yesterday, and turned out in full force. Recording secretary Westbrook went early in the day to Superintendent Murray and asked for a permit to parade.

Father Stumpe has been the priest at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church at Melrose for 15 years. The parish buildings, which are near Third-avenue and One Hundred and Fifty-firststreet, have all been put up since he first took the church.

CHICAGO, Aug. 31.--The first bale of California hops of the new crop was received in Chicago yesterday by H.B. Falk Co. The hops were grown in the Sacramento Valley and were of very fine quality, indicating a good crop on the Pacific coast.
SING SING, N.Y., Aug. 31.--The earnings at Sing Sing Prison for August were $19,067 68; expenditures, $13,067 66; leaving a profit for the month of $6,000 02.

LONDON, Aug. 31.--In the House of Commons this afternoon Sir Michael Hicks-Beach, Chief Secretary for Ireland, stated that during the riots in Belfast one head constable had been killed, five officers and six members of the constabulary had been seriously wounded, and that altogether 322 policemen had been more or less injured in the various encounters with the rioters.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31.--The 15 days' "go-as-you-please" race between Anton Strokel, of East Saginaw, and the running horse George H., owned by George H. Hicks, of Pontiac, from 7 A.M. to 7 P.M. each day, closed tonight, having been partially or wholly interrupted on several days by rain. The total score foots up: Strokel, 780 miles; the horse, 781 miles. At noon to-day Strokel was 5 miles ahead of the horse.

READING, Penn., Aug. 31.--The midnight freight train coming into Reading struck an unknown man in the cut near the Big Dam, instantly killing him. The conductor testified that through the darkness in the out he saw an object on the track, but being only six feet away it was too late to avert the tragedy. The re mains were brought to this city, but could not be identified.
The Guion steamship Alaska, which sailed yesterday for Liverpool, grounded last evening during the rainstorm on the south side of Gedney's Channel.

READING, Penn., Aug. 31.--The Hon. Daniel Ermentrout, Representative from this district in Congress, was to-day nominated by acclamation for his fourth term, the opposition having withdrawn all their candidates. A band of music entered the Court House where the convention was held and serenaded it.

BOSTON, Mass., Aug. 31.--Nichols Farnsworth, dealers in shoe manufacturers' goods at No. 98 Summer-street, have suspended. The firm has carried on business in this city for many years, and ranked with the leading houses in the trade.

MOUNT CARMEL, Penn., Aug. 31.--Anthony Gillespie, a prominent grocer of Mount Carmel, left here on horseback for Shamokin yesterday. Last evening his horse was found roaming through the woods, and a search this morning revealed Gillespie's dead body on an abandoned road. A bullet hole was found in his head. Three rough characters who were seen in the vicinity are suspected of his murder.

SEDALIA, Aug. 31.--The Republican State Convention, which convenes here to-morrow, will nominate a Supreme Court Judge, Railroad Commissioner, and Superintendent of Public Instruction.

Young Harry Porter Todd graduated from the University of New-York when he was 18 years old--seven years ago--and two years later he went to Mexico to seek his fortune. His father, Paul Porter Todd, a wealthy real estate lawyer and broker at No. 145 Broadway, who lives at No. 225 West Fifty-second-street, gave him a little money to start with.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 31.--Thirty-five strippers and toners in the South Norwalk hat factory went on strike to-day. They demand an advance of 25 per cent. in their wages. Their action throws 100 other employee ont of work. It is believed that the trouble will only be temporary.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 31.--Thomas J. Nolan received notification to-day from the department at washington that he had been allowed a pension, with back pay, amounting to more than $4,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 31.--Sight drafts on New-York, 12 ; telegraphic, 20.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N.Y., Aug. 31.--There have been showers along the Hudson to-day, and farmers are congratulating themselves over the end of what was rapidly becoming a serious drought. The streams are all very low, and cattle have to be driven long distances for water. This being the last day of August, the rush of Summer boarders down the Hudson on cars and boats has been very heavy.

Mr. Rene Van Note has written to THE TIMES to state that he has not been at Manasquan, N.J., for two months, and that therefore be could not have been the person who was arrested there on Friday last.
The will of Samuel Colville, the theatrical manager, was filed for probate in the Surrogate's office yesterday. The instrument was executed on Oct. 1, 1882, at the Westminster Hotel.

The weather was dull and gloomy yesterday in the vicinity of Sheepshead Bay, and a heavy shower at noon made the track heavy. Long-striding horses had much the worst of it, and the tribulations of the betting element began early in the day.

WAYNESBOROUGH, Ga., Aug. 31.--Lola, the 6-year-old daughter of William Lovell, while hunting hens' nests was bitten on the foot by a rattlesnake. Her lips, tongue, and throat were fearfully swollen, and foam issued from her mouth and nostrils. At first her mother thought it to be but the prick of a thorn, but a search of the old house discovered the snake, which had 12 rattles and was five feet long. It was killed.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Aug. 31.--James Hearn, a prominent farmer residing near Cherry Valley, Wilson County, was shot and mortally wounded by his son, John Hearn, to-day.

The best bowling performance in cricket match on record was done by E.W. Markham last month at Staveley, England. In eight consecutive balls he bowled seven wickets, and only missed bowling the eighth by a hair's breadth.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 31, 1886. The commission of Thomas E. Benedict, as Public Printer has been received at the White House, bearing the President's signature of date the 20th of August. It is understood that the new Public Printer will relieve Mr. Rounds about Sept. 15.

TIRNOVA, Aug. 31.--Prince Alexander's journey here from Sistova was a series of enthusiastic receptions. The people, headed by priests, flocked to the different points on the route of the procession and greeted the Prince with joyous shouts of welcome.

Mr. Matt Morgan's Diorama of the Battle fields of the Civil War, to be seen during the Winter at the Star Theatre, is now on exhibition in Cincinnati.

DETROIT, Mich., Aug. 31.--William Wandsor, the young man who was arreated at Lansing on a charge of passing bogus money, was brought before Commissioner Graves, in this city, to-day. He waived a preliminary hearing and consented to go with the officer to Vermont, where he is wanted on a charge of being implicated with a gang of counterfeiters. He went East this afternoon.

DELHI, N.Y., Aug. 31.--Ground has been broken for the erection of a beautiful little chapel, which to to be presented to the vestry and congregation of St. John's Episcopal Church, this village. The structure will be of unique design.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aug. 31.--The arrivals for the Republican State Convention are not yet numerous and are confined almost exclusively to the candidates and their immediate friends. To-morrow the delegates will begin to arrive, and by night there will be a large attendance.

This will be the third day of the meeting of the Brooklyn Jockey Club, and a great programme is offered. The principal event will be the second special sweepstakes of a mile and a quarter, for which the great flyers, Volante, Barnum, and Dew Drop, will compete.

The new North German Lloyd steamship Saale will sail for Bremen to-day. Among her passengers will be Dr. A. Jacobi, Dr. H. Kirchhoff, Dr. Richmond Lennox, Dr. V. Leser, Dr. D. D. Redmond, Baron Speck von Sternburg, and Commodore John G. Walker, United States Navy.

READING, Penn., Aug. 31.--Charles Luther, who has a wife and five children, crawled under a car siding, for shelter from the rain last evening. A shifter engine unexpectedly came up and drew the train away. Late at night he was discovered by a freight crew, who heard him groaning. He was badly hurt and died this morning.

NEW-ORLEANS, Aug. 31.--For more than a month vessels have been lying at the quarantine station on Ship Island with yellow fever on board, but most of the cases have been of a mild type, and yielded readily to prompt treatment and good nursing.

TORONTO, Ontario, Aug. 31.--A Winnipeg dispatch says that the baggage of Sir Charles Dilke and Lord Kingston, who recently passed through Winnipeg, on their way to the Pacific coast, was seized by the Northwest Mounted Police because it contained liquor. Dilke is traveling under the name of Tetlow.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Aug. 31.--The new State Fair Grounds, near this city, were dedicated, to-day.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 1.--The trade report for the year in this State, shows that corn on bottom lands has been practically destroyed, while upland will produce a good yield. Cotton reports to date are very unfavorable, and the crop will be 20 per cent. less than last year.

CHICAGO, Sept. 1.--A curious scene was witnessed in Justice Hawkinson's court this afternoon, when a little woman bustled in, carrying a small but heavy basket. UTICA, N.Y., Sept. 1.--Thomas Gray, proprietor of the American Hotel in this city, who was shot last night by John V. Bender in an altercation, died at 8:45 o'clock this evening. The ball had passed through the stomach and lodged in the spine. Gray was quite popular. There was an excited crowd of his friends around the police station this afternoon.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 1.--The greatest catch of mackerel ever know here occurred today. James Kelly and John Harrington went out early this morning and discovered huge schools of fish surrounding Seal Rock Ledge. With simply hooks and lines they succeeded in getting over 2,400 mackerel, half of which were large ones.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 1, 1886. The public debt statement issued this after noon shows the reduction of the public debt during August to be $1,910,699.02 and the total cash in the Treasury $474,270,651.74.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 1.--A strike has been declared by the Shoemakers' Union in the factory of Williams Hoyt, this city. Last week the firm refused to grant the scale of prices prepared by men employed in the team room, expecting that the men would take some action to enforce their demand.

SALEM, N.J., Sept. 1.--James Russell, a noted horse thief, escaped from the county jail here last night. A confederate broke into the Sheriff's residence and secured the keys, and, unlocking the outer and cell doors, liberated the prisoner. Russell, about six weeks ago, shortly after being released from the State Prison, stole a team at Elmer, this county. He was arrested in Philadelphia, brought here, and placed in the county jail.

Gallant Scots and fair matrons and maids poured through the gates to Jones's Wood in an endless stream yesterday morning. For the thirtieth time the New-York Caledonian Club was to have its annual games, and the Committee of Arrangements had decided that Jones's Wood was the best place, as a piece of Scottish heath could not be had.
WATERBURY, Conn., Sept. 2.--Michael Welch, of Wolcott, drove to Waterbury this morning in a two-horse lumber wagon. On his way home he had to cross the track of the Naugatuck Railroad.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 2.--Full particulars of the seizure of the Wellflect schooner Highland Light off East Point. Prince Edward Island, have been received. They show that the vessel was fishing one and a half miles from shore.
OCEAN CITY, Md., Sept. 2.--The schooner Meyer Muller, of Belfast, Me., Capt, J.H. Perkins, is ashore six miles south of Ocean City. The wreck lies on the outer bar.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2.--A special dispatch to the Chronicle from Tombstone, Arizona, says: "A rumor reached here to-day that the Mexican troops demanded of the American troops the release of Geronimo. The latter, according to the report, refused, and a fight ensued, in which five Mexicans were killed and two Americans wounded. Geronimo escaped during the melee. There are no means of verifying the rumor, as the wires are down."

The steamship Alaska, of the Guion Line, which grounded in Gedney's Channel on Tuesday evening, was floated off at 10:20 yesterday morning. Agents of the underwriters examined her and pronounced her perfectly seaworthy.

LONDON, Sept. 3.--The steamship Crete, (Br.,) Capt. James, from Montreal Aug. 16, arr. at London yesterday.

The efforts recently made by California fruit growers to sell their products in Eastern markets do not, in the opinion of some Eastern papers, indicate that the eastward movement of California fruit will be continued. But California papers reply that those who grow fruit in that State and ship it to Eastern cities are not discouraged.
Several members of the Clothing Manufacturers' Association sent word to the United Clothing Cutters' Union yesterday that they wanted to come to an understanding with their men.
TROY, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The Saratoga special on the Boston. Hoosae Tunnel and Western Railroad, due South at Eagle Bridge at 4:07 this morning, ran off the track at the switch at that station.

Appeals from strangers for charity are said to pour in upon Cornelius and William K. Vanderbilt at the rate of over 100 letters a week, a stream that has been kept up constantly ever since their father died.

A truckload of 29 bales of bright rye straw jogged peacefully along a part of Centrestreet, Park-row, Nassau-street, and Printing House-square at 1:15 o'clock yesterday afternoon.
CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--Director Frederick Billings, of the Northern Pacific Road, whose home is at Woodstock, Vt., was in the city to-day on his annual trip over his road.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 2.--Robert D. Lawton, of this city, ex-Secretary of the General Executive Committee of the Knights of Labor, spoke freely to-day in reference to the inception and progress of the plot to murder General Master workman Powderly, giving much new information on the subject.

JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 2.--The First Chautauqua Assembly District Republican Convention at Mayville to-day nominated the Hon. D.P. Horton for member of Assembly. Jerome Babcock was defeated for renomination because of services in behalf of the bill to retard the building of the Chautauqua Railway last Winter against the wishes of his constituents. Mr. Horton served in the Assembly two terms.
NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 2.--The English polo players not only succeeded in beating the American players last week, but they also succeeded in selling their ponies this afternoon at very high prices.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 2.--The Democratic State Convention to-day nominated Jackson Temple, of Santa Rosa: J.F. Sullivan, or San Francisco, and Byron Waters, of San Bernardino, for the three vacancies on the Supreme Bench.
Prof. P. de Janon, of West Point, is at the New-York Hotel. Paymaster L.G. Boggs, United States Navy, is at the Albemarle Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--Congressman King, of Louisiana, who refused to fight Cuthbert B. Jones, of that State, not long ago, when challenged, for the alleged utterance of a slander upon certain aged ladies, is again made the subject of Mr. Jones's uncomfortable attentions.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 2.--Capt. John S. Wharton, Nineteenth Infantry, has been found incapacitated for active service, and his leave of absence has been extended till further orders.

Except what the newspapers contained information here about Charleston yesterday was almost as meagre as on Wednesday.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett acted Richelieu in Bulwer's play at the Star Theatre last evening, and the performance, which was characterized by earnestness, vigor, and artistic finish in a rare degree, was enjoyed by a numerous and appreciative audience.

ROUSE'S POINT, N.Y., Sept. 2.--Hosmer won the race here by eight lengths. The first mile and a half was made in 10:10 and the three miles in 21:15. The time was very fast considering the fact that the water was extremely rough. Hosmer and McKay will leave for Erie, Penn., to-night, to row in the regatta there on the 7th inst.
PLYMOUTH, N.H., Sept. 2.--There was a heavy frost here this morning. Much damage to corn, vines, and fruit is reported.
I desire to inform market men and others that by a law passed by the last Legislature the sale of reed birds, robins, and meadow larks is prohibited.

Argument was made yesterday before Judge Barrett, in the Supreme Court, on the question whether a temporary injunction on behalf of the Commmercial Telegram Company should be continued.
The third day of the meeting of the Coney Island Jockey Club was a great success. The weather was fine, the track fast, and the attendance of spectators very large, while the racing was fairly good.
Katie Richie, who is lying ill at the Jersey City Hospital, tells a remarkable story. She says that she had been ill with heart troubles for some time and that her father is out of employment.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 2.--The Giants lost another game here to-day, through their inability to bat the curves of young Conway, Detroit's new pitcher. The latter handled the ball in rare style, and, with the exception of Connor, completely puzzled the batters from New-York.

In view of the extraordinary statement made by Secretary Sheehan to the Aqueduct Commissioners on Wednesday that the cost of condemning to the use of the city for aqueduct purposes 16 acres of land, worth only $59,000, had been $104,000, Corporation Counsel Lacombe yesterday gave out some figures indicating the facts in the matter.

WATCH HILL, R.I., Sept. 2.--The Boundary Commissioners appointed by the States of Rhode Island and Connecticut to establish the disputed boundary between the two States held an adjourned meeting to-day and have, after two years' consideration of the matter, come to a definite conclusion.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2.--A decided sensation was created to-day in political circles by the filing of a petition in the Common Pleas Court by Edward E. Nisewander against the Hon. John McBride, the Democratic candidate ...
COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 2.--The refugees who arrived in this city last night from Summerville have taken homes here for the present, and will probably remain here during the week.

Superintendent Price, of the Newark Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, threatens to prosecute the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad Company for cruelty to animals.

FALL RIVER, Mass., Sept. 2.--The Fall River Academy of Music was opened for the season with Roland Reed in "Cheek." There was a very large attendance. The academy will be under the management of Mr. Thomas R. Burrill, the same as last year, and he has already a long list of engagements on his books for the coming season. The outlook for the season is better than at any corresponding time in ...
MADRID, Sept. 2.--Several shocks of earthquake were felt at Malaga Wednesday. Some losses were caused by the disturbances.

MOBILE, Ala., Sept. 2.--Benjamin R. Popham, a railroad conductor on the Georgia Pacific, and William F. McDonald, contractor on the Government building at Aberdeen, met Henry C. Roberts on the street this evening, when shooting was begun. Roberts hit Popham in the knee, and the latter fired twice, hitting Roberts in the neck and head. He dropped dead. It was a domestic misunderstanding, and all three men were prepared.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 2.--The Common Council to-day appointed a committee of seven to investigate charges of malfeasance in office against Mayor William B. Smith, and instructed the committee, if the charges were found true, to present articles of impeachment against the Mayor at a special meeting of the Chamber to be held on Thursday next.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 2.--Dr. Joseph Holt, President of the Louisiana State Board of Health, arrived this morning from Biloxi, and a meeting of the board was called at 12 o'clock to receive his report. Dr. Holt made the following report:
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Sept. 2.--There were fully 45,000 people at the State Fair to-day. At many points the railroads were compelled to leave crowds behind for lack of cars.

CHICAGO, Sept. 2.--Republicans representing the first six Congressional districts of Illinois held a meeting here to-day to discuss the attitude which the party should be asked to maintain with reference to the temperance question, and to select delegates to the national conference of anti-saloon Republicans, to be held in Chicago Sept. 16.
Israel Levy, of No. 42 Clinton-street, has made an affidavit in which he says that he expects his mother, 70 years of age, on one of the Monarch Line steamships, which left Liverpool late in August.

PANAMA, Aug. 24.--A duel was fought at Bohio, on the line of the railway, on Aug. 18, between two Frenchmen. The weapons were rifies. Two shots were exchanged and honor was satisfied, although neither of the parties to the affair was wounded. A negro who was at work on the canal, however, was struck by one of the bullets and instantly killed.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 2.--Henri F. Requier, for many years on the editorial staff of the Pleayune, died this morning of Bright's disease. He was an accomplished scholar and a brilliant writer. He was a native of Charleston, and 50 years old. He was brother of Abram J. Requier, of New-York.

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 2.--On the farm of Rutger Vanderburg, in the town af North Greenbush, three miles northeast of Bath, at 7 o'clock this morning, the sudden explosion of a boiler of a steam thrashing machine caused the death of Edward Phillips, the owner and engineer, and of Archie Hankle, of Bath.

WAUKESHA, Wis., Sept. 2.--Two ballots were taken to-day in the Second District Democratic Congressional Convention, and while Gen. Bragg realizes that he cannot be nominated himself he showed by his tactics that he hopes to name the winning man, and if he has his way that man will be some one he can control.
"Little Jack Sheppard" will be produced at the Bijou Opera House Sept. 13. During his present engagement at the Star Theatre Mr. Lawrence Barrett will appear as Richard III.
