ERIE, Penn., Sept. 6.--The sailing and rowing regatta which will begin to-morrow morning has drawn hither a very large number of oarsmen and their friends. George H. Hosmer, of Boston, will be referee to-morrow, and James Wilson, ex-champion of England, will be referee for the rest of the rowing races.

The need of Charleston is that of a city of which one-half the inhabitants are suddenly rendered homeless. Anybody who will consider what would be the condition of his own neighborhood if such a calamity should befall it will see how important it is that relief should be promptly furnished.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Sept. 6.--John Q. Cannon, First Counselor to the Presiding Bishop of the Mormon Church, a member of the late Legislature and of the City Council, and son of George Q. Cannon, made a public confession of adultery in the Tabernacle yesterday, and was cut off from the church on motion of his uncle, Angus M. Cannon.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 6.--Constable James F. Ryan was shot and fatally wounded about 6 o'clock this evening by Bill Gooley, private watchman at the Standard Theatre. Ryan, it appears, went into Tom Kelly's saloon on Market-street, and had some angry words ...

KALAMAZOO, Mich., Sept. 6.--A mob from Norwich Township, 100 persons in 12 wagons, visited the Missaukee County Jail at Lake City last night armed with revolvers, rifles, battering rams, and ropes to lynch Craft and Mrs. Brass, imprisoned for the murder of the woman's husband, but Sheriff McBain finally persuaded them to desist. The prisoners were terribly frightened.

LANCESTER, Penn., Sept. 6.--The Columbia Rolling Mill Company's mill remains idle, although a report gained circulation that the differences with the hands would be settled and work resumed early this week.

CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 6, via Galveston.-- The Hon. Arthur G. Sedgwick, the special agent sent here by the United States Government to inquire into the Cutting case, has completed his investigation and has gone to Chihuahua, having obtained permission from the Mexican Government to look at all the records in the case.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 6.--Mrs. Belle Blake was killed at her home near Glen Elder, Mitchell County, Kan., Saturday afternoon, and the circumstances strongly indicate murder.

CHICAGO, Sept. 6.--Ten of the Chicago batsmen were sent to their bases on called balls in to-day's game against the New Yorks, and the result was that the Giants encountered another defeat. Welch, who pitched, was very erratic, and when the occasion demanded it he appeared to be unable to put the ball over the plate.

STEVENS HOUSE, Lake Placid, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The President's party breakfasted at 7 o'clock at the Stevens House, Lake Placid, this morning and drove 40 miles to-day over a stretch of country affording some majestic mountain scenery. The route was through the Wilmington Notch and down the west branch of the Au Sable River, ...

Jeremiah P. Robinson, the millionaire warehouseman, died on Aug. 26 from the effects of a malignant carbuncle. Yesterday it was rumored about Brooklyn that his entire family had died in great agony from poison introduced into their systems while handling the bandages on Mr. Robinson's neck.
BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 6.--The East Buffalo live stock men to-day played a card in the game at present going on between them and the Central Traffic Association, which euchred Agent Pake.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 6.--major John W. Johnston, President of the Georgia Pacific Railway, states that the company has resolved to alter its gauge to the standard from Greenville, Miss., to Johnsonville, and to extend its line ...

It was announced in the House of Commons yesterday by the Government that "a change in the Government of Bulgaria can only occur in accordance with the treaty of Berlin, and with the consent of the signatory powers to that treaty. England had no separate interests in reference to Bulgaria.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 6.--In the suit of the City of Pittsburg against Dr. David Hostetter, to recover damages for breach of contract on the part of Andrew Hartupee, contractor for the new city water works, a compromise was effected to-day by Dr. Hostetter agreeing to pay the city $143,500. Hostetter, who was surety for Hartupee, has paid to the city altogether over $400,000.

ISHPEMING, Mich., Sept. 6.--Michael Davitt, on his trip through Northern Michigan, was followed by a shorthand reporter in the pay of the British Government. All of his speeches and some of his private conversations were taken down in full by this indefatigable agent of the English authorities.

The entries for to-day's races of the Coney island Jockey Club are very heavy, especially in the short races, and the speculators will have a hard time in picking the winners. The full entry list is as follows:

BRISTOL, R.I., Sept. 6.--Babbit Post, G. A.R., of this town, have offered to escort the remains of Gen. Aspinwall from the house to the steamboat, and the offer has been accepted. Mrs. Aspinwall and her brother, Mr. William B. Dewolfe, and son, will leave here Tuesday on the 1 o'clock train for NewYork.

The organized workingmen wre in their glory yesterday, and very many of them took a day off, put bits of ribbon in their buttonholes, and fell into the ranks of the procession that marched by the cottage in Union-square. The announcement that Mayor Grace and Henry George would review the parade brought out their respective friends in full force, and now ...
Lester Wallack and Col. John A. McCaull are the first New-York managers to take action in regard to furnishing aid for the suffering citizens of Charleston.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 6.--While Rachel Bernstein, aged 14 years, was heating an alcohol lamp last evening it exploded and set fire to her dress. Her screams brought to her aid her aunt, Mrs. Philip Hirsch, who threw a bed cover over her. She was herself badly burned while doing so. Miss Bernstein's injuries were such that her recovery was at first thought doubtful, but her condition is better to-day. Both will probably recover.

The third race for the New-York Canoe Club's international challenge cup, which was sailed on the club course, off Tompkinsville, Staten Island, yesterday afternoon, again showed the superiority of the sloop model to the cutter model in smooth water and light airs. Mr. Baden-Powell's canoe, the Nautilus, which is in model a slight variation of the American ...
The Count Giuseppe Mucciola was a passenger on the steamship Polcevera, which arrived yesterday from the Mediterranean.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Circle is one of the fashionable and most beautiful quarters of this city. This morning it was the scene of a most cold blooded and deliberate murder. "L.S.L."--Gen. Joseph E. Johnston is still living. THE TIMES has received $5 from "A.F. H." for the sanitary tent on Bedloe's Island.

HALIFAX, Nova Scotia, Sept. 7.--The schooner Florence B. Parr, at Canso, from the Grand Banks, reports having spoken on Sunday, Sept. 5, in latitude 45 53' and longitude 58 50', the yacht Corona, from Cowes for New-York. She reported having had heavy weather. She was lying to for eight days on the edge of the New foundland Banks.

ATLANTA, Ga., Sept. 7.--The Agricultural Department has completed the compilation of the reports secured from its corps of crop reporters throughout the State. The report indicates a general improvement during the month of August in all-crops.

SOFIA, Sept. 7.--The Russian Consul here has informed Prince Alexander that the Czar accepts the proposals made by the Bulgarian Notables as the conditions of the Prince's abdication and that the Czar will recognize the Regency, the union of Bulgaria and Roumelia, ...

The journeyman plumbers prepared a statement yesterday denying the charges made by the bosses that they objected to the employment of apprentices. They never intended to prevent boys from learning the plumbing trade, but they did object to the manner in which the master plumbers employed them.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Western Convocation of the Protestant Episcopal Church began a two days' session at St. Andrew's Church, Walden, this evening, with an attendance of 15 clergymen. The speakers at the first session were the Rev. Mr. Bedinger, of Matteawan; the Rev. William McSlatherly, of Middletown, and the Rev. Mr. Thomas, of West Point.
ASBURY PARK, N.J., Sept. 7.--Postmaster Adam Hummer, of Millstone, N.J., was assaulted and robbed by two masked men last evening near the Asbury Park railroad station.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 7.--The committee of the Court of Common Council, appointed to investigate the charges of corruption and bribery in the Aldermanic Board of 1884, held its first meeting to-night.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 7.--Gov. Abbett to-day appointed Col. Charles W. Dickinson, of Salem County; the Hon. William S. Taylor, of Burlington, and Oscar Dunn, of Sussex, as the New-Jersey delegates to the annual convention of the National Agricultural and Dairy Association, to be held in Philadelphia on Sept. 15 and 16.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 7.--An impressive ceremony took place yesterday at Gouldbourn, near here, when a wealthy Protestant lady named Mrs. Brown and her young daughter were received into the Catholic Church.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 7.--A fire in which two lives were lost occurred this afternoon at Cliff Mine, on the Montour Railroad. At 4 o'clock the house occupied by L.L. Mathews was discovered to be on fire.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7.--The Pacific coast Freight Agents of the transcontinental lines have announced a reduction of rates on eastbound freight of 50 per cent., with the minimum 50 cents per 100 pounds to Chicago and St. Louis. This action was taken because of the fierce opposition of the Pacific Mail Steamship Company and the Canadian Pacific Railway Company. The reduced rates have been guaranteed up to next Saturday.

SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 7.--Their three days' carriage drive ended when the President's party drove up to the long cabin once more at noon to-day. They left the Stevens House at Lake Placid at 8 o'clock this morning.

Judge Allen, of the Court of Common Pleas, yesterday refused to grant a mandamus to compel the Commissioner of Public Works to give the New-York Electric Lines Company a permit to open the surfaces of the various streets for the purpose of laying conduits for telegraphic, ...

HARTFORD, Conn., Sept. 7.--Social and financial circles here are greatly excited over the disappearance of Thomas F. Plunkett, President of the Hartford Silk Company, situated in Tariffville, and Treasurer of the Union Manufacturing Company, situated in Manchester. He left Hartford a week ago last Saturday, saying he was going to New-York and Philadelphia on business ...

LONDON, Sept. 7.--The stemship Lake Nepigon, (Br.) Capt. Tramner, ald, from Liverpool for Montreal to-day. Arr. Sept. 7, Charles.
ERIE, Penn., Sept. 7.--A few weeks ago during a painters' difficulty Enos K. Jones, who came to Erie from New-Orleans, shot and mortally wounded Charles Yoder, of Northumberland County.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Sept. 7.--A natural gas vein was struck to-day at a depth of 815 feet at Five Mile Lock, near here. The gas rushed up with great force, and, igniting from a boiler, consumed the entire rig, and is now blazing 35 feet high through an eight-inch pipe.
CITY OF MEXICO, Sept. 7, via Galveston, --It is understood here that Minister Jackson will return to the United States about Oct. 1.

VICTORIA, Tamanlipas, Mexico, Sept. 7.-- Gov. Cuelar is in receipt of telegrams informing him that Hilario Rodriguez Martinez, a brother of the famous Coyote, crossed the Rio Grande, near Rema, leading 33 Texas Mexicans to join the revolutionists.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The contest over the will of Francis W. Tracy, the millionaire husband of Agnes Ethel, who is now in Europe, was resumed here to-day after a rest of eight weeks.

MADISON, Wis., Sept. 7.--The Republican state Convention meets here to-morrow noon. Of 322 delegates who will compose the body over 200 are already in town, and the air is filled with rumors and speculations as to the turn of events. The present State officers have held their places for ...

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Sept. 7.--The following candidates for cadetships have passed their examination and been admitted to the Naval Academy: C.S. Smith, W.L. Norton, and E.H. McDonald, of New-York; R.N. Chappell, of Indiana; G.B. White and D.H. Kreamer, of Wisconsin; F.L. Eaton of Michigan, and Porter Chandler, of Missouri.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 7.--To-day's session of the committee investigating the charges against Mayor Smith was mainly devoted to the examinations of persons whom it was alleged have been carried on the police pay rolls while performing no duties for the department.

The scientific gentlemen who have gone to Charleston to examine into the causes of the earthquake are indignant because the ministers of the Gospel in the stricken city did not take the scientific view of the terrible demonstration of nature in their sermons last Sunday. Their indignation, however, seems to be a little unreasonable.

The career of Emil C.W. Macholdt, who was formerly a real estate broker at No. 1,216 Third-avenue, has been brought to a sudden close, so far as that locality is concerned. Emil was not unusually good looking, his English was very faulty, but it was plentiful and persuasive.

PORTLAND, Me., Sept. 7.--The Catholic pilgrimage to the shrine of St. Anne de Beaupre in Canada started from this city to-day under the direction of the Rev. Father Massen, parish priest at Danville, Quebec, Accessions to the ranks are expected along the road. They will reach Quebec at 5 o'clock to-morrow morning, and from there take steamers for St. Anne.

MONTREAL, Sept. 7.--De Lacy and Dempsey, the New-York boodle Aldermen who have been passing the Summer in Europe, arrived at Quebec yesterday by the Sarmatian, and now are once more installed in their old quarters at the Windsor, where they were welcomed by Keenan. Billy Moloney, the ex-reading clerk, has not returned with the exiles, but remains in Paris. De Lacey was accompanied by his wife and son.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--The Trustees of the Chicago University to-day concluded to give up the struggle to clear the institution of the great debt hanging over it, and the university in its original form is a thing of the past.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 7.--Martin Irons, the leader of the great Southwestern Railway strike, was looked up at the police station last night, on a charge of drunkenness. He was unable to give bonds for his release.
MONTREAL, Sept. 7.--The Rev. Dr. R.R. Kane, of Christ Church, Belfast, Grand Master of the Orange body in Ireland, and Mr. G.H. Smith, barrister, of Armagh, arrived in this city this morning.
MEMPHIS, Tenn., Sept. 7.--The tangle in which West Tennessee appointments have been involved has been straightened out at last.
NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 7.--At the regular meeting of the Board of Health to-night the fact of the disappearance of the alleged yellow fever from Biloxi was reported.

CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--For the sixth successive time the Giants were defeated to-day. They played strongly against the champions, and held the lead from the first to the eighth inning, but at that stage of the game the Chicago men used their bats to good advantage against the delivery of Keefe, and scored 4 runs that made them the winners by a score of 13 to 11.

PITTSBURG, Penn., Sept. 7.--It is understood that at the National Convention of the Knights of Labor at Richmond, next month, changes in the present laws will be made which will amount practically to a complete reorganization of the order.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The summons and complaint in the action of the United States Trust Company of New-York against the Buffalo, New-York and Philadelphia Railroad Company and others, trial to be had in this county, were filed yesterday.

MEMPHIS, Sept. 7.--The Directors of the Kansas City, Memphis and Birmingham Railroad, now being built hence to Birmingham, meet here to-morrow. G.H. Nettleton will be elected Superintendent, and the road will be treated as a division of the Kansas City, Springfield and Memphis.

ERIE, Penn., Sept. 7.--The Erie sailing and rowing regatta opened to-day with the olinker and four-oared shell races. James Taylor, ex-champion of England, was the referee.
JAMESTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The first an nual regatta of amateur oarsmen on Chautauqua Lake began at Long Point to-day and will con clude to-morrow.

HAMILTON, Ontario, Sept. 7.--Edward Myers, who obtained $2,500 from Thomas Maxwell, of St. Louis, to buy horses, and absconded to Canada was arrested here to-day. He will be prosecuted for bringing stolen money into the country.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 7.--The Board of Education last night decided to establish free night schools in this city. This action was taken in view of the fact that it was impossible to enforce the compulsory education law, and the establishment of evening schools will give children who work in shops and factories an opportunity to obtain free instruction.

ATHENS, Sept. 7--Fresh shocks of earthquake were felt to-day in this city and at Kalavrita and elsewhere. Seismie rumblings were heard yesterday throughout Peloponesus.

John Schmidt, a German saloon keeper, yesterday shot and killed his wife at her saloon, No. 19 Fair-street, Newark, N.J. Two weeks ago, in a fit of jealousy, he made over the saloon to his wife for $150 and went to Chicago.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 7.--The State House Rebuilding Commission held a business meeting at the Capitol to-day. It was decided to have no cornerstone-laying ceremonies, it being the sense of the commission that such exercises would not be appropriate, since the event is not really the construction of a new building but only a part of one.

BOSTON, Sept. 7.--The National Party of Massachusetts has issued a call for a convention to nominate State officers, to be held in Boston on Sept. 21. An invitation to take part has been extended to the Knights of Labor, trades unionists, and members of all other industrial organizations in favor of distinct political action.

Manning, of Louisiana, to be Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary to Mexice; John Drayton, of South Carolina, to be Consul at Tuxpan; Charles H. LAKE GEORGE, N.Y., Sept. 7.--A race over a 20-mile course was sailed on Lake George to-day by the cutter Leila and the centreboard yacht Coquette. CHICAGO, Sept. 7.--August Dahms and John Muelto, two sailors, are locked up at the armory pending the arrival of extradition papers from Buffalo, N.Y. The prisoners are wanted for the murder of one Thomas J. Cavanagh. They are both non-union men, who served aboard the schooner Halsted. The murder, which occurred on Aug. 27, grew out of trouble between union and non-union men.

PITTSBURG, Sept. 7.--Gen. James A. Beaver, the Republican candidate for Governor, arrived in this city to-day from the Pacific coast. He is in good health and spirits concerning the political situation.

NEWARK, N.J., Sept. 7.--John Kerns, an engineer at Ballantine's brewery, met with a horrible death to-night. Physicians say he has swallowed poison and will die before morning.

NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The United States Brewers' Association opened a special convention at the Park Theatre at 10:30 o'clock this morning. About 200 members were present.

The firm of Hanan Son, manufacturers of fine shoes, at No. 122 Centre-street, has had an experience with the Knights of Labor through District Assembly No. 91, out of which the Knights claim a victory, which is not begrudged them by the firm.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 8.--About 2,500 persons attenned the second day of the racing at Hampden Park to-day. The track was in fair condition, but the sport was somewhat drawn out, and lacked enthusiasm.
ST. LOUIS, Sept. 8.--The Republicans of the Eighteenth Illinois Congressional District to-day nominated Jehu Baker for Congress.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 8.--The body of Charles Myers, about 35 years of age, who was drowned, was recovered from the Hudson River near Poughkeepsie to-day . Myers was a German. The inquest was deferred until to-morrow evening in the hope that friends would come forward and claim the body.
SARANAC INN, N.Y., Sept. 8.--Little has been done by the members of the President's party to-day besides resting comfortably in the shade and recovering from the fatigue of their long carriage drive.

The return match between the Manhattan Cricket Club, of Brooklyn, and the Newark (N. J.) club was played yesterday at Newark. Davis's 37, Cuddihy's 15, Love's 19, and Middleton's 11, hit off 117 and won.

BALTIMORE, Md., Sept. 8.--The contest this afternoon was very spirited, especially on the part of the Metropolitans, and in the fifth inning they scored the 8 runs which eventually decided the game. McGinnis was then batted quite freely for four-singles, with a total of six bases.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Sept. 8.--News of a shocking murder in Stone County was received here this evening. Giles Miller, a stockman and resident of Missouri, was waylaid while buying cattle, shot three times, and left for dead on the roadside.
Of the 137 counties in Georgia, 108 have absolute prohibition and 12 others have partial prohibition. There are only 17 counties in Georgia where whisky has full swing.

Cappa's great jubilee at Brighton Beach began yesterday, and was marked with great success. The weather was not favorable, but this did not hinder a large number of people from listening with pleasure.

CALAIS, Me., Sept. 8.--Reports from the surrounding country in all directions say that forest fires are raging, and that it is almost impossible to prevent the spread of the flames. Large crews are fighting fires all through the upper townships. The water in the rivers and lakes has not been so low for years. Saw mills are doing very little work.

Daniel Manning, Secretary of the Treasury, arrived in Buffalo this morning with his wife for a brief visit to Mrs. Manning's brother, Mr. Robert Livingston Fryer, at No. 724 Main-street. Belcher, after whose father, the late Joseph Belcher, the school is named. It is possible to live to a very ripe old age in Yates County. Yates is making a reputation for good health and longevity. It has within its borders 72 persons whose average age is over 86 years. TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 9.--Luella Layton, a 13-year-old girl living with farmer Samuel Eldridge, at Hamilton-square, two miles from this city, committed suicide yesterday morning by taking a dose of Paris green. The reason for pleasant and she was in good health and spirits. County Physician Lalor learned that relatives of the girl have committed suicide in the past, and he believes she inherited the suicidal mania.

NEW-BRUNSWICK, N.J., Sept. 9.--SubContractor Conway, of the City Railroad, has procured a mechanics' lien against the company, represented by Delano Richardson, of New York, for money advanced by him in buildinng the road. All work on tho road has stopped. The streets are broken up and the people of the city are indignant at the company. The local Directors, who were as badly deceived as anybody, will withdraw.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 9.--A letter to the Bulletin from Seoul, Corea, dated Aug. 2, says that the deaths from Asiatic cholera from July 15 to July 25 numbered 3,140. Since then from 267 to 497 persons had died daily. Coflins could not be obtained, and bodies were wrapped in sacking In many places dogs and vultures had scratched away the light covering of earth and devoured the bodies.

WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 9.--Col. Gilder started this evening for York Factory, having been detained waiting for the Hudson's Bay steamer, upon which he sails to-morrow from Selkirk to Norway House.

TURN SEVERIN, Sept. 9.--Prince Alexander, M. Stambuloff, M. Karaveloff, and nearly all the Bulgarian Ministers arrived here this morning in a yacht. SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Sept. 9.--Fully 5,000 persons witnessed the Grand Circuit races at Hampden Park to-day. The track was in fair condition, and the races were the most exciting of the week, with lively betting.

The second competition for the lacrosse championship of the United States between the New-York Lacrosse acid Brooklyn Athletic Clubs will take place to-day at the Staten Island

ALBANY, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Prices on lumber in this market are to be advanced at a meeting of the lumber dealers of the city to-morrow afternoon. The new scale is to go into effect on Monday. The increase of Western prices and in freight rates are the reasons for the advance.

LOUISVILLE, Sept. 10.--The Louisville Presbytery met promptly at 9 o'clock this morning to continue the Converse trial. The meeting was opened with devotional exercises led by the Rev. J.W. Pratt, D.D. After the usual routine the prosecution continued its testimony by introducing the affidavit of the Rev. John B. Adger, of South Carolina. Dr. Adger's testimony was to the effect that he was acquainted with the reputation of the Christian Observer.
FORT WORTH, Texas, Sept. 10.--From parties arriving here to-night on the Missouri Pacific Railroad train, the facts of an exciting contest at Vinita, Indian Territory, are learned.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 10.--Lucius Botsford, a 3-year-old boy living in West Stratford, while playing near a second-story window in his father's house last night clambered up on the sill, lost his balance, and fell to the ground below. He was picked up insensible. It was found that the fall had broken one thigh, and that both his legs were fractured.

Henry Conley Wilkinson, a dealer in patent medicines at No. 24 Cliff street, who lives in Brooklyn, was taken to the Jefferson Market Court, yesterday, on complaint of Edwin Adams Weed, of No. 156 West Thirty-fourth-street, who charges that Wilkinson and R. M. Kennedy, of No. 28 Wood-street, Pittsburg, and No. 263 Oxford-street, London, cheated him out of $5,000.
SYRACUSE, Sept. 10.--Justice Williams to-day handed down his decision in the Wilkinson case. He appointed Charles E. Hubbell and Albert K. Hiscock Receivers.

A Boston physician was called out of a sound slumber the other night to answer the telephone. "Hello! what is it?" he asked, little pleased at the idea of leaving his comfortable bed. "Baby is crying, doctor.

"The earthquake!" cried the handsomest member of the Knickerbocker Club, as he felt himself soar from a camp stool on the deck of the Luther C. Ward, that able sea-going tug, exactly at 8:49 o'clock on Thursday night, two marine leagues this side of Sandy Hook Lightship.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 10.--The State Board of Health has requested local boards to endeavor to obtain evidence against physicians failing to file a report of births, as specified by law.

WHITE RIVER JUNCTION, Vt., Sept. 10.-- Complete returns from the entire State, comprising 241 towns, give the Gubernatorial vote as follows: Ormsbee, (Rep.,) 37,681; Shurtleff, (Dem.,) 17,091; Seely, (Pro.,) 1,832; Greenback ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--The Philadelphia Club played a great game of ball with the Washingtons to-day, batting hard and fielding almost perfectly, the only error being Irwin's failure to stop a slow hit.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10.--Michael J. Sheehan, general merchant, of Yarmouth, Nova Scotia, who has failed with liabilities of $30,000, will be brought before the court here by Montreal merchants for obtaining $25,000 worth of goods under false pretenses.

The question as to how long the public can stand the pecuniary pressure of every-day racing is yet to be answered, for the crowd at the track of the Brooklyn Jockey Club was large enough to indicate that the source of the golden stream is not near exhaustion.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--By making concessions pretty nearly all around the managers of the Western Roads to-day managed to form a pool to take the place of the old Western Freight Association.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The Western Railway General Managers, after a three-days' session, succeeded to-day in reaching a basis of compromise and reorganizing the Western Freight Association.

NEW-ORLEANS, Sept. 10.--Dr. George J. Adams, of Massachusetts, was arrested here today charged with embezzlement by a number of persons who had furnished him money to promote a search for hidden treasure.

The Mayflower and Galatea lay at their anchorage at Bay Ridge yesterday morning. They had met with no mishap in the dense fog of Thursday night, and were safe and sound from keel to main truck. The Mayflower, after rounding the outer mark in the race and being shut in by the fog, ...

The New-York Cricket Club played a match with the St. George's Cricket Club yesterday at Hoboken, N.J. The St. George's, which were first to the bat, scored 58 runs, H. Martin being the highest scorer with 19.
WINNIPEG, Manitoba, Sept. 10.--Col. Gilder and his companion, Griffith, started for the north pole last night. They will take the steamer Princess at Selkirk and proceed to Norway House.

LANCASTER, Penn., Sept. 10.--S.S. Snodgrass, a farmer in Little Britain Township, this county, last week brought 96 head of Durham steers from Chicago, selling a number to his neighbors. Four have since died at Snodgrass farm from splenic apoplexy and a number are very sick, while several deaths have occurred among the stock sold in the neighborhood. The disease is pronounced very contagious and the cattle have been quarantined.
BYRON, Ga., Sept. 10.--A shocking case of attempted parricide is reported here. Six miles distant lives Mr. S.D. Arnold and his son, John Arnold.

OTTAWA, Sept. 10.--It is proposed to hold a musical festival or convention here. Dr. Perkins of New-York will likely be conductor.

SCRANTON, Penn., Sept. 10.--A picnic held at Freeman's Grove, a short distance from Scranton, last night for the benefit of the Holden Shaft Keg Fund Association was the scene of several desperate encounters, which resulted in the murder of a young man named Patrick McAndrew and the maiming of a number of others, ...

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Sept. 10.--John R. Neal, the present Representative, was nominated for Congress by the Democratic Convention last night from this, the Third Congressional District. The convention was in session two days and more than 150 ballots were cast.
VICKSBURG, Miss., Sept. 10.--The Mississippi State Board of Health to-day issued the following letter to all States interested:

Over half of the cotton crop grown this year in the South is the product of white labor. Few people who have not personally witnessed the marked changes that have taken place in recent years down in Dixie can understand what this really means.

BOSTON, Sept. 10.--The West Indies and Longwood Cricket teams played on the latter's grounds to-day, but although playing was continued for five hours the first inning was not finished when the players stopped for to-day. The Longwood team have six more men to bat before the inning is completed. The game will be continued to-morrow. To-day's score stands: West Indies, 97; Longwood, 38.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Col. Charles S. Stewart, the senior Colonel of Engineers in the army, has formally applied to be placed on the retired list next Thursday, Sept.16, for 40 years' service, instead of waiting until April 11, 1887, when he would be retired for age.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10.--The Provincial Synod of the Church of England met again today, when the whole time was taken up with discussing missionary work, the Synod resolving itself into a meeting of the Domestic and Foreign Missionary Society, with the Metropolitan ...

COLUMBIA, S.C., Sept. 10.--The State Department of Agriculture has received 229 special reports from county and township correspondents regarding the condition of the growing crops. The weather during August had been variable in different sections of the State, 74 correspondents reporting it as as favorable and 51 unfavorable.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept. 10.--Recently there have been several icehouses along the Hudson River destroyed by fire. The insurance companies carrying risks on the various icehouses decided that it would probably be to their advantage to investigate how the other icehouses and premises were kept.
LONDON, Sept. 10.--The steamship Burgos, (Br.,) Capt. Ohlenroth, from New-York Aug. 25 for Havre, passed the Lizard to-day.

Lizzie Bower, age 15 years, a pretty and intelligent looking girl, complained at the Tombs Police Court yesterday morning that she had been assaulted on three occasions by her employer, Frederick Daub, a restaurant keeper.

BUTTE, Montana, Sept.10.--John Hobbar, 16 years old, a tool packer, attempted to jump across a shaft in the Alice mine yesterday. He struck his head on a cross bar and fell down the shaft, a distance of 817 feet. His body was terribly mutilated and his head was smashed flat.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Sept. 10.--A story is published here to-night that four men, Timothy Downey, Michael Mulvey, Michael Goggins, and Richard Barry, went sailing on the Sound last night, and off Stratford Light saw a sea monster over 100 feet long. It is said that they fired at it with a revolver and that it sank out of sight.

OTTAWA, Ontario, Sept. 10.--The commercial telegraph system of the Canadian Pacific Railway will be inaugurated within three weeks. Canadian messages will then be carried between the Atlantic and the Pacific over wires extending the entire distance across Canadian soil.

HALIFAX, Sept. 10.--Capt. Quigley, of the Terror, has made another seizure at Shelburne. CHICAGO, Sept.10.--Capt. Marsden, of the propeller Donaldson, in from Lake Superior, tells of a curious experience which befell him the night the great earthquake shook up the country.

GEORGETOWN, Texas, Sept.10.--The negro Irvine Murry was hanged at 1:43 P.M. to-day at a point one mile from this town. Six thousand people were present. Murry died without a struggle. After the body had been suspended l2 minutes life was pronounced extinct. Up to the last Murry preserved a cool demeanor. Every one present remarked that he died game. He made no confession. Murry murdered his wife in cold blood at Taylor in December last.

"The reign of imported work is rapidly coming to an end," said a theatrical manager yesterday, as he threw three applications for free passes on one side, "and I think that, with the present season, American playwrights will have that show for which they have been struggling so long and so unsuccessfully. ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept.10.--The lock-out in the shoe factory of Williams Hoyt was terminated at a conference held this evening between the firm and a committee of the employes. The men will resume work to-morrow. The firm granted a partial increase of wages.

CRAWFORDSVILLE, Ind., Sept. 10.--Miss Lulu Bates, of Cincinnati, made an ascension in a gas balloon from the fair grounds to-day and came near losing her life. When five miles north, and half a mile above the earth, she attempted to descend.
A check for $1,000, sent by Edwin Booth, the tragedian, to an old and dear friend in this city, whose home was destroyed by the earthquake, was received yesterday.

The quarrel between the journeyman plumbers and the bosses is becoming more bitter. The men claimed that several of the bosses had already given in. While the Master Plumbers' Association stoutly denied the assertion.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Alonzo Blondin, leading juvenile of Robert Buchanan's "Storm Beaten" company was arrested tonight as accessory to criminal malpractice.
CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--The house of Horace Branch, at No. 1,075 Washington Boulevard, was struck by lightning in the storm last evening. It is a two-story frame house with a brick basement.

WILLIAMSPORT, Penn., Sept. 10.--A verdict of not guilty was rendered to-day in the case of the Common wealth against Shaw and Harrison, jointly indicted with Ford, Lacey, and others for assault and battery and kidnaping.

BUFFALO, Sept. 10.--It is not generally believed that Adam Forepaugh's horse Blondin will walk across the Niagara gorge on Monday, nor is it thought he would have done so if Henry Bergh had not announced his intention to interfere. None of Forepaugh's or Bergh's representtaives are in town to-day.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10.--John J. Gorres, a music dealer, of No. 27 Elizabethstreet, has been missing from his home since Wednesday. Some years ago he conducted one of the largest music establishments of the city, on State-street, and later did a commission business at his home.
SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10.--Drafts on New-York, sight, 15 cents; telegraphic, 20 cents.

Frederick Weidman, aged 26 years, and who lived at No. 73 South Ninth-street, Williamsburg, with his wife and two children, has been suffering for some time from melancholia caused by business troubles. Last night he went up to his room and shot himself in the heart with a 32calibre revolver. Death was almost instantaneous.

NEW-HAVEN, Conn., Sept. 10.--In a pleasant little house on Atwater-street, in Fair Haven, live a family by the name of Matthews, the widowed mother residing with her two daughters, Elia, aged 33, and Minnie, aged 20 years.
PARIS, Sept. 10.--The Marquis Tseng, Chinese Ambassador, has stated in an interview that the Russo-Chinese difficulty has vanished.

FREEHOLD, N.J., Sept. 10.--Although today was the last of the fair of the Monmouth County Agricultural Society at this place it was by no means the quietest one. The racing was good and the track in fine order, although a little heavy from the recent rain.

TROY, Sept. 10.--Statements have been printed to the effect that Walter N. Thayer, of this city, who was a candidate for Public Printer, had asserted that Col. Lamont had, after promising his aid to Thayer, broken his promise, and that Thayer's friends were to endeavor to defeat the confirmation of Mr. Benedict. Mr. Thayer issues the following card:

DOVER, N.H., Sept. 10.--The Knights of Labor in this city have been looked upon as an important factor in State and county politics. A month ago they were in a position to control every office in the country at the coming election.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10.--Capt. W.E. Plummer, of the steamer Mary D. Hume, which arrived in port yesterday, reports that while 16 miles northwest of Point Reyes, on Wednesday, he felt nine distinct shocks of earthquake. The vibrations were from north of east to south of west. They were not felt in San Francisco.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10.--Judge Taschereau has decided that guarantee companies are not liable for the amount of their guarantees in cases of defalcation, unless served with notice of such defalcation immediately upon its being discovered.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Sept. 10.--Whitney won the game for Kansas City to-day. Only two hits were made off him after the third inning. The Black Diamonds were also outfielded. Following is the score by innings:

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Sept. 10.--In the tennis tournament to-day Brinley won the deciding game in the open singles, and Brinley and McKenzie secured first place in the open doubles. The contests for second place in each of these matches will be played to-morrow. The matches for club prizes will be continued next week.
DETROIT, Sept. 10.--William Waite Warner has been arrested by United States officers at Jackson on complaint of Post Office Inspector Purcell on a charge of using the mails for fraudulent purposes.

CHICAGO, Sept. 10.--Between 8,000 and 9,000 people witnessed a hard contest at the ball grounds between the home team and the Wolverines to-day. The Chicago men won the game by batting at the right moment and by good base running.

LITTLE ROCK, Sept. 10.--Election returns from 10 counties, namely Benton, Bradley, Clark, Craighead, Dallas, Grant, Hot Springs, Jefferson, Perry and Sebastian, the only counties from which a detailed vote has been received, ...

AUGUSTA, Ga., Sept. 10.--There is consternation among the mill operatives to-day. The dreaded order has come, and the striking operatives must vacate the residences owned by the Augusta factory.

READING, Penn., Sept. 10.--To-day was the one hundred and third anniversary of the incorporation of Reading into a borough. The occasion was celebrated with a grand banquet on Flying Hill, given under the auspices of the ...

READING, Penn., Sept. 10.--A young man named John Blachman was engaged this morning in examining a revolver at his mother's house. In going up stairs he pulled the trigger several times on the empty chambers.

PARIS, Sept. 10.--The Univers publishes a telegram from the Bishop of Tonquin saying that 700 Christians have been massacred and 40 villages burned in the province of Manhoa, and that 9,000 Christians are perishing of hunger.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Sept. 10.--There was a great array of legal talent in the United States Court to-day in the complicated litigation over the Breckenridge Land and Mining Company's case. The portion of the controversy up for argument to-day was a motion by Dr. Hugh Kennedy to have a Receiver appointed for the concern.

OTTAWA, Ontaria, Sept. 10.--A Loyalist demonstration in opposition to home rule will take place here on Tuesday night. Speakers will be the Rev. Dr. Kane, Grand Master of the Orange Order for Belfast, and Mr. G.H. Smith, of Armagh, who represent the Association of Ireland. Senator Clemow, a leading Orangeman in the Dominion, will preside. The visitors will be banqueted on Wednesday evening.

ST. LOUIS, Mo., Sept. 10.--A special from El Paso says: "Special Envoy Sedgwick arrived at Paso del Norte this morning, and after taking breakfast with Consul Brigham began the investigation of the local records in the Cutting case."

LONDON, Sept. 10.--The Hamburg-American Line steamer Lessing, Capt. Barends, which left Hamburg Sept. 5 for New-York, has been towed into Queenstown. She has lost her propeller. The accident occurred yesterday morning in latitude 54 north, longitude 11 west.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--Gen. Drum, Acting Secretary of War, has given instructions that Geronimo, Natchez, and the other hostiles who surrendered with them, be stopped at San Antonio and kept imprisoned there until a determination is reached as to what course of procedure can be undertaken against them.

WEEDSPORT, N.Y., Sept. 10.--At the Republican Assembly District Convention held this afternoon the Hon. Frank M. Parsons, of Weedsport, was unanimously nominated as the Republican candidate for member of Assembly for the First District of Cayuga.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 10.--Both Morris and Miller pitched good games to-day, the former getting slightly the best of it. Pittsburg won the game in the third inning, when the Athletics bunched three ...

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 10.--Hoffman Co., fancy dry goods importers, of No. 19 Battery-street, made an assignment for the benefit of their creditors to-day, with liabilities of about $500,000. The assets cannot be ascertained.

LONDON, Sept.10.--Mr. Phelps, the United States Minister, has written to the Lord Mayor, on behalf of the American Government as a Nation, thanking him for his generous offer of relief for the Charleston sufferers, which, Mr. Phelps says, the American people will never forget. Mr. Phelps prays that no disaster that would enable America to reciprocate will ever occur in England.

CINCINNATI, Ohio, Sept. 10.--The town of Bartlett, Ohio, is threatened with destruction by fire. A jewelry store has already been burned and the flames are still raging.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 10.--A party of Charleston sufferers, consisting of Louis Luders, his wife, and seven children, the youngest an infant, arrived in this city last night in destitute circumstances, and were taken to the police station, where they spent the night.

INDIANAPOLIS, Ind., Sept. 10.--At present there is no change in the telephone situation, the next thing will be an agitation for the repeal of the three-dollar law. The Wallace Company, which secured a franchise for an exchange, has done absolutely nothing, and its rights have expired by limitation.
The gross earnings of the New-York Central and Hudson River Railroad Company and its leased lines for August were $2,980,973.55, an increase of $1,033,779.51 on those of August 1885.

DAMARISCOTTA, Me., Sept.10.--Mr. Blaine addressed the people of this coast town to-day, and very naturally dwelt some time upon the fisheries question, as one in which the townspeople take great interest. He characterized the treaty relations with Canada as the most remarkable diplomatic juggle of the century.

SYRACUSE, Sept. 10.--The Republican caucuses held in this city to-day were harmonious and indicate the re-election of Assemblymen McCarthy and Stacey in the Second and Third Assembly Districts.
LEAVENSWORTH, Kan., Sept. 10.--News has reached here of a shooting affair which occurred yesterday afternoon at Tonganoxic, 20 miles southwest of the city.

MONTREAL, Sept. 10.--Judgment has been given in the Superior Court here declaring three ex-Directors of the Exchange Bank responsible for the interest on a loan to an insolvent institution for which they gave their personal security.
SANDUSKY, Ohio, Sept. 10.--Albert Denman, a prominent farmer of Birmingham, this county, was arrested to-day on a charge of sending obscene literature through the mails.

DARMSTADT, Sept. 10,--Prince Alexander has arrived here. He was received by the Secretary of the English Legation and the Burgomaster, and at once proceeded to Jugenheim, his father's residence.
It was a red-letter day yesterday for the young people and the Sisters of the Third Order of St. Dominic, at the Convent of Our Lady of the Rosary, No. 329 East Sixty-third-street.

CHICAGO, Ill., Sept. 10.--While supper was being served to about 50 persons in a restaurant on West Madison-street last night the guests were horrified at seeing two persons pushing through the place--one with the blood streaming from him and flourishing an ugly looking butcher knife, the other running for life.

DECATUR, Ill., Sept. 10.--About 50 persons were mysteriously poisoned at a country wedding, about five miles west of here, on Wednesday night, and yesterday all the available physicians were hard at work attending the afflicted persons. Thomas W. Jacobs and Miss Alice Glasgow were married at the house of the bride's father. The supper which was served included chicken salad and fried and boiled chicken, and all ate heartily.

The new marriage laws that went into effect in October,1885, made it necessary for the license to be obtained from the Clerk of the Orphans' Court in the county where the marriage ceremony is performed.

SARATOGA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--The American Social Science Association held its concluding session this morning. In the Department of Social Economy the report of General Secretary Sanborn on "Social Questions of the Times" was read. A debate on thr right of property and the ownership of land was engaged in by Prof. E.J. James and H.L. Wayland, of Philadelphia; W. K. Harris, of Concord, and others. The meeting adjourned until next year.

In pursuance of the order issued several days age Controller Trenholm to-day imposed fines of $100 each on five national banks for failure to return reports of their condition within the time specified ...
A party of Sanitary Inspectors and Health Department clerks started out merrily on the steamboat Franklin Edson, belonging to the department, on Thursday morning, to witness the yacht race.

The statement made at Ottawa that the British Admiralty have instructed the war vessels cruising both on the North Atlantic coast and in the West Indies to report at Halifax for assisting the Dominion cruisers in protecting the fisheries is not yet confirmed by visible facts, although it may have a basis of truth.

During the second race for the New-York Canoe Club's International Challenge Cup last Saturday a cross sea washed over the cockpit of C. Bowyer Vaux's canoe, the Lassie, filling her with about a barrelful of water.

HAVANA, Sept. 10.--There is no change in the strike of the cigarmakers. Many of the strikers are without means and are suffering for want of food and other necessearies, Several others, who possess a little money, have embarked for Key West to look for work there. The manufacturers of Vuelta Abajo tobacco fearing that their employes may join the strikers, have formed a union and resolved to resist any unresonable demands.

ELKO, Nev., Sept. 10.--The Democratic State Convention met at 10 o'clock yesterday morning, effected organization, appointed the usual committees, and adjourned till 9 o'clock this morning, pending action of the Committee on Platform and Resolutions.

Miss Louise Parker will sing "Way Down Upon the Suwance River" at the entertainment in Wallack's to-morrow night in aid of the Charleston sufferers.

Jay Gould contributed $500 yesterday to help the Charleston sufferers. He sent his money to the Chamber of Commerce's committee, as did other contributors, until the day's receipts by Treasurer John Crosby Brown footed up about $10,000, making a grand total of $35,522 for this committee to date, not counting about $1,500 not yet turned in by sub-committees.

BOSTON, Sept. 10.--The closing session of the National Association of Stationary Engineers was held this afternoon. The following officers were elected to-day: President-Frank A. Foster, of New-Haven; Vice-President--R.O. Smith, of New-York; Secretary--G.G. Miner, of Cincinnati; Treasurer--G.M. Barker, of Nashville, Tenn.; Conductor--M.M. Walbridge, of Chicago; Doorkeeper--Harry knowlton, of Detroit, Mich. The next annual session will be held in Cincinnati on Sept. 8, 1887.

Mr. Lawrence Barrett appeared as Shylock at the Star Theatre last evening, using the familiar stage version of "The Merchant of Venice," ending with the trial scene, which, except that it contains two of the Belmont scenes made into one, discards nearly all the text not needed to exhibit the character of the Jew in his various moods.

About a week ago a well dressed young man called upon S.M. Blakely, at his real estate office, No. 1,526 Broadway, and said that he represented the Manhattan Mercantile Company, of No. 3 East Fourteenth-street, which proposed to issue "The New-York City Business Directory" on Jan. 1 next.
ITHACA, N.Y., Sept. 10.--About 20 members of the League of American Wheelmen, who started from Buffalo on Sept. 6 for Harper's Ferry, on their annual tour, arrived here at 7 o'clock to-night.

Mr. BLAINE made his first speech in the Maine canvass on the evening of Tuesday, Aug. 24, and he has kept pretty steadily at the work ever since. The canvass closes to-day, and the election will be held on Monday.

HARRISBURG, Penn., Sept. 10.--The Cambria Iron Company, at Johnstown, has asked Gov. Pattison to commission 188 policemen, whose names they have submitted, for the protection of its property, which they state is spread ...

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Sept. 10.--During a thunderstorm which passed over this city just before 6 o'clock this evening lightning struck the residence of Edwin Potts. Edwin Potts, Jr., who, with his sister Annie, was standing at an open door, was instantly killed. His sister was badly affected, but will recover. Young Potts was 24 years of age and was unmarried.

LOWELL, Mass., Sept. 10.--In a drunken quarrel with another man to-night John Shay threw a brick, which hit his own son, 4 years old, on the head, crushing the skull. It is doubtful if the child can recover. Shay has been arrested.

SAN FRANCISCO, Cal., Sept. 10.--In February last Frank Jaynes, General Superintendent of the Western Union Telegraph Company, was subpoenaed to produce before Judge Maguire, of the Superior Court, certain telegrams ...
A middle-aged man dressed in a light sack suit committed suicide last night by jumping from the ferryboat Musconetcong on its 8 o'clock trip from Hoboken to Christopher-street.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 10.--In the Supreme Court, before the full bench, argument is in progress to-day in the equity case of James Hanley and others against Gov. G.P. Wetmore, questioning the legality of the adoption of the fifth amendment of the Constitution, by which prohibition was made a law of the State, on the ground that the payment of registry taxes by persons other than the voters themselves was illegal.

NEWBURG, N.Y., Sept.10.--At the regatta of the Newburg Canoe and Boating Association on the Hudson River this afternoon, at this city, the six-mile sailing race was won by Grant E. Edgar, canoe Peggy; time--1:41:43. The sixmile sailboat race was won by Stephen Smith and Harry M. Waring, of the Bub; time-- 1:43:11. There were several starters in each race, and both were well contested. Pennants were the prizes. Many people viewed the races.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Sept. 10.--At least 3,000 laborers are at work to-day tearing down tottering walls, clearing away the debris from the streets, building temporary shelters for the thousands of homeless people, or repairing the damages to houses which were not overthrown by the earthquake, and may now be rendered habitable by careful patching.
